description:
I'm not a local so I can't make a comparison to other ramen places but I loved this. Gyoza (dumplings) was tender and delicious, and appeared to be handmade. Kara-age (fried chicken) was so good as well.

Ramen is SPICY when ordered as such. You have been warned.
author: Jacob W.

description:
Spicy food lovers, heed their level labels!!
I love spicy food, as this meal was later in the evening followed by some hot Cheetos which likely tipped my body. 

Good thing I didn't choose Hell or Death because as I sit in the bathroom the following morning, I'm contemplating why my palette of diverse taste has let me down in my suffering from the Fire spicy miso (which was delicious, and if you can handle it then get it bc I still enjoyed it). I imagine Death might have actually killed me because I don't see how my body could handle much worse than right now. 

If you come here, get on the waitlist through Yelp--saves time for when you get there! Seating felt a little cramped for 2 person party seating but wasn't unbearable. The staff was super helpful and ready to serve you at any stage of your meal. :)
author: Kimberly B.

description:
If you feel like having a fun time, order your ramen with the death seasoning, a pepper paste made out of the ghost pepper. When you take the first bite, it's not that bad, but as you keep eating, it builds and gets worse and worse. Soon, you will hate yourself and regret every decision you've ever made. 

But in all seriousness, this place had pretty good food. The karaage and the takoyaki were just average, but the ramen was quite nice. The Yamadaya ramen is essentially just tonkotsu ramen, which is my favorite. The broth was rich but not oily and it had a creamy and smooth mouthfeel. The noodles were perfectly chewy and slurpable. The pork belly was fatty and very tender. 

Although most of the ramen was good, there were some bad things about it. The egg was cold in the middle which means they don't make the eggs fresh. Also, for the price, I think that the portion sizes are a bit too small.
author: Shao-Lon Y.

description:
The kind of place you go to when all the other ramen shops have closed their wait lists due to full capacity. 

Ramen was mediocre, my mistake was ordering the "cayenne and habanero" level of spice. It was indeed hot but not flavorful, and of course tasted inauthentic. Shame on me for ordering tha

Super big turn off to see workers on their phones texting and eating by the cash register. Go take a break and eat in the back, not grab a spoonful of food and speed chew while talking to your customers. The only savior of this place was the tall, male food runner who had a good energy and seemed to be the hardest worker.
author: Nicolette E.

description:
I don't recommend getting the vegan ramen ($15) here. It was kind of bland and looked like there were less toppings than the meat ramen dishes. I was given one really small piece of tofu that was cold. The other toppings did not blend in well with the ramen. The only toppings that had flavor were the two bamboo slices. They were slightly sweet. I let my boyfriend try the broth and he thought it tasted like "Asian herbal medicine" (whatever that means :P). He thought my ramen looked pathetic... However, he thought his Yamada-ya Ramen dish ($15) wasn't bad. He thought his toppings were generous. He was given one whole soft-boiled egg and three thick but tender pieces of meat. 

The reason I'm giving this place three stars is because my boyfriend liked his ramen. I don't imagine myself coming back though.
author: Kristina M.

description:
First things first: Ramen Yamadaya is located on the SECOND FLOOR. I sat waiting inside on the bottom floor for like five minutes before asking someone who worked there about my joining the waitlist via Yelp and she directed us upstairs where there was a line snaking down the stairs. The line isn't in-order: there's a Yelp waitlist tablet at the top for people to sign in. Pro tip: sign-up for the waitlist remotely via Yelp before you get there and they do give you an estimated wait time! 

I tried the Kakuni Pork Belly Ramen and was impressed by the LARGE slab of it. It was cooked extremely well and flavored the ramen, adding to the complexity of the broth. There was a lot of fat on all of the meat, however. I really liked the seasoned egg though! It was runny and again blended with the broth well. 

My Hinge date who'd never had ramen before (the audacity!) tried the Yamadaya Ramen which was Tonkotsu Ramen w/ Kakuni Pork, char siu Pork, scallions, Seasoned Egg, and Dried Seaweed).

Everyone gets their own pitcher of water? Which was weird but I dug it, I do drink a lot of water. The broth wasn't actually that salty, I just like water.

Heads up: Yamadaya has an interesting layout featuring a couple of tables and a large communal table in the middle of the room. I was surprised by this because I did not expect to be seated next to other people! 

Service: 3 stars. Could've been quicker and friendlier. They bring you the check and then stand there while you scan the card. Interesting. 

Solid ramen but I'm still debating if it's worth the wait. Given the plethora of other options, I think not, although I'd come here if you're a big meat fan or if there's not much of a line or if you sign up for the wait list ahead of time.
author: Lizzie S.

description: Eh. I consider myself sorta snobby when it comes to Ramen. I eat lots of it. This place fell so far short of expectations of ramen in SF's Japantown. The apps we got were just ok. This included pork buns, karage, and a few others. My ramen was alright but definitely not the best broth I've ever had. Just overall mediocre. My friend did enjoy his katsu curry ramen but the rest of us were just not impressed.
author: Sarah M.

description:
I visited on a Saturday afternoon with a group of friends. We were seated shortly after joining the Yelp wailist.

I ordered the Kakuni Ramen, and my friends ordered Yamada-ya Ramen and Spicy Ramen. The ramen were all $15 each; you can add additional toppings or more noodles for additional charge. The service was slow depsite it not being a particularly busy time, but when the ramen finally arrived, they all arrived together.

As for my Kakuni Ramen, the Hakata style thin noodles were good, and picked up the flavor of the rich soy sauce pork bone broth well. The toppings were nothing special: kikurage, bamboo, scallions, nori, a whole soft-boiled egg. The kakuni (pork belly) was tender and cut in thick slices.

Solid ramen, but I'm not sure if it's worth the wait. There are plenty of other places in Japantown to get good ramen for a similar price with faster service.
author: Robert L.

description:
Ramen yamadaya...more like ramen yamada-eh.

I got the tsukemen, and my friend scored the tonkotsu because what else will you do during that awkward gap of time before an apartment pregame when it's 8 o clock? The noodles weren't as thicc as I had projected, but that was fine. The sauce was equal parts savory and fatty, and did not seem to carve out that much flavor. 

My friend's classic tonkotsu was kind of dope but off, like Jaden Smith's new single. I think there needs to be some soul searching with flavors here, but there are some seeds of inspiration.
author: Celena C.

description:
I have solid memories of dining here with friends, maybe more for the coziness of the place. My friends all adore Yamadaya and I'm not opposed to going when they want, but I personally don't love the ramen here, mostly because of the flavor of the broth. 

There is a Yamadaya in San Diego which I believe is the same franchise / ownership. Again, my friends love that place and I don't love the broth there either.
author: Sophia L.

description:
Ramen Yamadaya is located on the second floor of the building. Upon stepping foot inside its hallway, there's a Yelp waitlist tablet for people to use and also cucumber/fruit-flavored cold water available for waiting customers. We arrived at 8pm on a Thursday night and there was no line. 

I really enjoyed the layout of the restaurant. There were a couple two tabletops, four tabletops and there was also a communal table in the middle of the dining room. 

We decided to order the Yamadaya ramen and the rock shrimp tempura. When the waitress finally brought over our ramen, I inquired about the free soda yelp check-in offer. She asked me what beverage I wanted and I replied Coke. As we were digging into our ramen, the wait for the cola became increasingly long (it wasn't busy). As fifteen minutes passed by, I asked our same waitress a second time. She pretended to not have known anything about it, almost as if our previous interaction never occurred. This whole interaction involving the cola was bizarre and confusing. Later during our meal, I asked her for a refill and that refill obviously never came. 

As for our food, the rock shrimp tempura was actually excellent. It was fried perfectly and I like the sauce that was drizzled on top. The yamadaya ramen experience was very dissappointing. While I liked the noodles, nori and the broth, the meat and the garlic looked unpleasant. There were actually half-size chunks of garlic in my soup (supposed to be all sliced pieces) and the charsu didn't taste tender. The big pieces of pork were tough to chew. 

After asking for our bill, it took them almost twenty minutes to get our check. From start to finish, our dining experience here was abysmal. While the food had promise, the interaction with our waitress was terrible.
author: Philip M.

description:
My friends and I were craving for some ramen. I know Japantown has a lot of that, but this was the only place that was open at the time.

Luckily we did not have to wait and were seated right away. I ordered the Yamadaya Tonkatsu. It was good but the broth were too heavy for me. After the 5th bite I was already tired of the broth, but everything else was good.

Service was okay - fast.

Overall, there is really nothing special in my opinion, but if you are the type of person that like the rich taste of tonkatsu on your ramen, then this is the place to go.
author: Nicole D.

description: I used to believe this is the best ramen place in California. Coming back from japan, it's hard to compare. They messed up our order and charged me extra for corn even when it was their fault. For four people we were charged at $80 for 4 ramen. It was a bit ridiculous.
author: Brenda L.

description:
Probably never coming back... decided to try this place since we didn't want to wait in line for Marufuku. I signed up for the waitlist via yelp around 7:50 and they told us to come back by 8:11. at this point there were still 11 parties ahead of us so i wasn't sure how they were going to seat us anytime soon but we still went back. it took another 20 mins of waiting before they finally called us - i'm not sure if this is a Yelp flaw or just poor planning on the restaurants part. 

we were finally seated and it took a long time to even get our water. then i looked up and noticed that a couple of the parties who were seated after us got their food already. a server noticed and came up to us to apologize - that's cool I guess. by the way the bathrooms are really dirty. 

got our food around 9:07 and it was just okay. broth was bland. chasu - really thick pieces of fat - was bland. noodles were good buuuuut that's about it.
author: Ana G.

description:
We visited in August as a family of four stopping in SF on our way to China/Japan.  We were in Japantown and debating between sushi or ramen for our meal.  We did a quick yelp search and landed on Ramen Yamadaya.  This was located on the second floor above a window display and signage for the restaurant.  Upon reaching the upper landing, I saw some signs asking you to gain quicker seating by using yelp.  I was a little confused never seeing this before.  There was also an ipad just in that landing area but I walked inside to see if there was a hostess.  Sure enough I was encouraged once again to sign in on the ipad through yelp.  There was no wait and we were soon called inside.

We ordered a takoyaki appetizer to try before we got to Osaka Japan.  Had seen many videos on this but wanted a preview.  It was quite tasty.  We then each ordered our ramen and it was yummy.  The restaurant was quite steadily busy but very attentive during our meal.  I may have to come back when I travel for work in October.
author: Maria K.

description:
Why is it so hard to find decent ramen in this city?

Let's ignore the long wait, and sticky tables. We'll focus on the food.

I've come here twice and had the tsukemen both times, because I think dipping noodles are the best form of ramen besides tonkotsu - and because tsukemen is so hard to find anywhere, I had to order it.

The noodle portion is huge, so I'll give them that. You can even double the portion for $2, which is a great deal in my opinion. 

The broth... I'm not sure what's gone wrong here. Both times the broth has been lukewarm, which means it turns cold after you finish about 1/3 of your noodles. I forgave it the first time, but cold broth twice in a row means it's probably always cold. 

My excitement died as soon as I did the first slurp. No punch in the face, no drama, no fire (literally... because of cold broth). Usually when I finish good ramen, my body's telling me "no more" but my mind tells me "yes yes you can eat another bowl", but here, I don't feel any emotion after I'm done. Almost like agreeing to meet up with a date the second time even though the first time was questionable and then realizing "nope, the first time was definitely not an anomaly".
author: Calvin Z.

description: It's much improved with the new menu and new staff, must have undergone new management. There are vegan choices if you are looking for that. Good lunch specials
author: Regina G.

description:
I wanted to like this place because their ramen options seemed very attractive to me and the line seemed reasonable. When I arrived I put my name on the waitlist and got called in after 20 minutes and seated instantly. There was already water on the table and the waitress came over after a couple of minutes. I was excited for my ramen.

I put my order in and expected to have a nice, quick, satisfying bowl of noodles before I finished my exploration of JP Town but I had to wait nearly 50 minutes for one bowl of ramen, I understand it was a weekend but does it really take that long to put together one order when the building isn't even completely full? I thought that it better be the best bowl of ramen in San Francisco if it takes this long.

Anyways, when I got my order finally it looked pretty nice with 3 pieces of pork belly and a nice looking broth. The taste was pretty good, and the fire spice level was nice, but I was still perplexed on why it took so long seeing as someone who came and sat down when I was almost done with mine got hers in less than 10 minutes. It just made me think that they forgot to put my order in and scrambled when they remembered.

Anyways, the food was 7/10 but the service and pricing gets maybe a 3/10. It just seemed disorganized and unnecessarily slow and the spicy paste cost an extra $2 which was laughable. I won't be coming back, there are a lot of other better rated ramen places around the area that had patrons coming in and out in a half hour.
author: Philip C.

description:
Ramen isn't too bad but what's up with their unnecessary wait list?

My friend and I came around 1:30pm on a Monday and upon seeing many empty tables, assumed that we could be seated right away. However, the waiter told us we had to put our names on the Yelp waitlist and we would be called...which makes no sense to me since there are clearly empty seats. Their tone of voice was also a bit rude.

Ramen itself was alright, we both ordered the lunch set with spicy miso and karaage/pot stickers. The broth was good but pretty oily. Pretty good deal for $15.

-1 star for service, and while the ramen was fine, I would rather hit up the many other ramen shops in Japantown.
author: Kimberly K.

description:
I've been to Ramen Yamadaya almost 3 times now. My cousin & brother both live in SF and they used to come to this spot all the time especially when my cousin used to live in Japantown. 

There is usually always a wait at this spot so I would recommend going early or at an awkward time during the day. At peak times, just expect theres going to be wait but they have an ipad where you enter your number and they'll call you once your table is ready so you could spend the time walking around Japantown.

The service is what kills this review for me. I was with 5 other people and we waited almost 15 minutes before we even got MENUs and we wouldn't have gotten them unless my aunt hadn't gone up to the bar  & grabbed it herself. The service was slow and unattentive which is why I would not want to come back.

The food was good, not great. I feel like this place has gone downhill in the last couple of years. But we ordered the soy ramen, spicy miso ramen, curry katsu and 2 vegan ramens. I honestly thought the star was the curry katsu because it also came with miso soup and salad so definitely worth the $14 price tag.

The decor is like any other japanese spot with wooden benches and same silverware. But the restaurant is a good size space.
author: Caroline L.

description:
This was our very first time eating ramen that didn't come in a packet or styrofoam cup. AMAZING! Both the spicy and non-spicy options. Our waiter was super helpful and friendly. 

The only reason that I'm not giving a perfect score is that the bill came on an iPad and (another) waiter had already tapped the suggested tip amount for me. In hindsight, I should've not tipped at all because I find that rude and unacceptable.
author: matt n.

description:
We came here around 2pm on a Sunday and there was no wait. The service was prompt. 

I got their Yamadaya ramen. It was a good bowl of ramen but it was really nothing special. I wouldn't rate it as a top bowl or memorable but it was sufficient and fine if you're just looking for a solid bowl of ramen in the area. The broth was rich and a bit too oily for me. It came with two different types of pork - a thin cut and thick cut one. The thin cut was dry for me and the thick cut was fine. The noodles had a good bounce to them. My favorite was the egg. It was well flavored and I love that the yolk was perfectly runny. I could've eaten ten of those!
author: Maggie W.

description:
Ramen that's worth trying! It's located on the second floor, right outside the Main Street of Japantown!

Very very homey feeling, employees very welcoming, and long wait lines during peak!

The smell will draw you in, and the ramen will keep you filled! I'm a firm believer that every "Good" ramen place has its own unique, intricate taste! And this place has just that! So I had to try their main ramen dish the Yamadaya!

Perfect ramen in my opinion!
Will be back!
author: Marc P.

description:
Another ramen joint that have been on my to-go list for awhile so ventured to Japantown after work with the boyfriend to try this place out. This place is on top of Shabu-Sen and you have to go up the stairs. Many tables were open around 615pm on a Thursday night. We stood for a couple of minutes before we were seated. We were seated at a small table for two by the entrance, my back was to the stairs leading up to the restaurant. It was super cold as they had a window opened, the whole time I was shivering but was hoping the warm broth would warm me up!

Yelp tip: Check in for a free soda with a purchase of a meal. I ordered the Spicy ramen (mild) which is soy sauce based with pork bone broth, chasu, pork belly, bamboo, scallions, rayu, nanami, nori, soft egg. My boyfriend ordered the Chicken which is soy sauce based, chicken broth, chasu, pork belly, naruto, scallion, woodear mushrooms, bamboo, nori, soft egg. The spicy ramen was perfectly spiced at mild, I like a hint of spice but not to the point where I can't handle it. Broth was steaming hot. Plenty of meats and noodles however my noodles were the thicker ramen while the chicken noodles were thinner which I prefer. Both bowls were pretty good. I did enjoy that it was not at all salty but rather rich broth with plenty of flavors. 

Upon checking out there was a mandatory tip of 15% in which they put in for you. Our server punched it in for us and didn't see an area for custom tip which we didn't like. Otherwise, worth a try and didn't miss out on too much from waiting this long to try this place.
author: Annie L.

description:
Surprisingly long line for a Sunday night even though there are a myriad of other options nearby.

Gyoza (pork): rather flavourless. Would not order again. I would try the chicken next time though.

Yamada-ya ramen: thin noodles, a full soft-boiled egg cooked to perfection (as opposed to a half like most other cheap places give you), and many slices of meat (thin and thick), which was quite surprising given most ramen joints give you two thinly sliced pieces of pork and call it a day. They are generous with the meat portions in ramen here. Soup base was good. One down side of the ramen here is it's extremely salty, you will find yourself drinking a lot of water during and after the meal.
author: Tom P.

description:
The most popular Ramen shop in Japantown, SF. But you can eat not only Ramen but also Karaage, Gyoza, Japanese famous ones there. This time, I ordered "Tsukemen" because I really like this so much.
Actually, tastes not better than any other Tsukemen in Japan... Of course, I know this Tsukemen localized in the taste of American people. But I don't like. mmm
author: Shun Y.

description:
A ramen I actually like! 

I'm so surprised that I actually like this ramen. I usually am not a huge fan of ramen because I think it's too salty. But the broth here is so rich and savory. It has a lot of flavor and it isn't too overwhelming. I think that the noodles were cooked perfectly and that there was a good amount of meat. 

It wasn't too rich because I could finish the whole bowl. 

I would come again and recommend it to friends.
author: Tina Y.

description:
Hands down one of the best ramen I have ever had! The broth was amazzzzzingggg. The pork was perfect. Even the small appetizers we got were good. 
I got spicy miso. I asked for mild but it came out super spicy, I still finished all of it!
author: Becky S.

description:
I had issues using the iPad to add my name to the waitlist at Ramen Yamadaya, but it worked perfectly well through the Yelp app.  There were 8 parties ahead of my friend and I on a Sunday evening, but we managed to get a table within ten minutes or so.  Please note, though, that unless you specify a separate table/booth, RY will give your party the first available spot.  For us, that ended up being two seats at the communal table in the center of the restaurant.  I typically prefer a separate table, but if you're engrossed in conversation with your party it doesn't really matter that there are others seated near you.

Service here is pretty quick, but a little scattered.  One person dropped off menus, another took our order and brought over hot tea, a different person dropped off our ramen and yet another came over with the bill.  That said, this is not the kind of restaurant where it's ok to be shy and quiet.  If you need something, be prepared to wave an arm and holler.

As far as the food goes, I think it's decent.  I've gotten the standard Ramada Ya ramen with black garlic oil, chashu, pork belly, bamboo shoots and a halved egg on two different visits.  I appreciate the option of switching from their standard thin noodles to something thicker, as well as the option of double the portion of noodles or other ingredients, but the regular bowl is usually satisfying enough, and still leaves you with some room to grab dessert from Uji, Belly Good Crepes and/or Boba Guys' Fillmore location.
author: Iona C.

description:
Too much fat in the ramen. 
The fried chicken is really good but the gyoza is too salty.
author: Helen Y.

description: I thought this place was fine but my boyfriend, who has become quite the connoisseur of Tonkotsu broth thinks Ramen Izakaya Goku in Mission is better. We had the Yamada-Ya ($15) and Kakuni ($15). The Kakuni Broth was slightly better than the Yamada-Ya broth. Otherwise two are pretty similar. Yamada-Ya has a few pieces of chashu and a big piece of kakuni while Kakuni broth has two big pieces of kakuni. They don't skimp on the meat!
author: Julia C.

description: Food was great! This is coming from a picky ramen eater (lived in Tokyo for a few years) but I knocked the stars down due to the service. Waiter messed up our order, dropped off the wrong food, told us we made the wrong order then pulled his note pad and realized he didn't deliver what he wrote down for our table then still continued to get our order wrong. Didn't want to argue with the guy, I'll give him the benefit of the doubt he has a hard time paying attention at his job. I just never thought i would witness in the food service industry a waiter would tell the customer they are wrong yet the correct order was in his notepad and it didn't match what was delivered?
author: Chuck L.

description:
Customer service: My friend and I weren't getting catered to until we had to call them to take our order. They never checked up on us throughout our stay and they forgot to give us our utensils. We waited a long time and other people who got seated after us, got their food before us. 

Food: The food and flavor was okay, I'm not a big fan of the noodles though. The meat was nice and tender, a bit fatty. 

Their sake cocktails were okay, the waitress mixed up my friends and I's drink, but fortunately, we were able to tell which ones were ours. They were just okay though, mostly ice. 

I don't think I would come back here.
author: Tiffiny C.

description:
Ramen Yamadaya is now my new favorite ramen shop. I came here on a Friday afternoon with a couple of friends and was happy to be seated almost immediately. I ordered the Spicy Miso Ramen with medium spicy, which was super good and filling! I love how heavy and saucy the broth is, and all the things it comes with (boiled egg, seaweed, roasted pork, corn, etc.) I love how they have so many levels of spicy; my friend ordered "Death" ramen and that looked amazing as well. 

The customer service was good, probably because there weren't many people in the shop. Definitely coming back for more.
author: Vivian C.

description:
Having tried many ramens, I could only describe theirs as "nothing special" at best. Broth was cold on a surface, pork overly fatty, which ruined the taste and left me with a heavy stomach.

Mediocre food, multiplied by indifferent staff and somewhat worn out premises makes me highly recommend not to give it a try.
author: Alexander B.

description:
Ramen boom has been influencing a lot of the shops in Japantown. There's so many ramen places and this is one of the ramen shop in Japantown. I am not particularly a fan of their ramen because it was too heavy for me. However, I can see how it may be favorable for others. It has a rich taste of tonkotsu. 
If you are like me and prefer not to eat heavy food at night, come here during the day. After eating the ramen, you can enjoy Japantown and possibly digest your ramen to enjoy dessert :) 
The restaurant was pretty clean when I went. If you get the outer seats near the window, you can see people walking outside.
author: Kiyomi K.

description:
Made a trip down to SF and planned to try this place out. We arrived at 12PM on a Tuesday. The place clearly states it opens at 11:30AM, which was perfectly planned. First, we couldn't figure out how to enter the restaurant. The doors to the stairs was locked and apparently the lights were on in the building? I called multiple times and the voicemail said that the number was unavailable, tried calling another number and no answer. 

Like seriously? Update your information or something. Make it easier to know where your restaurant is at. Like there were so many things that could've been avoided and time could've been saved to do more around the area; my group and I are glad we ended up going to another ramen place.
author: Abbie S.

description:
Spicy heaven!

Ramen Yamadaya was a first place with japanese food to visit when me and my husband move to SF. And we was very satisfied with variety of Ramen and beer. Ramen was served in less than 15 minute which was very satisfying.  

 Highly recomend for every people who loves japanese food.
author: Anna K.

description:
Despite our protest, we ended up at Ramen Yamadaya bc we were too chicken to tell my fiance's friends we should go elsewhere so... We got what we deserved i suppose LOL

The restaurant has a nice positive vibe, almost like a bar but a ramen bar (they serve beer & sake).  Its definitely a little louder than your typical ramen spots.  

The ramen was just ok.  I got the ramadaya ramen while my fiance got the tsukemen ramen and there really wasnt anything special.  Dont get me wrong: it wasnt bad or anything but there just wasn't anything special.

I can see how some people would like it here as they have their own unique flavor to their ramen but it just wasnt for me.  The pork portions were pretty small although their ramen portions were more than generous.
author: Jang N.

description:
Staff weren't as friendly but the Ramen wasn't bad at all. Spicy Miso was definitely good & good amount of spice. 
You can choose thin or thick noodle & choose your level of spicy. I'd come back again.
Staff need to be more friendly though.
author: Jennifer H.

description:
Came here with a party of 8 so we knew wait would be awhile.

Shout out to the staff for accommodating our party and apologizing when we were waiting for another house sake cause they had to replace the box. 

Got to order their Yamadaya Tonkotsu Ramen. I should have asked if it was possible to get the broth cause it felt slightly extra thick. The noodles and meat taste good.
author: John Kevin G.

description:
By far the best ramen place I have been to, thanks to my cousin who was visiting the Bay Area! She suggested we eat ramen to end our day and so we did!

The food was delicious, we all ordered soup, I got the chicken ramen with egg. We also ordered the Takoyaki and gyoza. Everything tastes fresh and hot! What I liked seeing on the table was the complimentary add-ons for your soup like the seaweed flakes, sesame seeds with a variety of seasonings. I don't see this often at other ramen places! The portions are great! Not too small or large and it felt like a lot food. We were so hungry after being in Japan town that we devoured our food!

We ordered the 3 flavored mochi ball ice cream they had (strawberry, choco and vanilla) for dessert and we left there happy full!

The service was also excellent, and the location is nice, on the second floor over-looking the plaza of passerbys in Japan town.
author: Nessa V.

description:
Service was awful. 
The window was open and we asked if they could please close it after the guests sitting next to it left and they opened it all the way! WTF? We were freezing and it would have been decent if my soup came out hot but it wasn't. It was a cold and tasteless experience. We also waited for our soft drinks to be refilled and not once did the servers refill it. Not coming back!
author: Fayte T.

description:
I absolutely love ramen, but I've unfortunately been a ramen-deprived girl as of lately. I told my friend who I was visiting that I needed to eat good ramen while in San Francisco, as the ramen in Portland is decent but not great. We originally tried to go a newer ramen spot in Union Square, but the wait was insane. She recommended Ramen Yamadaya as her favorite ramen spot she's tried so far since moving to San Francisco, and also noted that the line will likely be shorter. 

We put our name on the wait list through Yelp and we only had to wait 10-15 minutes to get a table once we arrived. Me, her, and our other friend were starving and shared a chicken katsu bento to start. The chicken katsu was really nicely fried; not overly oily and still crispy. A good starter to share, though sharing rice and miso soup doesn't work out quite as well (haha). I ordered the Yamadaya and it satisfied my ramen craving for sure. The broth was flavorful and I liked the chewy consistency of the noodles. The piece of pork on the top was huge, though my piece was a bit too fatty for my liking since it wasn't rendered down as much as I'd like. All in all, however, a good meal! Service was a tad slow, but I'll give them a pass since it was a Friday night.

PS: Check in on Yelp to get a free soda. If you ask nicely, the staff will let you substitute it for hot green tea.
author: McKena M.

description:
There was mold growing in the white pepper container - unfortunately one person in our party didn't notice it until they had already used it on their ramen. We had not multiple servers come to our table to address the issue, however not ONE person apologized. They also gave us dirty water glasses and never refilled a single drink. 

There are much better ramen places to go to with comparable prices in the area. Don't bother.
author: Jenny K.

description:
Pretty bad service. We ordered the Sapporo, and the server said they only had large size. My partner asked if it's the 720 ml which was printed on the menu for $9, and the server confirmed yes. Instead we get a 650 ml can so we mentioned it to one of the servers. He asked his manager and returned with a BS excuse that the 720 ml should've been $12, but because of a misprint they gave us 650 ml instead for $9. 

As for their ramen, I've been here when they first opened and thought they had decent tonkotsu. I was excited to see tsukemen on their menu this time, but the tsukemen was just ok. The smaller bowl was enough to fill me up, but the broth was lukewarm, not thick, and very salty. It comes with a large heap of dashi powder so it's heavy in the fish flavor. Noodles were nicely balanced between chewy and al dente, and noodles, pork and egg were all served chilled. Egg wasn't runny.

When I finished my noodles they immediately cleared my bowl, and without me asking brought over the bill without saying anything else to us. Service was pretty bad when they messed up to begin with.
author: Diana B.

description:
This is probably the worst Ramen place I have been to (and I'm a true Ramen fan). Ramen was tasteless and low quality. And to make it all worse, we were served chicken when we specifically asked for tofu and mentioned at beginning of order that we are vegetarian. I never ate Chicken EVER in my life and someone's carelessness today broke my religion. I have never been more disappointed and sad. :( 
The server was heartless and did nothing, just avoided us throughout the meal. 
Vegetarians watch out when you eat here!!
author: Megha T.

description:
I would maybe rate this a 3.5, but find myself leaning more towards 3.  When I'm in San Francisco, Ramen Yamadaya is probably the most reliable place for a bowl of ramen.  I almost always go here when I'm visiting Japantown. So why the three stars?  

First of all, the wait.  If you can beat the lunch rush, great!  But the lines can get a little ridiculous, and when it's crowded, the service is sub-par (and sometimes a little rude) and they're not great with customer turnover (sometimes I'll see empty tables with dishes sit for as long as 30 minutes... which is not great when there's a line of people going down the stairs).  

Second, the tsukemen is pretty good, with a good sized plate of sides to go along with the broth/noodles.  However, the additional meat is usually just okay.  Last time I went, I was thinking maybe i wasn't haven't a spectacular experience because I didn't get the specialty tonkatsu ramen, but I was still left a little disappointed in terms of the broth quality (I feel like every time I go here, the broth is more lukewarm than warm/hot??) and the meat (again!!) 

Overall, it's reliable and a decent bowl, and I'll probably be back when I'm hitting up Japantown.  But it's nothing to write home about, just another ramen place in the Bay.
author: Cat D.

description: Very tasty ramen had the Yamadaya-ya. Husband had spicy hot. Make sure you stir up lots of spice in the bottom.
author: Randi M.

description: I went here with my boyfriend for a late lunch and there was no wait. We both ordered a tonkotsu ramen and we loved the texture of the ramen and how the broth tasted. The ramen here is more on the soft side and chewy too. The price is moderate for ramen and the portion of ramen we got was huge! It was enough to make both of us feel full. We've tried a bunch of other ramen places in this city and Ramen Yamadaya is one of our favorites.
author: Elaine N.

description:
We had lunch here for my birthday weekend and I was craving some ramen. Actually, I just wanted noodles as it's tradition to eat noodles as a symbolic for future birthdays to come and long life. 

It was a Saturday afternoon and we just beat the lunch rush so there was no wait.

I believe I ordered the regular level of spicyness for my ramen and my mouth was still on fire. It was still delicious tho but I was forming beads of sweat on my upper lip and wiping the sweat from my forehead with the sleeve of my sweater because it was a little too spicy for my tolerance. Lol 

We also ordered the hasty kare which was also delicious. It came also with a soup and salad entree. Very good also, you're quintessential katsu kare. 

I also luckily got a free soda with my meal when I used my Yelp Check-in offer, so why not? 

I'd come back.
author: A Z Flor H.

description:
I know that Ramen Yamadaya is a well established chain from SoCal, but I felt that the ramen here (at least at this store) was somewhat overrated. Don't get me wrong, it's not bad by any measure; it's just not great either. The broth was very oily, which isn't surprising for a tonkotsu broth ramen. The oiliness of the pork bone broth usually adds to the flavor, but the problem with Yamadaya's broth is that it lacks depth in flavor. There's the superficial salty flavor of soy sauce and salt, but no umami. The two things that stood out were the egg and the actual kakuni. The ajitama was cooked to perfection and the pork belly (for the most part) was tender and flavorful. The service was mediocre at best, as it seemed like nobody was communicating with each other. It took us a good 5 min to get someone to take our order for anything. I probably wouldn't eat here again, just bc there are still so many other places to try in SF! I'd say check out Hinodeya across the street before coming here. 

Here's the breakdown of the Kakuni Ramen:
- Noodles: 3 stars
- Broth: 1 stars
- Ajitama (egg): 5 stars
- Kakuni (pork belly): 4.5 stars
author: Rie U.

description:
Used to be my girlfriend and my favorite ramen in the Bay Area. The chicken karaage and black garlic oil ramen were both some of the best I've had. The chicken used to be served crispy, hot, and with delicious Japanese mayo for dipping, but everything has changed recently. 

Last night the chicken came out room temperature with an uninspiring texture. The ramen had a strong burnt flavor in the broth that carried into the noodles. This gave off an intense smoky flavor that ruined the aftertaste of every bite. You could smell it immediately. Both of ours eggs were also cold when served.

They offered to bring us new bowls which we accepted, but the problem persisted. We begrudgingly ate a bit more as we were cold and hungry from a day at Sutro Baths, but this meal was nothing like the comfort we were expecting.

Another customer was visibly upset and stormed off mid meal. When we told the person who brought out the check how our experience was he said they were having a bad day all around.. I'm not sure how that is helpful to us. 

The last few times we have been have been very disappointed despite the continued lengthy wait times. I know how good it can be so we will likely wait a while and give it another chance, but that will be our last if things don't improve.
author: Kevin L.

description: We ended up at Ramen Yamadaya after seeing the crazy long line for Marufuku. It's located on the second story of a building and luckily we got in right before the lunch rush! We ordered the Yamada-Ya combos with pork and chicken gyozas along with a Tuna Butsu. I ended up liking our sides more than the actual ramen itself. The noodles were great- thin and chewy. And the huge cut of fatty pork belly were delicious! But the broth wasn't rich and left a lot to be desired. With bland broth, I'd rather try any of the countless ramen spots in SF Japan town next time instead.
author: Jessica D.

description:
My boyfriend and I travelled from AZ and have been craving ramen for a long time. And we were recommended to this place but we were worried because the rating was kinda bad. Anyways... we still gave it a try. 

We had to wait about 30-40 minutes but we ended going across the street to the mall to do a little bit of shopping to pass time. 

Customer service was 4.5/5. Everyone was nice to us just wished they did a quality check back on us. 
Food 5/5. We order the Spicy ramen (Medium) and Yamada- ya ramen. My boyfriend loved the medium spicy ramen. It was pretty spicy for medium but still flavorful. The Yamada-ya ramen was also really good. I put some of the medium spice broth into mine and it definitely made it even better. 
Buns 4/5. We ordered the chicken and pork buns. We definitely loved the chicken one better. It was so crispy and flavorful. The pork one was okay because we liked it better who they added it in their ramens than their buns. 

A great visit, after our original plans didn't go well.
author: Josephine U.

description:
I admit, the only reason we ended up here was because our first choice (Marufuku Ramen) closed right when we walked up to the line. They were closing for that in between lunch-dinner time. My GFs and I were starving and really wanted ramen. Conveniently, Ramen Yamadaya was open, close by and had a 10 min wait time so we joined the waiting list via Yelp. I love this feature btw!! By the time we walked over, we checked in on Yelp, received a notification that our table was ready and were immediately seated. 

We all had the spicy miso ramen with a free side of black garlic oil (included freshly minced garlic). The broth was tasty but I've honestly had better. I had to add/play with the table-side spices and oil to finally get it to my liking.  The chashu was thick, tender and flavorful. The egg was soft boiled and only a little runny.

We also tried the rock shrimp tempura (3 per order) which were Ok. 

The karaage we also ordered that unfortunately came way later was hot, crispy and juicy. It came with coleslaw and a side of mayo. I ended up mincing garlic and added it to the mayo for an aioli flavor which turned out really good.

All in all, not bad. It definitely satisfied the craving.
author: Resa N.

description: I have had ramen at several places in the city, and Ramen Yamadaya was definitely on the lower end. Just taste wise, I was not satisfied with the ramen. I am Japanese, so I have relatively high standards, but the ramen wasn't creamy, the noodles were still a little hard, and it just didn't really cut it for me. Setting the food aside, the service was pretty slow, it took us about 20 minutes to get our check back after paying.
author: Ross S.

description:
Short review because I don't want to go on a rampaging review on this place. 

Ramen and the host were amazing. The broth was amazing, noodles well cooked, and the meat portions were huge. Host was amazing because he was cracking jokes and literally was the only one who answered our question about the free soda on yelp.

What's not amazing is the service here. I get it, we came during dinner time and it gets busy. But the fact that most of the waiters were standing around doing nothing WHILE it was busy. Doesn't help you guys. We also had an older Filipino gentlemen yell at our party and his co-worker. When my party asked to split the bill in half he visibly and verbally gave our party attitude. In no way were we being rude. So I have no idea why he would be so angry about it. I'm also going to going to be really rude by saying this but I don't care if he own the business or have a family member that owns this business. That man does not deserve to be working around customers if little things like that are going to make him that angry. 

Anyways, try the ramen it's great. If you don't want you and your party to get upset; just ask for another server if it's an older Filipino gentlemen.
author: Danny H.

description:
A ramen place that gives you your money's worth.

For $15 (Yamada-ya Ramen), you get a big bowl of thin noodle ramen with a ton of toppings, and not just veggies. You get 120g of pork in the form of chashu and pork belly along with seaweed, kikurage, menma, and GARLIC CHIPS! I love garlic, and that was the icing on the cake. 

If that isn't enough food for you, for $5 more you can make the ramen a combo, which gives you salad/rice and a half portion of an appetizer. You've got a hankering for karaage or gyoza but don't want a full order? This is right up your alley. I'm a karaage person, so having this option makes me happy. You can even pick from 3 styles, regular crispy, sauced up, or Korean style. Get some hot crisp chicken!

This place also does oomori (more noodles) and kaedama (extra noodles on the side)! I've been to many places that do one but not the other, so this is great!

The soup is very wholesome. I've heard reviews calling it bland, but to my taste buds, it's just right. Not too salty, not too heavy, and the toppings give an explosion of flavor. They have chili flakes on the side if you want some spice. 

The service is fairly nice. It gets busy, but the servers will see you given the layout of the place. I haven't had much problems with service as they get me in fairly quickly even during the 12-1pm lunch rush.

If you want ramen that's worth your money, swing by this japantown gem. Just be prepared line up for that goodness.
author: Daryl N.

description:
My second time having ramen in San Francisco and I must say it was a little disappointing. We got there around 1230 and good thing we did because we were seated right away. But once our food came we saw a bunch of people waiting for seats. We ordered takoyaki ($6) and Yamadaya shoyu ramen and another Yamadaya ramen. The takoyaki was pretty decent: crunchy on the outside and soft on the inside. It is one of the better takoyakis I've had in the states. However the ramen is a different story. The bowl is really filling but the problem is the proportion of the ramen to toppings. Way too little ramen and way too much toppings. Came with a lot of meat, two halves of eggs and tons of veggies. The soup base was alright.. not the kind that you would want to keep slurping. 

Also, there seems to be a lack of organization among the staff. We told one of the waiters that we needed more time to think about our order. He said ok and left but literally a minute later a waitress came to take our order. We turned her away because we weren't ready yet. We thought they were just trying to rush us but nope. 

The two girls sitting next to us experienced the same thing but with three diff servers.
author: Melody C.

description:
Last night, I was taken here with a friend who's been here before; said the place was good. I'm always down for a bowl of ramen so why not! 

The place is in the heart of Japantown, located on the second floor of the building across the street from the Peace Pagoda. When you walk up the stairs, you're asked to put your name in the ipad and someone will call you. The place was almost empty so we walked right in and a gentleman sat us immediately. The place was cute! Lots of windows, table tops, booths and a giant communal table in the middle. 

When we were greeted with a server in less than a minute; probably because the place was close to empty. Told him we needed another minute to look at the menu. While he was away, my friend and I decided on our ramen and was on the fence with what appetizer(s) to get. Once the server came back, we asked what he would recommend and he abruptly said, "you're in a ramen house! I recommend ramen!" Not in a playful way, more like an annoyed way. I looked at him and said, "no kidding? WE'RE IN A RAMEN HOUSE?!?!" Then rolled my eyes and said, "If you let us finish, we were asking for recommendations on appetizers." By that point, he was not having it with us, so he recommended we try anything lol It was quite hysterical how grouchy he was. Oh well, maybe the previous table didn't tip him well, or something...

For appetizers, we started with the gyoza for about $5; came with 6 pieces and dipping sauces. The gyoza was pan fried on one side but over seemed to have a gummy wrapping. Flavor was nice but not stand out. We also got (2) shrimp buns for $7. It was fried shrimp with cilantro, red onions and a spicy aioli. I liked it! Crispy shrimp, liked the aioli and the bun was light. 

For my meal, I got the Yamada-ya ramen for $13. I'm a little confused as the menus that were presented to me aren't the same menu as I see online or on Yelp pictures. There wasn't a variety of Yamada-ya ramen, like the shoyu or kotteri style. I could be wrong but I just saw Yamada-ya ramen: chashu, kakuni, bamboo shoots, garlic, nori, green onion and green onion. I thought it was going to be a normal broth, more like a shoyu broth, but what I got was something SUPER oily...too oily I could drink it. It was heavy and the oil seem to mask a lot of the flavor. What I did like though, were the noodles. They were cooked perfectly and held up in the broth. Overall a good dish, not stellar.

I think I would return for another try at another kind of ramen. This was a quick trip and not a lot of time to think things through. It was good for what it was, a quick Tuesday night grub session.
author: Rockne H.

description:
This was a really nice place to sit in with my wife and kids. BUT, being the stickler with my ramerner, I didn't particularly enjoy the garlic slices in my Yamadaya ramen. It way too much garlic- reminded me of my ex-wifes perfume. 

Other than that, it wasn't too bad, and the atmosphere and the shrimp on the rocks made this a super duper 4!
author: Jerry C.

description:
I'm always on the lookout for the best ramen... With that being said this is going to be one of my favorite spots... I ordered the spicy miso Ramen(the spicyiest level, but still not spicy to me).... and it was so rich and filling.

Pro: the ramen broth is cooked for over 20 hours... making it rich and creamy like... they have a waitlist on the Yelp app so you can put your name on it before getting there, which saves you time.

Cons: this place is not big, I do not recommend coming with a group bigger than 4... we got our food fast, but it took forever to get our bill to pay  and leave... I don't know if it was because we were only two people, but we basically got served our food and never checked up on again( I'm willing to look over this because the ramen was so good).

So overall if you're looking for a great Bowl Ramen for around $15 this is the place to go right in Japantown.
author: Marshawna C.

description:
What you need to know: 
- relatively spacious seating area for a ramen shop, but gets crowded! 
- staff are very informative and friendly 
- accepts credit cards
- make sure you sign in on the list 
- their broth is painstakingly cooked for 20 hours!!! 
- you can select the thickness of your ramen noodles! 

What we ordered: 
- Spicy Miso Ramen price $14 - comes with 3 types of miso, pork belly, chashu, soft egg AND bamboo shoots! The broth was rich, thick and cloudy, the way tonkotsu broth should be! I ordered mine with thick noodles, which I much prefer over thin noodles. This was an excellent bowl of ramen, from the expertly prepared broth, the generous portions of pork belly and chashu to all the delicious additions (soft egg and bamboo shoots). This was also a good deal for the amount and quality of food you get
- Yuzu Kosho Ramen $14 - the broth is chicken dashi which the waiter recommended as something a little lighter than their tonkotsu broth ramen. The broth is clear and not as heavy, but still very flavorful. This bowl came with A LOT of stuff including kara-age, soft egg, bamboo shoots, wood ear mushroom, fish cake and pork belly.
author: Karen L.

description:
My to go place for katsu curry. Free drink is an added bonus.

Ramen is great! And to top it off the price is pretty fair.
author: Sra P.

description:
Average ramen experience on the second floor of a Japantown building. There was quite the line during Cherry Blossom Festival but it moved along pretty quickly, and there's a variety of seating inside, whether at small-group or large communal tables. 

The ramen itself was as satisfying and decent as you would expect, although not necessarily the best I've ever had. The tonkotsu kakuni (pork belly) ramen, for example, was a decently constructed bowl with all the ingredients reasonably holding their own, although the single small chunk of pork belly did feel, well... small. Service was a bit hurried given the crowds. 

There's a new venue for ramen that just opened inside the Japantown mall nearby, and if you search Yelp, there might be even more. If those venues have lines and this doesn't, then it's a decent fallback.
author: Vincent L.

description:
Man, am I a fan of this place's broth! I ordered the regular tonkatsu ramen and it was so full of flavor with the right amount of saltiness and creaminess. The only downside that I will say is that the broth relies on a lot of fat for its flavor, meaning it is super thick and you can see the bits of fat floating around...so when you do take it as leftovers, its the type of broth that completely hardens because it's mostly all just fat.. which can be a bit off-setting.

Other than that, I do think trying Ramen Yamadaya is worth a 20 minute wait and would recommend this place to a friend :)
author: Lauren L.

description: We arrived right at closing but the manager was very kind and still served us- left a great impression on me. The ramen was solid- not the best I've ever had but the broth was very tasty. Located right in the center of Japantown- nice to walk the shops after your meal!
author: Kelly W.

description:
I found myself in Japantown and realized I was getting hungry. I did a quick search for ramen places in the area (assuming I would be in the mecca of quality). I have had Marufuku Ramen bookmarked for a while and wish I had braved the long line to try that instead. 

With that said Ramen Yamadaya isn't bad it's just completely average. I did enjoy sitting at the communal table in the middle of the room with my friend. It never felt crowded and I was never bothered by neighboring conversations (but then again not much talking happens while eating ramen). As far as food goes my ramen (vegan) was tasty and filling (in fact I couldn't finish a full bowl). I felt like $3 for tofu was a bit much (it's not like I asked for avocado) but it was a decent size portion. I also asked for it to be spicier and went with the lemon-yuzu option which I think added a nice flavor. 

It was a little strange having "club" music playing in the middle of the day, Sunday, with young kids here. The restrooms were a bit surprising given the decor/atmosphere of the rest of the restaurant. It was like a complete after thought. I've been in gas station restrooms nicer than these.
author: Tarah P.

description: The ramen was good but they messed up our order twice and we waited about half an our to pay for our food
author: Teya T.

description: Vegan ramen with tofu quite good but only one piece of tofu. Broth was miso based and not at all salty like other ramens. I would return and ask for extra tofu!
author: Joe D.

description:
I'm going to start by saying that I'm not sure if it's completely authentic, but I LOVE THIS PLACE. I've had a lot of ramen in like Vegas, sf, A few places in sac and Reno... and honestly, I find myself thinking about this place a lot and missing this place hahaha.

I got the spicy miso & also one of the first spicy one on the menu, I forgot what it's called. But the broth they have is so thick and rich. I did take off half star for that tho becuz it's sooo thick... I'm the type that likes slightly heavier tasting food but even that is a LITTLE too much. so if you are into lighter seasoning for food, this is probably not so much for you? 

Also, level 2 spicy is pretty spicy, my broth was red, so beware! I also love getting their karaage because you get a lot for the portion and it's yummy. I also like that they have the $5 side option so that you can try their other dishes on top of ramen, I actually... LOVE THAT A LOT and I wish every place does that. 

My friend also got the takoyaki and that's one item that I don't really recommend. It was kinda too soggy inside and wasn't very crispy on the outside either. Another half star for that.

The service was also pretty good. I was there near the end of the night so the service got a little slow but nothing too bad, it only happened toward the end when we paid. Prices are also very reasonable for sf. I would come back just to try all of their different ramen ;) they have a lot!!!!!

Lastly, if I've learned anything about ramen is that people do it v differently and ppl like diff taste. Don't listen 100% to reviews and try it yourself too ;)
author: Jen K.

description: We came here just in time and didn't have to line up. But we felt rushed eating, while watching the line outside grow longer and longer. I got the spicy ramen and it was definitely spicy enough since you could choose spicy levels! I loved that it already comes with an egg, since that's something I find myself having to add at other restaurants. The only complaint is that the broth was a little oilier(?) than I would have liked, and the serving was a little large (though I'm sure this wouldn't necessarily be a con, I just didn't like wasting food)! Good place to eat if you can catch it without a line.
author: Charmaine L.

description:
I ate around noon on a weekday.  It was fairly empty when I arrived.  It was full when I left.

I had a lunch special ramen bowl.  I don't remember its name.  I had the medium spice.  I really enjoyed the food. The spice was just a bit hot, in other words medium spice.

I was served a large goblet of green tea.  It was almost room temperature.  That surprised me.  I noted that to the hostess when I left.

Also, the music was suitable for a much younger crowd, and it was too loud for me.  I suspect that's a technique that ensures high turnover.  I don't care for it.

Good food but loud.
author: Micky L.

description:
Yamadaya served one of then best ramen I've had in a long time.

The soup was so smooth, savory, rich and creamy. The Chashu  pork and pork belly were cooked to perfection that melts in your mouth. Noodles were thin and chewy. This place is probably one of the most underrated restaurants I've ever been to.
author: Kyle Z.

description:
We came here for the first time on a Sunday around 5:25pm.  There was no line and we were immediately seated.  It should be noted that by the time we left at 6:15pm there was a long line of people waiting to be seated. 

Our table and seating area was clean but smelled like bathroom cleaner (at least initially).  We stopped noticing the odor at some point during the meal but it seemed worth noting for this review.

We ordered the Kakuni Shio Ramen, the Spicy Miso Ramen, the Donburi Curry Bowl (beef, potato, onions, and carrots), and Tori No Nanbanzuke (fried chicken in shoyu, ginger, and garlic).  All of our dishes were really good: the ramen broth was well flavored, the curry bowl had good seasoning, and the chicken was crispy.
author: Paul O.

description:
Walked up the stairs to the second story of a Japantown building and tried Ramen Yamadaya.

I went with the house:

Yamada-Ya- Sea salt , pork bone broth , 7 g Chashsu , 50 g pork belley woodear mushrooms, bamboo, tokyo scallions, nori soft egg and black garlic oil. 

One thing that jumped out was the wait for this place. It was not super busy but it took the longest out of all the places I've been to for the ramen to come out. At least 20 minutes and I just ordered a simple plate and was here by my lonesome

What came out was pretty good and pretty taste. 

I ranked it  5/5/5 for (taste of broth/taste of noodles/taste of other stuff). It falls at #11 in my rankings below. 


I recently embarked on a completely pointless quest to rank most of the Ramen Places in the Bay Bay Bay similar to lists I have for Boba.


Ranking explained:  #1 (listed at the top)  is my favorite/ #?  (listed at the bottom) is my least favorite. Check out my latest reviews for my latest up to date Rankings.

* Please note that I don't have a preference for thick or thin noodles or thick or clear broth I just call it like I feel it.

# 17 Slurp Ramen *Rod SF Bay Area Ramen Rating * 4/4/4 *Rod's Yelp Rating *2 stars

author: Rod M.

description:
We had a very poor experience here. Ramen Yamadaya is on the second floor of the building, and on the steps there was a sign that said we can get waitlisted for a table via yelp. So I signed myself and my partner up for a table though the yelp app. After waiting for a table for 20 minutes, the yelp app told us the table was ready, but the problem was when we went in and showed the staff that my yelp app said our table was ready, we were told that we actually weren't put on their guestlist. Instead of investigating the situation, a staff member, a middle aged asian man with glasses, simply told us to start over and put our name on their waitlist again. I asked why they would advertise to have a service for table reservations through yelp if they weren't going to follow through with giving us a table, and the waiter, the middle aged asian man with glasses, started going on a tirade, saying that they didn't need yelp, they did fine without it, and they weren't responsible for getting us a table if we use their services to get a reservation, since he claimed yelp's reservation requests weren't connected to their internal system. After around 10 minutes of getting awkwardly standing there while being berated, we asked to speak to someone else, while the older man finally gave up and ignored us to serve accepted several parties that came in after us. Finally, one of the young waitresses finally came over, pressed a few buttons on the check in tablet, and there were our names, in the completed table's section, verifying our reservation. 

The man then looked shocked and instead of apologizing for the treatment and the lost reservation, doubled down on his argument that we should have checked in at the desk in addition to checking in through yelp. Hungry and tired I simply informed him that if that were the policy, they should have someone at the front able to address people's inquiries. Having taken a good look at the tablet while the waitress was on it, I believe that they had already crossed our name off the list as they believed that it had been completed. 

In regards to the food, we both ordered two Yamada-ya Ramen and found them to be quite average. The booth, although thick, was very bland with the noodles slightly undercooked. 

Overall, this was one of the worst services I've ever experienced and I will never be returning to this establishment. I recommend Marufuku across the street in the Japan town Mall, where the old Sapporo-ya ramen shop used to be. Or if you're out in Palo Alto, Ramen Nagi, who actually brought people over from their Shinjuku, Tokyo branch to work over there. That ramen is on par with the best of Ramen in Tokyo. They're the real deal.
author: Phillip M.

description: Probably one of the not so great ramen places I have been to. The Yamadaya's broth and soft boiled egg was bland, the chasu was over salted but the pork belly was decent, however, all the toppings and meat to fat ratio were inconsistent. The lunch special appetizer was underwhelming as well as the the pork bun. Not to mention the customer service wasn't the best. No one came back to check in on us and the wait time for the food was a little unreasonable.. 20-25 minutes for 3 bowls of ramen..(although I would understand if they were short staffed in the kitchen). Overall, my experience here was not the best and definitely not worth the money ($65 for 3 people and we got the lunch special, 2 Yamadaya's, and a pork bun).
author: Asia N.

description: I ordered spicy miso. It is not bad, but for a bamboo lover, 3 small pieces is too little. I give 3 star for 2 reasons: 1. My hubby ordered a tsukemen, and it was horrible, probably the least tasteful one ever! 2.  The food waiting time was comparatively long!
author: Jane W.

description:
3.6 stars for the ramen, but 3 or the strange ambience and service.

Unlike what some of the other reviews highlighted, I don't think Yamada's ramen is all that bad. It's just a bit greasy. You can see bits of fat floating on top or congealed onto the slices of see weed on the side. It deters me from wholeheartedly enjoying the broth. 

My boyfriend ordered hell ramen and I ordered the Yamada spicy ramen.

Though he claims hell ramen wasn't very spicy, he was drenched in sweat by the end of the meal. He ended up going to the bathroom to splash water on his face to cool down. Later in the evening he told me that he can feel the hot oil swooshing around in this stomach....

Flavor wise the ramens were decent. Both portions came with generous amount of pork, though there was a huge fatty slice in mine that I did not eat. You can see in the pictures. No heart attacks for me thank you very much. 

The part I didn't like about the meal was the ambience. They played 1960s hits which didn't go well with the more modern decor of the restaurant. The waiters while kind and generous skewed on the younger side and were not very professional nor knowledgeable. When asked about the spice levels our waiter said he doesn't know. When asked about how spicy hell ramen is, his response was the same. While wiping down the table next to us, another waiter splashed some water towards our end, but didn't wipe it down. 

Adding to this was the fact that the restaurant staff all worked conspicuously next to the counter putting together to go deliveries and the like. It was just not very polished...I also saw several restaurant employees come back to the restaurant holding bags of frozen shrimp. Probably brought from the store across from the street. The floor was also very slippery...from grease?

Overall it's a good place for a quick meal. Don't know if I'd come back again though. :/
author: Sherica L.

description:
They have a diverse menu for a ramen joint.  I noticed that their menu was different from what was advertised on their website.  Not sure if it's because we came on the weekend and if the website menu was for weekdays only. Besides ramen, they serve appetizers and rice bowl (donburi) dishes. 

We ordered two karaage plates and a Yamadaya ramen bowl for the kids to share, a Salmon and ikura bowl for me, chicken katsu curry and two nikuman pork steamed buns (like bao buns) for the hubby.  Everything was good and the portions were very generous.  I would probably pass on the salmon and ikura bowl.  Though it was good the cut of salmon did not look like a decent cut.  It had no marbling on the pieces I got.  The chicken katsu curry was my favorite.  Huge portion and the curry had potatoes, carrots, and meat. The ramen broth had a deep umami flavor and was a little on the fatty side but was delicious when paired with the noodles. We had leftovers to pack home for dinner.  Service was efficient but not great.  Would come back again.
author: Nai P.

description: If you love finding the best ramen in the city, this is a pretty strong contender, especially if you love spicy. I went with the Spicy Miso at the Fire level and it was perfect. Hit this place up!
author: Anthony B.

description: The server was the RUDEST I have ever seen. When we enter the restaurant, we asked for high chair for the kids but the server guided us to the bar! then we ask him to move to high chair to the table, he looks extremely unhappy like we owe him money and never return it back! The ramen was so so but when we ask for the check, the server was mad and leave us there waiting for 10 minutes, the tip option for lunch was start at 18%! How ridiculous this place are! I would never ever come to this place again!
author: Yufan X.

description:
Ordered a Spicy Miso Ramen and Kukuni. Both were super rich and delicious. Meat was tender and fatty.
One of my best Ramen Experience
author: Dencil Deepika D.

description:
I'll start with the service - extremely slow!! Our waiter looked like he could not care less if we got menus, water or our food. I don't think he said more than 5-10 words to us. 

We finally got our table after about a 20-30 minute wait. You have to sign up on the waiting list at the front and they'll text you when your table is ready. If your phone number is synced to yelp and you use that number to get on the wait list, you'll see your place in line listed on the yelp app on the restaurant's page as well. 

The tonkatsu ramen had an excessive amount of lumps of fat in and on the broth - so much grease that I felt a little ill. Black garlic oil is a tiny, tiny amount in one corner of the bowl. However, huge pieces of meat!

I ordered the chicken katsu curry to go, and that was a mistake. Extremely dry chicken and a thin curry. Comes with macaroni salad and spring mix salad (and white rice of course) which wasn't bad. 

I wouldn't come back.
author: Melanie W.

description: I grew up in Japan. I knew what kind of taste ramen should be. I was surprised at the ramen offered by Yamadaya. Oh my god! This restaurant offered real ramen from Japan!!! I loved the soup and charshu. I definitely recommend this place if you are serious ramen eater.
author: Cool K.

description:
Ramen Yamadaya has the best ramen I've ever tried. I ordered the Yamadaya Tonkotsu Shoyu. I was not the biggest fan of the chasu which was a little dry. However, I am so obsessed with their pork belly that I think I'll only be ordering from the Kakuni Ramen from now on. The broth was extremely thick and rich. 
 
In addition, I also tried their Salmon/ikura over rice, Takoyaki, and Karaage. I will note I was surprised their Salmon/ikura over rice dish had smoked salmon and plain, not sushi, rice. Everything else was mediocre and just pales in comparison to their ramen.
author: Sheila H.

description:
Thank God for my good friend who drove me all the way to SF for Ramen Yamadaya. I've been living in San Diego for the last several years and I lived super duper close to the Ramen Yamadaya in SD.I pretty much went almost everyday and got their takeout ha ha I was obsessed with their Yamadaya bun and their takoyaki. It's always a big task to go all the way to SF for food especially Japantown since it's far from the bart stations.

I came here on a Monday last week and even though the website says they open at 5:30pm for dinner, they let us in at 5! Woo! I obviously ordered the Yamadaya Pork Belly Bun, Takoyaki and the black sesame oil ramen with thick noodle. I'm a lover of pork belly! Everything was really good! I like their ramen better here than the one in SD honestly. Their Yamadaya bun was served differently, the one in SD doensn't have any onions with theirs. I'm not a big veggie fan so I ended up taking them off. All in all everything was delicious! I'm definitely returning if I'm in Japantown again!
author: Ramona G.

description:
Tonkotsu shio ramen add corn ($14): Ramen $13 and add corn was an extra $1. The ramen came with a generous portion of pork belly and the broth was really good I almost finished it all!!! The ramen was a little different than other places but it was still good just different.

Something to know: The restroom is unisex and there's only 2 kinda weirddddd
author: Daisy M.

description: Nice food, noodles are soft and easy to eat. Water's always on the table, ready for you to pour it into your cup. However, it's kinda dark and needs some brighter lights. The camera doesn't work too well in some parts of it, but at the window view it's bright and clear. Also gives a nice view, watching all the people down there. On busy days, the tables are always full with about 1.5x more people waiting than available tables, so they should probably renovate I as it appears relatively old.The tables are semi-sticky and require a waiter/waitress to clean it up for you, just a slight inconvenience. I feel so full with so little amount of noodles, and the takeout let's me eat more at a cheap price. Overall, though, Ramen Yamadaya is great in most aspects!
author: Pyritian T.

description:
If you're planning on coming here, make a reservation. The line up around dinner time can get pretty long! 

The food: I got the tonkatsu ramen and my friend got the chicken ramen. We shared karagee (Japanese fried chicken) and octopus balls. While this was all delicious and fairly priced, especially for the huge portions you get, I felt a bit sick afterwards. I suspect that the amount of oil in my meal contributed to that, and I suspect that their fryer oil hadn't been changed recently. 

Service/Ambiance: short and sweet but very efficient. I guess when you have a lineup outside 20 people deep you have to be! They have a large communal table in the middle for smaller parties and solo diners which I actually kind of liked.. felt very Japanese street style!
author: Julie N.

description:
We waited 30 minutes to be seated, but the restaurant had an automated waiting list that texted us when our table was available. The layout of the place was very efficient. Booths surrounded the perimeter of the restaurant while larger tables spanned the middle. I liked the dim ambiance and the cool light fixtures that hung from the ceiling. The place had a nice traditional but modern feel to it.

[Kakuni Ramen] I loved the large chunks of pork belly. The ramen was very firm but chewy. I really enjoyed the rich flavor of the broth and its thick texture. Unfortunately, the egg had a very liquid yolk and tasted extremely bitter, which made me slightly concerned. The people I ate with said their eggs were just as bitter...
author: Annie Z.

description: The ramen here was great and they have booths and tables large enough for groups. If you've got a group, get here early because it's pretty small but worth the wait.
author: Patrick C.

description: The place is not very clean. The ramen is not too bad, but, in my taste, too fatty. Overall it was not very pleasant experience. Disappointed
author: Elena B.

description:
I came here on a Sunday afternoon anticipating a long wait, but to our surprise it actually moved pretty quickly. They don't just call one group at a time, they try to clear out as many tables as they can inside and call a bunch of parties all at once. 

Once we were seated at the center communal table, we ordered pretty quickly. We asked for tea, but in the end, got water (tea has an extra cost). We placed our orders, all 3 of us got ramen and a takoyaki appetizer. 

Here is where things went down hill... the ramen took almost 20 minutes to come out.. but when it did, our ramen wasn't the traditional, it was very thin, which I thought they should advertise, vs my friend who got the thicker noodles I'm used to when eating ramen. The flavor of it was really good, and they actually give you a lot of meat! But towards the end of our bowls, we asked the waitress where our takoyaki was and she said it's coming. Once we were done with our ramen (they took away our bowls), then came out the appetizer. The waitress had 5+ orders of takoyaki on her platter, so I think they just make one large batch and serve it all at once... which isn't convenient. Isn't an appetizer supposed to come out before the meal?
author: Carrie L.

description: So rude. I went to the place and the waitress was impatient and told me to go back out there to enter my name on the waitlist even though there were plenty of seatings. I would have no problem with it except her tone of voice was so mean. I don't care how good of a place it is, it should at least have some decent respect for customers.
author: Eggie S.

description: I ordered the Yamada-Ya Ramen and it was recommended by the waiter to me. I thought the ramen was okay - not the best and not the worst I've had. I thought the service was great, the staff were friendly and kind.
author: Maria J.

description: We had Katsu curry and spicy ramen.  Ramen had too much fat and broth was not good.   Katsu curry was not tasty and pork was too gamey.   Service was good.
author: EunJoo C.

description:
I had visited this restaraunt previously and had an unsatisfying experience, however, the time before that, it was great so I decided to give it another shot. I was extremely impressed. I was seated promptly, the food was fresh and full of flavor, staff was friendly, and our food came out quickly. After my most recent visit, I would definitely dine again! I recommend this place to all of my friends!

I gave 4 stars because of the one experience I had at their restaraunt that was not expected due to their exceptional food and service I received during previous visits. With that, I would recommend calling ahead, before visiting on a busy evening, to make sure they have plenty of meat left.
author: Mikki R.

description:
The ramen was good, but not the best I've had.  I came in on a Saturday around noon to have lunch with a friend.  I ordered the Yamada-ya (shio tonkotsu broth).  It was a rather large portion size.  The broth was ok, the noodles were ok, the toppings were proportional, and the meat was a bit fatty for my personal liking.  My friend ordered the spicy ramen and her review as, "It was okay... I wouldn't have a hankering for it."

When we came, it was still early in the lunch rush.  We were seated immediately.  However, they wanted to seat us at a large, shared center table that appeared "cozy."  We asked to have our own table (yes, there were open tables) and the waiter obliged seemingly begrudgingly.  We placed our order, the food came, the bill came before I finished eating.  (Which I was okay with as there was a sizeable amount of people waiting outside, but it irritated my friend.)
author: Stephanie L.

description: Considering they charge $15 per medium sized bowl of ramen, I didn't like it at all. The broth has little to no flavor, the meat is fairly dry, and there are hardly any vegetables. I also didn't order thicker noodles but received them anyway. I didn't end up eating more than two bites of my ramen and brought the issue up when paying. I was given a very small discount of $1 and was told I need to say something earlier - which would've made sense if I would've eaten more of the food I didn't like. Also, the restrooms are crazy dirty.
author: Nataly V.

description:
Kakuni Kotteri Ramen - generous pork belly portion, flavorful soup, love the thin noodles. A
