Takoyaki - the breading and fried exterior was excellent, but the octopus portion was lacking. Wish the breading/octopus ratio was more like 2:1, rather than what felt like 5:1. B-

Gyozas - these were disappointing, they tasted like defrosted dumplings you fry in your weak kitchen pan, and somehow got them all soggy before serving them. C-
author: Anthony W.

description:
While I was arrived at Japantown during the last day of the Cherry Blossom Festival on Easter Sunday (4/16/2017), I decided to head this local Japanese noodle restaurant of, "Ramen Yamadaya." This place serves the customers to taste their authentic and superb Japanese cuisines: Ramen, Soba, bento boxes, appetizers and many more! The atmosphere is very active and on-going as I welcomed there. The concept is much modern and touristy filled with traditional Japanese flare and a wonderful mini garden island table right at the center of the room.

The employees from servers, hosts and cookers are doing a great job for accommodating the customers like me a sensational service despite the busiest environment. No cons at all.

Now onto the food! I ordered their signature and customer's favorite: the Tonkotsu Kotteri with additive toppings of yellow sweet corn and fresh spinach. As I ate it, that bowl tasted very good! The broth is perfectly amazing cause I can feel the flavors of the black garlic oil and "rich and fatty" ramen aromas combined. Speaking of ramen, that noodle is not that bad as I can bite the noodles in ease. The rest of the ingredients of the Tonkotsu Kotteri along with corn and spinach also tasted flawless too. The pork, hard-boiled eggs and bamboo shoots did it justice to make this entree a breathe of fresh air! Wonderful lunch meal!

Parking at Ramen Yamadaya can be challenging to park. You can park at the nearby surface street parking nor the parking garage near Japantown shopping center available. Alternatively, you can also ride a bike, walk, carpool, ride sharing or public transportation easier without the hassles and gimmicks.

In the end, Ramen Yamadaya is the most excellent local Japanese restaurant that I've ever discovered all thanks to the Yelp app. Perfect for friends, family and co-workers gathering all day and all night. A well visit! My rating: 4 solid stars.
author: William L.

description: Not recommended. I ordered spicy miso. The noodles and the broth are fine but the MEAT was TERRIBLE! It was very hard, dry and was cut into very huge pieces. I had a piece which was 3 times larger and was mostly fat. Definitely not recommended for ramen. In fact, One of the worst ramen that I've ever had.
author: Yuting L.

description:
Sighhhh... the last time we ate here, the food was good. I think it is under new management and the crew are not Japanese people anymore. The menu has changed and the service crew is mostly Filipinos. We ordered spicy miso and my hubby told the waiter to make it spicy hot. The ramen came and it was not spicy hot at all, the noodles are a bit tough, Chashu had a funky smell, and the broth was just ok. I don't think it's worth $13 for a single bowl at all. $7 for three pieces of ebi for appetizer is just too much and it was served cold, could be sitting in the kitchen.. who knows. Waiter didn't even check us if we need anything. 

Their chicken karaage was dry and flavorless, not the typical Japanese chicken karaage that is when well prepared, it's crunchy and flavorful. We have eaten at so many ramen place so we know what it should look and taste like. Anyway, I guess we will cross this out of our go to ramen place when we're at Japan town.
author: Lyn W.

description:
Ugh. Not great. First of all the wait time was over an hour and a half. I finally get seated and have the Kotteri Ramen as well as the karaage.

Let me just say that this was the worst ramen I've ever had. It smelled bad and tasted awful.

The karaage was decent but it is meant for a table of at least 3 or 4 people. There should be a smaller option for one to two people.
author: Han D.

description:
I ordered take out through postmates on a rainy day and it definitely hit the spot. I got the Yamadaya ramen. Their bone broth was very flavorful and the amount of meat they give is kind of crazy. I'm used to getting two slice of thin pork. Here I got like 5 chunky pieces and half of them was quite tender and juicy. The other half was a little dry. Maybe the cut of the meat? They also give one whole egg in halves rather than just half an egg. 

There are also two options of noodles. By default you will get the thinner version. The thicker version is suppose to be chewier but I didn't think it was. The meal was packaged nicely in a bowl with soup separated. I could've used a little more soup. The noodles were stuck together, but what do you expect for take out? My friend had added a fire bomb to it. She said it was pretty darn spicy and she only added a little bit of it. I wonder what level the death bomb is at. 

I want to go try this restaurant in person to give it a true rating. I heard though, that the line is out the door and around the corner on some days. So go early!
author: Julie V.

description: Don't get me wrong; the food tastes good, and the staff is friendly. However, you can tell the operation here is pretty inefficient and understaffed. I came here with my family, who all ordered ramen. The ramen came out fairly quickly, but what I ordered, (the karage, gyoza, and pork bun,) took about 35 minutes. I noticed that there's often food left on the window for a long period of time without a waiter to collect and distribute them. It's a busy place, and the staff seem to have trouble keeping up with the pace. This isn't the staff's fault but more of a management issue.
author: Yuki W.

description:
PRO TIP: They have listed specials on some boards in the waiting area that AFAIK are not written anywhere inside the restaurant. It's always a good idea to check them before being seated!

On my first visit here, I tried their tsukemen which I thought was pretty good. Now that I've tried their ramen, there's no going back to that! I came here on a Sunday evening with a group of four and decided to try their special spicy miso kakuni ramen which was heavily recommended to me. The pork belly is juicy and fatty, and their noodles are springy and chewy. The broth was rich in flavor especially after mixing in the scoop of spicy miso paste they place on top. The spicy miso really adds a nice kick to the broth that makes all the components all the more flavorful. I highly recommend this special for those who love some heat in their ramen!
author: Joshua M.

description:
Best ramen in the history of ramen, maybe ever.
Jokes aside, food is great (amazing takoyaki). The portions are really generous. Definitely worth the waiting time.
author: Alexia Q.

description:
We ordered vegan ramen by assuming the same excellent ramen would be served, but this time totally different. Noodles are good. Miso-based soup which I'm not a big fan. Pumpkin topping -complete NG. Corn topping -sweet corns from can isn't a good choice, non-sweetened corns should be there. 
Will keep searching on a good ramen place.
author: Chiemi K.

description:
I came here with three of my friends to grab some ramen! The ramen was great (Broth was rich and creamy, Kakuni and chasu were tender, noodles were great).  Our server was attentive and refilled our water/tea.

Everything was good until it came paying the bill.  We placed our credit cards (4 total) so that we could split the bill evenly. The server took our cards and that's when things started to take a turn for disappointment. The server began consulting with one of the male employees (I am assuming to be the manager?) to see if it's okay to split the bill.  To be clear I am okay with restaurants requiring only one credit card; they just have to politely inform us!

Instead the manager came to our table and proceeded to give us attitude. He began shaking his head and THREW the iPad in front of us to sign/pay our bill. How disrespectful is that!?

I am disappointed in their customer service as the manager was rude, disrespectful, and downright  insulting. This is no way to act towards paying patrons. 

TLDR: Food was great! But the manager was trash and needs to be taken out!
author: Collin C.

description:
OMG customers please go and taste Ramen any other place.
This is not a Ramen.
Better & put so many cameral.
This is not a food.
Be genuine wise choose. This is totally Junk.
author: Hayong K.

description:
Wow, its been over a year since I've been back, and I wasn't impressed.

Yamadaya has a good variety of ramen's on the menu including tonkatsu, tonktatsu miso, and shio. You can customize your ramen in a variety of combos and tons of extras, both for your ramen or if you are craving a side of dumplings, salad, or pork buns.

I went with a group of friends and we all ordered something different to sample the menu, but unfortunately everyone walked away with just an eh opinion of the place. The meat was pretty tough, and soup was just lukewarm. If you are looking for a good tori shio ramen, go across the street. If you want tonkatsu check out the new place that opened up on the far side of the mall.

I used to be a huge fan of this place, and I'll def come back to see if the place has a turn around. However, with so many better ramen options opening up in the city, and just in J-town for that matter, coming to this place is a tough sell.
author: James S.

description:
So this time I got the spicy ramen and it was much better than whatever I got when I wrote the first review. I loved the broth and how creamy and tasty it was. The meat was so soft and perfect and was just amazing!

I got level 3, but it seriously wasn't spicy. I feel like the added spicy paste just made everything saltier. The noodles were still meh, like I said last time. If they had better noodles it would be soooo good. 

I also recommend ordering fresh garlic (which comes with a garlic crusher) to add some extra flavor into your ramen, if you are a garlic lover like me.
author: Stephanie K.

description: The first restaurant my grandkids and I stop by when we enter Jtown was this cute, simple ramen house. I did quite enjoy our view considering we got a window seat and the ramen was such a big portion. The sweet lady who bussed our table was so kind and took great care of us. Will return soon.
author: Zeta A.

description: No good at all,the noddle soup smell very strange,and tasted very strong and fat,it not worth $15 at all
author: Yanci K.

description: Great service , I ordered the fire sauce and couldn't handle it but other than that it was excellent! Will try a milder sauce next time
author: Carl W.

description:
As others have noted, it seems like sort-of an Invasion of the Body Snatchers thing, because it looks the same ... the menu is sort of the same ... but something ... just isn't right ...
I'm pretty certain the chicken kara-age was microwaved - it was hot, but the coating wasn't crisp.
They forgot the egg in my ramen and when I asked, they came back with an cold cooked egg in a cup. I'm pretty sure my dining partner's ramen was supposed to have one too, but they didn't acknowledge that one way or the other when we asked.
I also miss the old menu. The xeroxed paper ones they have now were all spattered with grease; sort of off-putting for the first impression as you sit down. Also, they've cut down on a lot of things they used to do, the combos, the donburis, etc.
They get stars because the ramen was still delicious, but it seems like they're getting sloppy around the edges.
author: S M.

description:
Tried this ramen place for the first time today! It wasn't too busy when we got there so there wasn't a wait. I ordered the shio ramen ($13) and added corn ($1). It was delicious but a bit too salty/oily. That's always a risk with ramen though. I would still come back to try the cold ramen when it gets a little warmer.

Service wise - it was fine, nothing spectacular, but they tend to get pretty busy so I get why the service isn't amazing. 

Would still recommend though if you're in the area and can't decide what to eat!
author: Jacqueline H.

description: By far the best Japanese ramen place I've been to in San Francisco. The broth is tasty, the noodles are thin and chewy, and the servers are awesome! I ordered the Kakuni ramen. There's fat in the pork pieces but this is what I came for.
author: Customer L.

description: My friends and I were craving for ramen so we checked this place out. We were seated right away and the staff were pretty attentive. I like the ambiance of the restaurant because its not too loud. I got the spicy miso and i didnt like it. The broth is too thick for me; thicker than the usual ramen broth. However, i liked the ramen noodles and the pork. I also got the chicken kaarage which is nice. I would def come back but try the other broth because like i said, the one i got was pretty thick.
author: Rafael A.

description:
First of all, I've never been publicly berated by anyone but my own mother until today.

Let me start by saying that my meal was for the most part enjoyable. Their broths were extremely rich just the way I like and the ramen was cooked well. Unfortunately the "soft egg" was not a soft boiled egg but rather an over cooked ball of rubber. However, the egg didn't deter me from enjoying my meal because I didn't eat all of it. 

Now comes time to leave. It takes an excessively long amount of time for someone to come. But my party and I are still gushing about how delicious everything was. 

An older gentleman finally comes with the tablet to charge us. And like most people these days my party and I ask if they are able to split the check. He becomes visibly unhappy which is understandable, it's peak dinner time and they're busy. But what comes next from this gentleman completely blows my mind. He raises his voice enough that neighboring tables turn around to see what the commotion is. Half my party was asking if they would be able pay with cash while I paid with card. He loudly exclaims, "DOES IT LOOK LIKE I HAVE A CASH REGISTER ON ME?" I wasn't sure how to answer him but good thing he decided to storm off without another word. After a couple of minutes he comes by with a printed check and  practically drops the tray on the table. A younger gentleman comes by after seeing the commotion to see if he can help us out. We quietly hand him a card and cash to pay for our meal hoping the same older man wouldn't be coming back to terrorize us further. But he's back and this time he snaps at his coworker saying, "DO YOU EVEN KNOW WHATS GOING ON. HOW THEY WANT TO PAY?" He then looks down at the tray and sees a single card and a single bill. And again he raises his voice saying, "I THOUGHT YOU GUYS WERE PAYING INDIVIDUALLY WHAT IS THIS?" He grabs the money out of his coworkers hands and storms away once again.

Never did we ask to pay individually all we wanted to know was if we could pay a sum of cash and the rest on a card. 

The food just wasn't good enough to make up for getting yelled at the way we did tonight.
author: Sidney W.

description:
I am a Yamadaya loyalist and I've been loving the tonkotsu ramen that Yamadaya has put forth ever since I first tried it in San Diego.  I've gone several times to a few locations, and I have also been to the San Francisco location several times too.

While the tonkotsu ramen here is still very delicious, a couple things about this location seemed to have changed from the previous times I had been here.  One of them being the menu.  It was definitely different from when I last visited and what stuck out was that I couldn't find the kotteri version on it.  I'm not sure if they got rid of it or if I just missed it somewhere, but since the kotteri version is my go-to at Yamadaya, I was a little sad that I couldn't find it.

The service also seemed to have gone down a little bit.  I remember previously the service was very top-notch, but during this visit, the service did run into a few snags, including a missed order (got resolved quickly though).  Not to say that the service was terrible, but it definitely wasn't the same as before.

That being said, Yamadaya is still a great place to go to for tonkotsu.  Since I couldn't find the kotteri, I ordered their regular tonkotsu with the extra thick noodles (my personal preference), and it still turned out great.  Broth was spot on, the crispy garlic was a nice touch, and the chashu was particularly memorable, very good char yet very juicy.  Recommendation is try to go during earlier times as it does get crowded later on.
author: Ken D.

description: I would give them no stars if I could. I get there around 9:20 and a guy that works there tells me they can't serve me because they turned down everything inside already. I've liked their food but it doesn't take that long to make mediocre ramen. U don't need to deny customers before 40 mins before closing.
author: Ingyin M.

description: It used to be my favorite ramen spot in the entire Bay Area, until yesterday. My roommates and me got there around 6:30 and the wait was not so bad. We got two spicy ramen, one Yamadaya ramen, one chicken curry and one order of gyoza. All dishes  were great expect for the gyoza. It was not crispy at all and when I told the manager about this issue she explained to me that "these are not meant to be crispy cuz it's not fried dumplings." She just took the dish away. However, she did not charge us for it. But, today we discovered that all three of us got food poisoned and here was the only thing we had together since this week.
author: Mia Q.

description:
The interior is nice, they play some loud hip-hop, which not my taste but acceptable. The wait is sometimes pretty long, but last time we went at 8pm, and we got in within 20 minutes.

The service was okay, about average. I asked them multiple times for the same stuff, which I do not really care.

The ramen was where it shines. I ordered the tonkotsu ramen. The broth was very thick, flavorful, and I added the black garlic oil which made it much richer. The ramen was not the typical low end ramen that I might find in a lot of other ramen stores. They used a thinner, yet still has a very good texture and taste. Combined with the broth, it tasted beyond my expectation. The pork belly was gigantic, yet tender, very rich in flavor, and it was one of the best pork belly I have tasted. However, people might find it a bit too oily and has too much fat. I personally not a pork lover, but I will have this pork belly. All other ingredients were nice, good quality, and went well with the ramen. We also order salad and curry rice bowl, they were both nice. We ended up not finishing the meal, because we weren't too hungry, and the ramen broth was thick and made me filled up easily.

I think most people could handle the broth, I personally not a big fan on oil and fat. The broth maybe too thick for me.

Overall, the ramen was very good. It was a very different, yet very good style among all other ramen shops in the Bay Area. The best thing is that they used better quality ingredients, from the ramen, bamboo shoots, and to the pork belly. I will definitely come again.

*December 5th update*

I m here for lunch this time and found out they retired their confusing-flashy-fastfood style menu! I ordered the Yamadaya, which is still very good tasting. The tonkotsu broth is still think, flavorful and quite salty (just for me, but I think most ppl would be okay especially if you are American). The fried garlic can be a little bit too hard to chew sometimes, but nothing too serious.

Overall still very good, but i am kind of sick of the super outdated pop song play list that they still used. If you go there more than two times you would hear the same songs.
author: Zack Y.

description: Noodles were amazing, wait was not so good but that wasn't completely their fault. The broth is salty but super good and huge portions. I had ordered takeout and they didn't answer the phone to confirm for an hour and a half. For such a well reviewed place I was surprised. I really enjoyed the food but that kind of put me off. The frozen was good and they did bring out new food and the manager was very helpful.
author: Tara K.

description:
I don't recommend you to visit this restaurant if you don't want to have a terrible stomach ache and illness on your ride home. I had a terrible food poisoning the next day :-( 
I got the Spicy Miso ramen but first of all, the broth doesn't taste like miso, and the flavor is too light - there is not a hint of spicy miso. It just tastes like chicken soup. Also, the night of eating it, I felt unwell and felt uneasy to my stomach twice. I actually felt so nauseous either from the uncooked meat or from the noodles that I could not eat at all after it until the night of the next day. There is a piece of chunky meat in the ramen that is so fatty that it is impossible to eat.
The server greeted us rather unprofessionally once we showed up on our reservation time and when we were paying for our meals, the server spilled tea all over our stuff and did not apologize for it. 

I do not recommend this place as there are better ramen places in San Francisco that you should check out, despite the wait time. Unfortunately, this has to be one of the worst Japanese restaurants that I've had the worst experiences with, that I have visited here in the city.
author: Risako S.

description:
2.5 stars for the Yamada-Ya Ramen. The broth was just okay--did not taste the expected richness from the 20-hour cooking process touted by the big poster as you walk up the stairs.

The soft egg was a bit overcooked. The ramen was on the thinner side. Interestingly the texture was closer to hard & crunchy than the expected chewiness of ramen. It did come with a generous portion of meat. The pork belly was soft. But the chasu was dry. As for the sea salt, I really could not tell.

The low-light was the Salmon & Ikura Donburi. The Ikura was sitting in a pool of some sort of soy sauce marinade. It was so salty it was barely edible.

The menu was different from what's posted on their website. And as expected, prices were couple bucks higher.

Overall, the staff was friendly. The decor was nice. But the food was underwhelming.
author: David W.

description: The ramen is good. The environment is OK. He restroom cleanness needs to be improved.
author: Xiaoshi Y.

description: This is a chain ramen place and I first had it at their Costs Mesa location in S Cal. The SF location is a bit more expensive due to rent/cost of doing business but the quality is consistent. Their soup broth rocks and if you order a spicy ramen, it is definitely spicy. This place has a short wait and compared to Ramen Marufuku inside Japantown mall across the street (2-3 hrs of wait), this place definitely does not disappoint!!
author: Sharon H.

description: Good ramen.  Good tasty broth. Overall good menu and selections. Service is good. Karage is delicious. Remember to check in on the iPad when checking in for a seat.. overall good ramen.
author: Andrew M.

description:
Why Ramen Yamadaya is a Hard Pass:

1) When you sign up on the sheet, no one comes by or acknowledges you despite all the open tables. (Beuller? Beuller?)

2) The Unfriendliest Server with Permanent RBF.

3) The Gyoza that was ordered but never showed.

4) Meh eats. The Spicy Tuna Bowl was overpowered by the salt of all the roe. The Chicken Katsu Curry was fine but on the bland side.
author: Amy C.

description:
The Ramen here is amazing! The broth is very RICH, the noodles are very well done (in my opinion).

I really love their Spicy Miso and Spicy Yamada-Ramen Level 2! I really recommend those if you want some kick into your Ramen! 

Their Tako Yaki and Chicken Karaage is ALSO amazing! 

This place gets pretty packed (due to it possibly being a tourist attraction), but I am sure on Sundays it is a little easy.
author: Erito S.

description:
Katana-ya Ramen.
Spicy level 3.
+ Thick Noodle.
+ Garlic
+ Side of Kakuni Pork Belly
+ Chicken Kara-age

I noticed that this place is usually better when there is a crowd, which there is during hours leading to the peak lunch and dinner rush (11:30-1PM and 6:30-8PM).
Maybe something about the rush makes everything hotter and tastier.

After auditing a client for a couple of months, in the Japan Town area, I tried a good amount of places within the area.
I feel like this is probably one of the best, at least for my palate, places to get ramen.

For some reason, the men's bathroom is always destroyed whenever I have visited the place.
But overall, I really like this place. 
This is my go-to ramen place whenever I have a craving that needs to get fulfilled.
author: Kevin W.

description:
Solid 3 star ramen place in the city. I really wanted to try the other new ramen place next door, but wasn't about to wait another 30 minutes in the car until they opened. I wish I did now.

So we opted for Ramen Yamadaya. 

I got their Kakuni - Kotteri Ramen and was joyfully full with the portion-size. The broth was a smacking blend of delicious garlic and pork broth - super thick and fatty. It was piping hot too and the noodles definitely had the right consistency for their specific ramen noodle style. Mhm! However, the flavor was a tad bit bland for my liking and the garlic did feel a bit overpowering. My party agreed.

Unfortunately, the pork belly was bland as heck. Isn't it supposed to be marinated or something? My party didn't like their orders either. To make things a tad bit more disappointing, the chicken karage was very fatty, plain and just meh. We didn't even finish it all and left the restaurant with 3-4 pieces uneaten.

Overall, I'm glad I got to try a different ramen restaurant that is famed in SF Japantown. However, I'm not a fan and don't understand why people would wait an hour plus for this place. For our party of 3, we left with a bill of about $75 with tip and tax. I had to flag down the waiter multiple times just to take our orders and refill our waters - and guess what - it wasn't even that busy! Customer service definitely needs work too.
author: Chinsin S.

description: Came by looking for quick lunch. After short wait, seated at communal table. Small place. About a dozen tables and one long table in middle. Not planning to come back. Food is mediocre. Takoyaki balls just fried balls of mashed potatoes with tiny bits octopus. Must use dipping sauce and Bonito flakes to have any flavor. Broth is bland. No pork flavor. I ordered Yamada Ya which uses sea salt so tasted like salted water. Sis got Kakuni which uses soy sauce so her broth tasted like that. If they used pork bone either seriously diluted broth or bones from really small pigs. Food not served hot either. Broth lukewarm. Really skinny ramen but warm. All toppings cold. Egg was refrigerator cold. Chasiu cold and old tasting. Pork belly tasty but again cold. Bamboo shoots, wood ear all cold. Why give two stars? Pork belly at least tender and tasted good. Oh, and I was half way through mine when we finally asked where my sister's food was. They forgot. So I sat here and wrote this while I waited for her to finish.
author: Carrie W.

description: So the menu has changed in a bad way. It looks very underwhelming. The old one was so much better! I ordered the spicy ramen - medium spicy and it was so lackluster. It really was not that good. The noodles were SO thin and there really wasn't that many noodles in there. There aren't many ingredients in the bowls - just the pork belly and a few bamboo shoots and some seaweed. It's not as good as I remember and I'm disappointed I spent so much on it - I won't be back.
author: Emily H.

description:
This used to be our favorite ramen restaurant, but clearly they have changed ownership. If I could give it no stars I would. Imagine our surprise when we found that there was no line. We thought it was our lucky night, but now we know why there was no line. We are NEVER going back here. A bit sad as we used to go here a lot. My kids left and both said how sad and disappointing it was. 
The ramen broth was flavorless and lukewarm. It used to be extremely flavorful, but not anymore. My son's miso soup was so salty that it seemed like they gave us concentrate that they forgot to dilute. We had to pour more water than the original soup to even make it close to drinkable.  The staff just looked at us pouring water into the soup and never inquired why would be doing that. 
If the bad food wasn't enough, the service was horrible. They took our order and disappeared. When they served the food, they just dumped it randomly on the tables and sprinted off. The only way that we got enough glasses and plates was to take them off of other tables as we couldn't get the staff's attention. When we were leaving I noticed parking of the problem, one of the waiters was busy FaceTiming with one of his friends.  Definitely didn't want to let his work get in the way of the conversation. 
Anyway, don't waste your money. Go somewhere else to eat. As we were leaving, I really wanted to turn around other customers walking up the stairs. The overall experience was really just that bad. 
Disappointing and sad!
author: Andy N.

description:
After a rave review from my friend, featuring an in-depth explanation of the different peppers used in the spicy broths, curiosity got the best of me and my roomie/food bro. So we breezed past the (nonexistent) Yelp Res line and took a seat. We were served almost immediately, and the food came out in about five minutes, a quick turnaround!

But what came out was underwhelming, if I'm honest. The noodles were pretty good, they're thinner if that's your kind of thing (I know it's mine). I like that there were multiple kinds of meat in the bowl, but I didn't really like any of them. They were there, and cooked well, but they didn't have much flavor and consequently just served as a distraction from the noodles. The spicy tonkotsu broth sort of just tasted like the peppers I ordered in it (Hot, because I didn't want to jump straight into Fire, Hell, or Death without at least a little confidence in their idea of what "hot" meant). It didn't have much of a taste of its own, sort of like a blank canvas, but the picture the peppers painted was uninteresting, sort of like the finger painting of your neighbor's preschool kid. The "Hot" also wasn't terribly spicy IMO, definitely less so than Mensho's spicy bowls. And at $14/bowl, it wasn't "cheap and cheerful" ramen either.

Also it didn't sit well with either of us, and we don't have particularly weak stomachs either, so take that as you will. For that reason alone we won't be back, but I don't think we'll be missing out on much.
author: Shawn W.

description: We had to wait for quite a while, I think about half an hour, but it was definitely worth it once we finally got to order and eat. I had ordered the Death ramen and honestly, I wish I had asked for the spiciest level from the start. But that's my own spice tolerance. I definitely need to go back. But the taste and spice was well balanced
author: Jenny Y.

description: Yamadaya Ramen is really delicious here, they use a very good ramen. There is a wait but its worth it! Love this place!
author: Madel G.

description: I had their vegan ramen and it tasted pretty good without any meat. However, it was price $17 tab for just a few veggies on top of a bit of noodles in a clear broth. Wish it was a bit more substantial to satisfy my hunger.
author: Zee B.

description:
I was in the area and craving ramen for lunch. I ordered the Yamadaya Kotteri with black garlic oil. Bowl is quite big and high on the sides. Most importantly, the temperature of the soup was hot.

The noodles were thin and had chewy texture. Tonkotsu broth was flavorful but I was hoping the pork slices would have had a bit more meat.
author: Nette T.

description:
I ordered the Kakuni Shio Ramen and got generous chunks of pork belly (mostly fat). The broth was rich and filling; I almost licked the bowl dry.  We also ordered a taiyaki on the side which was a great desert and really warm. 

Some tips: Don't take your ramen to go! Your noodles will get soggy by the time you get home. They also have GF noodles, so be sure to bring your GF friends! 

The second bowl I posted below was the the Spicy Miso Ramen that my friend ordered. He got medium spicy and was tearing up a couple of times, but it was tears of fulfillment. 

We waited in line for 30ish minutes and I thought that was pretty short for a Friday night at 7:30PM. It was really confusing because people were waiting in line but there was a sign up sheet up front that they probably were not aware of. Also, the host would call out names from 2 separate sign up sheets for some strange reason. I think they were ignoring the 2nd sheet so my friends and I got in pretty quick while the people in front of us were complaining. I did enjoy reading their set of rules while waiting in line; it got me pumped! 

I liked the interior design of the shop. They had a open space table in the middle in the room so multiple parties can sit and eat. They had about 6-7 lamps hanging above them (perfect lighting for those instagram photos). The bathrooms were kind of a hot mess tho 

Overall, I definitely come back again!
author: Searit H.

description: The spicy ramen here is delicious. This is one of the OG places in the city. Now that all these new spots have opened up, this place doesn't get that much attention but I'm still a huge fan. If you like pork broth, this spot will do it. You can order it quite spicy as well.
author: Vinayak P.

description:
Warning: They calculate tip after tax....

Note: Make sure to use yelp to waitlist because they use the yelp app for waitlists. Doesn't require you have the app but it's helpful because you can get live updates as you go around Japan Town. 

Had the Spicy Miso at HOT, wasn't that spicy compared to most restaurants when I order medium. Foods not bad, but I wasn't wowed by the food. My spicy miso included a bunch of toppings like corn and bamboo!

Service was nice though, the employee asked about us while he was setting us up and Then moves moved to a seat by the window when it cleared up a bit early.
author: Frank C.

description: I thought Yamadaya was pretty solid - I ordered the hell ramen and if I had mixed in all of the chili sauce I probably would have had to chop my tongue off because it was pretty spicy as it was. The texture of the ramen was nice and thin, but if you prefer thicker ones you can request them. Nothing too special about this place; the prices are a bit high for decency but it's SF and everyone's got to pay rent.
author: David Y.

description:
The host was very friendly, but that's where the friendliness ended. The waitress was very rude, condescending,
and unresponsive. We asked if we could have another minute to look over the menu and she rolled eyes. After she rolled away, she didn't come back to bring us our drinks. We asked the bus boy for our drinks. She only came back to take our order because she was directed by the host. She kept walking by our table and pretended not to see our attempts to get her attention. I would not recommend coming here. You might not get your food or drinks and if you do be prepared for some condescending eye rolls!! Her name is Alexander, so if you don't want bad service suggest another waitress/waiter. The food is good, but one bad apple ruined it for us,
author: Jae T.

description:
It is one of the best ramen places you can find.
Prices are still considered fair, the taste is superb.
The soup base has great flavor, the portion is generous.
The line outside the door start forming about 45 mintues before it opens, (I was there for lunch on a Friday) So, go early if you don't want to wait. I notice the amount of people in the line exceeds the seating availability for the first round, so that means if you're in line but outside of the first round of seating, then you'll have to wait till the first round customers to finish their meal to turnover the table for you.
But the serving speed is very fast, as soon as you order, the food gets to you in a very short time.
author: Felix L.

description:
Update

So I come here and there's no one in the waiting area so I walk in. Not very busy either, empty tables. Yet two waitresses throw me serious attitudes and mini fits because I didn't use the yelp ipad in the lobby to check in. Okay. I walk out and check in and instantly get a text message that my table is ready and I have only one minute to claim it. Uh, fun. 

.........


I like this ramen a lot. I prefer hearty tonkotsu style and this is about as rich as it gets! The yuzu-kosho seasoning choice is an awesome mix of avid and spice, though I always get a small side of vinegar with my ramen anyway. 

The one quirk is that you must order extra noodles ahead--even though they come on a second plate (and are pretty much cold and dried out by the time you'll add them to your remaining soup
author: Anthony B.

description:
Location: 2nd floor inside the Tokyo town, where there are a bunch of other restaurants and dessert shops.

Parking: was a b!@#. Circled a few times around the block and decided to park at a nearby structure to save my sanity.
 
Food: The broth has a lot of flavors to it, slightly thick and fatty. 

The Wait: line was very long. Try Yelp! "Add to Wait List" on the way the restaurant to avoid the long line down the stairs.
author: Dee P.

description: i don't know about you, but when I go out for ramen I go for that beautifully marinated soft boiled egg that once bitten into oozes a rich, golden yolk. Here? NAH. I bite into my soft boiled eggs only for my mouth to meet a dry, crumbly hard yolk. Server says it's because it sat in the hot broth for too long, which would inevitably cook the egg to "hard-boiled." To which I say, "yeah right! i ate the egg right away which left no more cooking time." After utter disappointment, I persevere through the rest of my ramen... only to discover the missing TOFU which was promised via menu (vegan ramen). Server says they ran out. Two minutes later my TOFU yamadaya bun arrives. Hmmmm. Interesting. The only redeeming aspect of the meal however was said tofu yamadaya bun. Overall, sad, disappointed and wishing I had gone to the ramen place across the street (been there before, great). Don't remember the name, look it up. Save your money, don't go here.
author: Madi M.

description: Quick service, good ramen and delicious karaage. I was a little disappointed at the spice level of the ramen I ordered. I asked for very spicy, the waiter asked, "Are you sure?". It made me think so I ordered a level 5 of 6 on spiciness. It wasn't spicy... So for you hot heads, get the 6, but it still may not be that spicy. Broth was a bit greasy for my taste, but still good. Anyhow, the restaurant is good, go check it out!
author: Will C.

description: We went here on a Sunday afternoon. The wait was not very long. I was really looking forward to having Ramen. I ordered the chicken with soy broth, I asked for double the noodles, an extra egg and corn. I couldn't wait. We asked for extra cups for the water. One of the cups was dirty. It looked like it had sent to us without being washed. We asked for a new one. The rest appeared clean. We wiped them so they were dry and clean. We poured 6 waters and one of them had a hair. The hair came from the bottle, we just wiped all of our cups clean. The soup took a bit longer than expected. When the soup came it looked delicious. I went to move the egg to the side and the soup and egg had a hair on it too. We brought it to the attention to the waitress she said she would bring another. About 1 min. later they brought a "new one." The "new" soup was the same soup with a new egg. We returned it and ordered something else. No, apologies given by the staff. I ended up have the Katsu. It was alright. When it was time to pay, they took off the hairy soup and charged us for an extra drink. We will NOT be returning.
author: Mellissa V.

description:
My niece and I got the tonkatsu ramen, which was absolutely delicious. The only thing I didn't like were the bamboo shoots, which had an odd flavor. But the noodles were perfectly cooked, the broth rich and delicious, and the meat very nice. (I did pull a few pieces out of the bowl to strip the fat off, because I'm not too fond of eating fat pieces.) The egg was cooked perfectly and peeled somehow (I think it's magic).

We also got a pot of tea and were cracking up over the shot-glass water glasses and thimble-sized tea cups. We thought about pouring the tea into the water glasses but were worried we'd get in trouble!

We were there about 2 and got our ramen in just minutes. A lovely visit.
author: J V.

description:
I got the Yamadaya spicy and was really happy with it! At $14, you can choose your spice levels. I went with the lowest spice level because I didn't want the spice to overpower the flavor of the broth. It was definitely a good choice. 

Why the ramen was good:
-thin noodles
-broth wasn't too fatty nor too salty
-5 huge pieces of pork belly! It was A LOT I couldn't even finish. Though they were pretty fatty, I still can't complain
-egg was on point

Bathrooms here could use some improvement though........ 

Definitely come here!!
author: Sally L.

description: I ordered the spicy with death. I was able to finish everything, but it was a killer. They give you a lot of the sauce to add. But when I first tried it i was thinking that is crazy how the hell can anyone eat all this ghost pepper paste!, but after 3 pinch size full you get a good kick. They do charge $2.00 for  and . The Goyza wasn't fried to my liking but still good. Will definately come back to try a rice plate.
author: Bonnie C.

description: This place has gone downhill a bit. Quality just wasn't as good last time, but I can't exactly pinpoint what the issue was. The noodles felt a little overcooked, and the tsukemen broth just wasn't "right". A little heavier than before on the fish, the oils, etc... the whole thing felt excessively heavy. Perhaps the ramen game has leveled up so much in SF that it just can't compare to some of the other places that have opened up recently.
author: Kazu O.

description:
Sub par ramen broth, which was incredibly greasy, thick, and musky-tasting. For a starting price of $13 a bowl, the ramen was incredibly disappointing and served in small portions. 

White meat chicken char sui was alright, but outside of that, the karaage and katsu are mostly fat with very little meat. Food comes out at different times so someone in your party may end up finishing half their meal before others begin to get their food. 

Hot tea, which is usually complimentary, is $2 a cup. 

Inside is not climate controlled so be prepared to freeze in the winter months. 

With all the competition around like Ramen Underground, Ajisen, and others in close proximity, save your dollars and head elsewhere.
author: Alison A.

description: Best Ramen ever!  Of course, I've only ever had that instant stuff in a cup, but still... I loved it.  I got the spicy ramen and asked for hot.  It wasn't all that spicy for me, but I usually put a tablespoon of red pepper on my pizza, but that's just me.
author: Jennifer P.

description:
Came to Japantown looking for a ramen place to eat at and ended up at Ramen Yamadaya because of the 30min+ wait at all the other places. Even though there was a line here too, it went by pretty fast. I ordered the yamada-ya ramen, which wasn't the best ramen I've ever had but definitely a good bowl of ramen! Their ramen broth is too oily for my taste, but other than that it's very flavorful and has that rich pork taste. I like that you can choose thick or thin noodles based on your preference! The yamada-ya ramen comes with both chashu and pork belly so you get a generous portion of meat. I didn't care for their bamboo; I'm usually okay with it in my ramen but it didn't taste fresh. The portion size is great and one bowl is very filling. 

Overall, not the best ramen I've had, but still a pretty decent ramen place.
author: Sara C.

description: I ordered the vegan gluten free noodles. I got vegan because sometimes the broth tastes fishy to me. This one tasted like miso, and had bamboo and braised tofu (my favorite). I did add soy sauce because I like the taste. The noodles were really good for being gluten free. My vegetarian friend said that it was the best gluten free vegan noodles she had ever had.
author: Emma C.

description: There's usually a 10-15min wait but I think it worth it. Very generous portions of pork, which I rare as I typically need to order extra at other ramen places.
author: Josh M.

description: Ordered the spicy ramen (fire). I'm someone who loves spicy food and can eat Thai chilies by themselves. I was not expecting to get a whole tablespoon of the fire bomb on top of the spicy broth. It is spicy! I mixed a little into the broth and put the rest to the side. I'm curious what the hell and death taste like  Must be pure spice or a different type of pepper. Anyways, the ramen was very yummy and I enjoyed the thick broth taste. Would come again.
author: Elizabeth B.

description:
3.5 stars
I have had something better but this place is not that bad either. I came during the Festival. After signing up on the wait list, we decided to walk around for some goodies. It's actually really cool that you can track the process online (yelp app required), or they will send you a text to let you know. 
I had the Pork Katsu curry. Big portion comes with seaweed soup and potatoes salad on the side. Soup was a bit salty but I love the potatoes salad, the dressing really does something to it. I feel like it's hard to fail Katsu dishes, I should have ordered their ramen but my stomach wanted rice so haha! 
Service was quick and I literally have no comment about since it was so busy. Place is located in the middle of Japan town, grab a table by the window for view. 
My gut does not urge me to go back to this place anytime soon, but if I'm around the area again hmmm why not. I meant there are much more restaurants around the mall right? I let you make the judgment.
author: Krystal G.

description:
UPDATE: I've been coming here semi-regularly for a couple of years, and the ramen today had significantly less meat after the most recent menu change.


PREVIOUS REVIEW:

Best Ramen ever!

Staff is friendly; we were late to our online check-in time but they sat us down anyway.
author: Andrei C.

description: Food is ok. But the service is horrible and the waitlist makes no sense! Yelp has informed me that it's my turn, but the restaurant told me that they are not ready and I need to wait for their call. But the truth is that there are a lot empty tables inside. I ended up wait for additional 10-15 min, and the explanation was that they don't have enough people, wait outside is the same as wait inside
author: Fei R.

description:
Good: 
- ramen was tasty
- lunch special was a good deal
- no wait

Bad:
- lots of flies/bugs flying around inside
- no refills on lunch special fountain drinks 

There are several other places to get ramen nearby... would check those out first :)
author: Nate L.

description: Food takes too long and server was looking at me when I had to put amount of tip. He was giving me pressure. I felt so uncomfortable. Don't wanna go there again
author: S L.

description:
It was a pretty cool environment and nice location in Japantown. 
The waiters were very kind and enthusiastic which gave a nice vibe. They work hard and you can see they care about the customers. 
The Ramen was tasty and so was the broth, but broth was too 'thick'. It was lightweight chunky if you let it sit a little and I can tell that's m from adding too much flavoring/oil. That was a thumbs down forsure. 
I don't know if I'd pay the price again. I could've came at a bad time but I can say the most I can say was the flavors were definitely there.
author: Ivan P.

description:
TL,DR: Under New Management, Quality Has Suffered

I used to advocate for Ramen Yamadaya as the best ramen in the city and would go almost every weekend. The new management ruined it. The menu is completely different (more expensive, no more 'Basic Ramen'), the meat is rubbery, chopsticks are all disposable, and the food quality is not what it used to be. Everything we ate tasted like it was covered in vegetable oil. Very disappointing, will not be back.
author: Sarah U.

description: I've been reading the reviews on this place for nearly 30 minutes... I disagree with the negative reviews! We came on a Tuesday night, so it wasn't over-crowded. We were seated promptly, and our order was taken quickly. The server was very friendly and was helpful with answering questions about the menu. The ramen was nice and hot, absolutely delicious, and the Gyoza tasted fresh! I was told that there is no added MSG in their food, which is actually rare for a lot of ramen restaurants. I was even able to speak to the GM, Abraham and he walked me through with how they made their ramen. He is very passionate about maintaining a good quality. I even got to take a quick look in the back to see all the giant stock pots on a high boil making that wonderful broth! A lot of reviews have complained about the ramen being too fatty or rich, but clearly they have no idea with what ramen is supposed to be! Overall, a very good experience and a hearty, fatty and satisfying meal! I hope I get to visit San Fran again to enjoy it again.
author: Luke M.

description:
I am very happy to have a vegan option to eat ^^ Ramen bowl was insanely huge, sooo sleepy now after the dish. 

Vegan ramen is not bad, except for noodles being too soft and the br quite flavorless, but at least not too salty.  Anyway ramen was not created to be vegan :) Not sure if I will come back for vegan ramen, but will accompany my husband next time, as he likes his spice ramen and dumplings. 

Service is nice, friendly and fast. Place is packed and we got our dishes only after 10 min waiting.
author: Liza B.

description:
I have worked in the service industry for 2 years so I can understand how a busy night makes a cranky server, but we were one of the first tables sat and the server was hasty, rude, and didn't have the knowledge to answer any of our questions. When we had questions, he was very noticeably annoyed and was demeaning when answering. We were also brought the wrong food for a different table and our green tea was forgotten about. 

I'm very tolerant about slow service and mistakes, but the rude and dismissive attitude kills a place for me. 

However, the sishito peppers were very good and the ramen was well cooked. The pork in the ramen was soft and delicious. I only wish we were treated better!
author: Marily-Rose R.

description:
Terrible service. Our host, Filipino older gentleman, I would know, I'm filipina, was incredibly rude. I have several family and friends in the hospitality and service industries and we all know they follow a policy. Fair, but if the house is empty near close with no parties of 3 or more, you can seat us away from the by-the-door cold drafted door, and in a booth.....

I get the job is stressful and there are other parties being served with you fairness policy, but this is 20 mins to close and now two booths available...I simply asked a question, he put his hand in my face and told me the policy and fled away...ok?

Sucks because it's my home girl's bday too and Now, I'm in a mood lol. I'm hopeful the food won't disappoint like this service has. 
*********************************************

The cute server saved the day! Very sweet and surprised my lovely friend with a red bean cake 

Was very understanding and kind. Also the Yamada-ya ramen  was bomb! I was told they prepare the broth for 120 hrs on boil with the pork bones!
author: Nerrissa M.

description:
This ramen place is quite average. I would say you can expect a typical fast food ramen experience such that after you finish, you won't be thinking to come back here again anytime soon unless you have no other food choices nearby or about to die of starvation. 

To be fair there wasn't anything bad about the bowl of ramen I ordered (spicy miso), but at the same time there wasn't anything spectacular about it neither. 

Mediocre is what I would put it. 3 stars.
author: William Qi D.

description:
After a disappointing lunch and walking around Japantown, my girlfriend and I were in desperate need of satisfying sustenance. She suggested, knowing I appreciate Ramen, suggested walking across the street to here. 

It was a group seating type environment, yet the acoustics allowed everyone to their own privacy. Drinks were refilled, and food served in a reasonable timely manner. 

The ramen was standard, but in the best way possible. The broth was delicious, and the pork had fat on it....but for the first time in a while, the fat was so good it was great to eat as part of the whole. The best part...the egg. YES!!!! It was cooked perfectly....no seriously, perfectly. 

I rarely give 5 stars, but on their house ramen, a strong "4.5" rating
author: Dan W.

description: We hvnt been back for awhile. They have changed their menu and have better service. Price went up but is ok as you know min. wage and rent are expensive in SF. I like their dipping noodle as they serve with thick noodle. Spicy ramen (extra spicy) also delicious good. You will keep on slurping the spicy soup. Big portion, good service, is just loooooooong wait time. Make sure you check in with their Yelp page to get a free soda!
author: Katie M.

description: I was really disappointed with the ramen here. I expected more from the city's Japantown. The broth lacked flavor and was very oily. The meat was also fatty. The service was okay and the free soda was a nice perk, but sadly, the overall food experience failed to meet my expectations.
author: Hannah G.

description: disgusting. do not eat here. their eggs are hard boiled and the ramen is not even mediocre. go to the place across the street. it's better i promise you. don't waste your money and put yourself in a bad mood for something that wasnt even close to worth it. trust eat somewhere else , even if u really want ramen.
author: Ryan R.

description: Food was super good and the meat (pork) was super tender and juicy and I love pork.  I added corn to it and the egg was PERFECT. I got the spicy broth, fire level, the heat crept up on me for sure cut it was still totally doable and delicious. Service was decent but the bathroom was pretty gross.
author: Sarelle H.

description:
Ramen anyone?

I cannot forgive my-self for not coming to this place way before, living so close by! God the Yamadaya Spicy (level 1 ) Ramen with corn was absolutely yummylicious. To be honest, my sister and I were hopping to dine at Marufuku Ramen, but we didn't get a chance because they were sold out of reservations for the day, and we decided to try Ramen Yamadaya. When we got there there were like 7 parties ahead of us, and we were not sure about the wait. Fortunately some people left and we waited only 10-15 mins to get a table, and food was served within 5-10 mins. You can order drinks while you wait. You might be seated with other folks depending on availability.

Great customer service! We'll be back soon for sure!!
author: Maria A.

description: It's worth the wait! Full of flavor, the broth is creamy and the pork belly so tender
author: Tiffany R.

description: The worst experience ever. Ordered take out - it should've been ready in 30 minutes. When I show up at pick up time I was told it'd be another hour. Stay away. Stay away at all costs.
author: Al D.

description: This is our favorite ramen place in San Francisco. We come here average of 2-3 a month. Their ramen has a rich variety of broth, spice level, and add ons. I Even though they are a ramen place the other items on their menu are delicious as well. I love their chicken katshu curry and chicken karaage bun! Highly recommend this place if you are visiting Japan Town and are looking for an authentic Japanese food!
author: Neda P.

description: Great ramen, great sake, good cold beer, need I say more? No I think not. Avoid the place across the street if you look for quality and flavorful ramen with amazing broth, noodles, and toppings.
author: Brendan M.

description:
DO NOT COME HERE!! I literally just made a yelp account to write this review. 

The first time I came, everything was fine. 
I went again today, and got food poisoning.
My stomache is still aching as I type this. As a matter of fact, I feel like vomiting right now. The food feels indigestible. 
The ramen looked good, the taste was excellent, but ten minutes after consuming the ramen, I had a terrible stomache ache. I didn't think much of it at first, until I read similar reviews here. 
EAT AT YOUR OWN RISK!!!!
author: Emiliea C.

description:
Tried both spicy ramen and yamadu ramen, both really good, filling, generous with the meat. 
Service was good but the place was full so a little slow. 
Its a clean place nice ambiance but noiselevel very high, and music a little too loud.

Will come back for sure!!
author: Jo L.

description:
I stopped in here with my woof fiancée after a nice visit to Japantown that left us feeling a big hungry. Ramen sounds good yeah? 

We had high expectations as we knew that Ramen Yamadaya often has a pretty long line of people waiting to be seated, so when we noticed the line not too long, we were quite excited! 

Menu here was simple and we ordered the shio ramen as it seemed others near us were getting the same. We were quite happy that it came out quickly and soon we were digging into our meal like wild animals ( which we are I suppose! ) 

The broth in my ramen was wonderful but the noodles were a bit hard. Not too much an issue but worth noting. 

Service here was really slow. It took a while for us to get anyone's attention when seated, and getting our check was a nightmarishly long wait, and even when we did things got complicated and it took forever to get our credit card back. 

4 stars for food, 2 stars for service, puts this place at a 3 for me.
author: Jei C.

description:
I might be missing something here, but i don't get the hype. This place is located outside of the main Japantown center.  It is across from the peace plaze and you need to walk up the stairs to get here.  Getting a table here can be hard because this place gets back so fast, especially on a weekend.  They have great lunch menu where you can get a bowl of ramen with a side or two.  The few times I've been here, i've always ordered the Yamadaya Tonkotsu Kotteri Ramen.  The Yamadaya Tonkatsu kotteri had a soft boiled egg, chashu, pork belly, mushrooms, scallions, bamboo shoots, black garlic oil, fried garlic.  Yes, I'll admit this soup had a lot of flavor and the eggs where cooked perfect. The noodles didn't seem to do it for me.   The noodle seem too thick for me.   

If you want side dishes to share, I suggest you take advantage of their combination menu.  For 4 or 5 dollars more you can get gyozas or  chicken Karaage  with a small salad.  Be warn, their salad is not small, it's actually kinda big.
author: Belinda C.

description:
Came here for dinner on a Monday night because my coworkers very highly recommended this place to me, but I left kind of disappointed.

We came here pretty late at night, around 9 pm, and the restaurant was only half full. I'm not sure if there is a wait normally.

I ordered the tonkotsu kotteri ramen, which is what my coworker recommended. I had pretty high expectations since I trust my coworkers who suggested this place to me, but I didn't think the ramen was all that great. My favorite part was probably the broth, which was indeed rich and creamy as advertised. The noodles were a little bit thinner that what I like, but they were still okay. 

My main problem with the ramen was with the pork. There were two types of pork in my ramen, a fattier kind which I assumed was kakuni (braised pork belly) and two less fatty slices (which were chashu I think?). Both tasted dry and I had a hard time eating them, especially the chashu. For me, the pork that comes with ramen should be soft and melt-in-your-mouth tender, but the meat here was the opposite.

I don't know if I would recommend this ramen spot to anyone. My favorite in the city is still Mensho, which is a bit pricier, but they do a great job with the broth and making sure their meat is tender.

Paid around $15 for this meal.
author: Dianna H.

description:
Went in the early afternoon and had a short wait for a table. It was nearly full, but not as packed as I've seen. Service was good and everything else about the experience was good. Except...the wait for ramen. They were slow as molasses getting orders out. Ridiculously slow.
In the end, the ramen was awesome so that made up for some of the wait.
author: Bob B.

description:
The ramen here was good, but not the best bowl I've had. 

The wait for a table was out the door. BE WARNED: you must be within earshot when it's your turn or they might skip your spot on line. 

The spicy tonkatsu miso ramen was very smooth, but not as rich as other broths I've had. I got level one (mild spicy), and it was not spicy at all. The soup was not very greasy, so that was definitely a plus. Ramen comes with chashu, kakuni (braised pork belly), menma, cloud ear mushroom, and a whole egg. The chashu was tender and juicy, and the kakuni was a little lacking. 

But altogether: fast service, many additions available, with specials and combos on the menu. Worth a try for a filling lunch, but probably not worth a long wait.
author: Linda C.

description:
Amazing ramen broth!!! I ordered their shio ramen and I'm so glad I gave this place a try. The ramen noodle is very thin and the texture is great since the noodles were soaked with the broth. The pork (cha siu) is cooked just right and meaty. I also ordered a couple of their sides: shiitake bun, chicken karage, and gyoza. The shiitake bun was a mistake because the veggie inside the bun was super sour and ruined my taste with the ramen bowl. The chicken karage and the gyoza was usual and was ok. 

The only thing special about this place would be their ramen broth because it is very rich in favor!!! However, towards the end of my dinning.... they forced us to pay by giving us the check and cleaning our table before we are even finished. I know they're packed outside but they do have to think about their customers right........
author: Sammi L.

description: Came here on a Saturday night after visiting the Golden Gate Bridge. The ramen is upstairs from the hot pot/Shabu restaurant downstairs. When my cousin and i arrived, there was a waiting list outside the door. We were seated quickly as the names in front of ours were absent. We were seated quickly and given a good amount of time to look over the menu. I ordered the ramen with shoyu and it was very salty in my opinion. The ramen was a lot for one bowl but i was able to finish it because a bowl was $14 before tax. Although it did come with huge pieces of pork belly, i thought it was okay. Next time, i will go with their classic ramen base soups.
author: Margaret D.

description:
When I stepped into this restaurant, I got really excited. My friends and I were craving ramen, and after waiting for about fifteen minutes (Saturday brunch time - not bad at all), we were seated right next to the window. The inside of the restaurant is nice, with a large communal table in the middle decorated with succulents, and booth tables all around this middle table. 

I ordered the ramen yamaday spicy, and it was just... okay. Don't get me wrong, I love fatty ramen, but my friends and I all agreed that the broth was a little TOO fatty. Plus, I thought the "spicy" wasn't spicy at all, so if you're a big spice lover like me I would recommend bumping the spiciness level to "fire" which is a dollar more. I enjoyed the thinner noodles and the other toppings as well. Side note: my friend found a hair in her ramen, so the waiter quickly brought out another one. 

Overall, this place was just okay. Definitely did not live up to my expectations, and probably won't be coming back :(
author: Salley P.

description:
This place used to be my favorite place to get Ramen! There are 3 parts to every ramen bowl: the soup base, the noodles, and the toppings. As a first timer, the atmosphere and rich soup base makes a lasting impact. Coupled with the best noodle texture I've experience in Japantown along with the fatty pork belly this ramen place is bold! However like bold experiences, I would recommend coming here too often as the richness can seem overpowering if you had such a rich ramen recently. 

Spicy Ramen: 
You could even try the 3 - 6 levels of Spicy ramen, but I would start out with the less spicy levels as they just add more chili. Be careful, I don't think I would recommend higher than level 2 if you don't enjoy challenging your spice tolerance on a normal basis. At level 6 (Death), you could be practically scoping a chopsticks chuck full of chili each bite and still not finish the chili...you really don't need that much chili and it's an understatement to say how spicy it is. They do charge more for levels 4 - 6 now (or maybe all levels) so you don't need to get the max level just to prove yourself.
author: Dion L.

description:
This place serves some of the best ramen in the city! They have a few different broth bases and a nice variety of toppings, as well as a few specials. There is also the option for a combo with a rice dish, although I've never tried this. Everything that I have tried is delicious!

The place has always been busy when I've visited, so be prepared for a bit of a wait. BE WARNED: if you are not within earshot of the sign up list, your name will be scratched off and they will move on to the next name. This practice can sometimes make the list seem longer than it really is... there were at least 5 "no-shows" called before me last time I was there. 

If you are in a small group (1-4) there's a chance you will be seated at the center bar/table where you will side by side with other parties. This usually works out fine and actually adds to the experience in my opinion.

They have delicious cucumber/orange water while you wait for your seat!
author: Joe P.

description: My food came really quickly and I didn't have to wait a lot to sit (even though it was a Sunday night). Ramen was very good (I had the Spicy Miso, medium spice) and at the perfect temperature (unlike it happened to some reviewers here). Overall great experience!
author: Juliana C.

description:
I came here off the recommendation of a friend. (By recommendation, I mean that I read her Yelp review and trusted her standards.)

First off, this ramen joint is actually in Japantown which I think helps set the mood. Further setting the mood is the awesome interior. While I didn't get to sit at the middle table which had plants growing out of the middle of it, I got to admire from afar.

...but that's not why you're reading this review. You want to know about the ramen and whether or not this place can compete with the many other popular ramen shops in town. My answer is yes.

If you ask, they'll give you a garlic press so that you can have fresh peeled garlic in your ramen. Who doesn't love extra garlic? +1 for that

As for the rest of the ramen (I ordered the Yamadaya Tonkotsu Shio Ramen), everything else was pretty top-notch as well. They use the thin noodles here which I like. The soft-boiled egg was great. The broth itself was flavorful (though maybe a little too heavy?). The meat was kind of also just OK, but surprisingly I didn't mind since everything else was so good.

Would I come back? Yep, but it might have to be right when they open since it's a pretty busy place. :/
author: Charles L.

description:
8/5/16:  Ramen Yamadaya was my all-time favorite ramen joint EVER.  Or at least, the one particular location hidden behind cheap glass and draperies, camouflaged within the small strip-mall, reminiscent of a what you'd imagine to be a ghost town at the urban edge of Los Angeles:

https://www.yelp.com/biz/ramen-yamadaya-torrance

Alas, this place is absolutely nothing like the Torrance location, nor any of its outgrowths in the OC.  Sure, it has that Japanese ramen house look and feel, complete with servers outfitted in typical garb, though lacking those who shout Japanese greetings as you walk in... sure, it has all that, but so do many other places.

But the food..... WTF.  Again, WTF.  Now, perhaps I made the mistake of thinking that "Ramen Yamadaya" is a particular brand, and this place is associated with the those SoCal locations.  Is it not?--if you know, please message me.  But as it stands, the ramen might as well have been cooked on two different sides of the earth...

1. Yamadaya Kotteri $12.95 "rich & fatty ramen with black garlic oil":  Ramen to me can be scored by 4 components:

Noodles:  Definitely overcooked and too soft.  That was easy.  FAIL.

The Egg:  Perfect.  Absolutely delicious.  The yolk was rich and creamy, but just cooked enough to be more pudding than runny.  A bit of flavor in the white too.  WIN.

Chashu:  Mixed on this one.  The flavor is great--really rich and pungent.  And really tender--very much melts in thy mouth... but is always the problem.  It just falls apart.  Can't even pick up a piece with your chopsticks as it just disintegrates.

Broth:  Ah... Kotteri.... it states right in the menu "rich & fatty".  NOPE NOPE NOPE.  If you ever have the chance to go to that Torrance location linked above, then you'll see "rich & fatty."  Basically a melted pig there.  This.... I dunno how they could possibly think this is Kotteri.  If rich means milky, and fatty means ........ um, ... lean?--sure.  No, not even close.  As for that "black garlic oil"--I LOVE that stuff, and they add a sht ton in the Torrance location.  So much so that there is a layer of oil covering your soup.  Check out my pics for this location's--like a tiny 1sq in area.  Seriously Yamadaya?--situated in one of the richest cities in America and you can't afford to give another teaspoon more?  FAIL FAIL FAIL.

Disgrace to the Yamadaya name.  But alas, it still tastes alright if not comparing to The Beast from Torrance.  3.5/10

1b. Paigu Pork Loin Topping $3.50:  I like it.  Well, alright, though the top was crusty and crispy, the bottom was soaked in oil and a bit soggy.  The pork was quite juicy--about 1/3rd of the pieces might have used a little less cooking time, but that's being picky.  Still juicy.  6/10

So, food was a wash.

Service.......... sucked.  Like it took 10min for someone to ask my for my order, and only after I waved someone down.  20min for me to receive my first food--the ramen.  The pork actually came 5min after that.  And then after I was done I sat another 10min before I had to wave my waitress down for the bill.  So.... yeah, service is definitely worse than your typical ramen place.

Well, if you need a quick fix, I guess there's this place.  But don't come here cause you love Yamadaya, as this place is the angry and abused bastard child.

3/5

#japaneseramen #ramen #sanfrancisco #japantown
author: Dean C.

description:
Wait time was short which was great, everything else after that, not so great. This may be a long post, but I'll give you every detail on what went down. 

After getting seated it took a little over 5 minutes for anyone to come by even though there were about 4 to 5 people on the floor. (I needed to flag him down) no greeting or anything. He didn't even ask what we would like to order, just put his pen to his pad and looked at us. Okay, I can get over that part.  

The food starts to come out, I took a bite out of my tonkatsu, not bad. My girlfriend's takoyaki and ramen come out, bad. Takoyaki is bland, barely any sauce. We asked for some extra sauce and the waitress looked at me funny and said "takoyaki sauce" as if I asked for something that wasn't supposed to be found at a Japanese restaurant. Goes to the kitchen and comes back to tell me that the takoyaki sauce and donkatsu sauce are the same (even though they taste different). Fine. The ramen comes out luke-warm, and a little too rich. We didn't want to be difficult so we ask for some hot water to put in her ramen. Guy brings me a cup where I feel no heat at all, sees me looking at it and then brings me another. Same thing. No hot water? At a restaurant? That's probably a health code violation, by the way they hid their health score behind a piece of green paper in the kitchen. Figures. 

To top it all off the takoyaki sauce girl brings us the check while I was still eating. Horrible service. And you guys might want to get that circuit checked out for your hot water. (I was told by the manager that from time to time the circuit for the hot water goes off.)

Thanks if you've made it this far , you're a trooper. Don't eat here.
author: Peter Y.

description:
Came here with a larger group this time (10 people) around 3pm. We were seated right away and there was no line! Just as we sat down, a huge line formed so I guess we got lucky. You just never know with this place.

Service was great again, the food came out very quickly. This time I tried the Yamadaya Kotteri ramen and was not impressed. This one was labeled as "rich & fatty" which was right. Probably should not have chose this one since I'm not a fan of fatty broth. As my ramen cooled down I could see the surface of the broth congealing like how liquid fat in a cup forms a skin. It was so gross! Definitely blaming myself for this order though, since I should have known better. 

My sister got the vegan ramen again but added chili sauce and now says this is the best vegan ramen she ever had. She just wishes they had mock meat. The veggies were really good this time and they had a lot of variety like corn and spinach.
author: Sara S.

description:
Typical ramen joint.  

The portions are pretty decent and they give you a large amount of meat.  The noodles they served were just average.  There wasn't much to rave about.  The broth was also the same.  I ordered their spicy miso ramen, and it just felt a bit lacking.  It was still good though.  I appreciated that they cooked their eggs to a soft boil consistency because so few places can do this corrrectly.

It was decent ramen, but not much more can be said about it.  They have chains down in Southern California which knocks this location out of the park, so maybe by comparison, it just didn't meet expectation.
author: Jacky C.

description: So don't get me wrong, the ramen tastes good. It's a thick pork based broth so it can throw some people off by how heavy it can be but I like it. The reason why I'm giving this place 2 stars is because out of the 2 times I've went...My friends and I have gotten really bad stomachaches and I personally had to throw up to make myself feel better. Maybe we got unlucky the times we've went, maybe all of us coincidentally have a allergic reaction to an ingredient they use... but most likely not. If you work at this restaurant and kinda know what I'm talking about. please fix it.
author: Yujin K.

description:
#92/2016

Rules can be fun!

Like "rules" about slurping, not sharing and eating as soon as your bowl's set in front of you without waiting for your friends to be served.

It's a license to be legitimately rude. I like it!

Ramen Yamadaya will make you wait, tap your chopsticks together impatiently waiting for your food to be set in front of you and.... it's worth every minute.

Busy on a Sunday afternoon at 4pm (I was glad we arrived just before 3:30 pm and were seated 15 minutes' later), we foot-tapped a solid 30 minutes to receive our piping hot gyoza (potstickers) and karaage (Japanese fried chicken, each $4.95) quickly followed by little one's chashu rice bowl (pork slices over rice) and my shoyu chashu ramen (pork belly in Tonkotsu broth and black sesame paste with seaweed and bamboo shoots, each $12.95).

Savory, rich and deeply soul satisfying, I now know whom to call when I'm laid out on my sofa with a bad cold and begging DoorDash delivery to get this dish to me as soon as possible.

This soup is like a cozy blanket on a rainy/cold day. It is THE food you'd want to eat! 

Service was friendly and very accommodating. The team worked together to ensure guests had a pleasant and relaxing dining experience. 

Quite frankly, this level of service is novel and most welcome at this modest price point; it's been missing for far too long in San Francisco.

Ramen Yamadaya has a foothold largely in Southern California with several LA locations as well as San Diego.

This San Francisco location in Japantown seems to be its first Northern California spot and they chose it well.

Oh, I will be back.
author: Jennifer O.

description:
Came here today with two friends around noon and it was decently busy but not overly crowded. We came at a good time. We were seated quickly and looked over our menus.

One friend and I ordered the Yamadaya Shoyu while my other friend ordered the Yamadaya Shio. We were all so pleased with our food! I've never had ramen before (surprisingly!) and I was not expecting it to be that good. I wish I took the rest home with me because I couldn't finish it but for how much I ate, I enjoyed every bite. 

Definitely recommend coming here to try it out. I'm coming back for sure!
author: Cassandra K.

description:
The review is for the tsukemen solely. I've been looking for places that have this in SF. It's pretty amazing that you can get a 14 oz. size one. It's pretty good, but the broth lacked flavor. Tsukemen broth usually has a stronger flavor to envelop the noodles.

The restaurant looks really nice and would love to go back to try their ramen. The service was quite interesting... When I asked for water and also a napkin, the waitress didn't seem that pleased. To be fair, the carafe was empty. For a table of 5, we only had four sets of plates/napkins.
author: James N.

description: I've been here a couple of times and at first i had high expectations. The food looked good as i order the spicy ramen in mild. It tastes alright, the noodles were a bit thinner and the taste of the ramen in general was gross honestly. not just that but the service was terrible. whenever i asked someone for water or extra forks they'd roll their eyes at me! that was so disrespectful. plus it took me almost the whole time to get my water. i had to spend $20 on a bowl of cockroach soup  will never be going here again.
author: Mary Magdalene C.

description: My go to ramen stop. Soup is tasty and the pork is amazing. The vibe is also really trendy and fun. I wish the staff was nicer but it wouldn't deter me from ramen
author: Tina L.

description:
I'm a ramen n00b, so this was a great introduction. I had the yamadaya  ramen w/ black garlic oil. 
Broth: perfectly opaque, very delicious and not fishy at all. 
Everything Else: the PORK BELLY. I can't even describe the incredible-osity. Tender meat, supple fat that just soaks up all of the flavor.

Really cute ambiance, definitely a great spot to start your ramen adventure.
author: Kimberly H.

description:
I came to this restaurant after being put on a waiting list of 73 people ahead of me at Marufuku Ramen. I only had to wait 10 minutes.
