They just ask how many(They don't take a name) and as soon as a table leaves they bring you back. We got some peppers as an appetizer and the house ramen. We enjoyed both!
Update: I accidentally put this on the wrong restaurant
author: Shontel O.

description: I don't usually like ramen. I'll eat it but it's just meh. But I took a sip of the broth which is rich, flavorful, and surprising. The noodles were perfectly cooked and so easily devoured. The calamari was so delicious and well-breaded. The pork in the ramen melted in my mouth. It was amazing. AMAZING.
author: Jojo H.

description:
Waiting for my ikura donburi, because I asked if the Kakuni ramen had any dairy or nuts. Waiter had to check with another waiter, and I was basically told they all had butter. Also asked me "what kind of dairy?" "Like eggs, or milk or?" All dairy dude. It's a dairy allergy, not a yogurt allergy or a butter allergy. And for the record, eggs aren't dairy. Also really, really confused because I definitely ate one of their ramen options the last time I was here. It was ok; the soft boiled egg was excellent though. 

Friends got their ramen; still waiting on my donburi and friend's soda. I wonder if they're short staffed today.  

Verdict: The salmon and ikura donburi isn't bad, but at $12, I'd personally rather have a poke bowl.
author: Kelsey W.

description:
Came here for lunch and this place was better than I expected.

Ramen can come with thin or thick noodles, you'll get thin if you don't specify though. Broth has decent flavor but comes with a ton of meat which everyone at the table commented about. 

They have kitschy signs out front in the waiting area about how to be a friendly customer or leave... kinda feel like the staff should be held to that same standard then as they were pretty horrendous lol. 

But in the end, the food was decent so I'll prob give them a try and see how their dinner service is next time.
author: Mandi W.

description:
Our first time to visit last Thursday. Ramen is ok but seems no one care about the cleanliness n hygiene of this place. We all smelt of pee from the ground somewhere, perhaps leftovers days ago or what, we didn't know why there's stingy smell all over the restaurant. It ruined our appetite, definitely. How could I enjoy my food with all senses alongside with a thought/smell of pee or poo with me?!Perhaps you can check n smell next time while u visit.
(I m not working in this business, just a customer
author: Roseline Y.

description: They close at 3 for lunch and we arrived around 2:40. The sign said "CLOSED" but then as we sat sad-faced on their bench looking at other options, this kind angel of a waiter came out and said that he could serve us but that the kitchen was closing soon. Thank you!!! I had the fire ramen and it was h e l l a spicy and I'm Thai lol. CAUTION SUPER SPICY  (like I got blisters on my tongue) But my friend got the spicy miso and that was also super yummy!! I would come back again for sure!! Excellent service
author: Mora O.

description: My spicy miso ramen was delicious! But the service wasn't great, never once had our server ask if our food was okay or if i wanted a refill ect.. I had to flag the server down for a refill of my coke. And I got yelled at for wanting to use the free soda yelp offer because he said I should have told him before that I was gonna use it, uh how am I going to tell you if you never checked on our table lol.. ramen is delicious but I may venture out and try a new place since we only visit once every few months.
author: Katie C.

description:
Even with all the changes, This is still the best Ramen in Japantown. I love the two new places: Hinodeya and Marafuku, but this still has the absolute best. The best broth, best noodles, best chashu pork. And I love that it doesn't close between Lunch and Dinner. Always open, always a line.

Update:
Still the best broth and noodles in SF, but the constant price and menu changes are a little annoying. These constant high prices won't stop me from eating here, but I will be coming here far less.

Lines are still long. But get your prices right.
author: Ron Z.

description: The Tonkatsu was overdone and very dry.  The breading had a burnt smell.  I mentioned these to the waitress, but she was not concerned.  I ordered the same thing a few months ago and that time it was excellent.  Miso soup was served lukewarm.  When I complained, the waitress brought a hot one later.  But it came too late.  I just would like to have food hot and cooked right.  It ruined my evening.
author: Sanae K.

description:
I got the Yamadaya Shoyu - it was pretty good but not amazing. I would expect better from Japantown. 

Noodles - thin noodles with a nice, springy texture overall. Unfortunately, some of the noodles were glued together, forming clumps within the ramen.

Broth - Pretty standard shoyu broth. Could have used a bit more of it, since there was less than I expected. I ended up with more ramen than broth by the end of the bowl, and I'm usually not a huge broth drinker.

Toppings - The tonkatsu and menma were the favorite part of this ramen for me. The tonkatsu was sweet, flaky, and tender, with a generous amount. The menma was crunchy and not stringy - there were only 3 pieces though which was a little disappointing. 

My dessert probably brought my experience down from a 3.5 to a 3. I was hoping for a hot, fresh tayaki with creamy red bean paste, but unfortunately my tayaki dreams were not to be fulfilled. The tayaki was quite small (about the size of my fist). The fried exterior tasted stale and the bean paste instead was dry and crumbling. 

On a side note, my friend ordered the spicy ramen at level 6 ("death") and it was preettty spicy. So spicy that the spice completely overwhelmed the fatty pork flavor of the broth, but definitely good for spice lovers.
author: Hali M.

description:
I have come here twice and ordered the Tonkotsu Ramen at heat level 2 both times. For me, there was more than enough pork and noodles in my soup. My boyfriend said he would have liked more meat in his similar order. I thought it was the perfect amount and loved it.

The ramen is fairly priced which is nice to find in such an expensive city. The service was excellent the first time with fun staff and detailed explanations. The second time the service was more standoff and not as happy. Not everyone, but there were definitely some tired and upset employees.

Overall, the ramen is awesome. The appetizer selection is small but everything you could want option wise. Beware of the spice levels, they aren't kidding when they call some of them hell.
author: Madison L.

description:
Ramen Yamadaya is my favorite ramen place in all of SF!  Their pork broth is hearty and satisfying, the pork belly and other stuff is fab and they put plenty of noodles in the bowls.  I've tried many ramen places and I will always vote for this one. 

My second favorite place is Ramen Underground ...but the one on Kearny, more than the one in Japantown.
author: karen K.

description:
One of my favorite ramen shops in the city. I love their spicy ramen a lot. My go-to is usually either Tonkotsu Spicy or Kakuni spicy :) Their noodles is probably the best ones in the city, skinny and just a little bit tough that somehow makes it extra yummy to bite on. 

The wait is not bad, usually around 15-20 minutes. Try sit at their communal table in the middle if you can, I really like how there are plants and whatnot in the center - very cute and an almost romantic vibe. 

If you feel like getting dessert, make sure you order the Taiyaki - a fish-shaped cake filled with red bean paste. Ask for some cream/ice cream on top and it's delicious. You won't regret it!
author: Angel C.

description:
This place will make your taste buds want to party all night! Located in the second floor in cute Japan town.

My boyfriend and I both kept craving ramen... 

Here we go!
Spicy ramen - I went for the "fire" option and my boyfriend went for the "hell" option.. 

Me- spicy ramen fire level with no egg, extra corn and extra scallions
Boyfriend- spicy ramen hell level 

We also shared chicken karaage that comes with a nice cabbage salad with a sesame dressing (super yummy). And the fish red bean dessert thing (I forgot what it's called) but that dessert was on the dry side. 

Back to ramen.... NOW - you have 3 options within spice level - 
Fire, hell, and death. 

Personally, I wanted to enjoy the flavors of my ramen and enjoy the spices too... But hell was WAY to spicy for me. The waiter even gave my boyfriend a look when he said he wanted hell! Hahha 

The only reason I took off stars were because they got our orders mixed up. They put all my extra goodies in his bowl and we both agreed the hell was too much spice. We didn't get napkins until after we received our entrees (and not apps?) and had to keep looking for our waiter for spoons, napkins, and water. 

The vibe is really modern and welcoming in terms of space. 

I would come back .. And so sad that I found out you can get thick noodles instead of thin (which is what it's originally served with) bc I'm one of the people who didn't read their sign.. 

It's a good place for ramen and one of my top 5's despite the spicyness. I hope to come back with the correct food and options in front of me when I order it!
author: Kate N.

description:
This place went down hill. Absolutely terrible service. No one to take orders, bring table settings, or water. Water came with no ice. 

I'm not sure if it's under new management. Menu and food are different.
author: Willy C.

description: I ordered the vegan ramen and compared to the other vegan ramen options in the city, this was incredibly mediocre. The noodles are thin and more or less bland. I typically like more creamy and thick broth, but this broth was very soupy and not creamy at all. It also didn't smell / taste vegetarian which was a mental blocker. Would not try in searching for veggie ramen but for other kinds I hear it is good!
author: Nidhi M.

description:
By far my favorite Ramen place! 
I came here with friends and had the Kara-age (Japanese Fried Chicken) - it was amazing! 
We ordered Japanese IPA - a so called "blue devil"
Some of the best beer I've had!
As for main course, I went with the Spicy ramen. But when asked how spicy, I made sure to not go overboard with the heat. As I'm a firm believer of balance (too much heat, kills other flavors). The servings were generous. My pork belly was plenty, but they were bit stingy with my other friends meat. 

Overall, I pigged out and had the whole bowl, slurping the broth and enjoy it all with the blue devil IPA. Highly recommend! ^__^
author: Luis A.

description:
WORST SERVICE EVER!!! 

Honestly,  the ramen is really good.  However the service have always been the worse experience going there.  We had to wave at them for a water refill.  Also,  we waited twenty minutes for our tab and they still didn't even bring it to us.  We had to walk up the their register to let them know that we want to pay for our tab.  Then came down to the person that gave us our receipt telling us that their system is down and didn't even inform us while we wasted our time waiting. We wanted to pay cash,  then his attitude came to a conclusion for us to only pay by credit card (no split bill of what so ever). Now I'm thinking,  if the system is down and they're only taking credit card,  why are they going to straight up lie to us that they're not axccepting cash?  

Well,  to all of you that's going there,  all I got to say is good luck dealing with their horrible service.
author: Tchad T.

description: Something has drastically changed here; I have been here a number of times pre and post transition, and it has gone from a robust ramen joint getting the basics right to a place with overly fatty kakuni and a tendency to make me feel queasy post consumption. I remember savouring the broth!
author: Donald C.

description: We were looking forward to eating here for dinner all day and it did not disappoint, the food was delicious!  Sooo good!
author: Melinda D.

description: They are not the same Ramen Yamadaya they were two years ago. It looks like they have changed the owner. All the staffs are different and they cater toward a different group of customers. They no longer have the thin ramen similar to that of Hakata Ramen at Shinsengumi in SoCal.  The ramen noodle is now thick and chewy.  The menu has changed. The way gyoza was served was not authentic.  Each piece was placed randomly on the plate instead of nicely arranged, and with chili on the side.  Any authentic Japanese restaurants will never serve gyoza like that.  The Yamadaya ramen was overly garlicky , salty and fattening.  It was nothing like before. They did add more chashu pork in the bowl, like 5 pieces, but I'd rather have quality over quantity.
author: Elle W.

description:
Got lucky! We went to this place at around 3-4pm, I think... and for some reason it was pretty slow and not so much customers yet.   
By the time we finished our meals the line outside was super long and it was so crowded. With that being sad, crowded was definitely a good sign for most of the time. The food was good as well as the customer service. Enjoyed it completely as I finished my bowl to its last drop of soup. Would highly recommend to others.
author: Aris C.

description:
Best ramen place in San Francisco. First time I came here, I saw on Yelp they only had three or three and a half stars so I was a bit worried I'd be wasting my money but my friend wanted to go here so I gave it a try. To my surprise, it was really good. It has become my go-to place whenever I'm craving ramen. I always order the tonkotsu ramen. The broth is perfect. Good flavor; not too strong or light. It's almost as good as my favorite ramen place in SoCal. Ramen restaurants tend to always serve a few chashu pork slices in their soup which is not filling for me, so I always order extra chashu.
The longest I waited to get a seat was about 20 min on a Tuesday. The waiting area can get crowded because once the seating area gets filled, a lot of people are left standing. 
I went back to their Yelp page today and looked at their menu pictures and saw they had a health warning a year ago. It does make me a bit worried but I don't see the warning anymore. It also won't stop me from coming here since it's my favorite place for a good bowl of ramen.
I prefer this place over Mensho Tokyo. I waited an hour to try Mensho ramen, but it wasn't worth the wait.
I highly recommend you give this place a try.
author: Kristin H.

description: Since my friends and I made a trip to Japantown, we decided to try this ramen place.  They seated us right away and were pretty fast with our order.  I ordered the tonkotsu kotteri ramen and a karaage bun.  The karaage bun was pretty good but the ramen was alright.  The charsiu pieces were really fatty though so I didn't eat it.  Besides that, the customer service was good since they attended to us well.
author: Mikayla M.

description:
Came here with friends on a rainy night after a fun night doing an escape room event, and were craving some ramen. 

We ordered the nanban chicken which was perfect, and I had the Yamadaya Shio which hit the spot perfectly a rainy day. I was slightly disappointed how they burned my taiyaki but it wasn't charcoal so I could still enjoy it.

It probably now one of my favorite ramen spots in SF now since the food was great, the service quick and their nicely place on the second floor so you can look down onto Japantown while you enjoy your meal.
author: Vanessa S.

description: My girlfriend and I both got sick after eating here. The staff are pretty rude. Forcing people to use the automated waitlist is ridiculous when there is no line.
author: David K.

description:
Been here a couple times and it's always a solid bowl of ramen. I always get the black garlic tonkatsu ramen bowl and it's more than enough! The broth is thick and garlicky (pretty heavy but honestly I love my ramen broths heavy :p) and has a ton of flavor. This place is also NOT stingy with meat at all - I get 3-4 slices of pork in a bowl! I only really get max 2 anywhere else so that was a surprise. The chashu meat is decent - not quite as tender as other places but not bad either. The pork belly slices are lot softer and cooked well tho. 

Pro tip - ask for fresh garlic and they will bring you a bowl of fresh garlic cloves and a garlic press for you to press all the garlic you want into your ramen!!! Beware, makes my breath smell like garlic for the entire day but oooomg so worth it bahaha.
author: Grace D.

description:
5-stars for the service. My now ex-boyfriend and I went there for dinner a few months ago. At the time, I was working in the Financial District at a tech company: well-paid but very stressed. We had a great dinner. For me the ramen was pretty good but I have had better. The ramen I'd give 4-starts.

For me, it was the service. I'm a type 1 diabetic. I wear a continuous glucose meter (CGM). That comes with a little receiver unit. I usually keep it in my purse but twice a day you have to calibrate it with a reading from your glucose meter. I'm assuming that's why put it on the table. We had our meal, settled the check, and headed home. I didn't realize until later in the trip that I didn't have my CGM. We were still in the city, so I stopped by the office. It wasn't on my desk. Uh oh.

I had a lunch event the next day, so I went to the restaurant hoping I'd catch someone there early to open up. I did and, yes, someone had found it, and they put it aside. Hooray.

As it's medical equipment, that was really stressful. 5-stars to them for putting it aside.
author: Regina W.

description:
Looks like they've changed owners. Came here on a Friday night around 8pm and could already tell that service was going to be weak. 

When we walked up the stairs, we saw a couple waiting but multiple tables available. Oh boy. 

We got seated with time and then ordered - the waitress has to repeat our orders back to us numerous times. (Oh boy x2) As we waited for our foods, I noticed that they had their employees in one area (near the kitchen) while people we're waiting to get their attention...

The noodles are okay. The broth is not as thick as you'd expected. They also didn't have fried rice. How do you run out of rice?! 

Sadly, I don't think I'll be back.
author: Stephanie W.

description:
This place was definitely a lot better than I expected. I was kind of nervous to go considering Yelp's poor food safety alert, but I decided to go with my friend regardless. The place appeared to be decently clean with a fair number of booths, tables, and a large central table. I was seated with my friend at a corner on the large central table, which was a bit strange for me. The table was also super sticky, so I had to really try to avoid putting my elbows on the table.

My friend and I both got the Tonkotsu ramen and I enjoyed the thin noodles which were cooked just right and the meat which was not too fatty. The broth was also very good and just oily enough to taste good but not be so greasy and sickening that it makes it hard to finish the bowl of noodles. I actually finished my entire bowl of noodles this time! We also got the gyoza which were pretty tasty as well. If I were to come back again, I would probably try out the cheese ramen - seems interesting!
author: Catherine S.

description: Went there with my family for a casual Sunday lunch. Waited about 30 minutes after signing in on a tablet for the wait list. We all ordered the kakuni ramen with Shoyo based Tonkotsu soup. Also ordered gyoza, karaage, and nikuman. Waited 30minutes and got the ramens first. Ramen was really good, although I was not a fan of the straight thin noodles. Problem was that it took another 40minutes for the gyoza, karaage, and nikuman to be served. We had to remind the waitress about our order twice. The waitress was really nice and apologetic about the delay but usually these items should be served before the ramen. Not the best experience for a ramen place. We were expecting to have a quick lunch but it turned into a two hours long lunch.
author: Kengo W.

description: Some good vegan ramen but it's only served for lunch so you gotta get there before 2:30pm. Cute place. Kinda pricey. Bill was over 100$ for lunch for me and my 2 friends but I guess that's normal in the city when you order sake. Fun part of town.
author: Jennifer K.

description: I'm shocked by the 3.5 star rating on here.. I give it a true 5 stars. The service is amazing and you feel very welcome here. I got the yamadaya shoyu ramen and it was so good! I like this place because they don't charge you for "toppings", this ramen is loaded with all the necessary elements. They don't cheat you on the ramen either, they give you a good amount of noodles, broth, egg, and nori. Their pork belly was really good, it was soft and chewy just the way it should be! The location is amazing, you can go to daiso or enjoy dessert places around the area. This is truly a spot you do not want to miss if you're going to San Francisco!
author: Kaitlyn S.

description: Cozy Japanese ramen house. Get a bunch of appetizers and a little of everything along with your big bowl of ramen (extra noodle portion). Get adventurous with the spice bombs if you dare.
author: Martin C.

description: Used to be my favorite ramen place, but  owner or chef has changed hand. No longer good
author: Ben A.

description: Extremely flavorful, bowl licking pork bone broth ramen!  Friendly service BUT I GOT FOOD POISONING. An hour and a half later, and all night, praying to the porcelain god. Not going back, which is sad since it tasted good.
author: Jennifer C.

description: This might actually be the worst meal I've had in San Francisco. Ordered the ramen and gyoza via postmates. Ramen broth came on the side and upon pouring it onto the ramen noticed that the bottom portion of the broth was like sludge. Smelled terrible. Also, I'm pretty sure the gyoza has rotting pork inside. The smell and taste of both were very off putting. Long story short, threw everything out. $40 down the drain. If you know what's good for you, take your dollars somewhere else.
author: Zach B.

description: Horrrible service and waiter gave me the poke face since I walked in. I'm the first customer went in and requested a window seat and he sort of laughed at me and put me in another inside table instead. My $30 bill may not worth anything to them but I can choose another place being treated like a customer, so I stood up and walked out.....maybe their food is good but I'm not regretting.
author: Sue S.

description: I had the spicy miso ramen and it was amazing. They gave me the option to have my spice on the side. Since I got the "death" leavel of spice, I was able to control how much I put in.
author: James C.

description:
First time to try this place, it didn't disappoint me and my family. Their ramen noodles are good especially the spicy ones. The price is not that bad too. 

If you have about 8 person or more, better call for a reservation than to wait in line. 

We will surely be back here again.
author: Lou H.

description: I would rate them 3 stars because I believe the broth is very salty. The noodles were cooked very well. There is always a line here but it is pretty organized. People write their own name on the list and how many and they go straight down the list. If possible try to get a booth. You'll have some privacy. They also have a community table for those of you who are going solo. They also have the beer Orion which is imported from Japan. It is very good if you're into Lagers. Must try!
author: Derek P.

description:
this place went from a 5 star to 1 star.
 Ownership must have changed. Quality is low.  Pork meat seemed a day old. I will not be returning!!!!!
author: JR P.

description:
I flew into SFO not thinking to try ramen; however my cousin really wanted ramen. After finding this place on YELP we decided to try this place out. 

The gyoza was the BEST!!!! The ramen was so good! Broth wasn't too salty and the pork buns were amazing!!!!  If I come back I will definitely try this place out!!!!
author: Jennie K.

description:
I haven't had Japanese ramen in a while and was *really* craving it, so I went to grab a bowl with a friend. We decided on Ramen Yamadaya because my friend is a vegetarian and not a lot of shops in Japantown offer vegetarian-friendly options. 

I ordered the Yamadaya shoyu ramen and my friend ordered the vegetarian ramen. Both bowls of ramen weren't hot at all. The only slightly warm thing in the bowl were the noodles. I ordered corn as an extra topping and it was served cold, which was super weird to me. The other toppings (egg, mushroom, bamboo) were probably room temperature. For the shoyu ramen, the flavor of the broth was just alright... nothing particularly special to me. My pork was just kind of sad because it was dry and the pieces themselves weren't the best cuts. I didn't try the vegetarian ramen, but my friend said, "the water had more taste than the ramen did." Also, I really don't know how, but the vegetarian ramen made my friend's stomach hurt...

I would've given a 3 based on the taste/service, but the fact that the ramen was barely lukewarm made me bump it down to an overall 2.
author: Catherine T.

description: Service wasn't good, ramen was too oily and lack taste, not enough meat either. Too expensive for its quality.
author: Caven C.

description: This place is terrible and the service sucks I asked for my drink 3 times I front of the waitress and she ignored it everytime salmon donburi is terrible becuase it says regular salmon but I got smoked salmon
author: Arashi K.

description:
Pros: decently priced, great/friendly service, vegan option, lots of protein (in the meat option)
Cons: mediocre noodles and flavor
author: Kelly G.

description:
Colleen 
Is amazing 
She explained everything to us and she is so funny and nice and amazing and I am proud to have met her me and my friends loved her and we will come see her again
author: Nicholas H.

description:
This place was really disappointing. We stopped here for dinner because the line at Marafuku was too long. It took 35-40 minutes from the time we ordered for our food to come to the table. Another couple next to us left without eating because it took so long.
The pork in my bowl was mostly fat. The noodles were good, but the broth was really cloudy and strange, even the nonmiso ones. I'm not sure how this place has gotten good ratings, maybe we came on an off night.
author: Elle T.

description:
I'm always up for a hearty bowl of noodles, but on this particular brisk day I was craving ramen.  It was my first time here and was delighted to see my honey and I could be seated without waiting in line.  I know it was all the luck of timing as my eyes caught sight of the sign-in clipboard in the vestibule though.

Ramen Yamadaya is located upstairs in that tiny Buchanan plaza in Japantown.  They have booth seating, communal tables and side by side seating close to others.  The sounds of top pop songs are blaring in this vibrant atmosphere as friendly staff bustles around serving and bussing.  My honey ordered the modest  Yamadaya Shio with basic pork broth, and me being the spicy hot fiend was going to go straight for the Yamadaya Spicy's Death Ramen.  However, our server advised me not to go there if I hadn't tried their spicy ramen before.  I relented and went with the Hell Ramen, but ultimately, decided I would have been fine with Death Ramen like I do with Teeth SF's Death sauce in the Mission.  Regardless, we enjoyed our ramen full of kikurage mushrooms, egg, bamboo shoots, green onions and generous amounts of pork.  I added corn to mine which were in sparse amounts.  The broth had the typical thick viscosity of most ramens- very heavy.  My honey asked for kaedama (extra noodles).  So they brought more warm ramen noodles on a side dish.  It was more than enough for one person.  So I also indulged.  The ramen noodles here are the thin, straight kind.  It was my first time, but I stick by my favorite thick, wavy ramen noodles which seem to absorb more flavor than the skinny ones.  The incredible amounts of flavorful, soft morsels of pork in the ramen are not typical if you prefer a very carnivorous bowl of ramen.  

All ramen joints are not alike, but if you enjoy the differences despite deviating from your favorite, Ramen Yamadaya is worth it.  The service is attentive and most cordial here.  We would return again.
author: Elizabeth S.

description: Have been waiting 20 minutes for our food to come out.  They haven't even brought out the wakame salad, which I wanted as an appetizer and not a side.   Never coming back.
author: Jenny K.

description:
Love the ramen & love the workers!

Food always brings me to places but the customer service is what brings me back. The employees are so nice and friendly and they took very good care of us!

I always order the spicy kakuni tonkotsu and takoyaki! They never let me down! And I love the fresh garlic. 5 stars Yamadaya! I love you guys. :)
author: Marilee A.

description:
What drew me to Ramen Yamadaya was a pic I saw on their yelp photo gallery of their Kakuni Pork Belly.  It looked pretty impressive because they give you a huge slab.  It got me really excited to finally try a new ramen spot for me in SF.

Their menu is pretty extensive and I like how you're not limited to just ramen.  They also pork belly buns, rice bowls and curry bentos.  When I went there for lunch with a friend, we shared their Takoyaki, Chicken Karaage, and their famous Kakuni Pork Belly along with our bowls of ramen.

Takoyaki -- http://bit.ly/1EMwmFL
Takoyaki was good.  Each piece had a nice piece of octopus.

Chicken Karaage -- http://bit.ly/1GDhdqv
If you know me, I almost always order Chicken Karaage with my ramen.  Their Chicken Karaage is very lightly fried with a thin batter.  It was 

Kakuni Pork Belly -- http://bit.ly/1DwuKsr
Yeah, they're Kakuni Pork Belly game is serious here at Ramen Yamadaya.  Just look at the pic!  Huuuuuuuuge slab and it was cooked well and made for a great side with the ramen.

Yamadaya Ramen -- http://bit.ly/1Aa7FeQ
Tonkotsu Ramen w/ Yamadaya Topping (Kakuni Pork, Chashu Pork, Scallion, Menma, Seasoned Egg, Dried Seaweed)
I decided on trying their namesake ramen since it pretty much had everything I like included in the bowl.  And it was a good bowl of ramen.  The tonkotsu broth was just right and not too salty and the eggs were just slightly soft boiled making them somewhat runny which is how I like it.  And they don't hold back on the pork,  As you can see from the pic, they give a generous amount.

Overall, Ramen Yamadaya is a very solid ramen joint if you're in the Japantown area.  I would  love to go back and try their curry and pork belly buns.  I wouldn't come here all the time, but I know that if I'm around the area craving some ramen I'd be willing to drop by if the wait is not too long.
author: Rodney H.

description:
Service:
+ The place was very busy with long lines. Though the service was not the fastest, it was not that slow, considering the place was full. A big plus to the service was their flexibility as they still accepted us even less than half an hour toward their closing time (we couldn't find any other restaurant at that time and was very hungry).

Foods:
* The karaage was good but still within the expected quality.
* My spicy ramen was delicious. But overall, the ramens were OK, not to a level of mind blowing.
author: Rafael W.

description: The bathrooms are filthy, so that's the only thing keeping me from giving this place five stars. Other than that, this place is great. Had the spicy miso ramen - level 2 and loved it. Will definitely be coming back here.
author: Nico G.

description: This was great the first time I tried this place but not as good the second time...that's why only 3 stars. My vegan ramen was on the pricey side and I was underwhelmed!
author: Char S.

description: overrated and not very amazing. Ramen has not fully cooked and waiter/waitress are not polite.
author: Jojo L.

description: Great Ramen, broth was good. We also had calamari. That was good to. Price is reasonable. I will come back.
author: Rod M.

description: Friendly, bouncy, and packed with happy diners. What a phenomenal bowl of ramen. So rich and satisfying!
author: Lisa T.

description: Ramen is good, decent portion, ok service but Be aware of the mandatory "20%" service charge!!!! You can only choose "No Tip", "18%" or "20%". A ramen place ask for 20% tip!? I don't think they deserve it!!!! I would never come back.
author: Candice L.

description: I love this place and would have normally given it a five star review, but they recently reduced the size of their menu, changing the Yamada-ya ramen to be a totally different recipe.  It is now a lot less tasty in my opinion.
author: Luc B.

description: Will definitely return to yamadaya for their delicious food and quick service. From the time it took us to be seated to receiving our food it took only about a total of 20 minutes altogether. We came an hour and half before closing but that didn't change how busy it was and how attentive our server was to us.
author: JoshAnn Y.

description:
I really don't like to write negative reviews, so I will try to just be as objective as possible in this post. I ate at Ramen Yamadaya with my friends a couple weeks ago, and had a nice time. Half of the party was seated before we got there, so I can't really speak on behalf of wait times for dinner. Our waiter led us to our corner booth and had us all seated. The room is square with booths lining the walls. In the middle of the room is a long table (or two? I can't funny remember now; I didn't want to look for too long because people were eating there) where bigger parties or a bunch of small parties can eat. We were a party of 7, so the booth was full and I got to sit at the end. 

Our waiter seemed friendly enough when he took our initial drink orders, until he asked us if we were going to want to split the check. I've worked at a restaurant and I know that splitting checks for big parties can be a pain, and I try to avoid it if possible. I'm sure our party would have been completely fine paying on one or two tabs and Venmoing one another later (we do it all the time--in fact we'd been doing it all day during our day out in SF). But since he asked, we pretty much thought, "Sure, why not?" and said yes to splitting checks. He then responded by kind of sighing and saying something along the lines of, "Well, that's gonna be a lot of work, but I'll do it." None of us were upset about it, in fact no one acknowledged that that happened until much later and I think we were all more confused than anything else. 

Anyway, the food took a normal amount of time to come out. Each of us ordered ramen, and I can't remember which exact meal I ordered. We all started eating right away, but I honestly noticed the broth start to gelatinize not long after the bowl was put in front of me. I saw the little blobs of fat starting to form before it had cooled off at all, but I thought it might just be the meat I ordered. It got chunkier the longer it was out. The noodles were also pretty undercooked. Anyway, I thought I might have been the only one with the fat cooling too fast in my ramen, but when I looked at the other bowls before we left, I noticed there was pretty much a thick layer of almost completely solid fat at the top of everyone else's ramen bowls as well. Like, with normal broths and soups it would take hours and hours to develop a skin of fat that thick, but it only took around half an hour to 45 minutes for it to happen there. 

So yeah, I'm not too sure what it is about this place that makes the broth solidify so quickly. I liked the feel of the place and the workers were friendly overall. It's also in a really cute spot with a nice view of Japantown.
author: Jasmine R.

description: I travel from Reno to frisco to have this ramen. It never disappoints and always hits the spot.
author: Pedro V.

description: Amazing!!!!!! The ramen was filling and hearty in the broth. The waiters were very nice and patient. Apparently, Ramen Yamadaya has free refills on any soda!!! Atmosphere was casual and comfortable. HIGHLY RECOMMEND!!!!!!
author: Lorenzo S.

description:
My dinner companion is a ramen aficionado and has traveled Japan sampling many kinds of ramen. He proclaimed this to be the best ramen he's had outside Japan.

And we almost didn't eat here.

Standing at the door, a woman was leaving as we arrived. "How was the ramen?" we asked, but she made a face."Not very good. Okay, I guess." We waffled about going in.

A man joined came out. "How was the ramen?" He shrugged,"Okay." We waffled again, then he said, "We really wanted udon but they didn't have any," and joined the woman. They left and we laughed. Of course they didn't. This isn't a American Japanese restaurant that has one of everything on the menu. 

It took a while to be seated, but we felt almost like we were in Japan, except for the lack of smoke/grease/steam pall hanging about halfway down most ramen places. 

We both ordered the Yamadaya Kotteri, the "Rich & Fatty Ramen with Black Garlic Oil". Our eyes rolled back as we sipped the delicious broth and had pretty much the best noodles I have ever had. Amazingly thin, but still with a good chewiness, we expressed our compliments to a gentleman standing with a pad and he beamed - he was the manager. "We do our best to use the traditional way of making things" he said and we complimented him again. 

If you like ramen, this is a must-visit. Absolutely the best ramen I have ever eaten in North America.
author: Patience S.

description: Ramen yamadaya is my favorite ramen place ever ! Once you eat this ramen you won't be able to eat any other ramen again. I always take people here and I'm a regular ! My favorite is the kakuni, it's rich and the meat in the ramen is insane. The service could be better but the atmosphere is nice and fun. Definitely try this place
author: Kloe K.

description: Ramen Yamadaya is a cute little ramen shop near the heart of japan Town. It might be kind of hard to find since it's on the second floor. My party of four came in around 7:00 pm and waited around 3 minutes to get seated on a Tuesday. I ordered a pork katsu box and my friends each ordered a Yamadaya ramen. The katsu was really good ! I think it's a good alternative if you don't want ramen. It comes with miso soup as well, however my miso was not hot at all, the temperature was the same as warm sink water. My friend really enjoyed the spicy miso broth in his ramen, so I really recommend that! We all also ordered a Pepsi, but the Pepsi seemed like they needed to change their syrup cause it just tasted like carbonated water. Overall the service was great, minus the little things.
author: Angel K.

description:
I've been going to this spot for many years and it's been my go to ramen spot in Japantown. The ramen is solid for sure but lately service has taken a HUGE downturn!

The last time I went, we waited 10 minutes to be seated which is pretty normal. Then it took 55 minutes for us to get our ramen!!!! For some reason they decided to prioritize the take out orders over orders made within the restaurant! Not only that but the table that was seated after us got their ramen before ours. Not cool.

As for the ramen when it finally arrived, it was okay. Not sure if it was because I was hangry, but it was on the really salty side and the kakuni was mostly fat (may or may not be a good thing).

After this last experience it'd probably be better to just have Postmates deliver their ramen to you since they seem to be on the ball for takeouts. Otherwise I'd go elsewhere.
author: Kelly D.

description: Place is ok. Not my favorite style of noodle and they don't have gyoza. Will eat here again but not my favorite.
author: Yo Y.

description:
My friends and I gave this place a shot on black friday 2016. We got the following:

Food (would get it again?)

Yamadaya Kotteri (Yes) 
Everything about this yells fat, creamy, ultra rich at you. I couldn't even go on after a few sip of the broth and a bit of chasu/pork belly. 
If you're feeling gluttony, go for it. I wished they offer half portion. Love the thin ramen noodles. 

Tsukemen (No)
I've tried this at the SJ downtown branch as well. Both are consistent in flavor. However, I usually prefer more punch and viscous tsukemen broth and this one doesn't do it for me. The two big chasu were cold. I wished they at least warm it up. Torching/scorching it, now there's an idea. 

Karaage (No)
Nope. Soggy chicken. Maybe it was a bad batch. The flavor is good.
author: Zaw M.

description: Although the line appeared long to get in, we were in within 20 minutes. The ramen was great. The pork shoulder and pork short rice bowls were also great. Pricing is very fair.
author: Andrea A.

description:
I love this Ramen place! It's super authentic- noodles are chewy and not soggy, and the pork are fatty and melty:) Broth is on the oily side, but overall it's good. Only down side is that there is always a 30+ min wait, and you have to be right outside the door when they call your name or else your seat will be taken by the next customer on the list. 

Favorites:
Basic Pork Broth Ramen ($9.45)
Tonkotsu Spicy ($9.95)
author: Victoria L.

description:
Tonkotsu is probably my favorite ramen broth so it's nice to know there's a spot in SF that focuses on just that. 20 hours of boiling the tonkotsu broth to be exact. 

The result is a rice meaty broth that is creamy and unctuous. I had the regular tonkotsu ramen and I thought it was satisfying enough for me. Decent slices of pork, bamboo shoots, and a just-right soft boiled egg. My brother had the Kakuni ramen with extra noodles. Personally I don't think you need the extra noodles but the braised pork belly is worth the upgrade. Wished the noodles had a little more bite to them and that there was a little more broth inside the massive bowls. Satisfying on a chilly SF evening nonetheless.

Was surprised that they have a low health score. From our visit it looked like Ramen Yamadaya was a clean and contemporary well-oiled machine that got food to the table fast. I guess for a decent bowl of ramen in the city, one can ignore the score and just dig in.
author: Jon L.

description: I'm in Japantown for 4 days, so looked to take Yelpers' advice for the best ramen around. Tried Waraku's spicy tonkotsu yesterday, which was nice, and higher rated than Yamadaya. I had the ramen jones again today, so tried Yamadaya (it was earlier than Hinodeya was open). Wow... Twice as good as Waraku's. Better broth, noodles, better (and way more, and more kinds of) pork. I had the spicy miso tonkotsu. Spectacular
author: Mike R.

description: So Yummy! I have been here twice now for lunch and both times were really good! The service is really nice and attentive, the ramen is really good and the restaurant seems welcoming and clean.  My Japanese boyfriend and I are very likely to keep coming for a our ramen cravings over in Japantown!
author: Caitlin J.

description:
Be wary of reviews along the lines of "This is THE BEST RAMEN I've ever had". Perhaps it's equivalent of saying dominos is the "most delish" pizza. Objectively speaking, it's not bad, has all the right ingredients, but "best"? Common people. Knowing this is not Japan, I still left with an empty feeling and slight disappointment.

Neutral:
- tonkotsu kotteri (chashu was decent size, soup is objectively meh more on the bland side)
- karaage chicken (felt like the soft microwaved ones, at least it was warm) 

Pro:
- the interior is very well designed e.g. bonsai table, great window view 
- salad is fresh
- generally speaking service is pretty fast

Con:
- $2 for a cup of instant green tea.. (Not a big deal, need something warm since i had a cold)
- people waiting outside when restaurant is only 50% occupied. (3 groups outside on tues noon...maybe the waiter had a bad day?)

There's a reason why my japanese friends rarely eat in this area. Again it's like late night pizza from down the street, it's not bad, but would you go to a restaurant for the same thing? Your call.
author: Jeff L.

description:
I would have ranked them a 5 but the extremely slow service made me have to put a 4. We came on a Saturday night and they were busy as expected. We put our names down on a list and had no idea how long we'd wait. It ended up only being like 10-15 minutes so not bad at all! 

We were seated and had enough time to look over the menu before the waiter came. We ordered easily and enjoyed our drinks before the food came. The food was delicious! Everything we got was yummy. The ramen had so much meat in it! Which was unexpected but very filling. When we were done eating, a busboy came around and immediately took our plates which was awesome. At this point I was going to give them 5 stars. 

What was frustrating for me was after the dishes were taken, we expected someone to come by and give us our check. That's what usually happens. But instead we literally waited 20+ minutes and after trying to make eye contact with our server, we finally asked a different server for our check. That was annoying and took way longer than it should have.
author: Makenzie L.

description: My bf loves this place.  Tooo bad we moved top the East Bay or we'll go monthly. Menu has changed a bit since we first came a couple years ago but flavors still there.
author: Bri L.

description:
This place always has a long wait, so of course I had to check out the hype for myself!

I ordered the pork belly ramen, adding $1.50 for a chicken egg. Quite disappointing the egg wasn't a soft-boiled egg, especially since I paid extra for it too! The pork belly was pretty darn good though; not too fatty but not too lean either. I also quite enjoyed the broth. The broth was rich, flavorful, just the perfect amount of saltiness, and didn't leave me thirsty by the time I finished the bowl. Like other reviewers mentioned, the noodles were really thin. I like thick noodles, so I'll be sure to add thick noodles next time!

I would say our group of 8 waited around 40 minutes to be seated at 2pm on a Saturday. Quite a wait, but the ramen was good at least. This isn't a place I'd frequent due to the wait and poor health inspection score, but if the inspection score went up, I'd be more than happy to come back!
author: Kristi T.

description: This joint is located in Little Tokyo SF, across the street from the Tokyo mall. The interior is clean, nice and spacious; the atmosphere and decor is very nice!. Unfortunately, I wasn't crazy about their ramen. I added an extra egg - total price was about $15 for the bowl. Maybe my expectations were too high. The noodles are originally served thin; the broth is on the lighter side (I like my broth creamier). Tasted more on the sour side & I'm not a sour lover. Their spiciest level (3) still wasn't spicy. Customer service was very good. However, for the ramen, I wouldn't come back here. Still craving 大黒家 DAIKOKUYA Ramen in LA!!! :(
author: Hu L.

description:
Actually one of the best ramen spots I've had in the Bay Area. Their broth is so rich, flavorful, and so thick. The noodles are chewy which is how ramen noodles should be. I really like their Kukuni ramen. Just a slab of pork belly on top of everything!

There can be a wait, but it is worth it. 

For sides, get gyoza, chicken karaage, or both!
author: Rhommel C.

description:
Slow! And poor service in general. I mean, I'm not expecting exceptional service from a ramen shop, but it was remarkably lacking.

Ordered the Yamada-ya. Noodles, meat, egg were all decent-good, and had generous meat portions which was surprising. Not a huge fan of the soup but it got the job done.
author: Arlan J.

description:
This used to be our favorite ramen place. We had not been back for awhile,  so two weeks ago, we decided to go there again.  I was in for a surprise---The carpet on the steps had a musty smell as if it had not been cleaned for a long time. Then when I got to the landing, it was quiet with curtain drawn. I thought perhaps it was closed, but someone came out to greet us.  We were led to a table by the window which was pleasant.  
From there on, things went down hill---After we placed the order, hot tea came. I noticed there's a dark green rim around the cup, so I asked the waiter for a new cup. He said something about this being just tea, then realized that's not the point, and went and returned with a new clean cup.  I then went into the bathroom, that's when I realized the place had really gone down hill...broken edges, dirt on the sink & floor, closet door half open showing dirt inside.  But the biggest disappointment was the food---my ramen was so salty that I just ate the noodles without the tonkatsu soup.  
To me, it seems that the owner(s) no longer care about how the place looks, not to mention the food.  How much does this have to do with the opening of Hinodeya across the street?  Given what I experienced, I know I'll be going to HInodeya next time.
author: Stella H.

description:
I got the Kakuni Kotteri... and let me tell you, it was an OUT OF BODY EXPERIENCE. I'm in love. My friends and I spent the first 5 minutes in shock and disbelief at how good it was (seriously, one of them kept repeating "no,no,no" like he couldn't believe it). Then we spent the remainder or the meal in silence because it was so good-- and we're a chatty bunch. 

The wait is long but bearable and SO WORTH IT. We go near opening though so we never get stuck in the line. 

I give this place 6/5 but their bathrooms are 2/5. It's usable but it's like a restroom at a sketchy gas station off Route 66 from a music video about recklessness, drugs, and youth.
author: Jannine G.

description: The ramen here is amazing. I ordered the yamadaya ramen. It has tons of flavor and the noodles are so good. The service is a little bit awkward. Our server kept standing by our table to look at the rest of the restaurant and made us feel weird. Besides that the ramen is great.
author: Oceana M.

description: My boyfriend and I really liked the vibe of this place, as well as the fact that they offered a vegan option for me. The restaurant played a lot of alternative 90's music--which I'll take any day over the stuff that's on the radio now--which is something I did not expect at a ramen place...that was a nice change though! My soup was really good, but not perfect. I would certainly eat at Ramen Yamadaya again though. If you order a vegan dish, BE SURE TO SPECIFY VEGAN, because sometimes they assume vegetarian and only one noodle offering is vegan.
author: Christina M.

description: The best ramen I've ever had, great service super fast, everything looked super clean, love it. Will come again for sure
author: Juanita C.

description:
I'm torn on this place. On one hand, it's my favorite ramen in San Francisco. I'm obsessed with it. Super rich and flavorful broth, some of the best pork I've ever had in ramen, just overall delicious. 

On the other hand, the last couple of times that I have been here have resulted in some of the worst service I have ever gotten. One waiter that I have had twice now made us wait 20 minutes after getting our table before even batting an eye at us, and I'm pretty sure the kitchen staff had to remind him that we were there. He then made fun of us for asking questions while we ordered. When I havn't had him, service has been friendly but still slow. 

For now, I keep going back because the ramen is so good, but the service is a deterrent. 4 stars solely because of the food.
author: Jackson S.

description:
The first time I ate here, I loved it. 2nd time I ate here, it was not as good. Service was also really BAD because our server was hard to get a hold of for anything. She kept ignoring us and it took forever just to ask her for fresh garlic! This also happened the first time we ate here, too. It gets really packed here so try to come early.

PROS:
-I like how you can press fresh garlic in your ramen
-side curry dish is good
-love the spicy tuna side w/rice!!!

CONS:
-BAD & rude service, the waitress kept ignoring us so we had to call another waiter to get water
-The ramen is just OK. Nothing special. 
-Did not care for the broth or taste. 
-Pork was dry

I most likely will not be coming back here again. BLEH. Ramen Parlor is still #1.
author: Jennifer J.

description: My absolute favorite ramen place in SF. So addicting, I've been here probably more than 10 times and always go back for their super creamy and garlicky Kakuni Kotteri. Absolute heaven. Can't recommend this place enough. Very affordable menu with great sides such as takoyaki.
author: Alexandra T.

description:
This is not my first time here for ramen, booth and noodle texture are always solid. I especially like the karrage in Osaka style. It is not cool when you find yourself chewing some unexpected object with your ramen under dim light. When I split it out and have a closer look, it is a piece of paper! A PIECE OF PAPER!!!!

The gentleman just took the bowl away and offered to make me a new one but hell no! I completely lost appetite and just wanted to leave the place asap.
author: Sandy T.

description: This place is a great place to go for ramen, their spicy ramen was very delicious, it's the mandatory station near sf jtown. However, the line is usually very long and takes about 20-30 mins during lunch time. And the service is fine, they take sometime to notice that I needed something, it's always understandable, servers are busy most of the time. One thing I hate about this ramen place is that their water tastes so bad, that makes me wonder if they can clean and wash their covers properly.
author: Mack J.

description:
An amazing place to eat great ramen. Everything in their ramen is fresh and the side dishes are delicious as well. The line to get a table can get pretty long at times but well worth the wait for good food. Prices are reasonable.
The service is fairly swift, but keep in mind this place gets slammed and crazy busy at times.
author: Jon P.

description: Foods are good but the service is terrible. We had wait for about 10min for some one taking my order. No water served until the third time I asked for some water. I will definitely not come back again. So sad.
author: S7 H.

description: The best ramen ever. Also love their fried chicken and the small sea weed salad. Pick ur spicey level wisely - hot means hot hot hot. For real Japanese hot, not "American" hot. :)
author: Zita M.

description: If you like large servings, this is the place for you. Got a large tsukemen, and there were enough noodles for two. With that said, I'd never had such thin, watered-down broth for tsukemen. If it weren't so salty, I might've mistaken it for a drink. Noodles were nice and chewy, but much too thick for such a light broth. Otherwise, chashu, egg, and other toppings were decent.
author: Ivan T.

description: Horrible service and their food was just ok. Definitely go to spots nearby instead of here. The waiter was rude, inattentive and charged us for things we didn't order. We walked out without leaving a tip since he had already charged us for things we didn't order and was taking forever to refund us (we noticed after the card had been processed). Do not go here!
author: Aisha P.

description: I didn't like few things about this place. Some of the stuff was rude and not welcoming. No Vegetarian option only vegan. Vegan price is same as the meet one that comes with egg as well. And if you want to make a vegetarian option you have to pay extra charge. Over all experience not as good.
author: Milos L.

description:
This is more of a review for the service rather than the food:
We were seated rather quickly, but were not able to try the food. It was strange because some people who ordered AFTER us got their food way BEFORE us. No, we didn't get anything usual, just their typical ramen. We asked even asked the waiter about what happened to our food and he said "5 more minutes." Maybe they lost our order? We left after waiting over 40 minutes for 2 bowls of ramen.. l
author: Leesur S.

description: This is the best vegan ramen I've ever had. The broth is thick and delicious. Their pork broth is also incredible. AAAAA++++++ would buy from again
author: Adam H.

description:
Mmm. This raman is so good! There's always a wait at this place, but it's so worth it. I got the Kakuni Kotteri and the broth was delicious, the noodles were delicious and the kakuni (pork) was delicious. One bowl was perfect to keep me warm and fill me up. The flavors are so good and everything is cooked perfectly.

Overall, one of my favorite ramen places to eat at.
author: Sophia Y.

description: Our favorite ramen restaurant and always love our meal. We have tried many alternatives and always come back as it's the gold standard.
author: Dean B.

description:
I came here to try out their spicy ramen. According to my friend, they offer really spicy also tasty ramen. Lots of customers came here only to challenge theirselves with the most spicy level ramen.

Apparently I am not ready for letting my stomach burning for a week. Thus I started with a level 4 spicy ramen. It was good. Lots of good ingredients including a gigantic piece of pork and one egg cut into halves. The base soup without spicies is already super delicious. With the help of the spicies, the whole flavor became very special. The noodle is also different from the normal one you normally get. It's much thinner and bouncy. I would not say I always prefer this type but it is surly a new experience.

The only downside is the waiting time. We waited about one hour outside the restaurant and another hour for our food to come. That's kinda weird among restaurants in JTown.
author: Xian S.

description:
We had lunch here instead of going to Waraku again and I regret not returning to Waraku.

I ordered the Yamadaya shio. The noodle portion was small and the noodle themselves really thin, like somen; the meat was plentiful but it was 95% fat (gross), and the broth was really rich with fat globules throughout. The soft cooked egg was perfect though.

Overall, not impressed and I would not return.
author: Bella L.

description: This review is for the Hell Ramen. Now, I'm more of an udon girl myself but I really enjoyed the hell ramen. It had habanero and scotch bonnet peppers in the broth. It got me really sweating from the heat when I went in Oct. 2017. There is one more ramen that is more spicy called Death Ramen if you want more. I also tried the broth for one of the tonkotsu ramen. It was very rich and flavorful. I'd come back for the hell ramen.
author: Kam Z.

description: Although I had an almost spiritual ramen experience, my more seasoned ramen eating family did not like the ramen at all. They complained that the soup was greasy and a big piece of pig fat was inserted inappropriately. I ordered the house ramen whereas they ordered other flavors. To be safe, order the house special ramen. Another possible difference in experience may be that I tend to like soups and veggies over the actual ramen noodles (whereas my family likes the noodles).
author: Esther C.

description:
When this place first opened, I remember their service being pretty good and the food was decent. It isn't my favourite ramen place but good enough that I've been back a few times. My most recent visit has left me wondering if ownership had changed due to the quality of food and service. 

My boyfriend got some chicken that tasted like it had gone bad in his bowl and my pork belly was sour. When we told the server, she gave us an attitude, saying there's no reason the chicken should taste funny. I mean - no sh** it shouldn't but it did. One of the other servers kept moving my boyfriend's cup of water away from him to the other side of the table when we clearly had plenty of room. It was as all rather odd. I don't think I'll be back anytime soon.
author: Patricia L.

description:
I do not get why this place is not rated higher. I love Yamadaya because you can get your ramen spicy! My tip is to ask for the spicy paste on the side and then you can add to your own preference. This is one of my go to spots. Perfect place to visit if you are in Japantown. 

This service is good. They are typically pretty busy, but the servers will answer all of your questions regarding the different types of ramen. 

FYI it is located upstairs
author: Jennifer A.

description: It's SO rare to find a good vegan ramen.... but holy smokes there vegan Ramen is HANDS DOWN one of the BEST!!! So flavorful! I can't wait to go again soon!
author: Melody S.

description:
Used to like this place, but my latest visit was disappointing.

POOR SERVICE: previously, service was neutral, but had a bad experience this last visit. The older wait staff were a little short and rude with us and not particularly helpful.

OK FOOD, SOME QUALITY ISSUES: I used to like the food here, but this time, my ramen was mediocre. The broth wasn't hot, which made the experience lukewarm. The chicken charsiu in my dish had gone bad and was sour. I told the lady about it, and she was grumpy and defensive about the quality of their chicken. She claimed that they make everything fresh, but I said that it might the issue with their refrigeration, and she agreed. I asked to switch the meat for eggs, and she was nice about that.

Shame about this experience, because I will unlikely come again, with many other decent food options in the vicinity.
author: Raph T.

description: My food, my boyfriend's food, and my friend's food was all luke warm when it was served to us. The service was also unpleasant as the waiters would answer our questions with an attitude.
author: Melanie M.

description: The long-ish waits aren't worth it here.  The ramen's okay, and the karaage is okay.  I wish I could give it 4-stars, but I just can't bring myself to it.  It's a 3-star joint.
author: Andrew P.

description:
Every time we come here, the service staff is different and the prices keep going up.  The service is always inconsistent and so is the food.  Last night was it for us when they can't even get the gyoza right.  I believe it's the owner or manager that brought it out.  It was not even browned on the bottom and they were all stuck together.  It was doughy/sticky and very soft so I politely told the server.  The newly cooked gyoza came out and we were puzzled because it came out deep fried.

I'm all about giving feedback to the restaurant but we are not going back so I didn't bother.  There are plenty of ramen joints to explore.
author: danny m.

description: This is probably one of my favorite ramen places in the city! That is saying a lot in itself since San Francisco has some of the best ramen joints in most of America! The service is amazing and they are super accommodating to making sure your food is just the way you like it. For instance the spice level was a little spicier than I expected so not only did the manager get me another milder bowl of ramen but also let me keep the original one so I could mix it up. They also have very reasonable prices and a huge quantity!  My favorite dish here is the spicy miso ramen and they have 3 spice levels to choose from!
author: Natasha M.

description: I tried the yamadaya ramen and I enjoyed the meal. The staff was also very nice, fun, and accommodating for 8 people. However, I got food poisoning a couple hours later after my dinner at this restaurant. I've never had food poisoning like that in my life until this. Also, I wish they would give more noodles and less meat in their dishes. I would've totally come back to this place if I didn't get such bad food poisoning.
author: Jina B.

description: Service here is slow. Wish I was writing to say how good the ramen is... but it's not. Worst tasting ramen I've ever had. The noodles were good, but that's about it. I'm no ramen expert, but I've had from various restaurants- including ones in japan. This place was an utter disappointment.
author: Cris C.

description: We ordered the spicy edamame, fried chicken, and ramen with chicken. The food was delicious. I highly recommend this place. Great ambiance, great service, perfect company and yummy food.
author: Moon S.

description: My first time trying ramen in a restaurant. Got the tonkatsu yamadaya spicy,  broth is thick and flavorful. Im not use to the  smell of porky broth but the flavor is rich and level 1 spicy isnt hot.
author: On T.

description:
savory broth + DIY garlic crusher = awesome f*ing soup + noodles not chewy but served slightly al dente = my kinda ramen joint!

Lines do form so I can't say it's fast but it's definitely affordable. Location is authentic as possible (across the street from the pagoda), and it's next to the giant garage, no hate from this Japanese loving Chinese dude. There's a reason this second floor joint is packed and the ground floor place is always empty.

Pro Tip - GARLIC, add tons of that sh*t! And order the fried chicken on the side, just in case.

Random tidbit I learned from a Japanese homie, places that end with "Ya" are typically family/clan businesses, with recipes passed down through the ages. Usually a safe deal breaker if you can't decide between 2 ramen joints.
author: Roger L.

description:
Small wait time on the weekends, but the line moves fast.  

Had the Yamadaya special with thick noodles, it's a great choice and satisfied my craving.  Portion wise, it's small.  I finished the whole bowl, which usually doesn't happen. They're extra generous with pork and all toppings.

My only complaint is the poor ventilation.  It gets really hot up there.

$28.00 for two.
author: Angelica C.

description:
Nice ramen spot with really good food and ambiance. I got here at 5pm on a Saturday and only had to wait like 10 minutes. However if you get here at 6pm prepared to wait at least 30 minutes, there was a HUGE line at that point. 

Green Tea - the green tea here is actually green. Dark green... the way its supposed to be and its only $1. 

Kotteri Ramen (5/5) - $9.75 - This was very good, maybe one of the most flavorful ramen broths I've had. You can tell that they really do cook their broth for 20 hours as advertised. I liked that the pieces of pork weren't overly fatty and the noodles were cooked perfectly. Unlike other ramen places, the ramen here comes with 1/2 an egg that is seasoned. 

Spicy tuna combo with salad (5/5) - $4.50 (?)- slightly cooked tuna over rice had really good flavor. Nice to eat this alongside the ramen since the ramen can get heavy at times. 

Extras to your ramen are also really affordable - an extra egg only costs $1.

I would definitely come back here!
author: Sheena N.

description: 10/10 would recommend!!! A fun and laid back environment with good beer and a friendly staff!
author: Maryann Y.

description:
We loved the food but the seating area was off.  The door man closed the door in front of us when he called us to come in.   Seriously?   He was in a hurry.    He kept going and we were left outside.   Bad door man manners.   
When I asked to change the sitting area because we were only two they said they could not because the tablets by the windows were for larger groups.   Well I saw group of two sitting by the windows.   We were told to sit in the middle of the restaurant.  A large tablet with ten sitting areas.   I am not going back to that restaurant.   Stupid sitting area.    
Rude.
author: Sandra L.

description:
Been here multiple times before but very disappointed at this last visit.  LOng wait in the cold outside area despite several empty tables inside.

Main complaint is quality of pork, especially for $14 a bowl.  YEs I ordered pork belly ramen but 3 of the 5 pieces of pork were pure fat, not even a sliver of meat.  This should not be served to customers. Soup was very greasy - total artery clogger.

Service lackluster and slow.  Definitely not the place I remember or want to run back to.
author: J H.

description:
Sub-par ramen.  Came here over the weekend and it was nothing but downhill. The wait was too long, not because it was busy, but because they had issues with the orders printers. No worries, but that was a sure sign of the downhill.

After ordering, I asked for a glass of water, as they only place 1 glass of 2 on the table. After waiting, I asked again when the waiter brought my partner his drink.  After waiting 5 minutes, I ended up going to another server who was filling glasses of water for one.   It was delivered one after that.

When the ramen came out it was a disappointment. Smaller in quantity from other ramen the same price. I ordered the ramen with the black garlic oil. Yet after I started eating it, I noticed there was no garlic oil.   The pork was a good size of belly in the ramen, but overall the taste didn't win me over. I found it bland and lacking in flavor.

Happy I came here to try, but won't come back.  The service was bad and food not great tasting. Keep on searching ramen friends.
author: Marck N.

description:
Tough.

This came to mind when I thought of Yamadaya unfortunately.  We've known the restaurant from it's prior iteration as the "upstairs Japanese place" that had nice views of the Buchanan Street mall, but unexceptional food - in it's current incarnation as Yamadaya it is better but still not something to dream about.

Waiting area is gritty if you make it into the actual waiting area, otherwise you're camped out on the stairs.  Being seated at the big communal table was surprisingly OK but not happy-making.  Food was OK, got the Spicy Ramen with chashu...guess I'm not a big fan of the straight ramen noodles, prefer curly for the texture.

Curry rice, a small bowl, came with the combo I ordered, it was good though not as good as the splendiferous one at Dojima-An at Union Square.  Service was adequate though the dishes came out slow starting with the ramen and had to wait a while for everything else.  Very crowded busy place.

Probably would not come back...much prefer also Ramen Shalala across the way.
author: Alan O.

description: Long wait to get in. Long wait for the food. And OMIGOD WAS IT WORTH IT. I had the spicy... shoot, I forget. Spicy miso? I can't recall exactly. But it had a lot of pork in it. It was absolutely delicious, I've never tasted anything like it. I didn't know a food that came in a bowl could be so stick-to-your-ribs. I was in a wonderful food coma by the time I was done. I will be back.
author: David K.

description: Been here several times. Always consistent.  The dashi amd noodles are always delicious!
author: Koichi S.

description: Love it here. Little bit of a wait but organized enough that you always get seated fast. Great portions and amazing atmosphere. Skip the downstairs and go up the stairs to ramen heaven ;)
author: Carly A.

description: This was an okay spot. My boyfriend and I waited maybe 10 or 20mins before they seated us in the middle of the center table. Mind you, there was alot of open spaces in the center before any other person sat down. After we sat down, ordered 2 Tonkotsu ramen and fried callamari.The Tonkotsu ramen had alot of flavor and it was very rich. However, it was really oily and hard to drink. They put alot of meat and sides to make the ramen flavorful, but it's quite expensive. $14 for a ramen is alot before adding anything to it. Fast service once youre seated down, but very long wait.It felt more like a bar in a dark atmosphere. Its overhyped in the area.Not a good place for tourists like my boyfriend and I to try out
author: Ann L.

description: Wish I took a picture of the meal but the ramen was great. As a cook at a ramen shop, their ramen is definitely savory and delicious. The chashu and kakuni melt in your mouth and the Spicy Miso is a must try. The calamari was a little undercooked and I wish it was more crispier. Other than that, the atmosphere is lively and filled with good vibes. The corner booths are a little dark but decent. Would give a 4.2 if that was an option.
author: Michael L.

description:
Been here twice and it's by far one of my favorite restaurants to get ramen at in SF. It's a little bit on the pricey side ($11-13) for a bowl of ramen, but it sure does hit the spot. For what it's worth, their ramen always has huge portions. It has thin ramen noodles, which I'm a fan of. This joint is perfect for rainy and cold days. It gets very crowded during rush hour. 

SERVICE: It took us about 10 minutes to get seated after we were waiting in line. The friendly server took orders for drinks and checked in occasionally to make sure the experience is enjoyable. Our food took about 10-15 minutes to get served. 

SETTING: It's tucked away on top of the shabu restaurant in Japantown, really easy to spot. It's very dimly lit inside but still has a cozy feeling. There are booths around the outside and a large table where everyone is seated together in the middle that has a centerpiece of cute lil succulents. Also has additional tables lining the sides for smaller parties. On every table, there's two boxes that have spices in them so make sure to add the spices they have available if you're needing that extra kick in your food!

FOOD: I tried the Yamadaya Shio ($13) which is the basic salt-based pork ramen. It came with kakuni pork (fatty pork belly), chashu pork, wood ear mushroom, menma, dried seaweed, and a dash of green onion on top. The broth is so rich and flavorful, which is one of the things I love about this place. Some ramen places have clear and watery broth but it is evident that this restaurant puts some love into theirs. It also comes with a perfectly runny soft boiled egg, and is piled on with delicious and fatty kakuni pork.
I also had the Yamadaya Koterri ($13) another time I went, which is rich and fatty ramen with black garlic oil. The only point I would have to make about this is that it is very strong in garlic flavor from the big chunks of garlic that's added in it. The garlic oil didn't add too much flavor either. Other than that, a filling and flavorful bowl. 

Overall, Ramen Yamadaya is on the pricer side compared to some places I've been to but is worth it in the end. I definitely have to try their karaage in the future.
author: Anne P.

description:
How disappointing!!!   It's no longer the authentic Japanese Ramen restaurant.  It is either under new management or the business sold to a non Japanese operation.  The restaurant no longer has the Japanese ambiance.  There are no Japanese workers anywhere including the cooks.  

After signing on the waiting list, a hurried Pilipino man with a heavy Tagalog accent calling out size of parties to fill the available tables instead of calling customers by name in the order they came.  HIs only interest is to maximize filling in the tables regardless of who came first.  For an example, we were a party of three that was passed up for a party of four even though we were next in line.  

Then we were waited on by a Pilipino woman again with a heavy Tagalog accent that was barely understandable.   My wife ordered green tea as we do in every Japanese restaurant.  The waitress brought my wife a cup with loose green tea leaves in hot water.  The tea did not have the robust green tea flavor as it was not steep in a tea pot.  

Our food was delivered by a younger tall Pilipino man with an attitude.  The Ramen definitely was not the same quality as before.  The noodle has the texture of a Chinese Won Ton noodle.  The Tonkatsu broth is not creamy and smooth as before.  Instead, the broth is heavy with oil and soybean paste.  Tonkatsu broth should be a nice creamy bone broth.  The Gyoza was extremely oily and mushy, it fell apart as you tried to pick it up with chop sticks.  There must be an abundance of MSG in the foods, we were dying of thirst before we reached our car after leaving the restaurant.  

We asked the Pilipino server/manager what happened to the former Japanese long time waitresses.  He replied with an arrogance that he fired them all !!!! Wow!

Now, I understand why there were no Japanese patrons dining there as it had before.  Thankfully, there are many other authentic Japanese restaurants to choose from in SF Japan town.  The next time I'm in SF, I will absolutely not return to Ramen Yamadaya.   I missed the former Ramen Yamadaya who treated customers with proper Japanese etiquette and of course, their food.
author: Stan W.

description: My friends and I were craving ramen for the longest time so we ended up here. The venue was relatively big. We waited for about 20min for a table of 4. I got the yamadaya shoyu ramen. The ramen and broth was good, but I did not like the egg and the pork was pretty fatty and think. Overall, it was ok.
author: Tiffany W.

description: I've been many ramen places. This is the first time that I'm writing a review. The worst ramen and gyoza I've ever had in Yamadaya in Japan town. The soup was too much oily cuz of plenty of fatty pork, and the gyoza was worse than frozen food. It was dinner time, so they put mandatory tips at least 18%. It's just waste of time and money. I won't go there again.
author: B. L.

description: Best ramen I have had in a while. They have one in San Diego, but this place makes the ramen a bit better. I like how it's located upstairs, it makes you feel more upscale. The booths are comfy and can fit 4-6 people. Our server was great! There's sometimes a wait, so I'm warning you inpatient people now (;
author: Cinnie T.

description: Really long wait times so you have to get there well before time and out your name down on the waitlist. Food was delicious. The takoyaki was especially good. The wait staff were polite. They made a mistake with our bill and forgot to add the takoyaki. Our server was so nice that he let us have that free despite us offering to pay for it in a separate bill.
author: Dipti K.

description:
Pretty solid ramen! We were lucky enough to get seated right away since we came right when it opened. We ordered the chicken kara-age for an appetizer and I got the Yamadaya Spicy ramen (level 6, which is called "Death Ramen", haha). 

The chicken kara-age was really good, but maybe a little bit oily. It came with a really nice sauce: maybe some kind of mayo? Definitely creamy. I think maybe a more tart/acidic sauce would have been better so that it's not too heavy. 

The "Death Ramen" was just normal ramen with a huge dollop of chili paste (that you have to pay an extra $1 for...). The broth is really really rich, almost a little too thick. I wish I could have gotten a little more broth to slurp with the noodles but I guess the broth is the expensive part. I got a LOT of meat with my ramen so I guess the price is sort of justified. The noodles are good too! A thinner type of noodle than I'm used to for ramen but they were nice and chewy. 

Overall pretty good but I wouldn't wait too long for it.
author: Melissa H.

description: They were able to make a gluten free ramen bowl. They even remade my bowl when I went to pick it up because I wasn't able to order gluten free noodles on the app. Excellent customer service and great food! Anyone looking for gluten free ramen, look no more!
author: Chelsea D.

description:
With so many ramen shops in SF, it's difficult for me to keep track of which ones I want to try next, despite bookmarking them.
