In the midst of exploring the Japanese Cherry Blossom Festival a few weekends ago, a lunch visit to one of my bookmarked ramen shops, in this case Ramen Yamadaya, seemed appropriate. The wait for a party of two was quite lengthy, roughly 30 minutes, but may have been partially due to the crowd during the festival weekend.

I tried the tonkotsu kotteri, which was very rich, heavy, and flavorful from the 20-hour stewed pork bone broth (tonkotsu). Kotteri means rich or heavy, so they put the rendered pork fat back into the broth, thus yielding a thick, creamy, bold-flavored base to the bowl of ramen. It was a bit too much for me, so I couldn't finish all the broth. But if you love the idea of drinking fat, by all means give the kotteri style a try. I'll just stick to the regular tonkotsu next time.

The ramen noodles are on the thin side, but still have a nice al dente bite. The chasu was decent, though a bit tough and chewy. The pork belly was more flavorful, smokey, and fatty. But the standout ingredient I was most pleased with was the salty, gooey, medium-cooked egg. I was also taken by surprise that I received a whole egg, as several other ramen places offer only half.

Service is very quick, and the restaurant, although small, had a speedy turnaround time for serving hungry customers. I'll definitely give Ramen Yamadaya another try, hopefully when there's no festival in the neighborhood.
author: Priscilla W.

description:
First, can I say that I LOVED that the night I was there the music was all hip hop, rap, and R&B. Trap Queen by Fetty Wap came on and my life was complete, just for a moment. 

Ok, now on to the food. 

For the first time in forever, I tried a chicken ramen in a soy flavored broth. I normally order pork. 

The portion was definitely smaller than most ramen places given the price. If you are terribly hungry, I would suggest ordering more from the menu.

I found the broth to be balanced between savory and salty. The fried chicken pieces were moist, and the crispy exteriors held up to the broth. The noodles were also thicker, and held up well. Surprisingly, there was no jammy egg, which would have made the dish a bit better in my opinion. 

In the end it's a little pricey given the portion, but very delicious. I look forward to going back to try more of their menu when I am in the city.
author: Nathan K.

description:
I've been in this place three times and ordered twice to-go, and it doesn't DISAPPOINT. 

Let's start with the main event: the ramen. The pork is tender, delicate and juice while the ramen it's fine as fine a noodles go - a thin, not overly eggy, noodle with a mild wheat flavor. The real star here is the broth. The broth is rich and creamy with just enough spices and earthy flavors that meet you upfront and firmly shake your hand. It's utterly addicting. 

The place itself is actually small, which is why sometimes it can get busy. They have a communal table in the middle which some people like, but could be a bit cramped unless your party takes a whole edge. Be prepared for a wait if you hit the rush. 

Service is average. The servers are nice enough and are mostly busy trying to turn tables, and ,as some one who values privacy and quiet, since I am not fond of chatty service, I'm not knocking points for that. 

I highly recommend this place if you need a comfortable place to try.
author: Javier H.

description: The WORST service. You can only order for delivery until 2:30pm & I ordered it at 1 and it took two and a half hours to get to our hotel. The hotel is 1 mi. from this place. Our soup came cold (mind you there is no microwave in our hotel) & he forgot our pork dumplings. When we tried to call back to let him know, his phone seemed to be off service AND the stores number was not working either. By that time they stop delivery and the store closed so yeah. We got jipped. NEVER get delivery from this place. So unprofessional.
author: Adanna K.

description: We came here for lunch on a Friday. Waited about 5 minutes before we were seated, service was quick and friendly. The Yamadaya ramen was delicious, rich broth with a generous portion of charsu. Come here with an empty belly because one bowl will fill you up!
author: Lily L.

description: Great place to dine. This was my second time going there, Ramen was good, Service was slow.
author: Helen H.

description:
After shopping in the mall in Japantown on a Saturday night we were looking for a restaurant that didn't have a super long line and a place that served ramen.  We went upstairs to see how long the wait would be as there was already 15 people waiting but we didn't get an answer.  We checked out some other restaurants and ended up back here and put our name on the list.  We waited by the open window which offered a nice breeze.  The wait was about 30 minutes so not too bad.

There are some booths along the side of the window and then tables with chairs that are pretty close to each other.  It took a few minutes for us to decide what to have and we were approached 3 times by servers to see if we were ready to order.  I decided on the tonkotsu ramen for $9.25 and we shared 6 gyoza for $4.45.  The food came out quickly and the food was hot.

Was it good? Yes. But there was one or two pork slices and I like my protein.  Lots of carb but wish I got a meal with more meat.  We were in and out pretty quick as most people seemed to be.  There wasn't much of a wait when we left so the line moves pretty quickly.
author: Violet P.

description:
It's located on the second floor with a large island seating and then surrounded by either booths or tables. Some of the booths face the window so I thought it'd be nice to enjoy a meal there. We were directed to sit by the island and when I made the request, was told that those were for groups of 4. Fine. It was the only 2 booths left by the window. While other booths had two's by the side of the restaurant, they weren't by the window. I didn't feel like arguing then. 

I picked hell ramen and was asked if I'm aware that it's spicy. I guess there are different kinds of spicy. This kind is more of an oily base so it's not like instant, but will linger. The ramen was just alright. There were a lot of meat tho, really fatty but I couldn't finish most of it. The eggs are slightly soft boiled and it somehow didn't do anything for me.

Then get this: 2 people were seated by the booth that I wanted. And by the time I finished my meal, another party of 2 were seated by the window booths! WTF. Do I just have a persona of   getting rejected??! Anyway, the island in the middle of the restaurant was basically my party of two, and one other person in the corner of the island. I'm just so disappointed why they refused my request specifically but allowed others to seat in what was suppose to be reserved for parties of four. I bet those 2 two's didn't even request the booth! gah!

For the record, I like the decor. The island in the middle has succulents in the center and it looks really zen. The chopsticks and containers of peppers and spices were all made of wood. So it looks really peaceful and minimal. But you know what I'd rather like to see? The sunshine from a window seat.

For the ramen, I'm not used to this type of spice so it took me some time getting used to it. They also have good portions for the meat and they are tender but could be juicer.
author: Lana W.

description:
This is a busy and very authentic Ramen restaurant located in the heart of Japantown SF.
Excellent food served with a very friendly attitude. We loved it. The Kara-age is exceptional.
author: Morten G.

description:
I'm always on the search for good ramen and I am definitely a fan of this place! There was no wait on a weekend afternoon and the service was friendly and quick. Note it's on the second floor of the building.

I ordered the Tonkatsu Ramen ($8). The broth was very flavorful and the thin noodles were perfect. I really liked that the egg was gooey and still not fully cooked. The serving size is reasonable - I was full afterwards but didn't feel like I had too much sodium like some other places.

Overall recommend Ramen Yamadaya if you're Japantown!
author: Linda X.

description:
Horrendous service!! Especially the guy who took charge of the line.
The food quality is pretty good but the increasing bad service made me post this review. Also, there are other ramen options in Japan town offering equal or better food. Try those.
author: Han Y.

description:
Amazing vegan ramen! Blew my mind. Very popular place. Expect a wait during busy times. Tasty Japanese IPA went well with the ramen.

The vegan ramen miso sesame broth was rich and flavorable and the additions of spinach, arugula, corn, bamboo shoots and mushrooms was delightful.

It's a nice place. Some community seating. A young crowd. Definitely a favorite find!
author: Vegan C.

description: Came back to this place yesterday after almost 2 years and oh my god has it gotten worse! That broth was bad it tasted almost bitter and grainy and the pork was tough it's supposed to melt in your mouth. I've had really good ramen in my trips to Japan and Hong Kong damn even Berkeley lol but this was just a huge disappointment. As for service I was seated and after 25 mins no one came to give us water or take our order so we had to wave over a lady to take our order. She was ok she seemed annoyed. 2 stars for the gyoza and edamame they were good.
author: Kalel T.

description: I used to love this place. Now, they're trying to be more like Marufuku and not doing a great job of it. The egg is cold. The music is too loud and the service is not ideal. If you like top 40s blasting then this is the place for you.
author: Michelle L.

description:
To quickly sum my experience here, the ramen was great. I got the Yamadaya Shio Ramen, & the thin noodles and the broth are the main reasons it's getting a 3/5.

The reason it's lower than what it could've been was because my girlfriend and I got there when it opened, maybe like the 5th people there, and they completely forgot about our order. We waited about 30 minutes while other people who arrived got their food first. It was disappointing as the price rounded to around $26-27 without the tip and no complimentary pass for waiting so long! 

Will I come back? Probably not, as I've had better ramen in other places. Got to account for bad parking as well.
author: Kevin N.

description:
Ramen was remarkable, extremely tasty! The wait was long but worth it!
They even have vegan ramen which tasted amazing and perfect for me. Very tasty with a good portion!
author: Tina L.

description:
We ordered ramen with the kakuni pork belly and it looked nothing like the pictures on Yelp.  It tasted like beef, not heart attack inducing fatty pork.  That was a huge disappointment.  We ordered 2 of them and the waiter told us later on that they ran out and we got the last one.  However, I believe that tried to pass it off as pork belly because I know for sure it was beef.  It didn't have pork skin, the texture was that of beef and tasted like beef.  So sad.  When we asked if it was pork, they told us that it just tasted different because it was marinated in soy sauce.  REALLY???????  

Also, we ordered chicken karaage and it never came.  The waitress gave it to the table that arrived 10 minutes after us and we asked about it twice and was told it was coming, but never did.  We decided to cancel it after waiting.  At least the waitress apologized for the mistake and removed it from our order.  After we paid, they packed us some karaage to take home.  

I was really excited to try this place and what a disappointment it was.  Even the party next to us had issues with their orders.
author: Rachel L.

description:
Boyfriend and I have frequented here many times and we've always been satisfied (I might have owed them 4 stars in the past). Sadly, our last visit here was not on the same par. To make a long story short: despite getting sat first out of three other parties at our communal table, our order got taken last, our food came a 30min after theirs, and our water cups sat mostly empty despite our ramen being way more spicy than normal. Although I'm normally forgiving of such situations, having been a server myself in the past, we were upset that our server there was unapologetic and didn't take any time to check in with us or to let us know our food was on its way. She must have even avoided making eye contact with us as we tried so many times to flag her down. 

They did recently change their menu (or at least its format), making it clearer and easier to order what you want, but another question I have is: did the spiciness levels change as well? We consistently order the same thing (and at the same spice level) but this time it was just unbelievably hot. We had to order extra broth which also took another 10 minutes after a miscommunication with our server, and she still had nothing to say... no discount on the bill was offered either - obviously we didn't expect one but it would've been the right thing to do at a service-oriented restaurant. We still tipped the full amount, considering other staff members there were useful. 

I'd say this experience was almost unforgivable considering the ways the situation could have been fixed. Just about everything that could've gone wrong went wrong, and I'm afraid we will have to find a new go-to ramen place in the city.
author: Liz C.

description:
For a $14 ramen it was disappointing... soup was horrible tasted funky.

Service was crappy... asked for some extra mayo never got it!

No one even cared about the customers. 

I definitely wont be coming back ever. 

Worst $50 bucks ever spent, you should check out the Japan center across the street a lot of good food options!
author: John F.

description: The ramen here is delicious. I had the vegan ramen and it did not disappoint. The broth was thick and savory. The service was meh, but service isn't something I look for.
author: Andrew R.

description:
For someone who really isn't a huge fan of ramen, this place blew me away. I didn't read any Yelp reviews or look this place up on Yelp so I wasn't aware of the low health rating. But even so, this place exceeded all my expectations. 

For starters, the ramen here is a lot more affordable than other places I've been to. It's mostly $9.95 with the exception of that special one for $12.95. The bowls are freaking huge as well so portion sizes are decent. For $3.95 more, you can get an add on bowl of rice with curry or rice with spicy roe. And lemme just tell you that bowl is large! 

I had the shoyu ramen and it was cooked so well. The meat was really generous and the noodles are a bit thinner than ramen I've encountered before. But nevertheless, it was delicious. 

The waiters are really nice and helpful. They're pretty difficult to flag down but when you do, they provide amazing service. 

Despite the low health rating, I haven't gotten sick yet and it's been about 24 hours. I would definitely go back (and that's saying a lot from someone who never wants ramen)!
author: April Z.

description: Used to be my favorite Raman in the city. It was different tonight. Different menu, different noodles, different vibe. Hope it was just an off night. Tonight was a 3, normally it's a 5. Averaging out to a 4 and will try again soon.
author: Tina H.

description:
I came here with my friend, and the servers did not want to accommodate me needs when I asked him if I could sit in another table because I was wearing a short dress and the chair was too cold, they had a table with warmer seats, but he said that that table was for a party of four even though a couple was sitting in the same table right next to it. He did give me another chair from another table, but the restaurant was empty, so I did not understand what the big deal was. Anyway, so I order my food, and he puts in the order. I noticed that as I was waiting for the food, the kitchen staff kept looking at me and the server kept looking at me and my friend. When food arrived, I was worried that they might have spat in the food or put something nasty in it. I look at them and they continue to stare at me with very strange looks. As I was eating, I noticed that the server (a chunky Asian man) kept staring at my friend and I, and then he pretends to put on a smile as if he knew something that I didn't know, he kept staring at my friend eating and her food. It was very strange, and I had a strong feeling that they did something to the food. I WAS SO SCARED! I work in the food industry and I know that the servers are not people that you can ever reason with, I see them doing some nasty shit, but there is really nothing that anyone can do about it because they are nasty entitled people that just don't give a shit, so I knew that I could have been dealing with such a person. 
My friend didn't want to give a tip as she also felt something off, I wanted to give a tip but only out of extreme fear, but now I am happy that we did not tip as it would really not be right to be tipping them for harming us and putting shit in our food. Needless to say, I will never be back as I was scared the whole I was eating here. I do not understand why he had such an interest in watching us eat and our food, he kept a close eye on our plates and kept looking at us eating and putting the food in the mouth, while the kitchen staff stared at us as well. 
Btw, their ramen is MEH. 
Scary people...please do not mess with people's food, that's nasty and evil.

Thank you
author: Sam T.

description: This is my favorite restaurant in Japan Town! I love it here, the ambiance is loud and comfortable! They have melon soda ( low key over priced,bc you can get it at the pacific supermarket for 1.50$ but that's not the point.) I love the Nanban chicken, it's so good! Like something I never tried before! I very much love how flavored the chicken is. Very well seasoned! The calamari is to die for! Very buttery and well seasoned! For the ramen , it was my first time, I'm not a fan of ramen. So I can't judge if it's good or not
author: Ludy M.

description:
Came here with kids who have severe egg allergies. Horrible service. The adults' food came very quickly. The kids' dish (which, by the way, was just a bowl of white rice and some meat, MUCH less complicated than ramen) took the entire meal to come. We specified that the kids' dish should come first, as they're barely 2 years old and get fussy when they're hungry. We also asked if the dish contains eggs, as the kids are allergic to eggs. The waitress said there were no eggs. When the dish is served, at the END of out meal, it has mayonnaise all over it. We were furious. The waitress, after we complain to her, walks by and tells her colleagues that we didn't specify not to include the mayonnaise. Excuse me, but you are a FOOD SERVER! You should KNOW that mayonnaise contains eggs! We had to talk to another waiter in order to get the correct order - which only took five minutes to make and serve. That waitress needs to not only learn to do her job properly, but take allergies, especially kids' allergies, seriously. If we hadn't noticed the mayonnaise in that dish and fed it to our kids they could've had a very serious reaction. 

tldr; don't come here with anyone that has allergies. Food came extremely late for two little kids and when it finally was served, was not edible because of their allergy.
author: Phoebe L.

description: The ramen broth does not good at all. Not even close to the flavor that should be. Adding spicy just kill the flavor of ramen. Noodle is not good quality at all. Do not recommend thus place.
author: Simon K.

description: This is one of my favorite ramen spots in SF. The wait is never too long and the service is always fast. The ramen is always great and the staff is friendly. My go-to is the ramen Yamada-ya Shio with corn and extra porn belly!
author: Daniee T.

description: I got the fire ramen. It was fire. So good. So spicy though. I couldn't finish it. I couldn't stop eating. Vibe was cool too.
author: Bernardino O.

description: Door man was very nice. He the one who noticed us sit there. MEAN waitress good luck, very very rude service. We had to ask for waters after looking at all the other tables sit after us get service. Maybe she figured we didn't tip well because we had our son with us. Just be carful on poor service. Go to Walmart and buy a package of Raman and save some money! Why do people take tips for granted??? Don't get me wrong any and everyone wants free things that's not what we want. We just want the people to know it is not right to treat people in this business how ever they want.
author: Mr T T.

description:
Just came here earlier tonight with a friend. We were walking around Japantown and were looking for some dinner options. I actually might not have tried it because it's Yelp review is pretty mediocre, but my friend comes here pretty often and says that the line is really long so that was good enough for me.

We came around 6pm on a Sunday night and were lucky enough to only have to wait for about five minutes. When we left around 7, the line definitely was getting pretty long. 

I got the yamadaya tonkotsu ramen. Good stuff! Actually one of the better bowls of ramen that I've had in the area. One tricky thing that I experience with ramen is significant diminishing marginal utility when I have more and more of the bowl. With every bowl of ramen, I always think it's really delicious when I first start. With this bowl of ramen, I thought it was delicious and also managed to finish the thing without getting sick of it.

Noodles are of the thin variety though you have the option of getting thick noodles for an extra fifty cents. Though I would normally go for thick, thin ones are better for soaking in the flavor of the soup. I liked the yamdaya because basically it had all your add ins done for you so you didn't need to customize anything. You can also just build your own bowl of ramen i that floats your boat. 

Thin noodles were chewy and flavorful. Soup was rich but not too heavy which was great and also not too fatty. Yamadaya is a bit similar to Orenchi in the sense that they also do the simmering pork bones for 20 hours, but unlike the Orenchi broth, this one isn't super fatty. It's definitely on the thicker side though. Their ajitama!! It's definitely marinated in something so it gives you some nice flavor right there too which was great. The yamadaya comes with so much freaking meat. Pork belly slices, pork belly chunks oh lord, I was drowning in the pork. I didn't want that much meat so I probably should have just customized but if you like your meat, I highly recommend the yamadaya.
 
Final price post tip was about $14 dinner which I think is pretty decent for a good bowl of ramen. This place also has tsukemen which is really exciting to me because I haven't found many places in the Bay Area that offer tuskemen so I'll definitely be back to give that a try. The one potential con for the average person is that the portions are a bit small. I'm an Asian girl so I don't eat much, but I could see someone easily being hungry since the bowls are tiny. 

tldr; good ramen place in Japantown! not sure how long I would want to actually wait for it, but objectively a very solid bowl of ramen with little to complain about. come early to avoid lines!
author: Jasmine X.

description: My whole family went to that store yesterday. We ordered ramen, takoyaki, taiyaki. When we came back my wife and me have been vomiting all night. Will not recommend this store from now on.
author: Jiaming L.

description:
The food was mostly okay taste wise, but the service was just bad. 

The ramen was pretty okay, the pork was majorly fatty (as in a piece of fat with meat mixed in and not a piece of meat with fat on it) but the broth was serviceable. For the katsu curry they had a nice amount of meat but I did hear complaints that there wasn't much sauce and it was mostly potato. 

Service is where the low stars come from. We were seated 15-20 minutes before getting orders taken and getting water, it usually took 10 mins and 2 servers to ask for anything, and getting our check was oddly complicated. We tried to pay with cash then card and one server alerted us (after we noticed) that the other server may have "forgotten" some of the cash for our payment and tried to charge us more. Go if you want the okay food but the speed and helpfulness you'll get it at is a coin toss.
author: Mark O.

description:
The ramen here is good but my complaint is that the pork belly has way too much fat. Like, you'll get pieces with NO MEAT on it.. Just pure fat.

The Tonkotsu Kotteri is rich and flavorful; I'd drink all the broth if I wasn't so full!

Fair warning, if you get the Tonkotsu Spicy ramen, be careful which one you order! If you can handle habarnero, get the hell ramen. Death will kill you.
author: Nance W.

description:
According to the kanji, Yamadaya means Mountain Field House--I doubt that is Japanese for the hippie-turned-fancy farm-to-fork concept, but the food of Ramen Yamadaya is certainly something you can expect to find in the back alleys of Japan, stashing away a secret family recipe tracing back to rural mountain and field times and perfected over generations.

"Ramen upstairs."  It would be especially amusing if Ramen Underground were in the same building, so they could have a ramen downstairs sign.  

Anyways, the ramen.  Like the starkly traditional ambiance with wooden fixtures and a general shadowy lighting, there is no fooling around with the ramen--every component has the dead serious precision of a Samurai (hmm, now I wonder whether Samurai ate ramen...) The tonkotsu broth is cooked for 20+ hours to an intense richness, the soft boiled egg has a runny yolk of liquid gold, and the chashu is a melty tenderness that comes from actual cooking skillz rather than fatty cuts of pork.  

While the egg noodles were undeniably tasty with the flavorful broth, it was not as al dente/QQ as I would have liked.  Not so terrible so as to be condemned as soggy, but I much preferred the bouncy hand-pulled noodles from Shalala just across the plaza. (Perhaps it would be more al dente/QQ if I immediately began devouring the ramen as soon as it arrived, instead of letting it sit in broth while I took a picture)

The menu is more extensive than those basic places with minimalist tonkotsu/shio/shoyu options; I went for the Yamadaya ramen because a restaurant's namesake dish is typically also the signature.  Sadly, the level 3 required an additional charge, so I got the spicy level 2.  There was a dab of chili pepper, but it was definitely not spicy (if you really want a spicy ramen... like challenge level spicy, I recommend Ramen Underground's habanero ramen--it is quite an adventure)

A very unique and exciting aspect of Ramen Yamadaya is the freshly pressed garlic, which you get to squeeze into your own ramen.  I do wish they offered more garlic because we each only got a clove or two--next time I should sneak in my own.
author: Edna C.

description: This was probably the worst ramen place I've ever been to in my entire life. I ordered the lunch special which came with ramen, karaage, and gyoza. Let  me start with the karaage, it was actually really tasty but kind of cold. The gyoza tasted frozen and it was also cold. The ramen was the worst part of it all. I ordered the spicy flavor and the broth was just so bad. It was thick and the flavor was off because it was like gravy. The noodles were thin and had an awful taste. I highly do not recommend eating there and there are plenty of other good ramen places in Japantown and this one is definitely one of the worst experiences. I should've known it was bad because the place was empty and all of the waiters looked bored.
author: J S.

description:
Our first time dining in was a great experience. However, they do need a person at the front door to seat customers quicker. 

Foods were great, nothing negative to say about this establishment. Our waiter was awesome and very pleasant, we tipped him a very generous tip :-) 
I would so come back again BUT the traffic going back to the East Bay iz a biatch. Will definitely return if in town.

PS:  Their "DEATH SAUCE" isn't all that to me.
author: M. N.

description:
It's ok.  The shio and shoyu broth are well seasoned and well... average. The extra chashu bowl, which was mostly rice and and kewpie, and salad is not worth an additional $5.50.  Service is far below what one would expect from a Japanese restaurant in Japantown. 

So dings on service and food experience.
author: S F.

description: Got the spicy ramen and it was just way too salty and spicy. Service was good but given that there are other ramen houses esp in J town, I would skip this place.
author: Diane N.

description: Ate here by myself. They were super accommodating. Ramen was fantastic and I dug the vibe. Looking forward to returning :)
author: Mike J.

description: Very heavy broth, after a few sips I couldn't take it anymore. Decent portions though. If you like heavy broth, give it a try.
author: Beatrice E.

description: A fantastic environment to be in after a long day or even a night out. Great service, great views of Japantown from a corner booth, very aesthetic design of the restaurant that makes you feel treated regardless of being crowded. I recommend arriving from around 4:30-5:00 to beat the dinner rush. The ramen is absolutely scrumptious! Spices are perfect, served in small wooden boxes gives the restaurant a very hospitable feel. Enjoyable if you're okay with a loud restaurant, wait times, and a little bit of fat on your meat. Despite shortcomings, this restaurant is not your typical ramen house, it's got a couple of quirky rules and designs in the waiting room that are simply hilarious!
author: Victor C.

description: first of all the wait to get into this place is so ridiculous and not worth it. thought my ramen would be good considering i waited at least 45 min to be seated. service is almost non existent. like you can't even have a host? you literally have to just walk up and write your name on a list and wait to be called. and to top it off the ramen is garbage. like actually tastes like garbage. i don't even eat ramen ever since i visited cause of such a bad experience.
author: Courtney H.

description:
This is only the second ramen I've had in San Francisco, but I thought it was good! I got the garlic noodle one and the broth was delicious. I regret getting extra noodles because I'm way too full, but all the flavors were good. A little too much pork for my taste, but I just picked it out. The restaurant was very accommodating about taking things out or putting it on the side. 

Overall: I would go back, but I would also like to try other ramen places
author: Jenna G.

description: One of the worst services in San Francisco. The way they communicate with customers is unacceptable. Such a pity, because ramen at this LA based chain is pretty decent. The management of this particular location has to go.
author: Evgeniy O.

description:
I had high hopes for this place. When we first arrived there was a line out the door so I figured it must be good. One of the people in line popped their heads in said that over half of the tables were empty. Come to find out, they couldn't seat everyone because their computer system wasn't transmitting orders to the kitchen. 

So me and my honey were eventually seated. But then they only brought out one glass of water. Just one water. ????????  My babe had to ask twice for water, finally he just got up and attempted to get it himself. We also ordered a large beer. It came out with just one glass. Yes, one glass again. OMG.

Now for $12 - $15 bowls of ramen, it better be good. They also advertised on their wall outside that they boil their pork bones for 20 hours to make the broth. I wasn't too impressed with it. I had the kakuni spicy ramen. The pork was very tender but the noodles were a little underdone. I had much better ramen in Hawaii for a much cheaper price. They gyoza here are also a little small. Karaage chicken is delicious though. 

Service is severely lacking and food is mediocre. This place was so not worth the wait. I would not come back.
author: Kenson K.

description: Out of towner, but when I come to San Fran, I am always trying to find a good bowl of ramen as they aren't plentiful in Dallas. I stopped in on a Friday night, and I guess I got lucky as I usually have to wait a while for a seat in a ramen house here but I only wanted about five minutes. Nice sized bowl and the broth was very tasty. The chashu as well cooked and as I ordered it spicy (level 1, you get to choose the level of spice) it had a little kick to it. A really satisfying meal on a cool fall night, and good enough that I'll be going back several times during my short stay here! Service was quick, not overly friendly, but honestly I expect quick and efficient over small talk when I go to ramen houses as I know they are looking to turn as many seatings as possible. Found the prices to be very reasonable. Going to miss this place when I had back to Texas...
author: Raymon W.

description: I've had some top notch Ramen in my day, and this was near the top of the list. Great atmosphere, great noodles, great broth, and great pork bun! Would definitely go back again and again if I lived in San Francisco!
author: Will H.

description:
Credit Card Forgery ! 
  My friend & I came here for lunch not long ago. Our bill came out to $80.48. I paid with my credit card and crossed out the tip line. Then I put down $20 bill for tip together with my credit card transaction receipt. A few days later I checked my credit card app and saw they had added extra $20 more on top of my $20 cash tip. I try to call them a few times but no luck. So I decided to call my credit company.
author: Daniel D.

description: Such good vegan ramen! Large portions. Also, they have this crazy cheese ramen dish that is literally a mountain of shredded cheese. Haven't tried it, but 2 of my friends got it and ate the whole thing. Sometimes there is a bit of a wait, but worth it. You have to go upstairs to get in, entrance isn't super obvious. Love going here after jiu-jitsu class at Bay Jiu-Jitsu down the block on Post Street.
author: Lindsay L.

description:
I went here for my first time having ramen in SF, and I wasn't disappointed. I ordered the regular tonkatsu + karaage, and it arrived right when I got back from using the restroom. Don't worry though, I made sure to wash in between my nails!

The food was pretty damn tasty, and affordable as well! I did end up heavily bloated though (probably sodium sensitivity), but man was it worth it. The bowl itself was filled with a fatty and thick broth, a butt-load of meat, and well-made noodles. The karaage wasn't the best I've had, but boy were the portions huge! (Honestly wouldn't be surprised if the meat came from a dinosaur).

As for the ambience, they had a very eclectic mix of new-age/chill-vibe music (The Whitest Boy Alive Golden Cage Fred Falke remix I'm looking at you), slightly dim lighting, and it was just a little noisy (as expected).

As for the health inspection ratin..., it seemed as clean as a very busy place could be; one of the employees did end up dropping a soy sauce glass, but accidents happen.
author: Peter N.

description:
Unfortunately this was just average ramen. We had a Yamadaya Spicy and a Yamadaya Kotteri with the Yamadaya meat. The meat itself was rather fatty, too fatty really and we ordered it over the Kakuni (pork belly) in the hopes of avoiding too much fatty meat. The small portion of noodles are too thin. I tasted the Kotteri ramen without the spice and thought it was rather bland, not that rich and fatty broth you'd hope for. I had the spicy and it had more flavor but it was solely because of the spice which just comes with a lump of spice on top of the bowl (as opposed to already being mixed in) which was not really appealing at first. The egg, however, stole the show. Perfectly cooked, delicious flavor, one of the best eggs I've had in a bowl! 

We were there after 9 pm on a Friday and only had a 10 minute wait after we signed in although it seemed everyone else was at least a party of 4 and had been waiting longer. Added bonus is that you can at least order drinks from them at the cashier so you have something to enjoy during the wait. Overall I'm glad we tried it for the comparison point, but can't say I'd return.
author: Alana C.

description: First time trying this ramen place. All three of us ordered different things. I ordered the hell ramen which did not disappoint. I thought it won't be spicy, but I felt like doing the spicy noodle challenge. The broth is tasty, and the chashu is very tender, Awesome!
author: Angelica P.

description: The ramen is very very salty.....I usually can eat salty food.....I couldn't even finish the half bowl. My husband ordered curry tonkatsu. The pork chop is very dry and thin cut. Small portion of rice.....did they change the ownership? It was good before but not anymore now...I don't think we will come back here again.
author: Sara K.

description: The ramen noodles had the perfect bite and firmness to them. The booth was rich and complex. I would definitely come here again when I'm in the neighborhood.
author: R C.

description: I've been going here a couple times a month for the last year and I'm still just as excited for my shio ramen now as I was the first time I tried it. Stephen is the best waiter, so attentive and a great sense of humor. The laid back decor, the bumping of early 2000's hits, and the courteous and friendly wait staff makes Ramen Yamadaya my #1 ramen spot in the city. My friends and I are always craving Yamadaya's ramen and their chicken katsu is great too! Ask for extra katsu sauce!
author: Delaney C.

description: I like to visit this place once for while. The ramen and katsukare are testy! The price is really reasonable now days. My kids really liked to eat in Yamadaya for the last two decades.
author: Shirchin B.

description: They need to update their business hours. They close at random times when it's slow...how professional.
author: Aileen A.

description:
First impression at the entryway walking upstairs.The restaurant did not feel very clean, lacking attention to detail like the food stains on the menu and the unclean spoon. If I allowed my instincts to kick in I should have turned around.

I had the basic pork ramen and regret consuming calories I didn't enjoy. When a broth is bland and oily that's a bad combination. Yes, fat is flavor, but the ratio of good broth to fat was off. The master chef did not taste test the broth on Sunday afternoon. The broth was lukewarm and the yolk in the egg was still cold. I had the first spoonful of broth and couldn't believe how bland it was. And had only the second spoonful to confirm that it was not good broth, maybe the worst I'd had. The ramen noodles were thin and a bit too firm, especially since they didn't soak up the broth. Sadly, the pork belly was not very good either. I expect pork belly to have fall-apart tender texture full of flavor. This was not it. The meaty layers were a bit tough and the in-between layers of fat were slimy. Memorable but not in a good way. None of the ingredients- the seaweed, noodles or the bamboo shoots melded well together and the broth didn't make the dish.
author: Edith Y.

description:
I happened to stumble across Ramen Yamadaya when I was looking for food outside of the main mall in Japantown. Saw a staircase and a sign for ramen, so figured I would give it a try. Since then, I've been back a few times.

Despite its name, I thought the ramen was pretty average. What stood out to be about this place was their tsukemen, which are thick noodles with toppings (seaweed, egg, chashu) and a thick fish-flavored dipping sauce. The dipping sauce is very rich and flavorful. The noodles had a good texture and the toppings felt very fresh, and they combined well with the dipping sauce. But it's always too large of a portion and I have a hard time finishing it.

Be wary that there might be long lines during peak hours. Service is very inconsistent -- some days they are efficient, other days they can take a long time to take your order (even when it's not that busy).
author: Alvin W.

description: Was some of the best ramen I have had.  Broth was excellent, very flavorful but not overwhelming.  Great location and only had a small wait when we arrived at 7:30pm.
author: Edward N.

description:
This place was pretty disappointing. Went in and there was no wait--which might be a bad sign considering most ramen places I've been to usually have a decent wait time. But it may have been since we came in at a later time. The layout of the restaurant itself is quite nice, as it is on the second floor and is open with windows to look out to Japan town.

Our waiter (I think he maybe was the owner) was almost too friendly, and was talking big about the food here, so I expected a lot.

We ordered one of the yamadaya buns for appetizer. They were really small and aesthetically were not great. Tasted okay but nothing special.

As for the ramen, I got the tonkotsu shoyu, and the soup was just okay. They specialize in thinner noodles,  which I find I'm not a huge fan of. But you can ask for thicker noodles. They gave quite a bit of meat, but it was all just okay. 

Overall I would say go somewhere else if you want ramen.
author: Helen W.

description:
lunch ramen fixed menu $15 - spicy option
comes with karaage, gyoza and a drink. total cost $20 after tax & tip. 
2 pc gyoza deep fried?? weird but okay. they're small and vegetarian. . . damn lunch special gets me again!! did I mention deep fried? so just guessing they're frozen. 
3 pc karaage, deep fried is actually expected so we're good on those and they tasted good and cooked well. mayonnaise for dipping? wtf? throw in a little lettuce and a bun and its a kfc snacker
Ramen- egg's cooked right but how hard is it to cook an egg. pork is good portion and tasty.  everthing else about this dish is straight out of a grocery bag.  bamboo shoots from a can, wood ear straight from a bag, ramen just boiled long enough to tell it was bone dry 2 minutes before and from a bag. soup was very oily and almost like a gravy.  At $15 bucks for lunch, i'd hardly call the soda "free".  I only hit this place because the one int the main mall had stopped serving lunch and my stomach is regretting it as is my wallet. take a pass, there are wayyyy better Ramen places out there and less expensive too.
author: Jimmy J.

description:
I've eaten here three times in the last seven months and the menu has changed each and every time as well. I think the basic items on the menu stayed the same and it seemed like they weren't sure how large of a menu they wanted. 

The restaurant is very spacious which is a nice change of pace considering most ramen shops are small and cramped. Everything is very clean in the eating area, I love how they have WOODEN chopsticks. As any soupy-noodle lover knows, eating with wooden chopsticks makes all the difference in enjoying your meal versus when you're eating with plastic chopsticks. My boyfriend is not very skilled with chopsticks and he appreciates this place even more solely based on that. I also love how they play 90's music (we both grew up in the 90's)! Listening to nostalgic music while eating ramen is a pretty awesome experience :D

Last night my boyfriend ordered the Shoyu (soy sauce based soup) and requested to just have the pork belly instead of tonkotsu with corn on the side and I ordered the Kotteri (black garlic oil). When our bowls came, the corn was in my boyfriend's order and he got both the tonkotsu and the pork belly. My boyfriend said the waitress didn't quite understand what he wanted and when he tried to explain she still seemed confused, hence the errors in the order. I was sorely disappointed when my ramen lacked the rich broth flavor the menu claimed and I couldn't taste any garlic flavor either. I was also saddened to see that the noodles were thin, I prefer thicker noodles. I think the Shoyu ramen also had thin noodles too.

Even though we had issues with our orders, we still enjoyed our food and we will be coming back again. Hopefully there will be an option for thick noodles again (I remember seeing an option the first time I came here).

Oh! And another perk is they open earlier now! 5:30 instead of 6:30!!
author: Fanny W.

description:
Come here if you like fatty and heavy broth. If you have a lighter taste preference like I do, you might not enjoy the ramen as much. I think that the meat, egg and noodles were all good. However, I added corn and that was disappointing since it's not fresh corn. They do serve fresh garlic that you can crush and add to your bowl upon request, which was tasty. 

One other thing I didn't like about my ramen was how lukewarm the broth was. I prefer super hot soup. I'm not sure if they just don't keep the soup heated enough or if it's on purpose.

Service was okay, not super attentive but not bad. It's quite a long wait as well so be prepared for that! I've had better ramen so this doesn't rank very highly for me. That said I wouldn't mind coming back either.
author: Sophia H.

description: This place gave my boyfriend and I horrible stomachaches the morning after! Hopefully that was a one off experience but I would not recommend the ramen necessarily either. I got the spicy miso ramen and the broth was incredibly oily, noodles were very unsubstantial, and overall pretty average.
author: Dana W.

description:
I recently ordered the Yamadaya Tonkotsu Ramen for take out. Literally within an hour after eating it...I got a tummy ache. Something wasn't right. 

Thanks Yelp for the pop up Alert: Poor Food Safety Score. Wish it came earlier before I ordered :(
author: Tonia D.

description: I am writing this as I am here sitting waiting for my food for about an hour. No waiter came by and said anything about our food or when it is coming out. Yea sure they can say they are busy I give them the benefit of the doubt but the people who came way after us got their food before us. Is our order a lot more difficult to make? This is a bit sad to lower the stars not because of their food but their service has been very bad today. Their excuses were "there was a big Togo order" " there is only one person making the ramen". Honestly they can have all the excuses they want but acknowledgement of our order and apologizing for the wait would be good too. I also had faster service during cherry blossom festival... even other events that was going on through the day than today
author: Jade L.

description:
While there's already a good number of ramen joints around the Bay Area, it's been kind of exciting to hear about SoCal establishments spreading into NorCal.  Sure, that means I'll be even further behind on knocking them off my list, but that also means there's that many more to try!  Can't argue with that, no?

Located above Shabusen, Ramen Yamadaya has a much more open and modern decor than its predecessor, Iroha.  Similarly, much like how the look of the space has vastly improved, so has the menu.  Although there isn't an extensive variety of ramen to choose from (about five broths), there is a solid slate of appetizers and sides to add onto your order.  But more importantly, the food is much better.

-- YAMADAYA RAMEN with Spicy Tonkotsu Broth...$11.45
(http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/ramen-yamadaya-san-francisco#ox5_B5rxIUmYFhX5vV8ILw)
Although it was a little salty, the broth was flavorful and rich, had a nice consistency, and just the right kick (miiddle spiciness level).  I liked the eggs, chasiu, and kakuni as well, but the noodles were disappointing.  While these thinner noodles are great when done right (like Ipuudo in NY), these were gummy and overcooked.

-- KAKUNI...$3.50
(http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/ramen-yamadaya-san-francisco#850NZDjFq78OtjxlLvZbFg)
Even though it wasn't as thick as some of the cuts in the photos, I still thought it was a tasty dish.  The pork belly was juicy and had just a slight char to it.  However, if I had read the menu and known kakuni was already in the ramen, I would have skipped this.

As far as service went, I thought the workers were efficient and friendly.  Prices are pretty fair as well, especially compared to what you get from some of the other places in Japantown.  Still, I've been waffling for a while now whether to round up or down from THREE AND A HALF STARS.  Ultimately, I decided to be generous and give four mostly because next time, I'll just sub in the more common ramen noodles instead.
author: Mike L.

description:
Although their broth could possibly be the best I've had, unfortunately the rest fell behind.  The pork was dry and the egg overcooked and little portion.  Maybe I ordered the wrong things.   
Tonkotsu spicy
Takoyaki
House Sake
author: Naty D.

description: Excellent food and very friendly service. The wait may be a bit long, which is a function of its popularity. The staff is very friendly.
author: J A.

description: This place has the best broth, hands down! The service is great and the atmosphere is cool. We always have to eat here whenever we're in the city.
author: ERIK E.

description: Have been meaning to try this place for some time. Everything on the extensive menu looks great. I had the fire ramen, which lives up to its name. I even had to take some of the Thai chili out or else I don't think I would have made it through the meal. After five glasses of water I finished the bowl and it was delicious! The server does warn you that the spice level is four. Highly recommend the spicy tonkatsu ramen. I might go easy next time and get the spicy miso which is always a good choice. Will be back
author: Eunice Y.

description:
***************************** UPDATE REVIEW ************************

  I came back with my mom and niece this time. With 10 locations in California (LA, OC, San Diego, SF, and San Jose), they know what they are doing.

   They are proud of their 20 hours Tonkotsu Ramen is cooked with pork bone. Pork bone broth needs at least 8 hours and Yamadaya spends 20 hours boiling it to get the greatest amount of flavor possible. They use the highest temperatures to extract all the flavor and aroma from the pork bone. 

  They serve their ramen with soup temperature at 203 degree and I do enjoy the hardness noodles. Tonkotsu Ramen is similar to the Kyushu style and "Tonkotsu Shoyu Ramen" is the popular trend. 

  I ordered Tonkotsu Ramen Yamadaya, the spicy ramen, Char Siu Bowl, Spicy Tuna Salad, extra bowl of Tonkotsu broth, and iced coffee. Everything was good this time.

  Service was good, friendly and efficient. Our servers were attentive. And they remodeled the bathroom, finally! It's a go to spot for me now when I'm in Japantown. Plus they open all day unlike other Japanese restaurants here, they are closed from 2:30-5:30pm.

  If you don't want to leave your house in pajama, they offer delivery now ans well as online order for pick up, sweet!
author: Manda Bear B.

description:
Looking for a place to have ramen on a drive by of the bay, ordered the ramen "Yamadaya" style, or whatever it was. The broth really didn't have a flavor that reflected the amount of time they claim it cooks for. Noodles were not what I expected, though I can't recall what it was about them. Chashu was thickly sliced and lacking in flavor. Chicken karaage was good, especially with a side of rice.

I guess I came in expecting too much, but I have a bar that was set, and I was really hoping this was going to raise it.
author: Carlos F.

description: After not coming here for over a year, I visited for lunch today. The tonkotsu broth was not particularly hot in temperature, the once-tender pork was tough and leathery, and noodles were a little too firm. With newer and tastier ramen competitors in Japantown, I think Yamadaya needs to up its game or be left behind.
author: Keith R.

description:
(This review is long overdue, bear with me)

I use to hate ramen. Like, absolutely hate it. That surprised one of my friends and so we decided to go and grab some (I guess to convince me how good it actually is) for breakfast. 

Mind you, the first thing I could think of was Japantown, only because I saw this restaurant multiple times and never got around to dining in due to the long waits. Luckily, the wait one morning was about 10-15 minutes. Upon seating, I noticed how small the location was which explained the line out the door. The menu is pretty standard ramen with toppings for multiple options. 

I forgot what I ordered, but my friend recommended it because it was the non-spicy option. Let me tell you, I certainly changed my mind about ramen entirely after that bowl. It was the right amount of creamy and consistent. 

All in all, it was great. Fantastic even. I would recommend calling in to see how long the wait is before committing to this place if you're on a bit of a time crunch as it does begin to fill up quickly. Other than that, the location is ideal if you want to look around Japantown, but expect to dread the parking unless you want to park in a garage.
author: Tricia M.

description:
Ramen was pretty good but I wish it had more broth.
The service is friendly but may be slow as you can see people waiting outside when there are a few tables empty inside.  

I was there 2 weeks ago, but Yelp still shows the "Consumer Alert: Poor Food Safety Score!" when you look this place up.  Very surprising to see this from a Japanese restaurant.
author: Harue J.

description:
Pretty tasty vegan ramen - very savory and not too bitter like I've had with other ramen places. I ordered it with gluten free noodles and that was also tasty. 
Good selection of sake as well. 
The atmosphere on a Friday night was pumped up and playing a bunch of nineties/early 2000s jams.
author: Elizabeth L.

description:
I LOVE this place!  

Went back for my second visit last night.  I enjoyed the delicious Kotteri Ramen because I LOVE garlic.  The pork is delicious and fatty and the entire meal is hearty and filling.  Perfect comfort food for a rainy night.  

We enjoyed a nice cold sake that tasted of apples.  Very refreshing.

And for dessert we had the mochi ice cream.  The green tea and strawberry flavors were the perfect thing to cleanse the palate.

In spite of the long wait (Saturday night) we were seated within 20 minutes.

Excellent work, guys!
author: Robert M.

description: It was just okay. Nothing special. Add soy sauce to the ramen it makes it saltier/better. The curry was good. Not extra special, but worth eating. This place was also kind of pricy for ramen. Honestly, in the future, I would try other ramen places. Probably wouldn't come back here.
author: Amanda T.

description:
Downgraded from four to one star which means I'm not coming back.

The fall:
- Cold unseasoned egg. Not acceptable to throw a hard boiled egg into my ramen. Season it and cook it right.
- Cold chashu that subsisted of pork fat. Disgusting even if I had ordered pork belly.
- Regular ramen costs $8.45. Toppings are the same as the $2.50 extra for the Yamadaya topping. Don't bother since the toppings are lackluster.
- Having my egg and chashu served cold and dropped into my broth took the heat off the soup. Big drop on star factors.

Not returning here. Quality got compromised. Will travel to Orenchi or Kotetsu in South Bay than endure this place.
author: Yiven C.

description: This ramen place is a lot more pricey than most ramen places I've been to. It was $12 for a bowl and there was only one size. I opt for a rice bowl instead. I wanted to try the beef bowl but they were out so I got the pork bowl instead. The meal had so much fat in it (I know that the pork is suppose to have a lot of fat but it was like extra fatty). i just bit off the fat so that was fine. If i were to ever come back here, I would probably just get the ramen.
author: Nancy N.

description: Their ramen is pretty standard, tastes good. But their pork bun was really disappointing: the pork to bun ratio is off, there's too much bun for the amount of pork they provide. If anything, it would've been better if they had given a smaller bun to match the pork belly size.
author: David K.

description:
SF ramen challenge- Yamadaya ramen

Located on Japantown, probably one of the busiest ramen joints with long lines. The restaurant is located upstairs so don't go to the other Japanese restaurant downstairs which also has a line. We arrived Sat night around 630 and there was already a line but it does seem to move quick as the place is very big and efficient with communal tables.
As we sat at corner booth the menu was basically mostly Tonkatsu broth based we went for a few different Rennes with one being spicy very hot level 3 which is highest.
The broth is super rich and if you want the pork belly added it will be extra $3.50 which is not a bad deal considering the size of it.  Don't bother with their J pop alcoholic drink, it's very sweet and not worth the $5. I would add an egg though since you only get 1/2 an egg and it is very good. If you prefer thicker noodles you can swap for extra 50 cents.

The broth is super rich. There is a saying many people burn their mouth with this broth as it has a huge layer of fat disguising the steam coming off. So be careful not to burn yourself.
The ramen itself was ok, not the best nor worth waiting on line for too long.
I prefer waraku down the street or goku in mission. 
Value 4/5
Atmosphere 4/5
Service 4/5
Quality 3/5
15/20
author: Nina S.

description:
yamadaya yamadaya ya ya da da ma ma

I've always wanted to visit this place everytime I walked by the town center of Japantown. The sign that says "Ramen upstairs" always seemed intriguing, and today I've finally had a chance to visit!

The noodles were very thin, as other reviewers have pointed out. Overall, the ramen is pretty good, with a small but thick slice of pork, and good, creamy soup base. If the egg was a poached liquid egg then everything would have been even better!

The seats inside were also pretty good, with plenty of room. The wait staff are also very nice, although it does take quite a while for the food to get prepared.

A good place to visit once in a while.
author: Henry L.

description: Service is rushed. I got the spicy ramen and added black garlic oil. Without the black garlic it was already pretty oily and the flavor was just okay.
author: Atessa A.

description:
I get a little nostalgic when I go a ramen place that charges money for every little topping. It's like I'm watching commercials as a kid again.

"Ramen may not be suitable for anyone hungry. Corn, Seaweed, and Scallion each sold separately. Batteries not included."

lol the scallion costs an extra dollar. Inflation is real, guys.

Waiting for a table can also be frustrating. Especially when you look through the windows and see the other customers taking their sweet time. But it's quite another story when you look and see empty tables inside. 

We peered inside to see 3 open tables ready to sit the many parties that were starving in the waiting area. Yet, 20+ minutes late, the tables remained as empty as the pit of my ramen-less stomach.

After trying to flag down the busy hostess for a good while (she was super busy as she also served tables and processed bills in addition to her hostess duties), she finally sat us on one of the three empty tables. If she had just asked nicely, I could've sat myself. I could've maybe even sat two other parties for her. But what do I know about efficiency? 

After ordering, we saw some literature and learned that Ramen Yamadaya simmers their broth for 20 hours. Well, that explains why it felt like 20 hours before we got our food.

No kidding. It took 10+ minutes before we even got water (waiter apologized) 20+ more minutes before our ramen came (the busy hostess kinda just flinged it on our table). 

It's funny looking back at how inefficient this place was. But at that time, I was actually filled with frustration (instead of Ramen, oh the irony.) Yamadaya looked like one of those featured places from Gordon Ramsey's Kitchen Nightmares. Decent food, horrible management.

Honestly, if it's that 20 hour simmered broth that's causing all this trouble, then please just stick to Maruchan or maybe Shin Ramen on a more ambitious day. Also, hiring someone to help the hostess would be a good idea. Or maybe just training the hostess to see 3 empty tables would help too.

Can't believe I waited all that time to pay a dollar for extra scallion.
author: Ringo M.

description:
I've been to Ramen Yamadaya twice now and both times I have been please with my experience.  The service is always top notch.  Very friendly and accommodating.  The ramen (I have tried a few different ones) are pretty solid.  I really like the kara-age (popcorn) chicken.  This is crispy on the outside and juicy on the inside.  

Definitely one of the better ramen spots I've been to in Japantown.  The place is usually pretty busy.  When you get there make sure you sign in to the waiting list.  

Overall I give this place 3.5/5.
author: Paul W.

description:
3.5 stars. Way too spicy! The #2 was - like a 6 on the scale. Overall soup is good but still not rich like Japan. I got a side of pork and it was good but 2/3rds was fat.  I mean PURE FAT. 
Overall not a bad place but I heard this was the best Japan town has in sf,ca. If this is true, Honolulu is right up there.
I got the tonkotsu ramen with level 2 spicyness.  The portions were small even for Japan standards. It was ok. Nothing more. Good service though!
Messy bathroom!
author: Aron N.

description: The food is not the same and prices went up $3 from before. The don is not even sushi rice. Not the same. Not worth it. Sadly it was my fav ramen place but I guess not anymore. Boo
author: Roxane Z.

description: The yamadaya you used to know is dead. Server refused to serve us water even after we got our food. I got up to get some since multiple jugs and cups were in the open area but was quickly stopped because I wasn't allowed to. I got water only after we paid for the check. Bye quality and bye yamadaya. Rest in pieces.
author: Nona K.

description:
Had the spicy Yamadaya tonkotsu ramen and it lived up to its expectations. The serving of pork belly was overwhelming but I'm not complaining, bring on the meat! The noodles were very fresh and not too soft. You can trust the broth was brewing for hours. I asked for garlic on the side and they brought me a plate of garlic cloves and with a crusher to freshly crank it out myself which I thought was funny, didn't expect that.

I was thoroughly impressed with the service, not only friendly and humorous but spot-on it. We had a party of approximately 20 people and they were able to accommodate us at walk-in.
author: Briget P.

description:
Came in an hour and a half before closing and despite there being a bunch of people in front of us, we were seated in like 10 minutes. The place is cute and being seated at a communal table doesn't bother me, especially since it's clean unlike eating in HK or at a cafeteria. Yeah, that's pretty much where all the good stuff ends.
Ordered a yamadaya kotteri ramen and my friend ordered the spicy tuna bowl + kakuni kotteri combo, and a Wednesday cat beer of some sort. It took about 30 minutes for the food to come, and when it did, it looked beautiful. Ravenous, I grabbed my spoon to sample the broth. It was luke warm at most. WTH. HOW DO YOU GET THE FLAVOR IF ITS LUKEWARM?! My friend said it's because it was close to closing but I'm pretty sure an hour before closing, you should still serve good food like any other time. Why else would you charge the same price?! The flavors were gone due to how cold it was. The noodles were good in thickness. The bamboo tasted like it came out of a can (which means you did it wrong!). The egg was cold and man, how the hell do you warm up an egg in cold broth? Usually I really appreciate a place that can do a soft boiled egg the right way (which they did), but I can't appreciate it if it's cold.
The spicy tuna bowl was lackluster. The service mediocre (I watched a couple wait on their check for the entirety of our meal). My friend didn't even get his beer but they had the audacity to charge for it. Yeah, that check went straight back to the front. Overall, this place sucks. I know I can't compare ramen here to Japan, but at least be mediocre ramen! I felt completely nauseated after eating here and that's not an exaggeration.
author: Jenn T.

description: Super disappointed. The service was awful. Didn't even get our drinks until they brought the check.  Our food was subpar as well.
author: Amy L.

description: There's something with this place and garlic since there's a ton of it. FREE cloves of garlic to add to your ramen on top of a lot of black garlic oil. Super flavorful that way too. Plus, if you show your student ID you get extra noodles. I think I just got it because it was free but trying to finish the whole thing was pretty painful. Painfully good.
author: Sarina C.

description:
Just average! Tanpopo has much better ramen! The best ramen I had so far is still the one from LA japantown- Daigoku Ramen.

At 8pm on Monday, there is a 20-30 minute wait for a table of 2+1. There are so many empty tables waiting to be clean up while the waitress just taking her time checking her phone and walking back and forth pretending she is busy!
Appetizer: takoyaki 3.5/5
Ramen: yamadaya special and with black garlic. 3/5
( if you ask for extra broth, they will charge you $4 extra)
Beverage: spirit. ( because they ran out of Ramu drink)
author: Elaine Y.

description: Yeah I'm a fan. I appreciate the time and effort put into each bowl here. The wait can be tough on a weekend though and if you have a large group. The service however was top notch and very quick on anticipations. The table with a live eco system growing in the middle of it was quite incredible to look at. I wished we sat there, but of course the odds were against us that day haha. Anyway the food was delicious, but not mind blowing like I've had before. The egg was slightly over cooked and the noodles were a bit chewy, still good regardless. I'll definitely come back when I'm in the mood for ramen.
author: Guisela L.

description:
Came here back in January. I love ramen so when i heard they were opening in SF, I had to check them out! We didn't really have to wait at all and got seated at a table by the entrance. We got:

My order:
-Tonkotsu kotteri ramen ($9.45) - really oily and salty
-Yamadaya toppings (+$2.50) - nice assortment of toppings
-Kakuni pork belly ($3.50) - pork belly also came with the Yamadaya toppings so I didn't really need this
-Gyoza & small salad combo (+$3.75 to ramen) - salad is like a free salad that comes in a bento box, not really worth paying for, just really wanted the gyoza
-Chili sauce ($0.50) - not spicy

Roommate's order:
-Tsukemen ($8.95 for 7oz)
-Paigu pork loin ($3.50)

I found the ramen to be overly salty. And I love salt! I didn't mind the fattiness of the broth, but it was just too oily. I've had ramen in Japan where there were pieces of fat floating in the broth and I loved it! This, not so much!
author: Elena N.

description:
Skip the Kotteri ramen.  I got it because it seemed popular in many Yelp reviews but after I ate it I realized it was chock full of GARLIC. Garlic oil, crushed garlic, fried garlic. I unfortunately could not shake the garlic stench for hours after and even the next morning. I just read apples, lemons, and green tea are the remedies for major garlic breath so I'm gonna hit those hard. 

Also the pork belly was way too fatty. Just gonna stick to regular ramen if I ever come back here but I may be too traumatized now
author: Jessica L.

description:
If I lived in an isolated vacuum in San Francisco, this would be pretty decent.

Unfortunately, in the rest of the world, there are much better and cheaper options out there. Yamadaya's saving grace is the quality of their meats, and they definitely didn't skimp on that important ingredient. That particular part was my favourite component of the meal. I was excited, then dissapointed by a lackluster broth.

However, the rest doesn't really stack up, even if you only compare to SoCal or the South Bay.

Either way, it was weird waiting 30 minutes to order ramen, and weirder waiting 20 minutes to receive the ramen, and to top it all off, paying 13$ for ramen+tax and tip. 

Ramen: 1/5
Pork meats: 3/5
Broth: 1/5
Takoyaki: 1/5
Service:1/5
Diversity: 3/5
Price: $$/$$$$
Satisfaction:Price- 2/5
author: Stanley W.

description:
Nice! Love the fatty garlic-y broth. Not the most top-notch noodles but I'm super picky on that, and I thoroughly enjoyed their Kotteri!

THE WAIT: We went to several places before this one, and Yamadaya had the shortest wait by far. They seem to be pretty efficient at getting groups through their meal and then to clear out quickly. It was 20 minutes for 6 of us (everywhere else being a 45 minute to 1 hour wait), and they were true to their word.

THE COST: Not bad, about $20 a person for a bowl of ramen and their share of a pitcher.

THE SERVICE: Once again, efficient. But our server had a really strong accent that was difficult to understand, plus she couldn't really understand us. We had a long back-and-forth on the difference between the Tonkotsu Ramen with its set toppings and the Yamadaya Ramen, which could be the same broth and just had deluxe toppings. She basically explained the whole thing, verbatim, about 4 times (each time with that difficult-to-understand accent). 3 of those times were totally unnecessary.

MUST-HAVES: The Kotteri, for sure! All 6 of us got this. I loved my Kakuni Pork Belly topping. It was the thickest slab of pork belly I've ever seen.

* Tonkotsu Kotteri ($9.45) - 4 stars 
pic: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/ramen-yamadaya-san-francisco?select=NY2LsY2puK1c7MpM8Yyjlg#cZdi3aOPpwebV-5xpsvQHw
The broth was super fatty, flavorful, and tasty. The noodles were a good balance of soft and chewy. Overall great!

* Kakuni Pork Belly side ($3.50) - 4.5 stars
pic: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/ramen-yamadaya-san-francisco?select=NY2LsY2puK1c7MpM8Yyjlg#S04iac5w0Bdq-agpfedkMw
Wow, this was crazy thick, crazy tasty, crazy juicy. If you like any form of bacon or pork belly, get this! I was surprised it doesn't come in the broth though, and you don't get a knife to cut it, so you have to deal with kind of taking bites and eating it with your noodles/broth, or dunking the whole thing in and picking it up to take bites.

Dinner menu: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/ramen-yamadaya-san-francisco?select=NY2LsY2puK1c7MpM8Yyjlg#NY2LsY2puK1c7MpM8Yyjlg
author: Ziyan C.

description:
I kept my expectations low for this place and i'm glad I did because it was not all that great. I came here with two friends today for lunch a little past 1pm and the wait was 15-20 mins. When we were finally seated, we didn't even get water until after we got our ramen. They also have really bad ventilation because even with windows open the place was still stuffy. Now to the most disappointing part.

Yamadaya ramen with tonkatsu kotteri broth: 2/5: The broth was decent, it had a good tonkatsu flavor. While it said its a fatty broth, it was still good that was not the issue. The chasu pieces were the biggest issue. I get that i ordered the fatty broth but they threw in the fattiest pieces of chasu in our bowls. The pieces were literally all fat and tiny slivers of actual meat. And that was for all 3 pieces. And the other type of meat which is  pork belly was a bit tough and it had alot of fat too. I like meat, but i hate it when its really fatty. The egg was good, it was soft boiled and done right. the noodles were the thin kind, they were ok but not too bad. Other than the broth and egg being good, the rest of the ramen was forgettable. 

I honestly thought that it would be better but the fact that i was disappointed, i probably wouldn't come back. I would much rather go to nearby  waraku , tanpopo or ramen underground.
author: Stella J.

description:
The first thing I noticed when I stepped inside was the smell. I thought to myself, did I step into a bathroom? Previous reviews comment on the dirty rag smell... But whatever the smell... It's there! So be prepared for the smell or wear a clothespin on your nose.

I came here with my friend a few weeks ago, and had to wait about 20 minutes for a table mid-week at 730pm. About half the tables were occupied, so I felt it peculiar that the wait was so long since there were plenty of tables available.  Nonetheless, we were finally seated around 8pm and ordered our food. Service was decent, nothing remarkable.  

I order the kotteri ramen which many people raved about in reviews. Well I've had kotteri style ramens throughout the nation, and this one was average. Kotteri refers to a rich, thick broth, which is usually made with a lot of TLC and well... Fatty pork/pork fat. The kotteri broth here was salty but a bit lacking in bold flavors, and it was not meaty or rich/thick enough for me... That is, not enough pork fat!  Also the bamboo shoots they use are really stinky. They're so stinky that they overpower the soup base.  So while the soup was on the blander spectrum of ramen souls I've had, there was a pretty potent bamboo shoot undertone with every gulp of soup.  If you like bamboo shoots, then this might be the soup for you.  If not, it might be best to hold off on the shoots or to ask for them to be put on the side so that you can add them in as per your liking.

San Francisco is a hub of different cultures with lots of variety of food choices. While there are a lot of choices for ramen in the city, in my opinion, they are just average in comparison to the better choices in the South Bay and in LA.  When I saw this place open up I was hoping that it would be just as good as the "Ramen Yamadaya" in LA, but this was not the case.  

Unless the broth improves and the dirty bathroom rag smell goes away, I don't think I'll come here again. For an average bowl of ramen in an average ramen restaurant, this place gets three stars in my books.
author: Matthew L.

description: Japanese ramen noodles- a must try- Japantown was fun and the noodle variety was awesome
author: Donna R.

description:
Two words to express my opinion about this place - Disappointing and Unimpressed. 

Based on some of the reviews, I expected a good Ramen finally in San Francisco. I've had good and some great Ramen in the South Bay, North Bay, East Bay, LA and even Vegas. I bookmarked this place based on this photo http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/ramen-yamadaya-san-francisco?select=jBK-BHblUjgJ2OgKQncnug#jBK-BHblUjgJ2OgKQncnug that I saw months ago. A pork belly that is fat and thick and makes one's mouth salivate. 

We visited this place a few weeks ago and based on some of the reviews that I've read, a lot of Yelpers mentioned that the middle of the restaurant was and empty space that could use a table for more patrons. They also mentioned the Ramen was good. Well...they were half right, in my humble opinion. 

There was now a large communal table in the middle and more on the Ramen later. Although service was good, friendly and efficient, a lot was left to be desired about the Ramen. I ordered the Tonkotsu while the Wifey ordered the Shoyu. We also ordered the side of Pork Belly that made our mouth salivate based on the photo. While waiting for the order, we discovered that Ramen Yamadaya is a chain with the original location in Torrance, California. I had high hopes since SoCal was finally bringing some good Ramen to NorCal. AND...most of the people working here were Japanese. 

When the Pork Belly arrived, I was expecting the same cut, but what I got was this:
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/ramen-yamadaya-san-francisco?select=jBK-BHblUjgJ2OgKQncnug#DAkElJzg1P-sHZ4x3TE7Jw It's a far cry from the first photo and it tasted just as bad as it looked. It was dry, overcooked and tasted like it was left marinating too long. Typically I would be asking where's the beef. In this case I was asking where's the fat?

When our Ramen arrived and tasted the broth, it was lacking that umami flavor compared to some of the places I've visited. This broth tasted like flavored salt. The thin noodles didn't work either as the noodles are supposed to soak and retain the flavor. It just fell apart and created a messy and chewy sensation in my mouth. I tasted the Wifey's Shoyu and I got the same reaction. I don't think they cooked the noodles correctly. 

You know that a good sign of a great Ramen is when a person finishes the broth. Well....I left my bowl half full and left unsatisfied. 

On to the next one.
author: John G.

description:
We visited the city from Davis (the land of horrible ramen) so that might be influencing my review a little bit, but I thought this was a pretty solid ramen place! We came at 3pm in the afternoon so there wasn't really a line. The staff was very friendly and the food was pretty affordable (less than $15/bowl) pretty good so far. I ordered the black garlic ramen & when the bowl came out, I was surprised by how much food there was! And how good it was! Ok, I wasn't so surprised about the taste because it smelled so delicious. The thin noodles were cooked perfectly, soft & chewy, and the broth was very savory and rich, just the way I like it. Soft boiled egg was on point. I was starving so I ate the whole thing (broth included) & was so full I couldn't even eat dinner. 

For an appetizer our table also ordered the karage chicken & I thought it was done really well. The batter was light and crisp and the chicken was pretty high quality too. There were 10 large pieces for only $6 I think. I could have eaten this as a meal it was so good. If I found myself in the area, I would definitely eat here again!
author: Lori N.

description: Kinda slow service but the tasty ramen makes up for it. The spice levels are pretty accurate and the free quail eggs for checking in is awesome. Makes up for the fact that you pay extra for having the ramen more spicy. Imo it should be spicy to begin with.
author: Michael C.

description:
I don't understand why this place does not have a great review. This is by far one of the best ramen I've ever had! My whole party enjoyed it so much that we came back twice while out visit. It's a true authentic place and deserves much better reviews ! 
A big winner for me was the vegan option, a sits hard to find soups without fish soup or pork soup
author: Valeria S.

description:
Both the kotteri and spicy broths are phenomenal! The menus, however, are unclear. I didn't see anywhere on the menu that listed what toppings are included with the bowls (yes, my friends and I looked), and we ended up each with double orders of toppings. 

The service was also slow, especially for such a small space. It took forever to get water. Ramen makes us thirsty! I'm docking 1 star for service, but I was happy with the food.
author: Cora L.

description: The soup was great. I had gotten spicy ramen yamadaya - level 1 spicy - and it was amazing. They give you a full egg (not every place does that) and the texture/flavor of the ramen was delightful. I definitely will come back when I am in san francisco again!
author: Celaena P.

description: Altogether, this Ramen shop is pretty average and there are better places which give a better bang for your buck.
