The food was good, but the prices are too high for what you are paying for. With the service not being anything special either, I think there are much better places you could visit. However, being located in the middle of Japan Town, if you are hungry enough the location alone might be enough to persuade some.
author: Seamus G.

description:
Although I enjoyed my ramen, it's hard for me to understand why people wait so long to get into this place.  The ramen was tasty, but nothing special,  as was the takoyaki (a little too creamy for my taste). The pork cutlet in my ramen was also dry.  I enjoyed the ramen because I generally enjoy ramen,  not because this blew my mind. 

The service was a bit spotty, and the tabletop was extremely sticky, which didn't help make the experience more pleasant.
author: Jennifer O.

description:
The Ramen was too oily, with way too much MSG. Dragged in with hesitation, cause I have not had any good experience with Ramen in general.  
Had 5 bites of the ramen and the MSG is now making me sick. 
The waiter/waitress was nice. I won't be coming back.
author: Effi W.

description:
It's tucked upstairs in Japantown. When we got up there, it was packed. When we left, it was packed. I think that's a sign of a good restaurant that's not even on the main walkway area.

The ramen was really good. I had the garlic one. The broth was tasty... comparable to Shin Sen Gumi in SoCal. Everything in the bowl mixed so well together. I wish it had bigger portions and more meat but the taste is phenomenal.

Looking forward to trying the other ramen bowls there.
author: Kay T.

description:
Last day in SF, we were headed to Sweet Maple for brunch, but since the wait would've made us miss our flight, we went to Ramen Yamadaya.

Place was super stuffy as soon as we walked in. Thank goodness we were able to open a window by our table and let the cold air in. Eating ramen, during the summer, with no AC is torturous (me = spoiled).

We placed our order with a nice waitress and waited a VERY long time. It might've been because we were seated as soon as the restaurant was opened, but it still seemed to take too long by our standards.

Noodles were perfect. Not mushy. Broth was good. My mouth didn't feel like the Sahara after eating my bowl of ramen. Skimpy portion of pork. I dug around my bowl for more, but was only given a thin 1 1/2 slices. That was kind of a disappointment. I really think they can afford to give you a whole egg sliced in half too. But, I ate my one half happily.
 
Prices were decent. Additional charges galore for extras, but that's expected.

I'll have to try the location here in SoCal sometime.
author: Jenny L.

description: Vegan Ramen was not as flavorful as I would have liked with lots of noodles and few vegetables.
author: teresa s.

description:
As a preface, I absolutely love spicy foods and really appreciated the "fire" and "death" (lol) spices that could be added to the ramen. The waiter even let us try both before ordering at no cost! Fire is spicy/sweet and death is literally just spice... I suggest trying both before ordering.

I got the vegan ramen with egg. The ramen broth was very rich and filling. The ramen itself was decent, although I've had better. The eggs were a little below average. 

What won me over was the spice, hands down. TLDR order "death" spice because it's hilariously named and adds a kick to your soup.
author: Mia B.

description:
CREDIT CARD FORGERY.

My friend and I split the bill on our credit cards but because my order costed less, we decided I wouldn't tip and he would put all the tip his card.  Turns out when I check my credit card statement they added their own tip to my receipt.

Take your receipt. I wouldn't bother calling them. Your credit card company should be able to resolve the criminal activity and if you find yourself in the store you can give the manager shit in person.

CRIMINALS
author: C J.

description:
All I can say is the ramen here is darn good. I ordered the kotteri ramen and I looked for the following:

Noodles: Thinner than usual but cooked a little longer than I would like. 
Broth: Milky colored and added the extra fattiness by selecting kotteri. Slurped every last ounce.
Egg: Soft boiled 
Chasui: thin and tender.

The must add is the kakuni. A braised pork belly strip that is so tender.

I can't wait until they open one in San Jose some time in October 2014.
author: Kien M.

description: Ordered the Yamadaya Kotteri after craving ramen for the whole week. It was a short wait at around noon and the food came pretty fast. The broth was very rich, but there wasn't much garlic taste to it. Overall, it was a satisfying meal but seemed a little pricey at $13 after being spoiled by cheap SoCal ramen spots.
author: Aki H.

description: Maybe I shouldn't have had that green milk tea from Belly Good cafe. Maybe I shouldn't have had ordered a side salad and gyoza. Then maybe, just maybe, I would've been able to finish the Yamadaya Tonkotsu Shio Ramen. Broth so rich, pork belly cut bigger than most places, chase so tender, noodles cooked right...so. damn. good...and I couldn't finish it because my eyes got hungrier than my stomach. I need to go back for rounds 2...or 3, esp to try the other broth, Kakuni style. Friendly service and we got lucky to be served within mere minutes of just arriving. Soon after we got seated, there was a long queue outside. Hot tea isn't complimentary, but you get unlimited refills.
author: Shall P.

description:
Met up with some of our good friends in the city during the holidays at this ramen-ya that has a couple of locations in SoCal.  This location in Jtown had just opened and I've frequented the one in Costa Mesa a bunch of times and their tonkotsu ramen is typically on the richer porkier side, I was eager to try this one...

Unfortunately, they had been only open for perhaps a week and they were obviously not ready for primetime.  There were only booths and small tables lining the side of the dining area that was opened up and lined with hardwood like a dance floor.  Originally, I had envisioned us taking up one of their community tables like the ones down south for the 9 of us in our party, but they didn't have the furniture in place yet and crammed us into two booths instead...

From some of the early pics that people had posted, there was a long piece of pork belly that I was dying to try except that they didn't have enough that night and only offered a bit of it in a side dish, some separate embellishment offering extra toppings like half an egg, chasiu, menma, etc..  The Tsukemen that I had didn't seem as hardy as the one I'm used to ordering,  the dipping sauce seemed to have a different hue as well but I ate it all the same...

I have heard that they had recently put in their communal table finally, but it's going to take a momentous effort for us to return to this location when were in the city as there are so many other places for us to visit and our time is precious when we visit.  I hope these guys takeoff, in the meantime I can still get their ramen elsewhere.  The three stars is really too generous for this location based on our visit back in December, but I have a soft spot for their ramen based on other experiences...
author: Lawrence L.

description: Going here, the service was welcoming and a plus side was the wait wasn't long compared to the other ramen place. Their selection of ramen is very exquisite despite their main meat being pork belly. However, their selection of ramen broths is very diverse. From spicy miso broth (what i ordered), house special yamadaya broth to donburi broth.  Overall, the ramen was okay not something that I would lose my mind over but it's better than most places.
author: Dennis L.

description: I have got the chicken ramen and the one with pork belly- both very good but my favorite is the pork belly. They are pretty quick with bringing out the food too.
author: Anna L.

description:
Yep, after two visits, I've confirmed that I'm not a fan of the ramen here. They really shouldn't be putting "black garlic oil" on their menu, because there really wasn't any as far as I could see (and barely any that I could taste). If you want real black garlic oil, try going South to Ramen Dojo, Ramen Parlor, or Maru Ichi (sorry, had to name-names). 

There was just nothing really special about the noodles or the soft-boiled egg at Yamadaya. I've had better of both. It's cool that the egg was soy-sauced brown on the outside, but the yolk wasn't that bright yellow color with the almost-runny-yet-not texture that I have grown to love. Any ramen shop that puts canned bamboo shoots in their ramen also gets a thumbs down from me. It just spoils the flavor of the broth in my opinion. The only redeeming factor was their cuts of meat, which were quite high quality. 

Contrary to common sense though, the ramen in Japantown actually isn't that great! It's actually better in the South Bay -- San Mateo, Mountain View, or Cupertino area.
author: Audrey L.

description: Went there for dinner. The ramen is very tasty, the broth is exquisite and the vegetables were so fresh. I had the vegan ramen. My husband had the one with the pork belly and he said it was extremely tasty as well. Kids enjoyed it too. Definitely a place we will go back to when we go to Japan town.
author: Rupa C.

description: Alexis is The Best! -- It was my first time and I had no idea what to order. Thankfully waitress Alexis (very cute and bubbly) picked out a couple of things for me. I don't know what I ate, but it tasted real good.
author: Germaine W.

description:
The food was good, I have been there twice, both times with friends and family, both times the food was good, but service was not.
First time young asian waiter was impatient and rude. Second time waiters were good but tall overweighted asian manager was very rude and mean. I would be glad to go there again, but I really don't want to deal with the bad attitude from the management.
author: Vladimir P.

description:
Never been to a Ramen joint in Japan,  but from what i"ve experienced up and down Cali...hands down best Ramen Spot i have ever been to. 
Garlic crusher? Check 
awesome cooked pork? Check  
friendly? Check 
noodles?  Thin and thick deliciousness. DOuBLE CHECK!!!
Cannot go wrong here.
author: NoFluff B.

description: Delicious, their vegan ramen is one of the best I have ever tried. The staff is really friendly as well, one of my favorite places to eat in San Francisco.
author: Gerzayn L.

description:
This ramen place is okay. It was very dark from what I remembered and they were playing music from the early 2000s like
Backstreet Boys and Ja Rule. It's located upstairs. I got the skinny noodles which was the default noodle from what I ordered. It tasted like the typical egg noodle. I like the thick curly noodles when I order ramen. I don't know which one that is on the menu. I got overwhelmed and picked something random. I've tried a few more ramen places since the last time I came here so I'm a little more knowledgable about ramen now and know which I like. So the ramen I ate was okay. I think adding fresh crushed garlic makes a difference, tastes so much better. I also ordered the side curry bowl which was pretty good even though it had no meat. I wouldn't give this place a 4 star because it didn't wow me. It's just okay. Would I come here again? Probably not. I would probably try other ramen spots before  coming back here. Now I'm not so sure since this place got a poor food safety score! Maybe I will try their SJ location instead.
author: Jan E.

description: Decided to update since it is now my favorite ramen place. I guess they finally got their act together.  The broth is amazing.  For the record, I almost NEVER drink broth. This is my only exception.  So delicious.
author: S. Y.

description: Possibly my favorite restaurant of all time. Sometimes there are longish waits, but I've never had to wait more than 20 min for a table. The shio ramen is fantastic, and the shoyu is even better. I personally don't care for most of the toppings in ramen(menma, nori, shaved leeks, woodear mushrooms) and they're always very gracious about leaving these out. The gyoza are also amazing, and I'm sure their other appetizers live up to everything else. I've brought lots of friends here and they've all loved it. It's worth the hour drive from where I live to come here!
author: Lily A.

description: The ramen is actually pretty good for American standard.  The broth was creamy and flavorful, very satisfying.  We had a big party of 10 so the wait was longer than usual, as expected.  This place would have had a higher review if it wasn't for the bad staff.  One guy felt too big to help us and kept saying I don't take orders!  (Which arms crossed like he didn't want to be bothered). I get it... but you can say this in a more customer friendly way, "I'll get your waiter to take your order".  When the food came out, the old lady was actually getting mad at our party because we didn't know who ordered what.  Those dish names were all in Japanese.  How did she expect us to know the freaking Japanese name!!!!!??!? I finally went to grab the menu to ask her what exactly is she placing on our table.  She was sooo rude and didn't want to be bothered so she just left!!!  If you are the owner of this place, please talk to this old Filipino lady who was soooo rude to our party!
author: Mg M.

description:
2nd Time, this time we went lunch on Sat 3/15/14 around 1:30pm.  Found free street parking on the street, but the Japantown parking lot is still pretty cheap.

I think the menu has been expanded, more dishes availables besides ramen.

We got:

Tonkotsu Ramen $8.95 with Thick Noodle extra .50c - noodles are a bit wider & more curly.  I liked the noodles a lot better than the regular thin Chinese noodles.

Friend got the Konkotsu Spicy level 1 $9.945 - he seemed to like it, looks really red & spicy when you stir it up.

Gyoza - 6 pieces $4.95 - more crispy top and pretty salty.  We still finished them.

Friend got the Mentaiko bowl & small salad  combo which is extra $4.75 - the rice bowl has some raw fish looked kinda messy, he ate it all.  Small salad looked ok, he said dressing was good.

Now there's a communal table in the middle in the shape of a small rectangle.  It's good for single folks.

Worth a visit still.
author: Ann L.

description: OMG! I haven't even left and I'm already thinking of my next meal here. Where do I even start. The ramen broth is thick with intense flavors. I can't say I've ever had anything like this, not even in Japan. The noodles were perfect, not too soggy and not too chewy. And the Chashu and kakuni .... delicious melt in your mouth goodness! The ramen bowl was topped with scallions, bamboo shoots, wood ear, and thinly sliced garlic. Eating a little bit of everything in one bite is like a party in your mouth. The soft boiled egg was perfectly made, with a slightly leaky yolk. Man, everything about this place was perfect. Service was excellent with fast and friendly staff. Got our food within 10 minutes of sitting down. I slurped it all up in 10 minutes. I'm ready for my taiyaki dessert!
author: Miss L.

description: The ramen here is very good.  Service is ok too. Only complaint I have is that their menu is printed in such a small font size that it's almost unreadable, which discriminates against those with non 20/20 vision and a whole lot of older people.
author: C O.

description:
San Francisco is finally seeing some quality ramen shops to compete with the ones I tried in New York City like Momofuku, Ippudo and Totto, each with their unique blend of broth and noodles taking hold of my palate. First, I discovered Ramen Izakaya Goku in the Mission (review: http://bit.ly/1a2YLTs) and now there's this spot. In fact, advance hype was so overwhelming that I managed to make Jamie W. do something he hates to do. Wait in line. It looked like all the sock-headed, bespectacled young hipsters already knew that this SoCal-based chain was opening in the former Iroha space since there was quite a queue on the stairs. We tried to make our way to the sign-up sheet but an army of indifferent Asian youth apparently learned their manners from Rob Ford.

All of us were gawking at the empty space in the middle of the space big enough for a Jane Fonda workout class (photo: http://bit.ly/KuwHll). Had we known, we would have brought a card table and folding chairs. I heard in passing that they were putting in communal tables, but in the meantime, we all fell victim to the owner's lack of anticipation for a rabid ramen-loving clientele. Probably a half-hour passed before we secured a booth. The menu is all about the ramen - traditional broths, a variety of toppings and plenty of sides (photo: http://bit.ly/1eDRf4k). The wait made us hungrier perhaps by design. We both ordered the $9.45 bowls of Tonkotsu Kotteri Ramen which they describe indulgently as a "Rich and Fatty Ramen with Black Garlic Oil" (photo: http://bit.ly/1a2Y905). Did they really need to add "Fatty"?

What would have been nice to include on the menu are the standard ingredients to be found in the ramen bowl - a couple of slices of chashu pork, half of a hard-boiled egg, some scallions. We both thought it was purely a la carte, so I ended up ordering another full seasoned egg for a dollar (photo: http://bit.ly/JEYHme), some corn kernels for another dollar (photo: http://bit.ly/K0KKyB), and of course, the Kakuni pork belly for $3.50 (photo: http://bit.ly/1gBD41H). Not only did we go gluttonous with the toppings, but we both ordered four pieces of Karaage (photo: http://bit.ly/1lMakDZ) and a salad (photo: http://bit.ly/1hshPSS) for an additional $3.75. When all of it started coming out on separate plates, I felt like I was either in an Indonesian restaurant or at the Hungry Heifer, Norm Peterson's favorite place to eat on "Cheers".

So the verdict? The broth was indeed supremely rich, the product of twenty-plus hours of simmering we were told. The noodles were surprisingly thin, almost saimin-like with a nice al dente bite to them. The slabs of pork belly were generous to say the least. The corn was fresh and plentiful. The eggs looked to be boiled in some soy sauce-based broth judging from the amber color. Put it all together, and it's quite an abundant bowl of goodness that almost made us forget the long wait and snarky hipsters (photo: http://bit.ly/JEYXlk). Almost. Except for one lovely waitress who seemed genuinely willing to be patient with us, the wait staff was a mite pushy which I assumed reflected their need to turn over the tables quickly. Oh well, maybe the communal tables will ease their impatience a bit. But sure, for that broth, we would wait again.

FOOD - 4.5 stars...quite a bowl of goodness, rich broth, toothsome noodles and plenty of pork belly at your discretion
AMBIANCE - 4 stars...felt like I should have brought a yoga mat, so at least I could have used my wait time more constructively
SERVICE - 3.5 stars...a bit hurried though they tried to hide it...sorta
TOTAL - 4 stars...so close to five stars...will probably get there when the hype dies down and they start to use their space more efficiently
author: Ed U.

description:
Had lunch here this week with my group from work before we headed to the nearby Escape Room for a team-building event.

I tried the Spicy Ramen with pork belly. Nice richly flavored broth. Thin noodles cooked such that still have some texture to them. The pork was basically a 1" thick, full-length piece of bacon - it was fatty and luscious and wonderful. 

They only list three levels of spiciness on their menu but I was told that they actually have six levels, the last three of which (made with habaneros, ghost peppers, and something akin to Guatemalan insanity peppers, respectively) sounded like they were daring patrons to try them. I am definitely a fan of spicy food, but I like to temper it when I'm eating soups, so I went with level 2, which turned out to only be mildly spicy. I'd definitely try level 3 next time.

We also tried their gyoza and fried octopus ball appetizers. The gyoza had a nice filling and a beautifully browned wrapper. The octopus balls were crazy hot (temperature) and therefore a little difficult to eat, but pretty good.

Service was friendly and efficient. 

I will say that the place was noisy even when it was 2/3 empty, so I have to think it would be super loud if it were busy.
author: Jason G.

description:
My friend and I ventured into Japantown to grab a late dinner, and we just happened to pick this place because the wait didn't seem that bad for two people. We got there around 9pm and we were seated around 9:30pm. First thing I noticed was the big communal table in the middle, which we were eventually seated at. I don't feel any sort of way about it, I just noticed it first when I walked in.

We ordered the Takoyaki, I ordered the Tonkotsu Kotteri Ramen, and my friend ordered the large Tsukemen. The Takoyaki was melt-in-your-mouth delicious. I told myself I was only going to eat a couple of them, but I think the hanger got to me because I definitely ate like five of them. The ramen itself was delicious, in my opinion. I liked the texture of the noodles a lot better than other places I've been to. Also, I finished every drop of the broth. The egg was cooked to perfection~ And the pork was delicious (flavor- and texture-wise) as well. Although the ramen didn't look to be a huge portion, it was like a never-ending bowl! I have no idea how my friend managed to finish the large size of Tsukemen, but he must have been pretty hungry, too. I definitely could have managed to take some of the ramen home instead of stuffing my face so late at night. I like that when you ask for garlic (free!), they give you gloves of it in a dish wish a garlic press. Nothing better than fresh garlic with your ramen! I think next time I'll splurge and get a couple of the other toppings offered.

Service could have been a bit better. It just seemed really disorganized, like only certain tables or groups or people were getting service. We had to wave someone down a couple of times throughout the evening. But eventually we did get our food and drinks, so I guess I can't complain too much.
author: Eryn H.

description: Where do I start....From the great service....To the amazing ramen! My favorite so far is the Yamada-Ya Koterri. It has a very full flavored broth and all the fixings are just fantastic. I've tried many ramen noodle houses here in Japan Town and this one is by far my favorite, my girlfriend's favorite, and my co-workers favorite! The service is great as well. I do take out often but the dine in experience is great and I love the atmosphere. If you find yourself in Japan Town and love ramen, you will not be disappointed!
author: Dylan G.

description:
I didn't realize Ramen Yamadaya was a ramen chain from LA which only added to my excitement! Truth is, I miss the food in LA and would love nothing more than to visit for a week to get my fill. I was hoping maybe Yamadaya could fill a little bit of that hole in my heart. 

To keep this short and simple, I ordered the Yamadaya Ramen

Ramen portion was good and it had a great al dente bite feel
Broth was adequately seasoned, a decent richness but was missing a certain edge that made me want to go back for more
Proteins was solid and delicious, the belly especially was scrumptious; chasiu pork was ok but nothing special and felt it was dry

Karaage-good portion, lacked seasoning and coating needed more crunch factor 

At this location you can't order extra ramen but you can opt for thicker noodles 

Service was fair and wait didn't exist around 5:30pm when we showed up however that quickly changed. When we left there was a line out the door and saw half the wait list filled out already so get there earlier if you want to avoid the wait.

Overall Thoughts

While it was nice to have a piece of LA again, it was not nearly enough to satisfy my cravings. I believe there is possibilities for Yamadaya but time will only tell when I will be back
author: Eddie W.

description:
This is my go to place for ramen. I normally order the yamadaya spicy (level 3 or 4, out of 6) which never disappoints. It has very flavorful spicy broth, slices of pork, and other fix ins. 

Among the delicious pork ramen options, they offer a completely vegan ramen, which makes my vegetarian roommate very happy. She simply adds an egg and chili to make it a bit more flavorful. 

I'll be back!
author: Sarah P.

description:
My ramen tour of Japantown continues at Ramen Yamadaya. Small upstairs restaurant in the Jtown plaza. There is always a line, but it moves pretty fast - the wait was about 20-30 minutes on a busy Friday night.

AMBIANCE
Not quite so intimate. They have booths around the walls and a large community table in the middle of the restaurant. It was very noisy, with loud music playing in the background. Service was pretty fast.

FOOD
My bf and I both tried the tonkatsu with black garlic oil and thick noodles. I was confused by the noodles, because the thick noodles were still pretty thin. I didn't like the texture as much, and can't even imagine how thin the regular noodles are. The broth was good - it has a nice creamy pork flavor, but not as garlicky as I thought it would be. I was pretty disappointed with the rest of the toppings. The chashu was thickly slice and had a weird, dry texture. The bamboo and mushrooms were sparse, and the egg tasted a little cold. Portion size was decent - I left feeling satisfied, but not overly full.

Overall, nice place but I doubt I would come back with so many other good options around. My search for the best ramen continues..
author: Vivian H.

description:
A very small ramen shop. It's located across the street from the main entrance of the "mall" of Japantown, ontop of Shabu-sen. There is a large empty space in the middle, there is very limited seating. An estimation of around 10 tables maybe. Each booth can probably sit around 6 people max. I came here on Christmas eve, and was seated within 10 minutes. 

I believe that they are open around 5:30 till 9pm for dinner. As well as 12:30 for lunch.
Should definitely double check on this because opening hours are bond to change!

I got the spicy ramen and my boyfriend got the tonkotsu kotteri ramen, and an extra side of chashu. All ramens come with half an egg, one slice of chashu and bambo shoots. The spicy ramen was basically just tonkotsu ramen, with some tablespoons of chilli powder added into it. You can see that it was just scooped inside the bowl, so you have to mix it in when you get it. Overall the ramen was really good. The only thing I disliked was the chashu. It was extra lean. I prefer my chashu to have some fat in it-- like how they have it at Santoku. The egg was really small. Noodles were a little thinner than most ramen places. (Although I'm very indifferent about that)

Oh and there is free garlic upon request. (+1)
author: Jenny N.

description: I don't know why this place only has 3.5 stars, its my favorite spot. Broth and the pork is really good.
author: DJ Madison H.

description: So tasty! I love the atmosphere here too. There is usually a wait so make sure to sign in on the wait list so you can get in. Otherwise, I loved the ramen. I do wish they had more options for vegetarians though.
author: Anny B.

description:
Pretty good ramen. 

Thinking I had adjusted to spice lives outside of my Italian household, I ordered spice level 3 of 6. Boy, was I wrong. Shit was spicy. You know when you're eating somethings decisions but it's really spicy, so it's kind of painful to finish? That's where I was. 

I highly recommend stopping by, but be weary of the spice levels. 

Also, I was with this girl that sounded pretty bad (she said it's allergies, but I'm pretty sure she's sick) and the waiter went out of his way to offer her some warm water and lemon!
author: Matt F.

description: It's rather expensive, but it's not that special. They do give pretty large chunks of pork belly, though. I wish there were more noodles and it was a little less greasy. The environment is really trendy.
author: Serena J.

description: Crazy long lines but the ramen is as good as it gets around the city. I'm a huge sucker for creamy ramen so I fell in love with this place as soon as I slurped on that ramen. I got the Tsukemen, noodles were a bit soft for my taste but soup was amaaaazing.
author: Loan L.

description:
WOW- I am blown away by this little Ramen shop in Japantown. We came spontaneously after a stroll around Japantown, and am I glad we came.

Environment: 4/5
There's a weird awkward square in the middle of the restaurant that could definitely use more tables. Benched seating along the side, very few seats. Minimalistic. Japanese style look fitting for a Ramen shop. 

Service: 4/5
COME EARLY- there was a line out the door when we showed up at 5:00PM, and shop wasn't even open yet! We were seated right away once the business opened for dinner. We were full and got the credit cards back by 6:00PM. Those unlucky people who were right behind us had to wait maybe 30-45 minutes to get seated. 

Food: 4.5/5
TSUKEMEN IS A MUST ORDER! It's Japan's newest trendy dipping ramen- and both the flavor and the texture of the ramen is top notch. My brother and I ended up finishing my boyfriend's tsukemen cause it was so good.

The tonkotsu kotteri was pretty tasty- and yes, I know it's suppose to be a fatty and rich broth- but it was a little TOO oily for me. The Char sui pork is soft and rich and wonderful.
author: Megan Y.

description:
YES! second time here and the soup is still amazingly good. From my last visit, we were not sure whether we had got extra noodles for the boys coz we did not question it. Turns out students get extra noodles on a side plate which we did not get last time, so now we know.  Also, if you like garlic, they give you a bowl of raw garlic and you simply used the garlic masher and mash it directly into your soup...so delicious, especially when I LUV garlic.

Ordered my favorite tonkatsu kotteri with black garlic oil $8.95 plus Yamadaya ramen $11.95. Both delicious as usual, oh and we sat on the wooden table in the middle of the room.  Looks like the owners chairs finally arrived.  Nice communal table, you never know who you might get chatting to.  Seems they seat all the singles and doubles there.

Highly recommended ramen place.  Definitely will go back for more!
author: Elaine Y.

description:
Finally a real ramen place in SF! Don't get me wrong, Katana-ya has been in SF for years, but it's not your typical tonkotsu broth.

Came to Ramen Yamadaya Saturday around 12:00 p.m., there were only 2 groups ahead of us. We sat within 10-15 minutes. Not a long wait at all. However, moments after we were seated the line was LONG.  I also think it's a hazard to have people waiting along the staircase, thoughts?

The beau got the regular tonkotsu, and I got the koterri (black garlic). Both were DELICIOUS! It came with the right amount of bamaboo shoots, one piece of char siu, wood ear and half a smoked egg. The noodles were thinner than I'm used to, but had good slurpage to soup ratio, which was good. I think I liked the koterri broth more, it was more flavorful. The chasu reminded me of the same one used at Ramen Toto in NYC, except it wasn't grilled with a hand torch. 

We also ordered a side of chicken karrage as the beau likes to dip them into the ramen. The chicken karrage wasn't greasy, it was moist and tender inside, wasn't overly fried and didn't have too much batter. We also ordered a side of yamada topping which was enough for us to share. Came with A LOT of green onions, two sheets of nori, extra wood ear (which I would have liked bamboo shoots instead), half an egg, and three pieces of pork (two chasu and one kakuni). 

The service was slow, and it does seem like they're trying to figure out their groove. If you pay with a credit card, they use square on an iphone. They also added a communal table to the center to increase seating, which is good.

I would definitely come back, but would not wait more than 15 minutes.
author: Vanessa K.

description:
Went to this place for dinner last night since Waraku was busy and Sha-la-la across the way was closed for good, which was a surprise since it was better than Yamadaya.

Expect to wait an average of about 20 minutes, and don't forget to sign in on the clipboard.

They changed the layout of the menu for the worse.  It provides virtually no written detail of what each particular menu item is.  I asked the waiter what the difference was between certain ramen and he had no clue either.  What a joke...

There's no longer any instructions on how to order spice levels in the ramen.  You have to already know that there are six levels of spiciness.  Why you would go beyond level two is baffling to me since it starts to no longer taste like anything except a ghost pepper with weird textures.

The 10-pc Chicken Karaage is a great deal.  The batter is crispy and the chicken is juicy.

The Fried Octopus Balls are pretty damn good too.

They changed the shape of the ramen bowls, so it's meant to look just as tall and wide, but you actually get less broth than before since it funnels down more narrowly.  Nice try on the skimp!

I usually order the Shio broth and it does taste good, but the pork slices you get are either all fatty fat, or thick dry chewiness.

The noodles they serve in the ramen bowls are not actually real ramen noodles.  They're a thinner, inferior, and unsuitable version of noodles.  If the noodles were awesome, it would have saved the whole dish from being a major disappointment.

Overall, this place has nothing worth it for me to come back to and it is probably the last time I eat here.

The best place IMO within this block radius is Waraku Ramen.  They don't skimp on the amount of tasty broth and I really enjoy their ramen noodles.  Go there instead; it's much better!  

There is better ramen elsewhere if you're willing to look outside of Japantown.

J
author: John M.

description:
I ordered the Tonkotsu Kotteri $9.95 & "Yamadaya Spicy" $13.45 + $1.50 (changed to Thick Noodles). The meat were so dry & not much of the noodles (maybe just barely enough for a lady). Many other places tasted better. 

*The waitress here didn't give the absolute best service.
author: Wendy L.

description:
The wait was not really worth it for this chain store. There's rarely a wait for the one we typically go to down in San Diego, although the atmosphere here SAS nicer.

Food is still the same; tasty but also very greasy/oily.

The staff also told our vegan friend that the miso soup was vegetarian, then another staff came later with their vegan ramen and said there was fish in the miso soup. They don't consider fish a meat. A direct quote from the staff when questioned about it: "It is vegetarian, it's all vegetables with a little fish."

Also, unlike other restaurants in Japantown, they do not validate parking.

Due to the plentiful other options, I think I'll start steering clear of this chain entirely.
author: Shigeki M.

description:
Ramen in San Francisco is a tricky thing. Some places Know whats up and some places are just sort of going thru the motions. I have found some that are great when they first open only to have the service, quality and attention to detail fall off dramatically. Then a few places are fine on some days but otherwise are inconsistent over the course of time. 
That being said I hope Yamadaya can stand up to the test of time. The location they took up would indicate they are totally committed. The vibe is great when its busy. They have a wide open main dinning space that is very comfortable.
The service is fast but not at all rushed. While they might forget things or miss a few steps they more than make up for it. It's still brand new in San Francisco they have been in L.A. for some time. 

The noodles are not the best I have ever had, but they compliment the broth very well. The spicy tonkatsu broth is great and not overly salty. The cuts of meat are not stingy at all and the pork belly is huge. HUGE! Adding garlic is a must for most as it is free, I could go either way, I don't feel like it adds much to what they put in front of you. It comes as a very well balanced bowl of ramen, perfect just the way it is, with pork belly added.

The Ramen is the highlight here, its really good. In addition to the ramen I also had the Takoyaki and the spicy tuna. The Takoyaki was great! The spicy tuna I would not order again, it was good but unnecessary and a very small portion.
author: Ben M.

description: I tried the Yamadaya Spicy Ramen the presentation is great, you get veggies, creamy broth almost peanutty, a smoked egg and a huge chunks of meat which was the plus! The noodles have a great taste and consistency to them which helped the broth from being too overpowering. The atmosphere of this restaurant is calm at night they have old school hip hop playing in the background perfect way to enjoy a bowl of ramen.
author: Anna S.

description:
My experience at this restaurant was alright. I came here during a festival so it was quite busy, though I wouldn't say it was the reason for the little problems we had. 
That being said, I'd give it a 2.5 stars for the service and a solid 1 star for the ramen. It wasn't great but I wouldn't say it was exactly bad. I had ordered their Kara-age Shoyou Ramen and it was pretty mediocre. The broth was okay, a tad on the salty end, quite greasy and warm... just warm. The toppings in the ramen weren't even all that heated. The chicken and the 1/2 soft-boiled egg were close to cold. I had also bitten into a few egg shells!
A few of my friends had ordered ramen and experienced similar things: cold toppings and broth. One of them said that it seemed as if their noodles weren't defrosted all the way through or something. 
On the brighter-side, another couple of my friends had ordered something different: a Tonkatsu Curry and a Tori Kara-age Bento, which were pretty good compared to the ramen.
Although the food wasn't the best, the service was quite nice. Our servers were kind, but everything seemed a bit unorganized and inefficient. When we ordered, it seemed as if our server didn't know anything on the menu. Our food came out way longer than we expected. We saw a couple groups of people who came after us receive their food before us and left. Oh and we were left with a utensil that didn't look like it was washed thoroughly (i.e. there was still green onion and the remains of a smudge of brown sauce on it). However, keep in mind that it was very busy. It might be better on a slower day, but I wouldn't prefer to come back.
author: Karen C.

description: I came here with my hubby one Rainy morning to get something to eat. It was my third time here and this place never lets me down. I was very glad they had a Korean restaurant near our place, it's just a few blocks away. This time, I tried their spicy tonkotsu miso ramen, which was very delicious and it really suits the weather. One thing I dislike about this place, I asked for a glass of water to one of the staff and I was really pissed because they served it after 10 minutes.
author: Patricia B.

description:
Probably one of the best ramen places that I can think of. One of my Korean friends, who now resides in Korea, says that it's their favorite ramen place in the United States.

Ramen Yamadaya is a cool ramen restaurant literally on the top floor of Japantown in San Francisco. So, if you're lucky enough to get the back corner of the restaurant, you'll see the whole town from that one spot.

The atmosphere is nice as well. Pretty chill, they play some good late 1990s/ early 2000s music. It can be quiet when they're not as busy, but very vocal when they are.

For the ramen, they're great. Beyond what I was expecting! Pretty much, the broth is smooth and tasty enough to finish drinking, with enough noodles and meat to balance out the meal. It's not too salty, and it's pretty hearty. You get the eggs, seaweed, and meat, with your soup. For the price, it's agreeable. Not too expensive, but I feel that if it's at $10, it would be perfect.

I've been here two times, and the wait isn't usually that bad if you have a party of two to four (maybe around 5 to 20 minutes). So, if you ever want good ramen (and possibly a nice view), then come by here!
author: Lawrence T.

description:
Came here on a weekday and ended up waiting about 30-35 minutes which is about half the time I waited at their LA location.  There are probably six to eight booths and they added 8 two person seatings in the "empty" space in the middle.  

I ordered the tonkotsu ramen, which has a rich creamy broth.  It came with two pieces of cha siu, wood ears, green onions, and half a hard boiled egg.  I also ordered a side of corn.  

The hubby ordered the spicy ramen, level one with a side of corn and pork belly.  The pork belly was tender and very flavorful.  It tasted like the Chinese pork jerky. The broth is extremely flavorful, one of the best he's had. He could have drank all the soup but that's probably not a good idea...lol.

There's still some grand opening kinks I think they need to iron out:

1. Limited menu - saw a Yelper review about their takoyaki, but when I asked for it, the server told me it's not available (it's offered in So. Cal).
2. Service is a bit slow and chaotic even though there are several locations in So. Cal. They didn't seem to have their routine worked out.  It probably would be better if they sectioned off tables for certain servers rather than just helping customers as they walked around.
author: Candice H.

description: Went to have lunch here around 1 in the afternoon. Probably waited about 15 minutes before we were seated. I will say, after we were seated, the service was a bit on the slow side even though there were not that many people to attend to inside. It seemed like we waited a long time after deciding on what we wanted and just watched as the servers walked past without acknowledging us. Aside from that, we thought the ramen was enjoyable. I got the spicy tonkotsu miso ramen and ordered it mild. I'm not a huge fan of spicy things, but mild had the perfect kick to it. Overall, it was a good place- not the best ramen or service I've ever had, but a pretty good spot to go to if you're in the area with visiting relatives and can't decide where else to go to.
author: Sarah L.

description:
they seem a bit unorganized here but the staff are all reaaallly nice.
they try to be accommodating to booths/seating requests.

food: my meat was a bit hard to chew. they don't have chilli oil. is this common? lol at least they had chilli powder. food comes out pretty quickly.

also ordered  rice bowl and salad.. i love their salad dressing lmao. wish they could give me some to take homeeee.. yum.
author: Amy V.

description:
Just visited Yamadaya with my friends. We found an elastic band when we ate Takoyaki, so gross! We asked the manager to talk about the big problem, he firstly only said " do you want the Takoyaki for free or a new one" without saying sorry! really disrespectful! Before we left, they gave us 20% off the meal. Satisfied? Never come back!
So disappointed at the food hygiene and the service there.
author: Yiqin C.

description: On a winter day, it's colder inside than it is outside. Maybe it's on purpose so that you appreciate the ramen more, unless you go for the Spicy ramen Level 3 ("Death", vs. "Fire" or "Hell"), in which case the conflict of extremes might cause permanent damage. Not the best ramen around, but not bad, certainly better than the version served at non-specialist ramen outlets.
author: Lam N.

description:
Stuffed. I am Absolutely stuffed.
I ordered the Tonkatsu Ramen, with extra noodles and chashu.
It was quite good, too much food really.
Very rich broth. Huge chunks of chashu and pork belly. Damn good. 
Noodles were a bit thinner than I'm used to but good anyway.
I can't as to speak to authenticity, but for a pasty-faced white boy, this was the stuff.
Makes me wish I lived here.
author: Chuck M.

description:
I was taken here today with asian friends. Stood in line for the better part of a hour. I noticed
that most of the people were asian so I figured they knew if the food was good. We ordered
the fried chicken as a starter ( go figure, fried chicken!!!) It was 10 pieces of VERY HOT small
chicken with a side of slaw and mayo to tame the heat. It was damn good. Then we were
served the ramen my friends ordered. WOW!!! It was so so good! The broth was so rich!!!
Will be back, line or no line.
author: Peter F.

description:
Delicious spicy ramen. 
The egg is lovely, the broth is perfectly rich. I'm not a noodle connoisseur but I thought they were great, not mushy, perfectly chewy. 
I get the spicy ramen level 5/6 
It's just right. 
I love it super spicy. 

The best part is that I get two full meals out of this.
author: Nilu r.

description: Staff was very friendly. They explained the different choices of ramen & they gave really great recommendations! Thank you guys! If I'm ever in SF again, I'll definitely stop by
author: Jackie L.

description:
I've been here a few times and must say it's not bad. However, it seems they might've changed their noodles since my last visit. The ramen here is not life changing, but I liked Yamadaya solely for the type of noodles they served: thin, straight and absorbed the broth flavors really well. The noodles they served last Saturday were still thin, although curly this time (like actual instant ramen) and did not carry any flavors...I'm not one to drink the broth so my meal ended up pretty tasteless. I don't know if they cook different noodles on different days but, alas....disappointment. 

On another note, the service is usually a miss. One of the female waitresses (she's been there for awhile now) must be really unhappy to be working there. Exchanging a few words would be good for communication's sake. For example: "sure" when we asked for tea refills (they charge $$ for tea btw), or "thank you" when handing us the bill when we didn't ask for it yet (which arrived at our table before the tea refill lol).

Also, poor food safety score alert! Now I really don't have a reason to eat here anymore.
author: Mei H.

description: A little pricey but ramen is pretty top notch! their meat portion is a giant slab put in so you will not be lacking.
author: Vivian P.

description:
Ramen in San Francisco pretty much lives in the 3-4 star range, which is why you see so many 3.5 star places when you Yelp "ramen." Yamadaya, in my opinion, is towards the high end of the ramen scene in SF. Hence, a four-star review from me.

Yamadaya is located on the second floor above a shabu place, so it's a little hard to find the door, but once you do, take the stairs up and get your name on the waitlist. They are pretty efficient about going through the waitlist and getting you through the door as soon as they can, but it can still be a bit of a wait during busy hours.

The menu at Yamadaya is really confusing because they try to explain all of the different possible combinations of ramen you can order on a sheet of paper. If you're not interested in trying to parse the menu, my suggestion would be to just order the Yamadaya Tonkotsu Kotteri (black garlic soup base) and be done with it. If you're in a spicy mood, get the Yamadaya Spicy Tonkotsu (same as before, but spicy). If you're really into garlic, order some free fresh garlic to go with your ramen. It's fun to use the garlic smasher, and it tastes really good!

Here's the breakdown on the ramen:
1. Soup - Very flavorful without being too salty, which is exactly how I like it. Doesn't leave you feeling horribly thirsty after your meal.
2. Noodles - Thin and chewy and delicious, but not particularly amazing.
3. Meat - The pork belly is delicious, but they're pretty stingy about how much they give you (just one piece!). Same goes for the chashu pork.
4. Egg - Perfectly soft-boiled, yes!
5. Other - Seaweed, bamboo shoots, green onions: pretty standard.

All in all, Yamadaya is a pretty solid bowl of ramen. The prices are a bit high ($10-$13) which I suspect is due to the great location. As far as ramen in San Francisco goes, this is one of the best you can get, and probably one of the few actually Japanese places in Japantown that I'd recommend.
author: Brittany C.

description:
Very loud music. I asked the staff Javier to have the music turn down not once but twice. The issue was unresolved. 

I ordered Yamadaya Shio. It says in the menu it comes with under belly pork but my Ramen there was NO under belly.
author: Dolly S.

description:
I love the Tonkasu Ramen (level 2), but the rest of the food I have tried there is just mediocre.  Still, I come back again and again for my staple dish.  

It is sort of concerning about the health rating.  I hope they get that cleared up soon.
author: Karl K.

description:
First time here and had a great experience. We had a party of 11 and they accommodated us. We decided to split the group instead of waiting for the table to clear and by the time we got the food we just transferred tables, worked out for us perfectly. The place is small, so I wouldn't recommend doing what we did. Place is better for a 4 person group.
Ok so we had the takoyaki balls, ramen, and tar-tar. I have to say everything we ordered was good. One of the best ramen and takoyaki I have had here in the bay. Actually one of the best I've ever had anywhere. The big plus for myself is that they have both of the items I love takoyaki and ramen, to top it off they were both good. Some places I've been to have both but never had both items satisfy my taste buds.
author: Lanch A.

description: Great ramen restaurant upstairs that is perfect for chilly days in S.F. Can't speak enough about their tasty noodles that were also gluten free to boot!  Definitely will come back!
author: P S.

description:
Took our out of town friends here last weekend. 

I got the fatty creamy pork ramen, and boy, was it fatty and creamy. Wasn't a huge fan, but it wasn't horrible. Usually I'm a huge fan of creamy fatty kakuni broths, but this one was a little too intense for me. The egg was deeelicious and the charsiu was OK. 

We also got gyoza (yumz), karaage (eh), and some curry which was pretty standard as far as currys go.

What really made me smile was their spicy ahi! Brought me back home to Hawaii. Throw some shoyu on there and you're set for lyfe. 

Service was AWESOME. shout out to the lady who served us. she was so damn personable and made us feel welcome the whole time.

Yeah the wait was long, but it's a trendy restaurant and it only has so much space. Food came out fast, so they're trying their hardest to turn tables.

Would eat again!
author: Katie N.

description:
For Tonkotsu fans you will appreciate this joint. I was very skeptical at first, but I must say it's pretty good! My usual favorite spots are located deeper South of the Bay Area, but I am pleased to have found Ramen Yamada as it is conveniently closer.

The Tonkotsu broth is superb. It sure beats many other Ramen places I've been to. It is complex enough for me to appreciate it. Their Karaage wasn't bad either. I give it an above average rating which is better than most I've come across.

The dining area is one open floor plan so you could imagine how loud it can get. It is tough to avoid your dining neighbors conversation. Come here for the food and make an exit. It's not a place for a good conversation unless you like yelling.

Service was acceptable. There was one waiter who always checks up on customers with a positive attitude. Waitresses were nice as well. We accidentally dropped some dining utensils and we were given replacements without asking.
author: Gene B.

description: My favorite ramen place in SF. There is usually a wait but the line moves pretty quickly. Excellent broth! I always order the basic ramen spicy, level 2. It's a very nice portion and I always leave full and happy!
author: Daniel P.

description: We came on a Friday night and it was packed!! We were maybe sixth on the waiting list but it surprisingly went fast and we were seated in less than 15 minutes. It was my first time having dip style ramen and boy was it delicious! The sauce was very flavorful and garlicky! The only thing I would do next time is add more toppings to my noodles as it comes standard with only one piece of pork and half an egg. We also tried their takoyaki which was pretty good, and the shrimp dumplings I would not order again. We really wanted to try their thick cut of pork belly but unfortunately they were sold out that night.
author: Linz C.

description: The wait was incredibly long.  They say 20 min...it was 40.  Food came out quickly, but it was underwhelming
author: Jimmy T.

description: They have delicious vegan ramen.. friendly worker... packed of course but it's worth it... this is located on the second floor!! Remember that :) it's well worth the try
author: Vicky D.

description:
Absolutely one of the worst dining experiences ever for me. 

We arrived pretty early - at 5:35PM and saw there were some people seated but most tables were empty. We were the only people standing in the waiting area but the waitress barked at us and told us to put our names down. ...you don't have to yell... :(

I ordered the vegan ramen while Jason ordered the tsukemen potstickers & salad combo. Both with thick noodles. Also some wine and beer but that's a given.

Jason happily munched away at the potstickers and salad while I observed how sad the wine pour was.... For $7, I would expect the small glass to be at least 1/3 full if not more.

As I waited for my ramen, I looked to my left at the window sill....that was accumulating inches of dust and spiderwebs. Gross...health code violation(s)?

Vegan ramen took longer so I stole some of the tsukemen noodles. We were halfway done when my bowl finally came out.......yet it was the thin noodles. The waitress seemed rushed the first time I ordered, so it was understandable that she may have written the order down incorrectly. I try to catch her eye and finally get her attention. I point out the error and.....no apologies given - she literally just frowned and said OK and then took it away.

Jason and I then see her and her colleagues rummaging through the trash, looking for something...perhaps the piece of paper with my order....? They never washed their hands....We watched.

15 minutes later, I see the waitress head towards our table, and I was starving by this point so I'm superduper excited. She sets down the bowl and I dip my spoon in and take my chopsticks to grab....the same thin noodles again. How. Is. This. Possible.

I again try to flag someone down and I politely point this out, as it's kind of hilarious at this point. Waitress seems baffled, annoyed, and yells "again?!?"
It felt like she was upset with ME for some odd reason. I was really hungry and we were trying to catch a movie and I was a bit flustered so I told her that it was fine. That I would eat this bowl. Again no thank you or apologies! Fine. Whatever.

The noodles were bloated, mushy, and not flavorful at all. Was this the same bowl that they let sit for 15 minutes before serving it to me again??? Because that's what it tasted like.
I only ate the egg, drank some soup and then quit. 

Hungry, sad, frustrated Lisa.

Shit happens though. Maybe it was new staff. Maybe the kitchen was overwhelmed. Maybe maybe maybe... But we went on a Friday evening and the restaurant was not that busy yet... ALSO, If you have a shop that requires a sign-in sheet and waiting area, how could you not be well-prepared with experienced staff and cooks for Friday evening rushes? No freaking way. It doesn't make sense.

More hilarity ensues however as we ponder over how ridiculous the service and food quality has been, despite the reviews. The waitress screams out to the the entire restaurant, "No credit cards today. Our wifi is down so we can't process credit cards. Cash only sorry." A customer asked, "I didn't bring cash, what can I do?" Her response? "Sorry. Cash only! And then storms off."

Wha...what?? At least offer the location of the nearest ATM or walk over to talk to that customer privately. How can you be so incredibly rude?!?? 

Worst part is that she still charged me for the ramen I never ate (and charged me an extra $1.50 for the thin noodles). When I asked, apparently she was doing me a favor since thick noodles are $2.00 extra. I must have looked confused because she then yelled at me and told me not to pay if I didn't want to. I would have rather paid an extra 50 cents to get the ramen THAT I ORDERED.

Speechless.

We paid $40 for our meal - $13.00 of which was pretty much untouched ramen. Didn't wait for change because we were done with the place.


It was the most expensive bowl of ramen I never ate. ugh.
author: Lisa N.

description:
3.5 stars. 

The place is upstairs and it is very spacious. A lot of wasted empty space. Service was good. Ramen was ok. I got the Tonkotsu Kotteri with black garlic oil, add corn. Not bad in flavor, but the broth isn't as rich as I like and the noodles are thin. I like thicker noodles. I did like the chicken karrage and it was a huge portion and the gyoza wasn't bad.
author: Karen H.

description: Although it is a ramen place, they serve other stuff too like Katsu curry and rice bowls.  Pretty authentic Japanese food.  There is also "Death Ramen" which is insanely spicy
author: Sunny S.

description:
Don't forget to bring back your receipt.
I spent $63 but they charged me $126!!
I called them 10 times but they never answer their phone!!!!
I had to contact my credit card company.
author: Hara K.

description:
I believe this is a chain ramen house. Overall, I thought it was a pretty average bowl of ramen but it did leave me satisfied. The portion seemed a bit on the smaller side for a $10-13 buck bowl though. 

I really enjoyed the thinner noodles and felt like the broth had a good body of flavor. The broth was pretty fatty, but I found the thin noodles complimented the broth well. Chashu was tender and juicy, would have loved an additional slice though. I ordered the tonkatsu kotteri (black garlic). 

Our waiter was great and attentive. Bowls came out VERY quickly. I'm sure I'll be back to try their more staple bowls. Waiter did recommend the kakini ramen spicy.
author: Christy C.

description:
There aren't many places in SF that you can get Tsukemen ramen (deconstructed ramen / dipping noodle) so I tried it here, and it did not disappoint. The broth has great flavor, and was not too thick or tooo oily. The noodles were thick as tsukemen ramen should be, and it came with these toppings: seaweed, half of an egg, bamboo shoots, green onions, and ONE piece of chasu pork. They could have def given more than one slice of chasu, but the ramen was also only $9 something, so I'm not complaining. I'd def come back and try the other traditional ramens next time! They also provide  fresh garlic and grinder/smasher upon request.

Note: Students get free large noodles/rice upgrade, so bring them Student IDs!
author: Karen O.

description:
I'm trying to think of a spot in San Francisco where I've had better ramen and nothing is coming to mind but I've only been to a half dozen places so for now this is the go to standard.

The noodles are great and the broth even better. I will be back.

It is, just as the rest of Japan Town, a little bit of a dive.
author: Justin S.

description:
The service here was hilariously terrible. 

First, we were shown to a shared table, despite there being empty individual tables available. Was this server really not trained to ask our preference? BTW the shared table features 1000 watt lights, I guess for the cacti in the center of the table - should have brought sunglasses. 

Then I simply asked for a miso ramen with their basic $3 combo topping. "Um, I'm pretty sure we can only do that topping with regular broth" said the shifty eyed waiter. Knowing this wasn't true, I asked again, but got the same bizarre response. 

The coup de grace was when we were leaving, and, not being able to flag down a server, went to the cash register area to pay. This was the conversation:

"Two checks please."
"I can only do one check." 
"Well, we want two checks." 
"Again, I can only do one check." 
"Well, just pretend we're two diners eating separately."
"Again, that's impossible. I can only split the check down the middle." 
"Well, we got different items."
"Again, I can only split the check down the middle, or do separate items."
"Ok [trying not to laugh], so do two checks, each with the items each person ordered." 
"Oh, I can do that." 
"Isn't that the same as separate checks?" 
"No it isn't." 

Ramen was average, and mine was lukewarm, this place is a mess.
author: Nick C.

description: This place was pretty good! My only complaints are that they give you very little broth and the noodles are those thin friend noodles not the thick chewy fresh kind. The pork was excellent and they give you lots of it! Took awhile for food to come but it wasn't too long. Would come again for sure!
author: Garett S.

description: I ordered the tonkotsu kotteri. The pork was tender and not too fatty. The soup was rich and fatty. The eggs were perfectly cooked with the yolk having a nice dark colour, slightly runny consistency, and a soy like flavour. The noodles were thin and firm. However, the black garlic oil did not contribute as much flavour to the broth as I would have liked.
author: James S.

description: The broth was super thick and not very flavorful. I did not enjoy this ramen experience.
author: Mike C.

description:
After a long hike up in the Marin headlands, ramen was the first thing that came to mind as my reward of choice, and Ramen Yamadaya was the first choice recommended.

My friends are very familiar with the San Diego store and their excitement for its SF counterpart really set the mood. Starving, tired, and hopeful of a satisfying meal, we quickly ordered. 

The first thing we noticed was that our server seemed to be having a bad day as he was stand-offish and all but slammed our cups of ice on our table but no matter, we were there for the food.

My table all ordered their usual, a Yamadaya Ramen with tonkatsu kotteri, large portion of thin noodle, and fresh garlic. Unlike other places that serve garlic on the peninsula, Ramen Yamadaya literally gives you fresh cloves of garlic and a garlic press to mash to your own liking. Their Yamadaya Ramen is like their deluxe option with two types of meat and 3 sheets of seaweed.

The ramen itself, to me was not up to my liking. While I've never had ramen from Japan or frequented to so-called 'authentic' ramen places in the US, I felt that the ramen had many qualities that I disliked. The broth itself was flavorful but SO very thick. The thin noodles weren't chewy at all and seemed like they were purposed to soak up the grease from the broth as opposed to being a noodle in a noodle dish. The charshu was thick like a piece of toast at not at all tender or flavorful. The pork belly pieces and soft boiled egg were delicious though. 

For a 13 dollar bowl of ramen, I expected a lot more. If you're used to, and favor ramen from the likes of Ramen Dojo, Ramen Parlor, or Kotetsu, you will find that they are not at all similar and may walk away unsatisfied. If, however, you are into the type of ramen that is thick ,greasy, and in a word heavy, this is your place!
author: Christopher L.

description:
We went on a Saturday night at 7:30. There was a wait but if you live in San Francisco you expect to wait anywhere. It was only 30 minutes until we were seated. I asked if we could have a booth but they wanted to use it to seat a party of 5 that was up next, no biggie so we sat at a communal-ish table. I ordered the koterri ramen and it was fantastic! So much garlic, so good. The broth is rich and packed with so much flavor. I asked for half the amount of noodles because I hate wasting them if I know I won't eat them. The pork belly was delicious as was the perfectly cooked soft egg and the chashu pork. It was a bowl of delectable indulgence. 
After we ordered,  the co-owner who sat us came back over to us and declared "come with me if you want to live" and gestured for us to go to an open booth. Yay! I wasn't expecting that. He was very nice and friendly and chatted with us for a little bit later when our ramen came out. 
Go! Eat all the things and drink all the drinks! It's worth the wait. 
Pro tip, you can go inside and order drinks and enjoy them while you wait in the stairwell.
author: Sarah M.

description:
Yamadaya is one of the best ramen I have had in San Francisco. I like it so much that every time I try a new ramen place I don't like it. 

My usual is the tonkotsu ramen spicy level 2. You have the option of getting extra noodles. And you can always have extra garlic to put on the noodles. Always put the extra garlic to add some zing to the noodles. 

We also try the potstickers which are good. They also have green tea mochi to cool down your stomach after that spicy broth. they cook their broth for 24 hours which makes it so special. 

I come here at least once a month and the ramen is always consistent and delicious. I took off one star because the service can sometimes be slow.
author: Priyanka P.

description: The ramen claims to have "meat" all it came with was fat, they don't have any hot sauces and if you would like some chili paste it's an additional charge. A ramen bowl is $14 and it doesn't even fill you up. I would never recommend this place to anyone.
author: Amida W.

description: I would give this place 3.5. Firstly the ramen was. It as good as I was expecting it to be. The noodles were too thin and the broth was not all that great. I would say the Kakuni that you can add to the ramen was well worth it and tasted great. We also got the karaage and gyoza. The karaage that came with rice were cold and the rice was very dry and cold. The gyoza was okay but I could make better gyoza by buying the ajinomoto gyoza sold at Nijiya. All in all, it was an okay experience, but will not be coming again.
author: Miu K.

description:
After 2 visits, so disappointed!

First time here (5-6 months ago), it took about 30 minutes to seat. I'm a super cheese fans, so I ordered the Cheese Ramen. Oh NO! WHAT?!!  They put a lot of cheese powder on top only, No cheese soup.... It was expensive and very disappointed.

Second time here, took about 15 minutes to seat.  I ordered the YAMADAYA Ramen.  The broth was thick, very salty and too oily.

Honestly, I probably wouldn't come back.
author: Mushroom K.

description: A decent hakata ramen joint, with a nice and fatty kotteri tonkotsu. I got the tonkotsu with the yamadaya additions, and got a small mentaiko rice bowl and side salad. The food is a solid 3/5, and a solid place for a hearty bowl of noodles and soup. Unfortunately, the staff is inattentive and pays barely any attention to their customers -- we didn't get any water and waited for a good 10 minutes (with my hand raised up) before we could finally pay our bill and leave.
author: William C.

description:
It's pretty good but I totally forgot to get the side order of crispy pork belly.  This is a chain ramen shop with locations all over the state and it was featured on one of those food shows for the side of crispy pork belly.  Go figure that I'd forget to order it.  Oh well, next time....

The ramen itself is solid.  It's a medium size place so sometimes (especially weekends), it can get pretty busy and there might be a slight wait.  But the service is quick and efficient so the turnover is fast as long as people aren't lingering.  Sometimes they do.  It's in Japan Town so if you don't like to wait there are plenty of options abound.
author: Chrys S.

description:
Overall, the food was not mind-blowing, but also was not lackluster as well. We patiently waited for our server to notice our waving, and had to wait about 10-15 minutes before they even attended our table. The wait for the ramen was exceptionally long (20-30 minutes), considering that I've been to plenty of other popular ramen shops in the Bay Area and the wait time for ramen is typically around 10 minutes long. 

We started with the octopus takoyaki balls which came steaming hot. After biting into the takoyaki, it seemed that 85% of the ball was dough and 15% was octopus. The dough itself was good, but it also seemed as if it wasn't cooked fully as the takoyaki dough was a bit too mushy for my taste. Overall, I would still order again. 

The Tonkotsu Kotteri with thicker noodles came in a large bowl with a beautiful proportion of soup to noodle ratio. I wasn't particularly a fan of the toppings which included bamboo shoots, mushrooms, some odd crunchy almond-looking pieces that ended up being too spicy for my taste, green onions, and a semi-soft-hard boiled egg. The pork was soft and fatty, and complemented the soup well, which was a good balance of flavour and thickness/creaminess. While I found the broth the most satisfying part of the bowl, the layer of oil was a bit disconcerting. No one wants to eat ramen and consciously realise that they are eating a load of fat! I found the thicker noodles too limp for my taste, but prefer them much more to the thinner noodles which I prefer for lighter noodle dishes such as pho or soba. 

Overall, the food was more than mediocre and I didn't leave disappointed in the food, but more with the service, or lack of. We had to ask for water multiple times, flag down the multiple waiters for a check, and then finally had to go up to the cash register to receive our check. The food took too long to make, and everyone knows that ramen is more of a machinated meal. It seemed that the waiters were too occupied with whatever they were busy sorting out at the cash register, than the customers. The entire restaurant was full, and it seemed like most people were disappointed with the lack of service (and food!)
author: Jennifer S.

description: If I could give this place -5 stars I would.  I've been here before and the Ramen has been good.  Was just there sitting there and 2 parties of 2 that came well after me and my friend were seated.  When an Asian couple complained that multiple parties of 2 were getting seated sooner they got seated--and they came after us and signed in after us.  My friend and I left and will never go back.  This is the second time in 2 days I've had bad experiences at restaurants in SF.
author: Justin K.

description:
tasty, one bowl is totally enough for me. tried fry chicken, good too. tried sliced beef on the rice, never order that again, the beef taste weird, i do not know how to describe.

try the noodle first.
author: Heart A.

description: Awesome place and delicious broth. The reason for the 2 stars is because I was lied to and they changed their noodle choice.   My first 2 times was spectacular, but this current 3rd time something was different.   I asked our waiter if the noodles were different.   He straight up lied and said nothing was changed.  The current noodle is straight, not very ramen like, which was somewhat curly and kind of chewy.   The straight noodle lack character and doesn't seem to hold the flavor as well as the curly noodles.   I hope they change back their noodles.
author: Jerry Y.

description:
Nice place in Japan town. Ordered the koturi ramen, broth was pretty good. Although I would prefer the noodle to be a little al dente. Came with all the goodies, eggs, meat, bamboo, etc. 

Also got karage chicken, portion was big was for the price . It was juicy, a nice snack. 

Great server!!
author: Nhung T.

description: Service was indifferent at best. The ramen was average. The Kakuni was very dry, thick, and tough. The meat was too lean, and the chef should have cut it thinner.
author: Ryan L.

description: A great ramen place in Japantown San Francisco. Located on the second floor. Very good broth and good quality toppings. Could be a line and wait times, but worth it.
author: Peter K.

description: Very nice ramen for cold day!  Noodle and soup was very good generous portions.  Always can add more noodles and other things you can add to your noodles and make it your personal dish!
author: Alice K.

description:
How funny, I ate here exactly almost a year ago...and on a wednesday! 

This time I had the tonkatsu shoyu base, and I didn't quite enjoy it. I must say though, we just came back from Japan...SO our expectation now is...pretty high.
It was extremely "flavorful" as in salty, didn't like the black oil...garlic flavor maybe? I also think i prefer thick noodles to the thin ones they use.
The husband got the Yamadaya Ramen, less salty than mine, satisfying enough for him.
Gyoza and salad for me, too much dressing in salad, gyoza is average. skip
karaage- still juicy. good to get.

service from the ladies working was really nice, she was cheerful and always around. I think maybe the manager? The asian guy who sat us, didn't smile, didn't say hello or anything when we came in...he was a turn off....he was nicer at the end, when we left though. so maybe his day was just starting and needed a warm up?

oh and I hate the stairwell! so many flies UGH.
author: Christine M.

description: I remember Yamadaya when it was a different place for years. They have changed the interior somewhat but it seems a bit rough in the decor dept. The food was decent enough but like every place in Japan Town it's pretty so so. Ok, not bad but nothing to write home about either. Their posted health score was like an 83 and what keeps me from giving it a 3 is the fact that my bottle of house sake had a long hair floating in it. Of course they gladly replaced it but you know.....
author: Steven B.

description: Hands down within the top 3 best ramen shop in SF. Nothing can go wrong with any order for this place.
author: Willy S.

description:
One of the most legit ramen here. Probably one of the best on this side of the world. The tsukemen I had was pretty decent. I highly recommended having karage. It's fried to perfection. We all adored this place for its good ramen. It might not have adapted itself too much to American taste buds but this is how ramen and the creamy tonkotsu should taste like.

I personally prefer my noodles a little more kata. Flavourful rich creamy broth that doesn't try to cover up the lack of depth with pepper. If only, it super convenient to get to Japan town.  You'll find me here every other week.

Students get you upsize of noodle for your tonkotsu. The menu pricing can be a little confusing so check it with the staff if it bugs you.
author: Han Teng W.

description:
mmm, finally trying yamadaya in sf after visiting their LA locations a few times when i was traveling down there for work.  came in with a girlfriend on sunday for lunch, and there was already a few people waiting for the shop to open up.  interesting - must be a good sign no? restaurant has a large communal table in the middle, and different size booths and tables along the walls. 

alas - yamadaya was notttt excellent. first, service was pretty terrible. the waitresses 1) didnt look like they wanted to be there at all, and 2) were super choppy with their questions about what we were ordering. like abrasively so. ughhh. 

we ordered - fried chicken and spicy tonkatsu level 3 - with a side of corn toppings.  the chicken was JUST what we needed because we were both hungover - but it would've been kinda bland if i didnt need the grease so badly.  now. the ramen. broth was super salty - might be the effect of level 3, but i was not impressed.  toppings are all right - side of corn was brought separate instead of in the noodles, the chasu was pretty well cooked. you can ask for additional veggie toppings - but they were OUT that day. like out of spinach and bean sprouts. on a sunday. what.

overall not impressed - probs wont be back :(
author: Christina L.

description: On a cold gloomy day, I was so excited to find Yamadaya available through Postmates, I ordered Kakuni koteri w/ extra egg and a side order of takoyaki. Broth had great flavor and consistency, the protein was silky and fatty, and perfect soft boiled egg, with the yolk still runny. And every time I get ramen from them, I always finish the broth as well.
author: Danny V.

description:
WARNING: if you want any substitutions for your ramen, DO NOT go here. The staff refuses to substitute corn ($1 on the menu to add to your soup but it comes with the vegan soup) for seaweed (also $1 to add on the menu but does not come in the vegan ramen). In addition when I ordered my vegan ramen they ran out of the spinach noodles that they normally use so I asked if I could have ramen noodles but the server said no, that I HAD to get the tomato noodles instead because that was the only substitution option...I know the staff is not intentionally trying to be difficult but the fact that they are inflexible with their ramen (I also wanted to try the shoyu soup with vegetables instead of meat and they said no) is pretty ridiculous and frustrating. It really is not difficult to substitute a vegetable for meat and it would actually cost them less to substitute for veggies. 

In addition I wanted to mention that the wait time to be seated is usually 30-45 minutes on a fast day and for some reason they were not searing anyone in the 12 seat round table at the center of the restaurant when I ate there both times which would alleviate a lot of wait time. If you do not meat and do not appreciate long wait times and are particular about what goes into your meal, I highly recommend that you find another spot to spend your money at.
author: Bernice N.

description: Extremely terrible service!! Been living in sf for quite some time and would always like to have ramen there because of the great food. However, the service has always been bad since my first visit, and it's getting worse. After  experiencing couples times of bad services, I just started to feel the need to write my first review on Yelp. It's always been a long wait even when tables are mostly unoccupied. The waiters refused to let us choose the seats even when it's not busy. Food is served with fingers in the soup!!! I hope the management team of the restaurant will look into the service level of this restaurant!  It should be on par with the gray food you guys serve.
author: Ydel J.

description: I tried their signature pork broth ramen, wasn't pretty bad. We were lucky there was no line so we didn't have to wait but didn't make sense we still had to put our name on the list there were tables open. Any ways I had the ramen and it wasn't too bad but my friends got the spicy ramen got #2 spicy and it was pretty a spicy. They have a scale from 1-10. Ramen not bad but the service wasn't too good. The booth they were going to seat us at was by the window and had a funky smell.
author: Joyce K.

description:
Literally as soon as we were seated and ordered our food, a wave of a million people showed up. We were thinking maybe we were famous, but I was seriously convinced it was the food.

BEST. RAMEN. EVER. The pork fat ramen that I got was well worth the walk from Union Square.

Located in what I would say was the heart of Japan Town there in SF, Ramen Yamadaya quickly introduces you to it's signature dish, their Ramen.
