They have a picture with some words that say just how long they marinate the bones for to create the broth, and I swear that the hours it took to make that broth were very well worth it.

Service was amazing, and she was really on her A game that day handling multiple tables and groups, and she didn't mess up anything at all.

Thank you Ramen Yamadaya, well earned 5*.
author: Stanley M.

description: Ramen was good. Went around 9pm and so the wait to get seated wasnt that long. The wait for the food was around 15-20 mins but it was worth it though. They were generous with their meat unlike other ramen places ive been to.
author: Micaela A.

description: One of the best ramen places I have been to in the city. Be prepared for a long line on the weekends though!
author: Nitesh C.

description:
First time here and we arrived on a Friday night around 8:30pm and there were 8-10 parties ahead of us. The line went pretty quick and we finally got seated. And sweeeeet! We got a booth just for me and the hubby. The place looks really hip, modern with a very energetic vibe. We figured out what we wanted and waited a good 5-8 minutes before someone came to take our order. The waitress was very nice and helpful when asked about their popular dishes. We ordered two ramens-spicy and reg kotteri and added the Karaage (fried chicken) with rice for an additional $4. The chicken came out first and it was pretty good-chicken was moist and it wasn't too greasy. It came with lemon mayo and a bit of veggie with dressing. After we got the chicken we waited another 20 minutes for our ramen. When we finally get our ramen the broth looked really really thick and extremely oily. After eating about 1/3 of it I couldn't eat anymore (which says a lot cuz I pretty much can eat anything and hate to waste food). The pork belly was so thick and fatty and not in good way. It look totally different from the picture on their menu. The noodles were good but the whole dish was too much flavor for me. Even the hubby said so too. I decided I would just eat plain white rice with a little bit of my broth. 

Cool place and I probably would give them a try again in the far far future but next time I'll try another type of broth.
author: W W.

description:
My husband and I ordered the Death Ramen. 
The rich broth and hearty portions of meat were a strong accompaniment to the deep spice. The eggs were wonderful. The yolk was perfect  and made me smile. The other toppings were wonderful flavor bursts that made the spicy broth all the more enjoyable.
This place deserves a solid 5 star rating. It's a popular ramen house, there's a wait. It's worth it.
author: Natalia T.

description:
I went here for dinner Thursday night, and it was pretty busy even before they were about to close (I was here around 9pm). I waited about half an hour before I got seated, then ordered the Tsukemen ramen with a side of menma, corn and mushrooms and a potato salad.

Pros:
- Menma was super yummy, had a little sour/limey kick to it, unlike menma I've had at other places,
- Ramen and corn was good
- Good service, we had two people checking on us often and were happy to get us anything else we needed

Cons:
- Broth was way too salty 

The potato salad was interesting. I don't think I've had it the same way at other restaurants before. They had two scoops of potato (just potato) on one side of a dish and the salad w/ vinaigrette on the other side. Normally, I see the potato mixed in with the salad or something lolol. The potato salad was tasty though, just different.
author: Vy T.

description: Broth and noodles are excellent. Their default is thin noodles, but they provide the option to change to regular thicker noodles (more ramen shops need this). Service is excellent. Be careful about the spicy option. They didn't give enough broth but way too much spicy flavoring, which made it hard to handle even though my tolerance is fairly high.
author: Albert Z.

description:
I've been here before with some friends, the food at the tim was ok, didn't have to wait too long for a table, the experience from that visit, was acceptable. However, what I experienced tonight, completely blew my mind and greatly disappointed me. I will never be coming back again.
My mom and I decided to have dinner here, as we had just finished walking around Japantown. I knew the food was ok, had it only once so I decided to give it another shot. The wait time wasn't too bad, ~20 minutes for a party of two, with I'd say eight parties ahead of us, that was fair game in my opinion. We were sat down, the manager had to inform the waiter we had been seated and were ready to have our order taken down. I just got the regular shoyu ramen dish, however my mom is a vegetarian, but they did have a dish for vegetarians, there were no signs of difficulty. 
After we ordered, we were using our phones, looking at the restaurant, 10, 20 minutes went by, we were wondering where our food went. Normally, it doesn't take that long, or if it does, usually the waiter/waitress would have the courtesy of letting us know our food was almost done, and it would be served shortly, within a few minutes. Our server didn't even come by and let us know. What makes it even worse, the two tables to the left and right of us, already did one rotation of customers, and the second party of each table, even got their food and drinks, yet we were still waiting on our food. At this point, both my mom and I were very angry.
We called the waiter over, and they said it was taking such a long time because they had to make vegetarian broth. Please, we know how to cook, it doesn't take that long to make vegetarian broth. Then, I took it to the manager, even then, he gave me the same, unacceptable reason, with no sense of seemingly apologetic. 
Our food finally arrived, ten minutes after my brief talk with the manager, they made my mom's dish horribly (one of the factors, seemed like they didn't even rinse the noodles in cold water, it was in a huge lump), my broth tasted bland, even my noodles weren't to my satisfaction.
Bottom line is, don't come here. Horrible customer service, food isn't even good. If you're searching for an actual decent ramen place, this isn't the place to go. There are a bunch of other ramen restaurants in the bay, I'd much rather go to Ryowa in Castro, Downtown Mountain View, and we would have went there if we weren't so hungry.
author: Hannibal C.

description: Good ramen, horrible service. If you're going to go anyway, get the kotteri ramen and add a spice option.
author: Kyla K.

description:
So far the best ramen places I've ever been to :D
Not so many options tbh, but ramen and some appetizers are delicious. They offer a pretty wide range of spicy levels (I remembered it was 0--6) 
Personally level 2 is good enough for me since I want to taste the flavor of broth instead of just spicy. But I believe it will be fun to try out their death spicy level. 
Might be some line up during lunch time, but not really bad, approximately 10--15 mins of waiting.
author: Yuan X.

description: There's always a wait at this place, so make sure to go either at peak hours, or wait in line. On average, you would probably wait for about 15-20 mins.. Weekends, probably 30 mins. The soup and noodles verryyy yummy. Soup is rich and dense. noodles al dente.. Not too hard, not too soft... the char siu is tender and nicely fatty.. Price is reasonable as well.. service could improve as there are often times not enough staff to tend to all of the tables.. If there could be an extra server, I believe service would be an A+.
author: Samantha W.

description:
Tried it for the first time. 
All the food was tasty and came out of the kitchen at good temperature and promptly. 
I thought the broths, both for the ramen and the miso soup, were a bit over salted. 
The deep fried chicken and fish were right on, not greasy at all. 
The decor is sparse and almost industrial in look. 
The clientele is definitely toward the young and hip side. 
Will return to try out other menu items.
author: The Foodie O.

description: The waiter and the waitress were totally rude. Started cleaning up the whole table before we were done. I wouldn't come here again
author: Saki S.

description:
Great, great, great food. Very cheap, very affordable and good service. 

They were clean and got us in quick and timley. And the location is in a better part of the city and a personal favorite; Japan town.

For ramen lovers I'd say this all little place is a must.
author: Evan D.

description:
I was afraid that we may have ended up disappointed due to the mixed reviews of this place, but we were very pleased!  We arrived around 6 on a Tuesday night and there was still plenty of seating..in fact we scored the last window seat.  I like how they have a wide variety on their menu.  They even have a vegan ramen option.  Our waitress even explained to us all the toppings and popular choices.  It was a tough decision but I decided on the Tonkatsu Kotteri ($9.45), he got the Ramen Yamadaya ($11.45) with the tonkatsu kotteri broth and we shared an order of the chicken karaage ($6.95) as well. 

Our food was served to us quickly with the karaage coming out first.  It was 10 pieces of fried chicken goodness.  The pieces were big and plump and juicy.  It was fried well and not greasy either.  The dipping sauce was like a faint mayo.  We liked the side cabbage salad with an asian vinaigrette dressing.   Next came our bowls of ramen, they aren't the huge bowls that some places serve or once served, but the portion was just right.  His toppings came on a side dish.  I'm glad I asked for the free garlic topping as well.  They gave us cloves of garlic and the press.  We love our garlic!  The tonkatsu kotteri is a rich tonkatsu broth with black garlic oil.  It was full bodied with the pork flavor, and I did taste the garlic as well, but wanted a more prominent garlic flavor so I pressed one clove into my broth.  Made it even better!  The toppings of mine included the bamboo shoots, half an egg, the mushrooms, green onions and one slice of cha shu.  The Cha Su was slightly thicker but it had a great soy marinated flavor and was tender.  Noodles were al dente.  His toppings were the same with the addition of a nice size slice of pork belly.  The pork belly had a good meat to fat ratio and tasted like it was braised, fairly tender as well.  Both of our noodles were the thinner style (I think it's the Hakata style).  I believe there's at least one ramen item on the menu where it includes the traditional thicker noodle at no extra cost, otherwise it's 50 cents extra.  Although tonkatsu broth is to be thick and rich, it was a little thick for his liking; I loved it but I felt a little "jai' (my fellow Cantonese know what that means) later that night.  I can tell that a lot of time and love goes into their broths and meats.  

Food came out without much of a wait, place was clean and had simple mod decor.  The service was very attentive, friendly and helpful as well.  He likes Ramen Izakaya Kagura the most in San Mateo (part of the Men Oh and nearby J-Town Ramen Waraku Group).  I'm actually torn because I love both Ramen Izakaya Kagura and Ramen Yamadaya.  I would say out of all the other traditional ramen places in SF that I've been to: Waraku, Men Oh, Sozai, Izakaya Sozai, Sawaii, that Ramen Yamadaya is the best.  I do absolutely love the ramen at Kaiju Eats though, but that's more of a fusion style.  It's a tough choice, but I think I'll have to give Ramen Yamadya a 4.5 for now.  Hopefully I can give an update soon with a 5.
author: Cat C.

description:
Pros: Vegan ramen right on the menu, fresh garlic and a press given to you so you can add as much as you want yourself, a decent range of ramens, toppings, and other types of food. I also like the really large communal table and they seat you well around it so you're not really grouped up with strangers too much. If you prefer something a little less cozy with people you don't know, you can request a table (but you'll wait longer probably).

Cons? Service was pretty bad. We watched the two guys across from us get the incorrect food brought to their table three times before they finally got what they'd ordered. We sat there for almost 15 minutes before our ramens came out and we watched two other people get their orders before us despite it looking more complicated than noodles and soup and being seated after us. Seriously, it's noodles and broth and vegetables, it's not that hard to slap together and get out in under 10 minutes (and the place wasn't even that busy to warrant such a delay). Aside from having our food not delivered in a timely manner (and actually also brought out separately with about 2 minutes between my partner's food and mine), the waitress was on top of everything else (garlic delivery, water refills, check). 

The ramen is pretty good here and I really liked the broth. Noodles weren't the best I've had but they have some variation such as spinach and thick (if you swing that way). I felt like the portion size was a bit smaller than some other places, but it was good enough for me. 

Overall the food was good, but the service needs a lot of work (loss of one star for that).
author: Cassandra J.

description: There was a long line when we arrived but since they were mostly groups of 3+ there was little wait for this party of two. $10 for a large Asahi beer that is easily shared. Our total was $50 dollars for the beer, two ramen with combo (4 gyoza and a salad and gyoza/rice).  The gyoza were fresh and reasonably good. The rice not so much. The salad had a nice fresh sesame dressing but was little more than greens, radish slice and a cherry tomato. The ramen was the best shio broth we've had In quite some time, very good pork, the eggs were stellar though. Smokey whites, custardy flavorful yolks. Made me wish I'd added an extra egg instead of corn. We will return.
author: Shaz P.

description:
FRAUDULENT OVERCHARGE!
I had dinner and paid the check with credit card leaving more than 25% tip. However my bank account transaction (no pending) showed an additional 20% more than what I signed!
Will never come back!
author: Laura L.

description:
I can't say I'm an expert on Ramen, but it was really good. Didn't blow my mind, but the consensus from the locals we spoke to waiting there was that it's in the top 3 for casual food. 

Got the Kakuni spicy, did a 4 at the waiter's recommendation. It wasn't crazy spicy but really worked. 

Girl got the yamadaya it was good. 

I'd go if the wait isn't crazy or anything and you want decent ramen. 

Two bowls and 10 oz sake was $50
author: Nate A.

description:
5th time having ramen here, the past 4 visits were awesome. Flavor, authenticity, everything was great. This time however I ordered the Yamadaya speciality ramen spicy level 2 as I usually do. It was delivered to me with corn in it (which I didn't order) and so unbelievably spicy it wasn't edible. This is coming from someone who loves spicy food and the associated heat. This was essentially the spice level of eating the chilis right out of the jar. The "assistant mgr" visited my table, when I explained that I was a previous visitor of 4 times and that something was wrong with my order he offered to comp $8 of the bill. No offer of replacement was made. 

If you deliver a repeat customer of multiple times something that they tell you isn't correct, you should comp the entree or at least offer to replace it. This wasn't done. I'm sorry to say that I highly doubt that we'll be back. I'd love for someone in management to reach out to me here so that I could share with them my experience.
author: David C.

description:
This popular JTown ramen shop is across. From the Peace Plaza mall on the cobblestone cluster of eateries which are gradually becoming more Ktown instead of JTown. It is upstairs across from a Korean Karaoke bar, and a Korean Soon Dubu place. 

There is almost always a wait; no rezzies, only a wait list. The place can pack about 50 strong, with 2s and 4s on the right side, 4/6 booths on the back window wall, more 4/6 on the left, and a large community table in the center for onesy-twosys. 

They profess to stew 20lbs of pork bones for the broth for 20 hours. They offer several selections in Ramen styles, and as typical you can add extras for extra. 

On this visit, which was about 8pm on a Monday, they were still full from the 7pm rush, although there were a couple of singles available on the community table. 

I ordered the Kotteri Ramen, which came out quickly. The broth was tasty, not overly salty, the noodles were just right, not mushy or too hard. There was only 1 piece of Cha Siu, half a boiled egg, a lot of negi ( chopped green onions) and the crunchy tsukemomo type condiments. I enjoyed it but have had more ingredients at similar prices at other places. 

Service was good and Japanese. 

This is a good go-to spot in J Town for Ramen, but go early or late, or prepare to wait.
author: Wanugee N.

description:
Pros:
- Delicious ramen. I recommend the kakuni ramen and add a side of chili sauce
- Fresh garlic cloves and garlic press provided when they bring your ramen 

Cons: 
- Can often have fairly long wait times so I'd recommend showing up 30-45 mins before you'd like to eat
- Service has been pretty spotty each time I've gone (water isn't filled frequently, forgot about someone's dessert order)
author: Stephanie L.

description:
I'm not gonna sugar coat this people. I could devour a bowl of their spicy ramen as an appetizer, eat your bowl as my main entree, and then scarf down two more bowls from the table next to us, not freaking kidding.

The spicy ramen is definitely the way to go, but you need to get at least the level 2 spicy... Unless you want to challenge me to a spicy beat down contest? Sure bring it on, don't forget to bring your box of Kleenex when you lose and cry out of your nose.

We also ordered the chicken karage, which were crispy, and perfectly juicy (just like how I prefer it like everything else), and a massive slab of pork belly. The ramen, is filled with explosive orgasmic flavors. So much different things going on, I asked for a side of fresh garlic and squeezed in around five cloves into my bowl, giggity giggity! 

Well what are you waiting for? Let's get this challenge started!
author: Hungry Dan o.

description:
Came with my housemate a Friday night. Wait was not too bad. Food arrived quickly.

I got exactly what I asked for: disgustingly spicy ramen. I got the tonkatsu with their highest level of spice: Level Death (6). It'd say on a scale of 1 to 10 with 3 being what you consider spicy when you put Tabasco on your food, this ramen starts out at 6 and builds to 8 as you keep eating it. The soup is delicious until you stir in the heaping gobs of chili paste into it. Then it just turns into a mess of spicy goo. I've had a lot of spicy foods in the past, and this was not the spiciest thing I've ever had, but it was really hard to eat. Once I was out of noodles and toppings to munch on, and croquette to dip into that "broth", I had to quit. I am sure it is possible to drink the soup, just as it is technically possible to drink hot sauce, but what is the point? Anyways, you can't taste anything besides the chili paste in this dish, which is bitter and a bit grainy tasting. Even the fresh crushed garlic was overwhelmed.

On a side note, the gyoza was really delicious. I'm a glutton for punishment, so I'll probably be back.
author: Audrey D.

description: Ramen was delicious! While we waited for a table I really enjoyed the complimentary citrus water.
author: Paloma M.

description: Finally took a trip to Japantown and looked up "Ramen" on Yelp. My friends....when I tell you that the ambiance is (extraordinary) I want you drop what you're doing, look up the dictionary definition for that word and sound it out slowly...because this place was that amazing. The staff was professional and cheerful! Plus The food didn't take too long to arrive, there is definitely enough time to sit and talk to your friends or whoever like regular human beings and not stuck on your devices. In conclusion, the ramen was delicious, flavorful, spicy, warm, and satisfying, I will be coming here in the future and will look forward to all this goodness! Highly recommended!
author: Martin C.

description:
This restaurant replaced Iroha which was here at this location for a long time and had been one of my longtime favorite for ramen (that was before expanding on the places I would visit for this). I looked forward to the opening but at first was discouraged from coming because of not-so-good reviews in the beginning. This is until recently my friend suggested coming here for dinner. At the time I checked the Yelp review and noticed improved ratings so I looked forward to trying it.

The thing that stands out here is the noodle. Unlike other ramen places I've gone to, their noodle is very thin. I found that I like this in that it creates a different experience unique in its own way.

The menu does not include miso broth (my usual favorite) but the choices they have are quite good from the two times I came. When I came a few weeks ago, the menu says you can choose from six levels of spiciness and the server ask you to specify. I picked level four and even that was overly spicy but in a good way because it represented habanero style. However, when I came last night looking towards this again, I found the menu changed and they don't have the six spiciness levels anymore, and the server didn't ask how spicy I wanted my bowl. I was slightly disappointed but style very much enjoyed the Kotteri ramen I ordered.

I can safely say this is now now an additional favorite in Japantown, which is needed since I gave up pretty much on having sushi and sashimi here (with one place as an occasional possible exception).
author: H K.

description:
1. Service - very inconsistent. the servers seemed overwhelmed - most likely understaffed.  They took our order fairly expediently, and brought out the drinks quickly.  They were nice enough to exchange my chair for one that didn't have the narrow metal bars.  But then they forgot 2 of the items I ordered, even after repeating them back to me and specifically asking me a question about how I wanted 1 items to be served.....so I know it wasn't that they didn't hear me.....they just didn't put it in when they entered the ticket.   Then it took a good 20 minutes after we were finished eating for them to come by so we could grab the check....and then after they dropped off the check another 20 minutes to get their attention so we could give them the payment.

2. Food - The ordering is a little confusing - the photo made it look like the Tonkotsu Ramen I ordered came with pork, but when I got it there was no meat in the soup. If I had known I would have ordered some meat. Or maybe they just forgot the Chashu....cuz it's clearly shown in the photo on the menu.  The broth is tasty, but wasn't hot, just warm.  the shoyu egg was overcooked and there was only half an egg in my soup.  the garlic topping I ordered never arrived and the waiter never returned after dropping our soups so I couldn't ask for it.

If the Ramen had been AMAZING or even very good, I would totally overlook a lot of the little annoyances...but it wasn't any of those things and that was disappointing since this joint is supposed to specialize in Ramen.
Save yourself the trouble of the walk up the stairs and just go across the way to Shalala or if you come on a Monday night like we did and Shalala is closed....go somewhere else...ANYWHERE else.
author: Slinky ..

description: I came here with my friend who's an exchange student from Japan. Her friends recommended this place for her birthday. The place is very small. There aren't enough servers, but the time we came wasn't very busy so we got a table. However, we had to wait outside before getting called in to be seated. There's not a lot of options of ramen. Just the basics. There's only one ramen for vegans which I got because it's the month of Lent and I couldn't have any meat, unfortunately. The takoyaki balls were bomb! This place doesn't skimp on the bonito flakes and you can definitely taste the octopus.
author: Monica Colleen D.

description:
Pros: 
-Their ramen is decent 
-their tar-tar chicken is a spot-on! Very juicy and tender!
-Good price!

Cons: 
-Worst customer service ever! no eye-contact from servers and they will hand you the bill before you finishing your food. 
-sticky table, their tabletop are sticky!!!!! EEEwwwwwwww!
author: Fiona F.

description:
I got the Tonkotsu Kotteri broth with kakuni, corn, egg and it was really good. The chashu that came with the broth wasn't that great but it doesn't matter cos the kakuni was more than enough to compensate. It wasn't overpowering and it was seasoned and cooked to perfection. The broth was rich and slightly sweet, not too salty, just right. I added 3 fresh crushed garlic in it, I could've added more but I was busy scarfing it down. In retrospect, I think 5 cloves would've done it right and it could be a little bit spicy (there's an option to do this) and I completely forgot to order the extra black garlic oil. I'll definitely come back to do all that 

I also ordered the karaage and it was also very good! Light batter and slightly salted, the chicken was hot and juicy! I would order it again.

Service was good, we came around 5pm which was a good early dinner time. The host was very funny and nice. Our server was also very helpful in explaining the menu!
author: Angela A.

description: Great ramen, friendly service. It's one of my favorite places to eat in Japantown. They have a pretty big assortment of sides as well in case you'd like to eat things besides ramen.
author: VI Y.

description: Compared to Sacramento ramen spots, this place hands down wins. I finished my bowl within 10 min of getting it. That good. I would highly recommend this place.
author: Russell G.

description: I don't eat meat. I ordered a ramen with no pork. When the ramen comes it is presented as having no pork. As I began to mix my ramen (chili sauce) there is BAM pork. Luckily I didn't eat it. I ask for a new one they take it back and state they will make a new one. Two mins later (it usually takes longer to make) I was like oh cool. I look at it, it's the same Ramen!!!! I told one of the waiters, he replies it was freshly made. I told him it was the same one and I knew because I put my sisters eggs in mine so there were four eggs ( opposed to the usual two) and plus it was already mixed so that was another sign.
author: Trisha M.

description:
Tonkatsu = Breaded deep fried pork cutlet 
Tonkotsu = what you can get at Yamadaya 

Totally legit, almost like how they are in Japan.  When I go eat tonkotsu ramen I always ask for "hard noodle" if the waiter doesn't speak Japanese.  Yes, you can do it too.  I find noodles in US ramen shops too soft, often.  

Currently Yamadaya is one of the most legit ramen shops in the Bay Area, especially north of the Bay Area.
author: Taka T.

description: One of my go to places for Ramen in the bay. Usually I get the Kakuni ramen, the broth is thick and hot and the noodles are made write that they are soft and filling.   Plus the Ramen is pretty cheap compare to other Ramen houses in the area.
author: Jimi Y.

description: Last night was my second time here with my cousin. I ordered the yamadaya korteri combo with a small spicy tuna bowl and salad. The meal was delicious, I also got a good serving of pork which made me really excited. My only issue was I thought the broth was a little thick. Maybe it's supposed to be like that but just for my taste but I actually prefer a lighter textured broth. Nonetheless, this place is one of my favorite spots to get Ramen
author: Rommel A.

description:
Wanting something warm and soupy on a chilly SF night, I came here on a Saturday night with 3 other friends. I've been to the Ramen Yamadaya location in West LA and I knew not to expect anything too amazing. 

I ordered the spicy miso ramen (level 2). The broth was good, but the noodles were nothing special. They reminded me of noodles you can buy from an asian market that are already pre-cooked. There was nothing really special about the ramen I got here. 

The service was a bit slow, probably because we were eating at a prime dinner hour. Overall, I've had better ramen, but Ramen Yamadaya is good enough to satisfy a ramen craving.
author: Melanie H.

description: Best ramen place in SF? Not even close, but a decent bowl of noodles, particularly with a different type of noodles (thin versus thick). Makes for easier food delivery system. My girlfriend and I both went for the Yamadaya Kotteri (rich, fatty broth with garlic oil). The deal that goes with ramen bowls is particularly good though. For about $4 more, you get a side of gyoza, kara-age, etc. and salad/rice. Solid, solid deal, especially because we went for just one combo of kara-age and salad, and it was good enough for two people. What I like about their ramen is that the noodles don't lose their springy consistency even though they're not traditional ramen noodles. They also stack your ramen high with scallions, two types of pork, bamboo shoots, and seaweed. However, the noodle portion is smaller. For $14, sure, I can taste that I'm getting fresh pork, the way mom would make it, but my noodle portion is tiny. When my girl and I go to Yummy Yummy and order pho (of similar size), I can slurp noodles for days. My bowl for the ramen was large, but the portions weren't. The broth itself was also just mediocre. A little heavy on the salt, rich for sure, but nothing special where I'd want to come back. I don't know about the rest of these reviews, but service was great. The food is just meh.
author: Danny C.

description:
Very good tonkotsu ramen. The noodles are pretty thin, very similar to what you'd find in a cheap package of store-bought ramen, but more dense and chewy like you want ramen to be. The broth was delicious and the pork had great flavor. I don't do eggs, but my wife said they were perfect and tasted amazing. Definitely a great bowl of ramen. 

I wasn't crazy about the plastic chopsticks, spoons and bowls. Also, the booth I was sitting in smelled like pee. Otherwise, the experience was fine.
author: John B.

description: I love the ramen with garlic oil! The soup base is very rich, creamy, and flavorful while it's not very salty (I was able to drink the soup after finishing the ramen). There's also a lot of meats in the bowl, not just a few thin slices of pork. The ramen noodle itself is average, nothing much special, it's like the 'angle hair' type of ramen. I would still give the ramen itself a 5 star! Minus one point because of the service. Our server gave us an attitude, and it feels like she hated her job. And she never came to check on us. About the environment, I love the center table where there is a terrarium in the middle. But there were many people waiting outside for a table while there's a lot of seats available inside, I guess probably there's not enough kitchen staff?? Nonetheless I will still come back again for the ramen (not for the service)!
author: Karen C.

description: My family and I were visiting San Francisco and were referred to this restaurant when we asked about a good ramen joint. We had never eaten Japanese ramen before. We were had no idea how anything would taste or what anything meant on the menu for that matter. The waiter was great and was very patient while explaining everything on the menu. He gave us a popular choice and we went with the Tonkotsu. We were amazed at how fast the service was also how great everything tasted. We like coming to S.F. so we will stop here every time.
author: Anthony V.

description: Goooood ramen, excellent broth. Love the added egg, bamboo shoots, pork belly, and seaweed that come as a standard in most of the bowls. Reasonably priced. Nice ambiance. Fast and efficient service. Oh did I mention Beyoncé, Keyshia Cole, and Usher were on the playlist?! Awesome!!!!
author: T E.

description: This place is delicious the bowls of Ramen are the best. I had pork belly in my Ramen it was to die for. The broth is like cream.
author: Bryan R.

description:
My first review was fairly soon after their opening, and less than a week after I'd gotten back from a trip to Japan. So, my standards might have skewed too high, especially for a place still getting their opening week kinks out.

I've been back several times, and I'd say they hit most of the bases to make a solid tonkotsu that pleases most but doesn't blow anyone away. But, the main problem with this place is the lines. Maybe they get all the people that think the best place for Japanese food, including ramen, is in Japantown and that this must be the best ramen around.
author: masa s.

description: Food is really good. Really good ramen! It is quite noisy though and the line is usually long. I still think it is worth the waiting.
author: Nicki X.

description:
Food (4/5): My new favorite ramen place in the city!

 First off, the menu is super confusing since the pictures are so small. Each bowl of ramen comes with half a soft boiled egg, bamboo, chashu, green onion, and seaweed. If you want a full soft boiled egg, more chashu, and kakuni (pork belly), then ask for the yamadaya topping, which is about $3 more. 

I got the spicy tonkotsu (level 1...okay I'm weak haha) with yamadaya topping, and my bf got the tonkotsu kotteri (fattier broth) with yamadaya topping. The spicy level 1 was the perfect amount of heat for me - not too much to where I'm struggling to eat, but still enough of a kick to add extra flavor to an already very flavorful, creamy broth. Noodles were cooked just past al dente, which was perfect for me.

They're also really generous with the chashu - we both got 4 thick pieces. The kakuni was pretty inconsistent, though - I got a huge piece but it was literally all fat. The other toppings were all fresh and well prepared (esp the soft boiled egg!).

Service (5/5): Our server was really patient in explaining the menu to us and making sure we knew what to order. Our food came out pretty quickly, and our waters were refilled often!

Value (4/5): The ramen is really well priced for being in the city. It's not as big of a portion as some other places, but one bowl is definitely filling enough. For two of us, the bill was about $30, which I think is totally reasonable for SF ramen.
author: Abby S.

description:
This is a good place to go is you're looking for a quick average place. The wait is a little long during dinner but their service is quick so everything goes by fast. I came here with a group of ten people and we finished in less than an hour. Very average food! Simple and satisfying. We had nothing to complain about but there's nothing really to be praised about. Only their side of spicy tuna over rice keeps me coming back.

The second time I came back, our server seemed to be a little high (or intoxicated in some way) and kept misunderstanding us. He had to come back clarity our order a few times and stumbled around. Very unprofessional but it didn't distract us too much.
author: Kimmy L.

description: Food and atmosphere was decent.  Was never offered a drink refill, but food came out fast.
author: Michelle W.

description: Ramen soup has too much fat and oil. Bento box is not good too (I ordered fried seafood bento the most expensive one and the seafoods were over fried much!) Desert (Muchi ice cream) disappointed us too it was hard as stone and should be the one directly bought from a supermarket and was kept in fridge for too long). Won't go there again.
author: Luke S.

description: I was really excited to try this after all the hype and wait in line. Out of the ramen places I've been to, this definitely ranks in the bottom tier. We had the takoyaki, shio and spicy ramen. The broth was waay too salty...I had to dilute it with water. Also, the ramen came out lukewarm. Takoyaki was average. Not worth the wait in my opinion.
author: Amy S.

description:
Happened to be in Japantown and decided to give this ramen joint a try. We came on a Sunday evening just before sunset so half the restaurant was bright and sunny due to the setting sun. As a result, they couldn't seat half the restaurant as it was too warm. Wasted! 

The service was meh... I was curious about the difference between their signature yamadaya ramen and the normal ramen with different flavors. The waitress tried to explain it to us, but she spoke very fast and with a strong Japanese accent that we couldnt really understand her. When we tried to clarify, she didnt let us interrupt her and told us to wait while she continued her long unintelligible explanation.

I had the spicy miso ramen (level 2). It definitely packed the heat. This, coupled with the rather warm restaurant made it rather uncomfortable to enjoy the ramen. Nonetheless, while the broth was tasty, the noodles were rather subpar. I was hoping for springy chewy noodles, and this was definitely not that.

The fatty ramen with garlic oil broth was really good, but it was, as the name suggests, super fatty. There was so much oil in it that it is impossible not to feel guilty for eating it.

Probably would not return again since there's many other awesome ramen joints around.
author: Christina N.

description:
It has been a while since I've come to Ramen Yamadaya but it is still delicious. I love coming here and be early or it gets packed quickly! The restaurant itself is pretty spacious but they put you in tables so close together that I feel bad when I am trying to inch into my seat. 

I typically get there Tonkatsu with black garlic oil and it is amazing. The only thing is that the broth feels like it is missing a kick which would probably be the chili oil but I refuse to pay extra for something most other stores have as a condiment on the side. I do however love that you can get fresh garlic and press it into your ramen! 

If you come here I recommend getting the takoyaki because this is by far the best deal around town I think for under $6 you get 7 pieces and I always forget that they are piping hot but so delicious!
author: Angela S.

description: Been here and waited for our order to show up for more than 40 mins. People were seated way behind us got theirs much earlier than us. Not impressed by the ramen for this long of wait.
author: Fanny Z.

description:
Ramen Yamadaya is definitely one of the better ramen joints in San Francisco. 

Broth is solid, they've pretty much got that down. Only thing I do not like is the thin ramen noodles. Those come standard so if you're like me and you prefer the thicker, al dente ones, ask for them. I believe it costs a little extra too. However, if you go for tsukemen (dipping ramen) it comes with the thicker noodles already. 

For those that don't know what tsukemen is, continue reading. The hot broth comes separate from your bowl of cold noodles. Your toppings are on top of the dry noodles. Grab a few strands of noodles and dip it into the broth for however long you like. 
Love the tsukemen. Pretty damn good, although the broth was a bit overly salty. Still, they're one of the few handful of joints that do this. The difference is that Yamadaya executes it better. 

I'm a fan of the tonkotsu kotteri ramen. Pork bone broth with a bit of extra pork fat and black garlic oil. Robust, rich, thick, fatty, savory. Definitely order it with the thicker noodles (the thin ones tend to break apart quick) and ask for a side of fresh garlic (free). Press a clove or two of fresh garlic into your bowl, stir it up, and enjoy! The added fresh garlic just gives the broth a little bit more OOMPH! a little extra umami ;)

Skip the takoyaki and gyoza. Just eat ramen. 

Service is friendly and welcoming, I've never had any issues nor have I ever had long of a wait.
author: Susy C.

description: Super delicious ramen with very nice noodles I'v never had anywhere else. Not sure if they are more traditional or less, but super good.
author: Clark C.

description: It took us more than 30 min to get a simple frie chicken order, wich we found out later they have been forgotten! And we also had ask 3 times for knives and forks!
author: Sid C.

description:
Clean restaurant w/ a friendly staff that will not rush you out even if there are people waiting for a seat. Very nice and polite.

The noodles, I felt, were too small. Yes, you can order extra noodles but there wasn't much in my bowl. Every topping seems to be an add on so it racks up. Thought my soup was also very oily.
author: Julie L.

description:
You'd expect Japantown of all places to be the holy grail of all ramen shop finds, but none of the restaurants here have met my expectations! Would Ramen Yamadaya be the first Japantown ramen to appease me? Mostly, yeah!

Ordered myself the Tonkotsu Kotteri style ramen. Probably had the thickest broth that I've ever seen in a ramen. So thick that it starts to kind of coagulate on the surface if you let it sit for a bit. Good taste to the broth though, which is the most important thing. Noodles were a bit of a shocker though. They resembled glass noodles more than regular ramen noodles. Like, they were perfectly straight like hair, and almost as skinny! Nothing wrong with the taste at all but it was totally weird to pull up pho style noodles when eating ramen. 

There are however, two huge problems that I cannot overlook. The only problem taste-wise is with their Chashu pork, and it's literally the only thing holding it back from being up there in the ranks of my favorite ramen restaurants. It was slightly dry and chewy, and there wasn't much flavor at all. Also, with the Kotteri style ramen, they literally pour a top layer of oil on top of your ramen, and it just seems like the most unhealthy thing ever. Like, there was literally a layer of grease in my mouth that would not go away for the longest time. 

Intangibles were alright. Restaurant was super hot. Like crack a window open or something! Kind of an awkward big rectangular common table in the middle of the restaurant. Have fun facing some random people that hopefully have good etiquette. Service was pretty chill, and the price was alright. 

Ramen Yamadaya is actually my favorite spot so far in Japantown when it comes to ramen, but it's still a step away from being a usual haunt of mine.
author: Sean H.

description: Love Japanese culture, anime and food.  I have been 5-6 times now.  Recently I went with friends and they weren't fans of their 2 bowls, but I liked mine a lot (they tried mine and like it as well).  I chose the spicy one and asked for the spicy sauce on the side so I could add and stir as I went.
author: Jaiden F.

description:
Great service and great ramen.  I had the spicy ramen level fire and boy I bit off more than I can chew.  I was pretty drunk so I don't recall the name of our server, but the cashier name on our receipt says Abraham.  Boy, he was very fun to interact with and he took care of us very well.

Food was awesome, fire level was indeed too much for me. Hottest of all habanero peppers indeed, and I love that pepper. The broth was rich and yummy though. Definitely will come again.
author: Mich N.

description:
Horrible service.

Just because your internet is down, that doesn't mean you can be rude to your customers.

Learn to inform your customers that it's cash only due to technical difficulties before they sit down, order, and eat their food.

Not coming back here.
author: Ashley D.

description:
Before you question why the 3 stars, let me tell you first that I am a BIG fan of Ramen Yamadaya. Back in my UCLA days, I used to always go eat there and it hit the spot. I LOVED their soup broth and the amount of spicy/chili sauce they add in it. Don't forget about their egg and chasu, too! 

Anyhow, I was sooo excited that they have one in San Francisco (Because I thought it was only a socal thing). I told my dad and brother that we MUST eat here and it was one of the best ramen I've had. Anyhow.... I order my usual Tonkotsu Kotteri Level 1 Spicy with the yamadaya topping for $2.99 which includes everything. 

Presentation wise looks exactly like how I used to have it. However, something about their soup broth and chili sauce was off. The broth was WAYYY too heavy and salty. The chili sauce didn't even make the soup that much spicier. In fact, it felt like it added in more salt than it already needs ... I'm in awe of words. I can't believe my favorite ramen place turned to be such a disappoint. I felt bad to have teased my dad and brother that I wanted to pay to make me feel better. 

Other than the broth though, noodles and meat were right on point! Better than many places I've had.
author: Fiona L.

description: The waitress makes you waiting for nothing. There were many tables available . They learnt this hype from orenchi ? To make them appear or feel popular ? Childish. And they gave me very small portion comparing to others. Don't know why.
author: Vegg C.

description:
It's alright.

Haven't had ramen in the sf area for a long time, so didn't even realize there were so many "new" ramen places (well....to me they are new). Friend wanted to go ramen yamadaya so I gave it a try.

They were pretty packed on a Saturday. Three of us waited for around 20 minutes to get seated. They had a few choices on the ramen and we all decided to order the tonkotsu kotteri ramen. It came out around 10-15 minutes later. 

What I look for in ramen:
Broth - it was pretty thick, not bad.
Noodle - I think the thin noodle was over cooked. It was relatively soft, not "al dente".
Egg - I like my egg with runny yolk when I eat ramen, so it failed because it's not runny.

These are usually my main focus on judging a bowl of ramen. Ramen yamadaya didn't quite pass my standard. It was just alright.
author: Louisa L.

description: My best place in SF. Spicy one's are awesome!!! Ramen, karaake, orion and hot sake combination!!
author: Lee D.

description: 2nd Floor Jtown. Did not have to wait at 1:15 Saturday afternoon. Got luck. 1st time here. Food is good and enough. Only downside is the appetizers.  There is a reason why it is called appetizer because it comes before your main course. Alson never a refill with tea and water.
author: Jesiros B.

description: Ramen is really yummy! Service was okay kinda slow. When we (four of us) it was around lunch time so it was little bit more busy! The broth was really good, and ramen was presented very pretty! My bf liked his beer
author: Sally H.

description:
Maybe I should have ordered the pork belly. It looks darn good in other people's pictures. I was kind of disappointed in this place...and only giving them an extra star for having good wait staff who put up with our delayed friends. We were supposed to meet at 7PM...I got there at 7. Next person at 7:15. Next at 7:30. Last person arrived around 7:45. Oops...Asian time.

We shared some chicken karrage and takoyaki...and both were kind of meh. The chicken karrage was good, but not amazing. Takoyaki was stupidly tiny for the price, and not really flavorful. The octopus in there was the size of an eraser...on top of a pencil...that's already been half-used. 

I got the yamadaya ramen, which was ok...but they have a thin noodle which I don't really like as ramen. I'm more of a slightly thicker, crinkle cut ramen person. But these thin noodles looked horridly lacking for me. So sad. I saw on yelp there's an option to change to thick noodles, but they didn't have an option for us. Maybe...that additional 45 minute wait had something to do with it...

Whatever person compares this place to Orenchi is not being accurate. Seriously, you can't compare the 2. Broth (Orenchi is better). Meat (Orenchi is better). Egg (Orenchi is better). Noodles (Orenchi, or any other place is better). 

Ambiance was decent. Wait staff were very attentive and nice. You could also see the chefs cooking, which is always a bonus. 

Oh, and this spot is on the 2nd floor. So once you reach the address, walk upstairs for the ramen. I saw a hand-written paper sign that directed me, otherwise I would have walked into the downstairs restaurant.
author: Lily W.

description:
There was a line during dinner time on a Saturday.  The wait was not bad though (10mins only for a party of two).  I had the Yamadaya ramen with garlic based soup.  Soooo delicious!! 

Servers were very attentive. Food was brought out quickly.  The only con was that the ramen noodles were too soft. I prefer the firmer noodles. 

A must try!
author: Goldie L.

description:
I came here with my sister for dinner on a Monday, and we had to wait about 15 minutes to get seated when we got there a little after they opened. It kinda sucks that their waiting area isn't in an actual room, more like an outdoor spot with a door and windows because it was freezing! There are stools for you to sit at while waiting; at least there's that.

We got seated and we both ordered the tsukemen (dipping noodles in a fish flavored broth). We read previous reviews on it being too salty, but when we got it we both felt it was just right. Each tsukemen dish comes with a piece of seaweed, bamboo shoots, and a piece of chashu pork. They offer a 7oz portion and a 14oz portion; I felt the 7oz was good enough especially if you're trying to get dessert afterwards. Friendly service and staff. Definitely a small restaurant, so do get there when they open if possible!

I think I would come back to try their other dishes, but for my first experience with tsukemen wasn't bad at all.
author: Kathleen S.

description: This used to be my favorite Ramen shop. I've been going to this place for years and sad to say it gotten worse and worse and worse maybe more commercialized so my rating has gone from a five star to a three star in three years.
author: Miguel Y.

description:
Filthy!

Look closely as you walk up the stairs to the second story restaurant and, once inside, at the walls and corners. They are filthy. We were seated along the south wall.  Couldn't help but notice that entire ledge along the the south wall was covered with a layer of dust and that the southwest corner of the restaurant dining area featured a well-grown spiderweb.  I didn't look into the kitchen area, but based on what I could see in the dining area, I can't see how the restaurant owner considers cleanliness and sanitation important and would keep just the kitchen area clean. 

Without even ordering any food, we got up and left. This was my second time here. The first time, we ordered, ate and left unimpressed by the poor service. But I'm not coming to this yamadaya again unless ownership changes. 

If you go there, look around. As a minimum requirement for any restaurant, don't you want a clean environment? does it seem sanitary enough for you to consume their food?  In my experience, this yamadaya is the filthiest japanese restaurant I've ever been in anywhere in the world. we are not cattle that'll consume anything thrown our  way.
author: Akir M.

description: Ramen was warm and service was slow. Wish I read Yelp before coming. Health safety rating is before 5%. Plus side the noodles were ok.
author: Calvin B.

description:
The overall rating of this place is average. I've been to places that are better. If you like spicy food, I'd recommend their spicy tonkotsu ramen (it's not on the menu but apparently there is a secret level 4 spiciness if you want to give it a try).

Pros
- Many adds-on options from thick noodle to extra soup
- Free fresh self press garlic (very interesting)
- Great price point

Cons
- Relatively slow service (might of be under staffed)
- Appetizers might end up serve after ramen (this happens to me a few times)
- Only the ramen is decent here (i'd say don't bother order anything else :/ )

If you are hungry and close by, go ahead and head on in for a quick meal but that's about it.
author: Sze Wa C.

description: I have a Service Dog and this has by far been the worst, most disrespectful service I've ever had. The wait staff was nice enough but according the business policy they couldn't let my Service Dog in- which is illegal- and asked me to leave her outside. When I explained that by law they're required to let her in with me they told me I'd have to talk to the manage, which is fine, I understand that business policy is above their head and they're only doing what they've been told, but the manage was incredibly disrespectful and rude. He wasn't in so I had to talk to him over the phone. He told me that it was against the law to let my Service Dog in without some sort of state paper or doctors note, I informed him that I don't need any sort of document and asking for it was illegal. He continued to deny me access to his business and it was only finally resolved because I called the police, who showed up and told him yes, he does have to let my Service Dog and I in. Again, the wait staff and food was decent but I've never been treated so poorly before.
author: Kitt C.

description: Good service and the interior design is well-appointed. The food though - not good. I had the tsukemen. The broth is too thin and not hot enough at service (in fact, every bowl we got was just warm). The noodles were OK but stuck together by the end. And, the chashu was cold and dull (I took a bite and didn't continue). The shoyu was a bit better. One of my friends liked it, the other didn't. Nobody liked the spicy tuna bowl. Ultimately I stopped eating and we left to get something else (an extremely rare occurrence).
author: Andrew G.

description:
This is my 3rd time being at Ramen Yamadaya. However, my crave for this place is decreasing after times I visited. The quality of food is getting worst than the first time I been here. The first time (December 15, 2015), the noodle and the favor of the soup is at a good balance level. What I mean balance is the texture of the noodle is not over or under cook and the soup is tasty and with rich pork favor but not too salty. The second (February 6, 2016) and third time (February 14, 2016) I noticed that the noodle is a little bit of overcooked and the soup has changed. It is not the same soup as I first time had it. There is no more pork favor, less rich as before, at the light side of the salt (close to no salt) and last but not least, the presentation of the ramen is closed to zero. 
Now, I should talk about their Kara-age. The first time I have it, me and my friend ordered the 10 pieces order. It was unbelievable big pieces of chicken sitting on the plate. It was tender and juice. No batter on the chicken. Totally impressive. However, I have there on the second visit, it is a totally different story. The chicken is un-seasoned, small and overcooked. No more juicy tender chicken.... ~~crying face~~ 
I think I will still give this place another chance since their first impression is too unforgettable. But I can say that, it will not be any time soon.
author: V L.

description: The service and the food was amazing! We loved Abraham and all of the servers. Everything was timely and delicious.
author: Heidi R.

description:
Way below any Ramen standard. Broth was unflavorful. The only thing that tasted good was the egg and the water. The pork shu mai tasted rotten, I spit it out. Pot stickers tasted like the premade frozen ones you buy at the grocery store. 

I came with a party of seven, and an infant we waited on the list for about half an hour until seated. Then when my name was called she kept saying party of four and then tried to seat us at a booth made for 6 with no where in site to place a high chair. 

A tip: Shabu-Sen directly downstairs.....100% better! It's a shame you have to give stars, I dont think it deserves one!
author: Melanie P.

description:
Wait times can be long if you're with a big group and it's busy, but always so worth it. I come here at least 3 times a month because it's just that good! My favorite is to get an extra portion of noodles with my student ID! 

Can't go wrong with any of the ramen choices! Love the takoyaki too!
author: Alison M.

description:
One of my favorite Ramen spots in the Bay Area. 

I always get the Tonkotsu Kotteri. The broth is so rich and not filled with MSG. The kakuni is my favorite but might stop your heart a little lol. #worthit. 

Highly recommend getting the thicker noodle! The noodles complete it. 

The service wasn't the best but I have no complaints, it just feels like they want to get you in and out as soon as possible, I guess because they're used to a high volume of customers.
author: Ariel N.

description: Been here twice, first time I got the ramen and Tsukemen (dip ramen) for the second time. The ramen was average I'd say. For Tsukemen, I was eager to try it since I just got one in Tokyo and was super impressed. There were bamboo shoots and half a soft boiled egg in the broth. Two options: 7oz or 14oz noodles, 7oz the normal portion. The noodles were pretty good and chewy, but the broth was somewhat disappointing. The broth in Tokyo was thicker (it was pretty like soup here), more fish paste based, and not as salty. But I know SF is no Tokyo! Probably will just get ramen next time.
author: Jaclyn C.

description:
Thee is something to be said about simmering the pork tonkatsu broth for 20 hours. The broth is so rich and thick that the soup spoon literally stands up in it. Amazing, sweet liquid. I am going to pour all 2000 calories of scalding hot broth down my throat. 

Plus I ordered the fatty tonkatsu version! The fatty pork is melt-in-your-mouth, accompanied by the crunchy mushrooms, the seaweed and the seasoned egg. And of course, noodles! I tend to like thicker, crunchier, more al dente noodles. Ramen Yamadaya creates thinner noodles which are lighter in color, but still fresh and delicious. Definitely coming back, but be careful as they tend to be closed on Tuesdays, which isn't necessarily noted on their website.
author: Shirley Y.

description:
They now have thick noodles for all bowls for 50 cents. This is the best tonkotsu broth in the city proper by far, seriously.

And they have big communal table in the middle now. Servers know their stuff now as well. This place is running on all cylinders now.

You guys need to go back and stop hating. This is some seriously good ramen SF can be proud of.
author: Derrick V.

description:
Ugh, there is some food poisoning going on here. It sucks as this is a new place and it seems they care, but I threw up 8 times already from my lunch and it's 4am. I'm bummed.
People who work here: this has been going on for more than 2 days now from other Yelp reivews. I am the 5th person on Yelp, and can't imagine how many others there are. I hope someone there reads this so you can fix.
author: Brian J.

description: I haven't had Ramen like this since I lived in Japan. It was so amazing had so much flavor and was so fresh and yummy. I wish they had one of these in San Diego it makes me miss Japan if you're looking for authentic Ramen this is where you want to go. Definitely perfect for the cold winter nights right now, it warms you right up. The broth is out of this world. It was quick and fast just as quick as we ordered it it was already on the table. Friendly and understanding staff that give you a minute to understand what it is that you are ordering and what exactly you want. They are not rushing you but giving you the chance to pick exactly what it is that you want from the menu.
author: Lisa D.

description: Probably the best ramen I've ever had (Most of my ramen experience is from Convoy St in San Diego.) The whole place seems to have a dedication to doing their food the "right way", and it shows in the flavor and presentation. The Spicy Kakuni Ramen nearly destroyed me, but it was worth every slurp.
author: カエル

description:
So....I decided to give this place a few more tries, and there are definitely a lot of improvements!! Before, I gave it 3.5 stars, but now,  A STRAIGHT UP 4 STARS (just for their ramen) ! Not much of a jump but hey, just read on (:

-Tonkotsu Kotteri Ramen: BIG BIG IMPROVEMENT ON THE SOUP. Before, it was really thick, but now it is soupy and perfect! 
They also have an option of getting "thick noodles" now with an additional $1, but I think it is worth it. The noodles that they use are the thin white ones, and I am definitely not a big fan of that. I prefer chewy noodles, so the new option is great news for me!
But just a heads up, if you don't like your noodles chewy, don't get the thick noodles because they are indeed quite chewy. My mother like softer noodles so she thought that the thick noodles were too hard.

-Chicken Karaage: DO. NOT. ORDER. THIS. I don't know if it was only that day, but there was absolutely NO taste to it. Maybe they forgot to add salt and seasoning to it, unfortunately. It comes with Japanese mayonaise for dipping, but that didn't help either. The only upside to this dish that day was that it was perfectly cooked. Crunchy on the outside and extremely juicy on the inside. It would've been perfect if the chicken had taste to it ):
author: Jackie T.

description:
A)Tonkotsu Kotteri -(Fatty w/ Garlic Oil)
-For a rich fatty and garlic option. Its loaded with more of a black sesame taste. (-1)
-Larger Cha-Shu portion than what I got at tanpopo downstairs. (+1)
-The noodles broke off really easily, rice paper double  dipped in hot water can hold better than this junk. (-1)
-Presentation isn't exactly the most appealing but on a cold night it can pass since some good looking things can taste like shit too. (+1)

B)Extra egg-1 egg two slices for 1.00( Pass) +1

C)Sprite-Current Batch says it expires in November 2014 (pass) +1

D) Besides the door. There is no visibly existent air conditioning. I see a white vent above the community table but I don't think its working. At high capacity, I just found the hotbox of japantown. (-1)

After all that math. Overalll = 1..
author: Eric C.

description: Oily oily oily....... I was craving ramen and my coworkers recommended this place and it was the only one that I had yet to try and was open for lunch. This place seemed to be popular during lunch hour on a weekday as a line was already started to form 20 minutes after they opened which gave me great hope. My ramen came out looking good with lots of meat compared to other places. However the cut was really thick! It tasted pretty decent since I was starving until half way through and I started to feel sicken after realizing how oily the ramen was which killed my appetite for the millions of interesting snacks nearby that I wanted to try after finishing the noodles *sad face*. Service was decent. It took them 45 minutes after the restaurant was open to serve tea on a cold day. Decorations and the view is nice if you get to sit near the windows. I will not come back since there are more than 5 other ramen shops nearby I can try.
author: An N.

description: Sooooo good! We had the traditional tonkatsu ramen and it was divine! Great flavors, perfect noodles and fixings in it. Vegan ramen was equally tasty. Go!
author: Meg W.

description:
Went in here with 4 friends and my fiance. 5 different people served us and the food was nothing to rave about. They werent even busy and it took an an hour and 20 minutes for our food to get to the table! The spicy ramen came in 3 stages of hotness and I got 3 (the hottest one) but it didn't taste remotely spicy. 
We left a smaller tip than usual because they were rude and forgot one of my friends water after multiple requests.
They said they were going to call the police on one of my friends because she didnt leave a "good" tip. Tips are earned from good service and we did not receive that! I definitely dont recommend this place!
author: Lorraine W.

description: I came here with some friends and as we walked up the stairs to the front of the restaurant, a waitress saw us coming and walked over to open the front door to us. Great service already. We got there prior to 12pm on a Saturday but soon after we were seated, there was a crowd out front. I ordered the tonkotsu kotteri ramen with the yamadaya topping. The broth was intensely rich and it's flavor and intensity made me believe it was a 20 hour broth as the restaurant advertises. I tried my friend's regular tonkotsu broth and it too was very flavorful but not as rich as the kotteri. I'm not a huge fan of the thinner noodles as I do prefer thicker ones with a bite. Also, the pork belly was flavorful but pretty fatty, and the slices of chashu had a lot of inedible cartilage pieces. Service remained great through the end of our meal.
author: Maya S.

description:
Two victims of food poisoning from last night at Ramen Yamadaya. We both ordered the yamadaya ramen (tonkatsu spicy and regular shoyu). You've been warned :(

I've been analyzing what could be causing these food poisoning cases so here are my thoughts:
- Pork is not fresh. you can tell it was frozen because it comes out colorful and metallic. 
- So much oil and pork fat = perhaps it's too rich and some people can't digest it well? 


Boyfriend thinks the food poisoning was worth it though. However, I'm stuck rehydrating with pedialyte and canned soup so I'm not sure if it was worth it.
author: Ashlee B.

description: It's good, I try different ramen every time. All tasty. Today I tried the cheese ramen, not that tasty as expected, but special. the fried chicken is really good.
author: Olivia J.

description: My table felt sticky and a little stingy. Service was not unfriendly, but it definitely did not feel very welcoming. Food was okay but not impressive. I guess it is a good place for a quick lunch if you are nearby.
author: Sydney C.

description: The broth for the Yamadaya Tonkatsu was so flavorful and the right amount of heat. Gorgeous noodles! best bowl of Ramen since my last trip to Japan!!  The Curry and rice was so fragrant and tasty.  Seven of us sat down, ordered ramen and extras, filled up and left with leftovers for under $100. Friendly, pleasant service.
author: Amie B.

description: Super delicious ramen, I got the Tonkotsu Ramen spicy level 1. The noodles were thin, but very good. I loved the pork, great quality meat! The service was OK. I had ordered edamame because we were starving and wanted an appetizer but it didn't come out until AFTER we got our ramen. Overall good place, I recommend getting there right when it opens because when we left there was a line of people waiting, we got there right when they opened and we were seated immediately.
author: Isabelle M.

description: Really great vegan ramen. Great atmosphere. Wish there was more vegan options available but totally would recommend
author: Kirsty L.

description:
This place is soooooo good! I try a lot of ramen places since I live in fairly Asian neighborhoods, and this is definitely my favorite one. The wait was ~20 minutes on a Sunday for lunch, which isn't bad. We ordered the Tonkotsu Kotteri, Tonkotsu Spicy, and Takoyaki.

Takoyaki: It was my first time trying this, so I have nothing to compare it to, but it was definitely delicious. The bready part was really soft and flavorful, and the octopus had an awesome texture.

Tonkotsu Kotteri: This is their rich and fatty soup base, which sounds weird, but I loved it. I always think ramen is really salty, but surprisingly, this one wasn't overwhelming with salt. Noodle to meat ratio felt just right as well. I couldn't stop eating!

I tried my friend's Tonkotsu Spicy at Very Hot, and it was way too spicy for me and I could usually handle a bit of spice. So when they mean hot, they're not joking!

Service was average, and it was pretty loud so just be aware of that.
author: Anna L.

description:
This would've been a perfect meal. Everything worked. Good food, little to no wait time, ambiance was pretty great. However, the service just fell short. My friend and I ordered two bowls of ramen while I also added a combination which included a bowl of rice with mentaiko and a small salad. We also ordered some karaage (Japanese fried chicken) which never appeared until the very end. The ramen was Tonkotsu with the kotteri (black garlic) oil with their Yamadaya toppings which included pork, onions, mushrooms, bamboo shoots and an egg. Overall flavored were great! The chicken never arrived. After informing multiple waitstaff, we were told that it was forgotten from the original order. Fine, I assumed maybe another 5-10 minutes. 15 minutes roll by, nothing. Finally towards the end of our meal, we are told they decided to comp the chicken and just give it to us to-go which we accepted. 

It was a good meal, food was spot on, good portions and I thoroughly enjoyed it. If it weren't for the elusive chicken this would've been a 5-star review. (All things considering I am pretty generous with my stars anyways.)
author: Nick Y.

description: We came here during lunchtime on a Thursday and there was still a line. It was not a long wait to be seated but the wait inside was long after we ordered our Ramen. You would need to wait about 15 to 20min for the food. I liked my Ramen, but it is a little bit on the salty side. They give a generous amount of meat for each bowl.
author: lydia m.

description:
Ramen Yamadaya was open new years day. 
with just  8 arge and 4 small tables, people were waiting in line after 30 minutes.

eats: 
-tonkotsu kotteri ramen(9.45)
angel hair-like ramen in fatty, creamy rich broth
large square, lean chashu, green onions, 1/2 boiled egg, bamboo shoots,
seaweed, black garlic sauce
*best broth ever tasted, toppings better than average
4.5 stars
-takoyaki(4.95)
8 fried gooey balls with kewpie mayo dipping sauce
octopus bits chewy, probably from frozen
*typical takoyaki, so so, 3 stars

footnotes:
-open kitchen, can see chef prepping noodles, broth....
-short menu, 3 ramen choices and a few appetizers.
-small table doesn't have sauce tray..
author: Victor G.

description:
My friends and I came here to eat dinner and I wasn't impressed with the ramen or the service here.
They just updated their menus, too- so much that when we asked our waiter a few questions about some of the items, he didn't know the answers and initially wasn't willing to find out until my friend asked him to let her know once he does. -_-
Anyways, I went with the Tonkatsu Kotteri Ramen and the brother was super thick- it almost seemed like I was eating ramen in gravy. We also asked for an extra portion of noodles but our portion was pretty much the same as the regular. Ramen noodles were average and the amount of meat in each bowl is underwhelming.
We also got 2 out of the 4 orders at our table mistaken. Each bowl of ramen was around $9 and I don't think it was worth it- you would have to add quite a few extras to be full.
Not a good place for groups larger than 4- each booth could hold a maximum of 5 if you add a chair at the end. 
Meh is a good word to describe my feelings for coming back here.
author: Grace L.

description:
Came here a week after it's opening and it was already pretty busy.  We came here at around 6:30PM on a Monday and were seated within 15 minutes.  The layout is a bit weird with a huge space in the middle so hopefully they plan to add more tables.

BF ordered the extra spicy ramen while I got the tonkotsu black garlic broth with a side of pork belly and spicy paste.  We both agreed that the tonkotsu broth was much better.  The highlight of the night was the pork belly and chashu though.  Both were super tender, which was beyond delicious.  The extra spicy paste wasn't really spicy to me even though I was warned to put it in a little at a time.  Ended up dunking half of the serving in and I didn't think it tasted that much different.  Even though the noodles were good, I prefer the thicker type and Yamadaya's is thin like angel-hair pasta.  That's personal preference though.

Yamadaya definitely went beyond my expectations.  I didn't really expect much from this new place but it's definitely the best ramen place I've tried in J-town.  Excited to go again.
author: Jane N.

description: Was so hungry and this changed my life! Spicy ramen is amazing, best meal in SF. Would recommend to anyone who can taste food.
author: Shaina S.

description: We hiked uphill for a mile and it was worth it. We did have to wait but it wasn't a long wait. There wasn't a large selection of Ramen but that was okay. If it's great and simple why change it with strange stuff that shouldn't be in a Ramen. The broth was wonderful and just what we needed on a cold rainy day. We ordered karaage with salad along with our Ramen and they were great additions. It was busy but the waitstaff were quick and courteous. We'll be back.
author: Rovi D.

description:
Ramen was definitely tasty and I would eat again here.  Two points that could be improved: the service and the bathroom.

I'm not sure if they were understaffed that night or they just don't have enough staff.  All the front end employees were hustling to take orders and bus tables but it still took longer than usual to have our order taken, get our check, and get our receipt.  It seems they may have needed at least one more person in the front to make the service more efficient.  

The bathrooms were also a weak point for this establishment.  Although the front end of this restaurant is clean and presentable, the bathrooms left a bit to be desired.  The bathrooms were small and dirty.  They smelled unclean and the paint appeared to be dirty and peeling.  Thankfully I only experienced the bathroom on the way out instead of when I first got there.
author: Kendall K.

description:
The service was good and the place was really cutely decorated! I only wished the place was bigger. When we went it was packed and it got really hot and stuffy in there ! Like sweaty stuffy! Prob the only downside here. 

I got the  cheese ramen. It was so good! If you are a cheese lover , it's a def must try ! It reminded me of ramen in Korea ! 

My friends also got other dishes , the rice plates. It was really good too, but I 
 forgot what they got . 

Def coming back here to try the other ramen dishes !
author: Alicia N.

description:
We were visiting from out of town and heard about this place so we checked it. We waited in line for about 40 minutes to get it. Once in we were starving. 

We placed orders and waited. and waited. and waited. 20 minutes later after watching other come in after us get their food first, the waiter walks up to us and starts apologizing. "Sorry, but we lost your order." 

I am guessing they didn't actually lose it, because he didn't ask us for our order again. 10 minutes later, our food showed up.

I was ready to be really pissed off, but the food was pretty good. I had the Yamada Tonkotsu. The broth and noodles were great. Pork belly and chashu were deelish.  

Waiting sooo long for our food made this place good vs great.

I'd go again if you were buying. And don't be surprised if I ask the waiter 15 times whether or not our order had actually been placed.
author: Jackie E.

description: Was here last night. Did something change to this place? Soup base tasted bland and tasted different from what I've had in the past. Menu was completely different too. Under new ownership?
author: jay l.

description:
One bad service person ruined the whole experience.

We waited about 15 minutes to be seated. It took may be another 10 minutes before the order was taken. Then, we waited for another 30 minutes. We were patient as they were full and busy. But then we noticed the tables that came after us got their food. We were still waiting. When I checked with the waiter that took the order, he has no idea and he asked "who took your order?". After another 6 minutes, the food finally came. Then I have to ask again for a couple missing orders. The waiter did apologize but he did not do anything to make us happier. 

Back to the food, I ordered Tokatsu Spicy. I think it was ok comparing to Shalala or Ajisen. I wasn't blown away or anything like that. The broth is B+. The side order of chili has enough kick and not too salty like Shalala. The noodle is too thin to my liking. The pork is ok. I do like the side topping. 

The bad service takes away 2 stars :(
author: William L.

description: Really good food! I love the whole hipster vibe along with the way the restaurant is setup on the second floor of a building. Wish the broth had a tad more flavor instead of it being mixed with a ton of vegetables and meat and all. Overall it's really good food!
author: Avery B.

description:
My friend had a bad experience here, but I was craving ramen and well, we were really hungry. Glad I dragged her back here because it was pretty good! I heard good things about the tsukemen but I was in the mood for the tonkatsu kotteri with black garlic oil. HUUGE bowl of flavorful goodness. Even came with a free drink since it was a weekday lunch or something..

It was nice upstairs but it's definitely not stroller- or wheelchair-friendly.
author: Vivian H.

description: Finally green tea that isn't over steeped! Great food and friendly staff. I ate till I couldn't walk! Definitely coming back.
author: Rebecca C.

description:
Very good food! There are few places you can even get genuine japanese snacks like taiyaki or takoyaki and this is the best takoyaki in LA. If you go here, get the spicy tonkotsu. The garlic one is alright, but none of the other ramen flavors compare to the spicy one. 

Also, they are on doordash with a relatively cheap (by doordash's standards) delivery fee. Which makes them the best ramen that can be delivered! Better in quality than ramenya or ajisen. Almost as good as tatsu.
author: Ben H.

description:
My boyfriend and I love this place. He travels every week and whenever he comes back, he always asks to eat ramen.

In the city, I've eaten Orenchi Beyond, Waraku Ramen Izakaya, and Ramen Underground and this is by far the best one. The South Bay is definitely the best for ramen with Orenchi and Santouka, but I need my ramen fix in SF!

I almost always get the Tonkotsu Shoyu. The Kotteri is good too - it's just a bit heavier than the other ramens. I've tried the dipping ramen and I wasn't a big fan. The sauce was too fishy. I've never had dipping ramen at any other place so I can't really compare.

I've tried the tofu salad, and that's just ok. Definitely stick with the ramens!
author: Lisa N.

description:
This place doesn't have a lot of seats (why does it look like they have a room for a dance floor in the middle of their restaurant).  Be prepared to wait.  The ramen here isn't bad, but really not my style.  I prefer thicker noodles, as the ones here are just too thin for me.  The egg is a bit overcooked for me.  

The surprise winner here was the Tsukemen, dipping ramen.  This dish didn't sound appetizing with it's strange tasting seafood sauce.  If you sip it, it has unusual flavors, but if you dip it with the extra thick noodles it has the right balance.  I'm usually more of a soup person, but this was clearly the better dish here.
author: Tiffany C.

description: Ramen was good however you should avoid ordering the gyoza as it was soggy and falling apart before we even ate it. Service was good even though they forgot to put through the order, as soon as they knew they advised us and deducted the cost of our drink.
author: Mia T.

description:
This is the first ramen placed I've ever tried in Japantown. And I was expecting a lot. 

SERVICE:
The service was friendly and professional. They could be a little more attentive though. But I was satisfied with service nonetheless. 

FOOD:
