Ramen -- Soup -- Base was good and flavorful. No complaints. 
Ramen -- Noodles -- I was expecting more of a texture complexity. But I wasn't impressed. I've had better ramen noodles from street vendors at farmer markets. 

Everything else like the chashu, egg, bamboo shoots were pretty standard and have no complaints. But the dish didn't wow me either. 

Overall:
I would recommend this place since the food was decent and the prices were average. But don't have high standards.
author: Christina L.

description:
I love this place mainly for their tsukemen. If you love ramen but have never had tsukemen, I highly suggest it. Cold, perfectly cooked noodles with a bowl of thick dipping broth. The perfect combination for those of us who love a good bowl of noodles

The ramen here is also pretty tasty- flavorful broth and you can choose your broth's spice level

Reasonably priced with friendly service. I'd definitely recommend
author: Josh C.

description: Never again.  This review is for caviar delivery.  There was a hair in the buns, and the ramen noodles arrive cold and clumped together like a brick.  Everything ordered went into the trash
author: David M.

description:
The pork belly was great; very soft, flavoursome with an amazing melt in the mouth texture. The pork chashu on the other hand was quite dry and had no taste to it. I also prefer my broth to be a bit more creamy in texture, with more of a fatty flavour to it.

I will continue my search for great tonkotsu ramen elsewhere!
author: Hannah H.

description: I've eaten here multiple times before and the service has always been good until my latest visit. The food is okay, standard ramen which is why I've give the one star, but the customer service is terrible. We asked to separate our tab into two spectate ones so we can pay separately and the waitress told us that wasn't possible. She then handed us a calculator and told us the do the math ourselves. Our other server, an elderly woman, was not friendly or welcoming at all. She made us feel rushed as she cleaned our table up while we were still eating. I can not bother to come back here after this. This is the worst customer service I have ever received, and the worst part of all is that we came midday when it was not even busy. The audacity of the servers and the customer service itself was shocking. I could not believe that I had to calculate my own tab and felt unwelcomed and unappreciated as a customer.
author: Crystal L.

description:
My 2nd time here and feeling review-y lately on my Ramen quest in the Bay Area. The first time I was here I ordered their Tonkotsu Kotteri Black Garlic Ramen w/ Kakuni Pork belly, egg and large portion thin noodles and it was AMAZING, the kitchen must've been in a good mood that day! The aroma and flavor was just right, noodles were al dente, the pork belly had just the right balance of fat and texture.
The 2nd time here I went for their regular Tonkotsu Ramen with Yamadaya toppings and I am struggling between the two because it's just as good. The Kotteri version is more rich combined with the pork belly I kinda left like I needed bypass surgery afterwards. With the regular Tonkotsu I could finish the ramen and the soup, the Kotteri was just too rich. I will be coming back in the near future and sample their other offerings and will be posting updates to this review.
author: Panchali S.

description: Holy moly! This place does not play around when it comes to heat. I'd like to think of myself as a spice enthusiast, but hot damn, it's spicy. I ordered the Yamadaya ramen, fire spicy, which the waiter described is level 4. Regular spicy is levels 1-3, "fire" is level 4, "hell" is 5, and "death" is 6. So I'm thinking... alright, I always add more chili oil and pepper flakes into my "spicy" ramen so I should be able to take level 4, fire. The waiter asked if I was sure and I said, hell yes. What he forgot to mention is that the spice is made from ghost chili peppers....and that's a whole 'nother level, my friends. Tried so hard but about 1/3 way through, I had to order a bowl of regular broth for $4 to dilute it out. Another $4 to be able to finish and enjoy my ramen? I'll take it. Aside from that, the broth was super rich, which filled me up quickly. The Yamadaya ramen comes with a thick cut of pork that was really tender. I'll definitely come back and try the other options.
author: Thao T.

description:
It was so gosh darn hot that Fleet Week Sunday, Blue Angels still roaring over the sky, that we just had to to stop somewhere in the shade with a bite to eat lunch.

But, isn't ramen typically hot? The answer is usually yes -- however, I found a cold dish upon this menu, their Cold Ramen Salad Special, that did just the trick. It was a hearty serving that I could not even finish, but came with lettuce, carrots, onions and other vegetables, with ramen at the bottom for you to mix around with a side sauce.

Took awhile longer to reach the table than my partner's dish (probably because it was a "special"), but it was very good. Also had an iced green tea and we shared the pork gyoza.

Decor seemed a tad tacky, with wires for lights strewn along the ceiling edge, but after Weird Al's song, I can't help but smile. Cheers to cold food on a hot summer-like day.

Total rating: 3.5 stars
author: Garett T.

description: After trying many kinds of ramen from multiple places, this is the most delicious I've tried! I've came here many times and service was good. Can't complain
author: Karen G.

description: The noodles in Yamadaya ramen were a little too thin for such rich broth they served, and I didn't really enjoy the oily Tonkotsu soup they had. I liked their tamago, the fresh garlic was nice, but the broth was way too oily and salty. Meat was dry and kind of chewy, didn't like that part either. Service was polite. Not too impressive overall, probably won't return.
author: Jane L.

description: Gave this place a second try. decided to order the Yamadaya Spicy w/ chicken karaage instead of the pork. was given 2 miserable pieces of chicken, and i am guessing they forgot to add the egg. bowl was less than half full. ended up paying $18 after tax and tip. wont be coming back.
author: wendy h.

description: Visiting SF from NYC with my fiancé, and as lovers of Japanese culture and frequent ramen eaters, we were looking for a great spot for Ramen in Japan Town. We stumbled upon Ramen Yamadaya and thought, why not? I was expecting to have an "ok" bowl of ramen because I'm spoiled from my favorite spot in NYC (Zundo Ya). Turns out, this place knows what they're doing! We got the Spicy Ramen Yamadaya level 3 and it was out of this world. Our waitress was also soo pleasant and efficient. Highly recommend!!
author: J S.

description:
5 of us went there for much awaited Ramen. Ramen was not even superb nor special.....just a regular ramen that has nothing to brag about. Service was so poor that i find the server named Abraham (guy that walks weird, thats without descrimination but only to be specific of who he was.) very rude. We asked few questions, he basically just nod. Pretty much made us loose our appetite. Only one server managed to smile.
All in all id rather go next door or the one in front. It's not worth spending a beautiful evening with friends in this establishment.
author: Dane B.

description: I really liked the Chasu Ramen, which is quite a feat as I usually abhor the texture of pork. The broth was lovely and the restaurant itself has nice feel to it. The restaurant is spacious and has ample seating, but it does get busy near the weekend. The only issue I have had though is they are not good about bringing the appetizers out before the food.
author: Jennifer A.

description: I used to love eating at this restaurant. However ever since the remodel, the quality of this place has gone down by far. Cutting the food quality and increasing the prices by 50% and the ramen was very discouraging. Literally was just noodles and a small amount of broth. When i asked them why the broth was so low they said i can buy extra broth. the takoyaki used to be delicious and bigger now its some off brand third party hamster balls of crap. I never had a bad experience with this place until today. I will not be coming back ever again. You lost my 4 year attendance.
author: Edd L.

description: 3.5 Stars... Flavors are good, service is nice, food service a little slow. -0.5 star for ramen portions. Highly recommend doing the combo; same ramen size just with extra food!
author: Stephen Y.

description:
Ramen is good on a cold winters night. Heck, it's good on any night. And any afternoon. I think I could even eat it in the morning if a ramen house was open that early! hahaha

Ramen Yamadaya is a pretty new place and apparently they are still waiting for a few more tables to arrive. The cool light fixtures in the center of the restaurant are really really low. If you are taller than 5'3" watch out when you are walking down the middle to get to a booth - you might hit your head! 

They had about 7 ramen options on the menu, but only one is featured with an anatomy of a ramen picture and a bright red "no 1" badge. The Yamadaya Ramen. You get to pick the broth you want, and I picked the Tonkotsu broth which according to the sign that was outside, they cook it for 20 hours! It also comes with a soft-boiled egg, seaweed, and a lot of pork (including pork belly!). The noodles are the long, thin, straighter kind of ramen. It was yummy!!! Really hit the spot. 

The place is upstairs and the entrance is kind of hard to find. They close at 9 on Fridays and we showed up like at 845 when we wrote down our names but they still seated us, which was great. The waitress told us that the other day they had to close at 7 because they ran out of broth! Come here early to make sure you don't miss out on ramen. But also maybe come when they get more seating in. I want to come back to try the tsukemen next time!
author: Sylvia K.

description:
I came here with a group of friends for dinner. It was packed and we had to wait for a table. I ordered the Tonkotsu Yamadaya Ramen. The broth was very flavorful. The meat was nice and tender. The pork belly was great. I thought the noodles were too thin. Maybe I should try the thick noodles next time. I liked that it came with a whole egg but it was too cooked for me.

If your still a student you can get extra noodles for free with your student ID.
author: Alexander L.

description:
Great service! Even for all 15 of us. We even managed to get seated next to each other. Without reservations.  Did I mention there were 15 of us?

I wasn't too impressed with the ramen broth here.  Doable.  But I much preferred the tsukemen!  The tsukemen dipping broth was nice and flavorful without being overly powerful.  Kept well to eat the next day too!  An extra $2-3 gives you double the smaller size.  As someone who can do math, you can't say no to that!
author: Jennifer M.

description:
Ramen here was pretty good, got the Tsukemen ramen and the Yamadaya ramen ($11.95 but there's quite a few meat pieces). Broth was flavourful and tasty. I would come back again, but the service was quite slow - hence the 2 stars.

Ramen is generally served pretty fast, based on my experiences at other ramen places. But it took almost 35-40 minutes for our ramen to come, which got me pretty annoyed.
author: Yentl T.

description:
We were there last night around 6p and waited 10 mins for the table. It was full house already. They only have ramen available for now. I had the tonkotsu ramen, the broth was rich and creamy and not too salty. The noodle seemed a little too soft for me, but the chashu was really tender and tasty. They are still waiting for furniture so that they can fill up the space in the center and will have more selections on the menu later on. 
This place has potential, would definitely come back and try other dishes. 
If you don't want to drive all the way down to the south for ramen, this is definitely a place to consider if you are craving for a good ramen place.
author: bebe L.

description:
I've concluded that people in SF have a different tastebuds when it comes to ramen. It still blows my mind that people consider Ramen Dojo the best ramen in the Bay. 

I first tried Yamadaya in LA when I asked my Japanese managers for good ramen recommendations in the Torrance area. Yamadaya received their stamp of approval so of course I went to check it out. Conclusion? Amazing. 

The tonkotsu here has a tasty rich broth with a savory pork flavor. They do a great job of balancing out the creaminess of the broth without making it too heavy and oily.  I'm also a big fan of the thin straight noodles here as opposed to the thicker wavy noodles similar to the ones you sometimes find in the cheap packages of instant noodles. Thin noodles don't tend to get soggy in the hot broth and maintain their al dente texture. 

Aside from the broth and noodles, I always judge a bowl of ramen by how well they execute on the tamago egg and chashu. The egg at Yamadaya is perfectly soft boiled with a creamy yolk though the chashu could use some work. 

Oh, and you must get the FREE fresh garlic to press into your broth. You won't regret it. 

Overall, a very solid bowl of ramen. It's a little pricey at almost $10 for a small bowl and only 1 slice of cha siu, but considering it's in the heart of Japantown, it's forgivable. I'll take Ramen Yamadaya over Ramen Dojo any day!
author: Tiffany W.

description:
Broth was fine.
Chashu was kinda tough.
Egg was overcooked. 
But GOSH DANG that Kakuni Pork Belly was straight bangin!!
Probably my favorite pork belly in the city. Its insane.
Unctuous and soft and fatty but not too fatty.
Falls off the bone (if it had a bone).
Pork belly was 5 stars alone and anchored my meal. 
I might just get an order to go next time instead of getting ramen.
author: Augusto M.

description: They need to get rid of their waiter... Very rude and horrible service!! Actually no service at all! I would not recommend this restaurant to anyone.
author: Peter K.

description:
INTERIOR: It's on point until you use the washrooms. I rather have an "okay" looking restaurant and the washroom looking phenomenal. It goes to show that you not only care about service, but quality all around.

SERVICE: They were welcoming at first, but the moment it came close to dining hours--they became frazzled. I was a waitress once and I know for a fact that excellent service is when one knows how to keep calm but provide service in a timely manner, not rush your customers to order.

QUALITY: We had the tonkotsu spicy and yamadaya ramen. We absolutely loved the broth and the thin noodles (: It's a good change and I would definitely come back!
author: Linda H.

description:
Accessibility (Parking / Wait Time)

1/1 Star: parking lot a block away. No wait. 

_____

Service (Waiter / Cleanness / Ambiance)

1/1 Star: clean. Different waiters/waitresses serve you. 

_____

Taste (0=Not Edible / 1=Edible / 2=Good (average) / 3=Must Try!)

2/3 Stars: the big pork belly was a disappointment.  It didn't have much flavor and wasn't stewed like other ramen places.  It was like boiled bacon. The tonkatsu broth was very tasty but their normal thin noodles lacked texture. The "think" noodle option is the normal size noodles anywhere else. The basic pork slices were really good. Normally I think pork belly is better than normal pork slices, but this place dose it opposite. Spicy option is more sour than anything else. 

_____

Overall Experience
4/5 Stars 

_____

Last Words
Don't get the big pork belly, get the normal pork slices.
author: Elliott N.

description: So happy this place was open on Christmas. It was absolutely delicious. The interior is modern and very nicely decorated. The chicken kara-age was so good and juicy. I would come back for just that alone. The katsu curry was also really tasty. The ramen is bomb and the broth has that really good, wholesome filling feeling about it. Would definitely come back next time I'm in the SF area.
author: Scarlett K.

description: The noodle, the soup,the  topping, just not right if you have tried real Japanese ramen before...
author: Simon S.

description: What's with all the ramen joints going downhill?! Used to love this place. They  seemed to have had a management change. Servers used to be all Japanese, not any more.  Ramen is soggy. Broth is not as flavorful. Have to say that their pork is still good.
author: Eric C.

description: Yamadaya kotteri ramen was delicious with a lot of toppings, including a seasoned parboiled egg cut in half, a big square of smoked pork belly, sliced green onions, fried garlic chips, trong but not too oily broth filled with falling apart pork that had almost the texture of perfectly poached fish.  A bit pricey with salad and potstickers added along with tip can out to $20. Nice for a treat every once in awhile.
author: tomohisa w.

description: Showed up at opening. Ordered as we sat down and they were already out of our appetizer. The service was mediocre at best. Had to physically get up to ask for service. Overall food was good but nothing spectacular
author: Chantal J.

description:
The ramen here were NOT good. Located in Japantown I expected better ramen. Or maybe we came during the wrong time? Anyways for $10+ per bowl, we were not satisfied with our meal. 

I ordered the spicy miso ramen with green onions. I did not expect half of my bowl to be filled with green onions, it was pretty horrific. There was about 1 tiny piece of pork that I found towards the end of my meal in which I screamed with surprise/glee. Yes the ramen I ordered is supposed to be flavored with the spicy onions, but does it really have to be half the bowl worth with barely any meat?!  I was not pleased with my noodles, didn't taste memorable or anything special at all. I powered through my bowl in less than 10 minutes and had to steal some of my bf's noodles. As for the spicy miso broth, I really cannot remember anything special with the broth besides the green onion taste... The only good thing that we got from the meal was the additional $3 or so for a side dish. My friend had curry along with his ramen, which was a pretty good steal. 

We ordered the karange, fried chicken, for the group which was pretty good. Total for 5 of us was about $90.80, around $18 per person. 

Service was okay. I really liked the waitlist policy, if you're not there when they call your name, your group is dismissed. Thus my group got seated within 10 minutes during the busy Japanese Blossom Festival. Will we come back here? No.
author: Rita K.

description:
I'm upgrading this review to 3 stars.  After I posted the review, a manager contacted me and apologized for the situation and offered to refund me the difference with the tip or give a half off discounted meal. So, husband I took up the offer to come back and had another meal there. 

Abraham, the owner, was really great and attentive. They really took care of us and made us feel like they were sincerely apologetic for the tip mistake. So, thank you, Abraham!

However, the food just did not blow me away. I really really tried to love the ramen (tried the regular Tonkotsu this time) but the broth and meat was not as flavorful as other ramen places I've tried. Husband's pork belly was also lacking in tenderness and taste. The food was just fine....nothing was horrible and nothing was amazing. 

Overall, it's a fine place to go if you want to try out ramen in Japantown. I haven't really hit any amazing ramen joints in SF yet, so I might just be overly picky with ramen. But I did appreciate their effort to apologize and make up for their mistake.
author: Sarah C.

description:
This ramen is served in really fun upside town triangle bowls! Anyhow, to put it bluntly, this is some incredibly overpriced ramen that tastes just kind of okay compared to a lot of amazing ramen I've had in the bay area. I do like that they have more limited ramen choices than usual - it makes choosing easier.

I had the Yamadaya Tonkatsu Kotteri, and my boyfriend had the Yamadaya Tonkatsu Spicy. These ramen are $13 each - whoa! Their kakuni ramen are about $14 each, which seems fair because usually there's a lot more of an upcharge when you order kakuni in addition to standard ramen. When I looked around the menu for cheaper ramen, I noticed there was a small section called "basic ramen" or something. So then, I got service that was a bit confusing. I didn't want the premium toppings that came with their "Yamadaya" styled ramen, so I asked about the basic ramen - my boyfriend mainly wanted basic ramen, which you know, is the ramen, some meat, some green onions - wouldn't even complain if there wasn't much more than that! But, we were told that the "basic ramen" they offer are JUST broth and noodles. Uhh... That is literally a first time, and one of the weirdest things I've heard offered on a menu, and from a well traversed Japanese ramen house, no less. Anyways, that sort of forced us to get the Yamadaya styled ramen, which includes pork belly, chashu, eggs (they actually mean one egg sliced in half), bamboo shoots, nori (three square sheets of seaweed), and the brown-black strippy mushroom.

The kotteri is richer soup flavored with black garlic oil, but I didn't seem to taste or see that - sort of just looked like soy sauce oil floating in a random patch, when I'm used to almost the entire bowl being kind of black with some garlic bits around, haha. The pork belly was extremely rich and fat and I enjoyed it; the chashu was slightly fatty and okay, and the eggs were a bit cold but had a nice semi solid but runny yolk. The amount of green onions was generous, but overall the ramen was okay, but still so damn expensive. The spicy broth was pretty good and orange while not being too intense, and I think I enjoyed it a bit more than other spicy broths I've had. The noodles were "Hakana" style, which means they are thinner; they were not my steez, no, but whatever - just a bit of a textural and form difference when you eat, and lack of nice and thick firm noodles. Sort of made me think about instant noodles. The ramen filled me up but not my boyfriend (probably because I ate most of his fat pork belly piece).

In conclusion, the ramen here is good but not the best, but I really don't like this place because of the price and how they do not include just regular ramen on the menu. I don't want the premium topping sometimes; I just want to taste the broth and even have a small slice of chashu and green onions. Unbelievable they wouldn't just have that on the menu now; it seems like they used to, but no longer do. They also have kind of aggressive ramen rules posted up front when you walk in, which come off as more rude than hip and cool.
author: Amy Y.

description: I came here when I was hella hungry so obviously the ramen tasted really good. But tbh I don't think I will come back to eat ramen here.
author: Rachel K.

description: I really liked the creamy Kotteri ramen. It was full and silky and had just enough saltiness that allowed me to drink more of the broth without suffering from hypertension. The thinner noodles were unexpected, and I may prefer the fatter noodles, but they were still tasty. They never got soggy, which is important to me. The chasu was fatty, just the way I like it, and the shoyu egg was delicious (though cold). The portion was just right for me, but friends hinted that it wasn't enough. Service was decent. Loved the 2nd floor location, and it's especially great sitting by the window where the place overlooks the plaza in JTown.
author: Rita L.

description: I ordered the Tonkatsu Ramen, it was good but just a little too salty for me.  I like the atmosphere too :)
author: Jillian C.

description:
In the world of Asian soup noodles, ramen is below both pho and Taiwanese beef noodles in my mind. No matter how much the ramen is hyped up, I can't get over the fact that, to me at least, it's essentially a deluxe version of instant noodles. Don't get me wrong- I love instant noodles from time to time (if my stomach allows for it), but that makes me think "why would I eat ramen when I can have pho or TWB, which I can't make at home". 

With that mindset in tow, my fiancee wanted to have some form of soup for dinner because it was a "cold" summer night in SF (it hovered around 13 degrees Celsius). With our hotel in the center of Japantown, we were presented with a good opportunity to try some ramen steps from our hotel. Having walked past the restaurant in the days before, we decided to pay a visit to Ramen Yamadaya for a late dinner. 

After a trip up the stairs and a 10 minute wait for a table, we were brought to our seats. The restaurant has booths along 2 of the 4 walls, with the 3rd wall and middle area lined with tables of sizes for 2, 4 and a long table for bigger parties. After a quick gander at the menu, my fiancee decided to try their new special, which was a shoyu-broth ramen with pork belly, BBQ pork, and a mountain of vegetables. I went with what I think was a tonkotsu ramen with 2 meats. 

For the special, they weren't lying about the mountain of veggies. it literally was a mountain peak of bean sprouts, suey choy, and lettuce on top of the ramen. Without my help, it probably would've been a messy affair trying to get to the soup underneath. As for the soup itself, Yamadaya claims to boil and prep their soup for 20 hours prior to serving. In both cases, the broth was rich and had some depth. It was definitely soothing and comforting given the temperature outside. Their BBQ pork was top-notch, while their pork belly in both soups were more fat than belly. While this added to the richness of the broth, my fiancee and I both left our belly portions unfinished. 

Having tried a few ramen places in Vancouver, I had a certain expectation with respect to the noodles. To my surprise, the noodles at Yamadaya were thin. Not quite as thin as you'd find in an instant noodle package, but a noticeable difference from what i was accustomed to and what I thought was normal. Now I'm not a huge ramen fan so perhaps I have it all wrong, but I do prefer a "beefier" noodle in my ramen. While thin, the noodle did have some bite and wasn't a mushy mess so it wasn't as bad as I had originally feared. 

Overall, it was a good bowl of ramen for a normal price. Since we opted for specials, the prices were north of $10. Their normal bowls are in line with what you'd expect for Asian noodles, so the pricing to me is just fine.
author: Vincent A.

description:
Ramen was good, service was eh.

I came here on a Saturday afternoon with my friends. We were shopping in japan town and we started to famished so we checked yelp for something good to eat in the area. My friend found this place and we said why not. We got seated and it took a while til we got our waters and our orders taken. When it was time to order, I asked for my broth on the side (for dietary purposes). Our waitress said it was ok to have my broth on the side but when I got my order, my request wasn't honored. I tried to explain to her what I wanted but I don't think she understood me so I just gave up and asked for an empty bowl. I just ended up separating the soup myself.  The food was good; I enjoyed the tenderness of the ramen and the broth was very flavorful and wasn't too salty. During our meal we had to ask for refills and that's a bit of a red flag for me. 

Overall good experience but it could've been better.
author: Luisa P.

description:
Finally a yummy ramen restaurant with decent prices in Japantown.

The BF and I came for lunch and when we arrived at noon there were a good amount of people already waiting! We put our name on the list and waited around 15 minutes to be seated, which wasn't that bad but when I saw how much empty space there was inside the restaurant I was a bit displeased. They could have fit an entire second row of tables and chairs in there but for some reason they haven't taken advantage of all the space.... hopefully they will do so soon.

Anyway we both ordered the tonkotsu ramen, and my BF ordered the Yamadaya topping: two pieces of chashu extra, a hunk of pork belly, green onion, nori, half an egg and bamboo shoots. It took 10-15 minutes for our order to arrive but that wasn't too bad since only two people were working the kitchen. Don't forget to order the free garlic so you can press it fresh into your ramen! So yum. The broth was very good here, it was salty, tasty, creamy but not overpowering in any of those categories. They add a good amount of green onion, a thick slice of chashu, too many bamboo shoots (not really a fan), and a perfectly soft-boiled egg. DELICIOUS! The Yamadaya topping really pushes the ramen over the top so I'd recommend ordering it if you need a little bit more than the normal serving. The noodles were really good as well, perfectly cooked and thinner than traditional ramen noodles.

In the end $8.95 for a decent sized, yummy serving of ramen is awesome in my book =) Will be back for more soon!
author: Sam F.

description:
The staffs are all pretty friendly.

The soup/broth is not as fatty as the ones in Socal. I guess that's a good thing. The taste is pretty much the same.  Overall, their noodles is very thin which I like. The broth is very flavorful and they also give you fresh garlic to enhance the flavor. 

About $11-12 for a bowl of ramen which is not bad given its SF
author: Jessica H.

description:
This was legit. I came here randomly one night for dinner with a friend, because I felt like my outfit was super fly that day, and wanted to make sure I got some good mileage out of it - you know that feel like, "Damn, I don't feel like enough people got to enjoy this today." Anyways. TMI already.

The tonkotsu ramen with pork was legit. Noodles and pork were tender, broth wasn't too salty, and it had really good flavor. Also, got some chicken karaage, and the pieces were pretty huge; big enough where we ended up taking some home. For dessert, I got the taiyaki, which oddly enough is not easy to find at places. I ate that shit up. Loved it.

BTW we just walked in and sat at the communal table. We didn't wait very long. I guess I should mention that the bathroom was kind of gross, but whatever, the food was dope and a good price. I'm definitely coming here a lot.
author: Shawn B.

description:
I hosted a company team offsite here and I can't give enough praise to the manager, Abraham, and his staff. Not only was the food delicious, but Abraham went above and beyond to accommodate the many requests of my group. He graciously helped with the menu selection, space planning, and even dessert delivery as a surprise for my team. His staff was extremely friendly and attentive to all of our needs. I HIGHLY recommend Ramen Yamadaya for delicious ramen and top notch service! 

Thank you for helping me make my event a huge success!!
author: Chelsea S.

description:
My friend recommended this place after going to Suzu's on our now-almost-weekly trip to Japantown for dinner after work. Located on the second floor, the entrance was somewhat tucked away, but the interior was nicely furnished and comfortable. It was foggy and quite gloomy outside, so the warmth was readily welcomed by us all.

The host greeted us with all smiles and our party of 5 was seated quite quickly by the window. Being on the second floor, we got a nice view of Peace Plaza and the pedestrian street-semi-garden area below. I could only imagine what it would look like had the weather been better! The tables are all on a sort of platform, so that was pretty cool too.

I got the spicy tonkatsu ramen. The menu was a sort of pick-and-choose style, but it doesn't mention that it already comes with some chashu pork, seaweed, an egg, and some other standard toppings. I think I'm used to the thick noodles as default in ramen, as the standard ones are thinner than I expected!

The soup base was really good. The noodles were good too. Overall I really enjoyed it - the spiciness wasn't as spicy as enthusiasts would like, but it had a good kick to it and compliments the flavor. I guess the portion was a bit smaller than I expected, but it was still filling! I will drop by again in the future!
author: Alex W.

description:
GET THE YAMADAYA TOPPING AND EXTRA GARLIC!

I got here around 8:15PM on a Sunday night and we were seated right away. The restaurant still feels a bit incomplete due to a completely open floor and other than the ramen, the rest of the menu isn't ready yet.

TONKATSU RAMEN with BLACK GARLIC OIL - I'm not quite sure what the black garlic is supposed to taste like but it was great ramen.  The broth was meaty but not too fatty and there 2 decent sized pieces of pork (one was beneath everything, so it was a pleasant surprise at the end).

YAMADYA TOPPING - It's a bit of all the toppings, so I was just expecting not much because it was only $2.50. But when that plate came out, I knew I made a good decision! Extra Chasu, extra pork belly, extra egg! All of it was flavorful and made the ramen extra nice.

In the end, it was a little pricey for ramen, but it will no doubt be my ramen go-to from now on! They don't skimp at all.
author: Alan C.

description: I was expecting to be wowed but I was not. Although tasty broth, the temperature was not hot enough. It was just above warm. I want my broth just below boiling as I think it should be. Noodles were sub standard. It was like Saimin noodles not ramen type that we're used to.
author: H L.

description: Salty ramen. Not the best or great. Just so-so. If you're hungry and want something to eat at 530 pm than go here lol. Soup base and noddle is different of course. Place still quit crowed even the ramen and salad I order is salty
author: Reynard L.

description:
Who doesn't loveee ramen. I mean, it's just so good!! And this review isn't totally just about the ramen because I enjoyed my bowl! 

4 stars takes into consideration the price and selection. I thought it was a little pricey for what we got, and their options for ramen add-ins was particularly limited. 

My boyfriend got the Tonkotsu Kotteri Ramen combo with a spicy tuna bowl and small side salad:

Ramen: hot, tasty, tender flavorful pork, and the best soft boiled egg of my life 

Spicy tuna bowl: honestly, somewhat of a letdown, a bit too heavy handed on the mayo for my taste 

Salad: light dressing, nothing fancy, but nice to have to give yourself breaks from eating noddles in a somewhat greasy broth 

All in all this place was tasty for a late night bite! I'd stop by here again since most places are closed well before 9 around there.
author: Katie 2.

description: Didn't have to wait and the staff was friendly. Ramen was tasty until I drove home and realized I was having side effects of their MSG. My neck started spasming and the following day I had a mild headache and body weakness. I wish more restaraunts found organic alternatives to flavoring. MSG is not fun to consume.
author: Chiara A.

description:
I took some clients here today and loved it.  The location (upstairs with a view of Japantown) and the setting are cool, service was great, and the food was excellent.

Our waiter approached us, asked if we'd ever been there before (no) and then explained the menu to us and offered suggestions.  It was a nice touch and helped my guests decide.

The food came out quickly and was very good.  I got the pork belly shoyu ramen with the extra noodle upgrade and some gyoza.  High quality, great presentation, and very authentic!

Can't wait to go back!
author: Jonathan A.

description: Ordered the Yamadaya ramen and the broth was excellent, very thick and rich but the Chasu in it was a little dry. Also had an order of the Gyoza and it was a bit soggy. I definitely will be coming back for the broth!
author: Virgil N.

description: Wish I could give this place more stars, because the quality was good, but as a chilehead, when something is advertised as "insanely hot", it had better bring the heat, and this just didn't.  Good flavor, seemed like good quality, but shockingly mild given the description.
author: Paul D.

description:
Good food
Bad service 

Misleading menu
And crazy waitresses 

Over charge my friends cheese ramen with crazy excuses
author: Kevin C.

description: The ramen was really good and super flavorful. The reason I docked off 2 stars was for bad customer service. The staff wasn't welcoming at all and my family and I felt rushed the whole time. They clearly have one objective: to get you in and out. But the food was good so I guess it made up for that.
author: Lauryn S.

description: If you like Japanese ramen noodles, this place is great. Also tried the spicy tuna bowl and it was delicious. At lunch time it wasn't even packed. All that plus a friendly staff; this little place is definitely worth five stars. Try it out if you are ever in Japan Town!
author: Braden S.

description: The food might be good but I wouldnt know because they never brought it to us. Terrible customer service all around. We waited for over an hour for our ramen to come out and everyone who came in after us had already been served. Our waiter never checked on the table during that time. We waived him down and asked how much longer the wait would be then he seemed to be putting in our order to the kitchen for the first time, after sorting through tickets at the kitchen counter and checking the bowls coming out. We asked to cancel the order because we had an event to get to and they took another ten minutes to get us our check. Just a quick "I'm sorry about that" with a full charge for the small salad and beer we ordered. I would not recommend this place.
author: Lauren L.

description:
I think this is a strong contender for my favorite Ramen place in SF! The tonkotsu kotteri ramen is perfect (a balance of thick, oily, and flavorful) and the pork belly add-on was tender and huge. The takoyaki was also cheap (just $5 for 8 pieces) for the area. 

It seems like there's usually a bit of a crowd here but the line moves quickly. It also has lots of nice window-side seating overlooking the plaza in Japantown. Overall, it's probably worth a strong 4 star, but I'll bump it up to raise the score of this really solid spot.
author: Cailin H.

description:
Tonkotsu with Black Garlic Oil
Tonkotsu with spicy #2

The broth had good depth and flavor in the beginning.  Through the middle and end it became on the salty side.  Included toppings were skimpy and not much special.  Didn't add additional toppings.  Hakata style noodles were overdone, no bounce and fighting back toughness.  Very disappointed.  

Chicken karaage bland and too much batter.  Shouldn't be much at all.  A good brine and thin corn starch with do.  It was like popcorn chicken from Popeye's without flavor.

Paigu (deep fried pork loin) - never heard of this word.  it was a lightly battered katsu with again not much seasoning.

Waited 20 min for the hype.  May try again but will ask for noodles to be cooked rare.

Great friendly service.

#santouka; #ippudoNY
author: Kevin L.

description: One of the best spicy Tonkotsu Kotteri Ramen I have had. The pork belly was off the chain, Gyoza cooked to perfection and the Kara-Age had great flavor.  Definitely a good spot to hit up.
author: Mark D.

description: Probably one of my favorite ramen places in Jtown and I hope the quality stays the same. I normally go to waraku but the consistency sometimes in all over the place. I went here with 3 friends the other day and the ramen was great. The pork was very savory, it came with a ton of toppings, and the service was awesome. The owner was super nice and kept on checking on us. They ran out of chicken karage which is a bummer but I'll try it next time. There are a buncha booths and center tables and our wait was under $10 minutes. I got the misobased ramen and others at my table to spicy ramen (3 point scale of how spicy you want it) and  black garlic oil one. Fresh garlic comes out to be served with the ramen if you ask. The noodles are thin so you need to be aware/like that. The ramen comes out with an egg which I really appreciated and I added corn to mine. The agedashi tofu was okay not that great. We got the seaweed salad (great portion imo) and mochi for dessert.
author: Lily P.

description:
their ramen is not bad! we came here on a weekday dinner time. Got seated right away. The place seem pretty slow. It might be because their ramen is overpriced. at least $10 per bowl with barely anything in it. 

we got the dinner combo (ramen with a side) for about $15-17. it barely filled me up. and i don't eat a lot. however much an average 5"3 asian girl eats, go figure. 

I like their broth but I don't like it enough to pay for the broth itself.
author: Jo L.

description: First of all, I would like to acknowledge the restaurant for having delicious ramen. But honestly, 2 stars down for horrible customer service. Don't get me wrong, they have good ramen, but the servers were not very attendant to us. They seemed to be more attendant to well dressed customers, we were in casual clothing (I mean come on, it's Ramen!) Props to you for good ramen, thumbs down for customer service. Would come back if customer service improves!
author: Vanessa N.

description: One of the best places in town for Ramen.  After eating here a few times then trying some of the other places in the area there is just no comparison.  Very healthy servings of meat.  Broth is amazing and noodles are perfectly cooked every time.
author: Chris O.

description:
I should start with the disclaimer that I'm vegetarian. However, I'm determined to not let that stop me from trying out all different types of cuisines. I WILL NOT BE LEFT OUT OF THE RAMEN WORLD!

Came here for dinner last night with a friend. I was pleasantly surprised that they had a specific vegan ramen dish listed on their menu! The folks at Ramen Yamadaya had come up with a soy milk broth recipe and substituted spinach noodles in the place of their normal egg noodles - so cool and sensitive to the hipster dietary needs of SF. My little vegetarian heart melted.  

Another disclaimer: we arrived around 9 pm on a Tuesday night. It took about 20 minutes to seat us. I too was surprised by the busyness, but took it as a positive sign. After waiting around another 20 minutes once we put in our order, our waitress came back and said that they had SOLD OUT OF THE VEGAN RAMEN! That was the only thing I could have on the menu...

My friend and I were seriously starving at this point, so I just resigned myself to having dessert (mochi ice cream) for dinner. The sweet waitress felt so sheepish about the situation but quickly rectified it. She noticed that I had ordered an egg side dish (thus hinting at my vegetarian-ness - I CAN eat egg!!) and quickly told me that they have the broth but no spinach noodles. She asked if it would be fine to replace the spinach with egg noodles. I said YES! And thus, my ramen was served.

Overall, service was great for being so late at night and a busy day. Still only giving 3 stars because my vegetarian ramen was light on the veggies with only corn, a couple of bamboo shoots, spring onions, and a few slices of mushroom. Was hoping for a little more since there was no meat in it. It was overall decent but not INCREDIBLE. Also, I'm pretty sure the mochi was the Trader Joes kind. Can't be positive, but I'm feeling 75% sure.
author: Anupama T.

description: This place is fantastic. The broth was superb. Delicious, filling, tasty and reasonably priced. I walked right in a little after noon on Sunday and got a seat but be prepared to wait a bit, there was a long line moments after I arrived and it was full the whole time. Some of the best Ramen I have had anywhere (including Japan).
author: Andrew M.

description:
My sister, daughter and myself found this place accidentally.  We were trying to go to a ramen place up the street that my sister had previously tried with her boyfriend but when we got there the place wasn't open yet.  I suggested we walk back to where we came from and saw Ramen Yamadaya.  We thought "what the hell, let's give it a try."

Walked up the stairs and was seated promptly at the middle communal table.   I didn't mind it at all.  Heck, I'm on vacation so I'll eat on the sidewalk if I have to.  

Starters:

Takoyaki - This is a must when my daughter is with me.  They came up piping hot but delicious! Nothing special about them, just your typical takoyaki.

Gyoza - Like the takoyaki it wasn't anything special but I wouldn't complain about them either.

My sister and I ordered the Yamadaya Ramen.  I asked mine to be super spicy.  I believe it's another $1 or $2 to make it spicy.  My daughter ordered the chicken katsu curry.  My ramen was excellent and was spicy.  I like my food spicy so it was a good heat for me to handle.  The broth wasn't salty either like some ramen places.  My daughter's chicken katsu curry was a huge portion.  Poor kid couldn't even finish it and my sister and I were able to sneak in a few pieces of her katsu.

I'll definitely be back when I'm in the mood for ramen.
author: Chau D.

description:
The 24 hr broth they advertise wasn't bad and was perfect when it's cold and rainy out.  But would I stand in line waiting for them to open? No.  Hell no.  Yamada Ramen came with a good variety of the usual toppings, PLUS, you get a slice of pork belly with it.  Score, right?  EERRRRR!!!! That piece of pork was SO tough you have to cut it into tiny pieces across the grain in order to chew it.

Ordered an extra piece of pork belly on the side and that was much better, more tender because it was fattier.  The curry rice ($5) was a great add on.  It had minced meat in Japanese curry. Lovely.

Can't say much for the service since they didn't bring a pork katsu "topping" for our ramen until we completely finished our meal and was paying for our check.  I told them to cancel it since we hadn't received it, but instead of taking it off our bill, she brings it when I'm asking for my credit card back... really??? No, I sent it back. SUPER slow service.

I'll leave this place to the masses and continue to have sukiyaki downstairs at Shabu-sen instead, thank you.
author: Alice L.

description: One of best ramen places I have been to.Decently priced,casual after work ambiance. The ramen was delicious. My girlfriend got the basic ramen and she enjoyed it. Since I'm a meat love, I really enjoyed the generous amount of meat in my ramen. I finished my noodles before I was able to finish the pork (can be a good thing/can be a bad thing) overall good experience. Happy tummy.
author: Joshua B.

description: I'm sorry, but with all the other ramen options in SF and San Mateo, I'm sorry I wasted my time here. Service was slow and inefficient, and the noodles in the Yamadaya ramen were way too doughy. They tasted like they were too undercooked, and even though we'd asked for our noodles extra firm, that didn't mean we wanted to eat them raw! My sister and I were super excited to try their tsukemen since there aren't too many places that offer it, and we had the most amazing bowl on our recent trip to Japan, but sadly the broth was disappointing and lost heat very quickly. Noodles were cooked better than the Yamadaya ramen noodles though. The last straw for me was that they didn't have a water heater, so we could only order cold drinks! Seriously? Can't you just boil some hot water on the stove??
author: Kathy L.

description:
Stopped by this weekend during the Cherry Blossom Festival. After about 20 minutes of waiting in line we got seated and where told that they had run out of the Ramen soup. It would take about 30 minutes to have Ramen ready, we decided to wait and just get some apps and drinks.  Ordered the Gyoza which was very good, a bit greasy, but good. also ordered Edamame as an app and had to wait about 30 minutes for those to come out.  The restaurant was not even busy and I think the staff just forgot to put the order in... even after I asked them three times on the status of the Edamame.

Very disappointed in the service.  Finally after about 35 minutes we got our Ramen.  The Ramen was very good!  We had the traditional type which is a smaller gauge noodle and the "dipping" type which comes separate from the broth.  Both had wonderful flavor.  The only thing you should be aware of is that if you order the noodles on the side, they come cold the broth is warm but as you "dip" you end up with cold broth and it is just not as tasty as if it would have been warm.

The management did take care of us because of the wait and the issue with our apps... I would visit this place again.  The food was good, but with so many Ramen shops in the area I would try another place.
author: Frank C.

description:
Long wait for a just OK-quality Ramen. Terrible services. Not worthy.

I had waited 30min for seats and then another 20min for no-shown Ramen. I asked the waitress where my order was. She said she mixed up with another table....
author: Purple L.

description:
I found out about Ramen Yamadaya from my coworker who said a lot of good things about this place. 
The entrance is on the second floor and there is a sign in for the seating but since it wasn't busy, we got seated right away. We came here on a Thursday afternoon. The interior is very well designed, and it felt like an authentic Japanese restaurant. The first thing I disliked was different waiters asking us if we were ready to order every minute. I'm assuming the other waiters did not see us being asked already. 
Some of my friends and I ordered curry rice plates. I got the standard katsu curry rice plate and it was very nicely presented. The food itself was good. Not super amazing but enough to satisfy my taste buds and my stomach. The curry was mild but feels like it could use a bit more spice. The chicken was pretty good. The breading was crunchy and the meat was soft and easy to bite. 
After paying, I was left a "Thank you!" note on the receipt, which made me feel obligated to give a bigger tip. I kind of find this as a deceptive way of getting more tips but that's just me. I would come here again but I'm going to stick to getting their rice plates because the ramen was a wee bit too expensive for my liking.
author: Ken Francis V.

description:
Places with horrible restrooms scare me. I used this one AFTER our meal- which I will talk about in a sec. The women's restroom was in need of a good cleaning. No lock on the door, and the toilet wasn't flushing properly. My husband told me there was a leak and water dripping from the ceiling in the men's restroom, which was also pretty filthy. I hope this is fixed- and fast. 

I ended up with the vegan ramen with spinach noodles- amazing noodles! You can't add a spice level to your vegan bowl, but can get chili sauce on the side. This place makes a beautiful broth. My kids liked the tar tar chicken bowl special after scraping off most of the sauce, and also the Yamadaya ramen which had roasted pork. Oh, and I love when places serve their edamame hot.

Hopefully they will figure out their restroom issue if/before we return!
author: Rosemary W.

description: The spicy ramen is better than the house ramen. Walked in Wednesday dinner time, no wait, service was fast and friendly
author: Alli K.

description: Terrible service and average food and that's when they aren't busy. It only goes down hill when they have more than 5 tables occupied. It's not worth the wait to eat mediocre ramen.
author: Lily G.

description: I ordered to go from here and I guess they forgot to close the ramen cups. In my car the spilled all over and they went all over me and left a horrible smell in my car. Maybe this place needs a little more noodle of there own
author: Adam B.

description:
NOT IMPRESSED AT ALL

I've eaten a lot of authentic/traditional Japanese food.

Their menu is very limited, and even though I came here because I wanted ramen, I could not find a ramen dish that sounded appealing.

So I ordered a spicy tuna bowl...mistake.  Bland and boring...couldn't eat it. 0 stars.

Gyoza...not bad....3 stars

Salad...bland and boring...couldn't eat it. 0 stars. 

My daughter had some eggs...mowed them down.  5 stars.

My wife had a vegetarian ramen...she ate most of it...3 stars.

Abouf halfway through lunch, the room got insanely loud...so loud it was annoying.

The server never bothered to ask how the meal was. Negative 500 stars.

All in all, it was a sub par meal.

1 star that they didn't earn.
author: Randy S.

description:
As I was scoping out what restaurant to go with my boyfriend, I thought Ramen Yamadaya would be a good choice since I haven't been there since they first opened. So when we first went up their was quite a lot of people in line and we didn't want to wait so we were about to leave but everyone got seated and we were next so we decided to wait. 
Now I don't know if this is part of their policy but I saw many empty tables and tables that have not been cleaned yet and we still didn't get seated. 
I never have seen a restaurant that likes to clear their whole room before letting other guests come in. 
We got there at 1:50 and did not get seated until 2:50 despite the fact that there was empty seats that were cleaned. 
Now I wouldn't have mind waiting that long if they even mention to us about the wait time but they did not talk to us til it was time to be seated and the fact that I had an appointment to attend to afterward made me very irritated. 
So we sat down and a minute later we were asked if we were ready (which we were not since its only been a minute) so we asked for another minute but the waitress was too busy to come back to take our order, so this waiter caught eye of my waving so he came over and asked us what we would like and confirmed with us our order twice.
( ordered one spicy tonkatsu, one curry chicken katsu, takoyaki and two ice waters)
After that we waited a while but noticed our food wasn't coming out and soon the waitress from before asked if our orders got taken down and we told her that the guy took our order but she looked confused.
( we had to ask her for the water since the guy clearly forgot)
So she seemed to ask the guy about our order and the guy seemed frazzled.
The guy came over and said that the chicken katsu was going to take a while to come out and we just nodded.
But I stared as he then just put in our order ( he forgot to put it in) 
At this point I was just tired and I wanted some food and what appeared to be my food finally came out and I received just a plain chicken katsu.. which i then had to tell them that I ordered curry chicken katsu. So they just looked annoyed then gave "my" chicken katsu to another table who ordered a chicken katsu. 
Our orders finally came but at that point I was so disappointed with the service that my appetite was gone. 
The chicken katsu itself was good but everything else was luke warm temp and just not appetizing. 
To be honest I really did not want to tip them but my boyfriend insisted that we did so our meal totaled up to around 28 dollars and we left them what I considered a generous 5.
While we left they did not say a single thank you or goodbye and just stared as left.
I don't think I ever encountered such a shitty restaurant experience and I tolerate quite a lot of stuff as long as the employees put in some effort. 

Overall Review:
Food: 3/5
Experience: 0/5

On a sign outside their restaurant is says the wait will definitely be worth it and it definitely was not. I won't be coming back.
author: Kayla F.

description:
I'm giving five stars to boost the overall rating. This place is not deserving of three and a half. 

We like to stay in JTown when we come to SF and ventured out unguided tonight.  We landed at Yamada because my 6yo wanted curry and this place had the plastic food in the window. Every other joint has an equal 3.5 rating so I figured good as any around... 

Immediately noticed the LA Weekly food review (among others) on the wall and hoped it would live up. 

Well, grandma even commented how tasty the Ramen was. She had the Shoyu and I had the Koteri and mine was rich and fatty delicious with super tender even more delicious Chashu (bbq pork). 

On top of it all a nice size portion under $10, unheard of.  Let's just mention a nice selection of beers and sake.  And just after sunset, a lovely view of the hood.
author: Jake P.

description: They give a good amount of pork with the ramen. Someplaces are so stingy. The broth was a bit too salty for me but overall it was good. Thumbs up for the R&B jams they were playing while i was there this afternoon.
author: Mike Y.

description: Came in to Yamadaya and it was so good. I got the spicy ramen and it was thebomb.com. Service was great and staff was super friendly. It was busy, so we had about a 30 minute wait around 9:00 at night on a Sunday. Totally worth the wait. NOM NOM.
author: Cat G.

description: The food was okay. Presentation wise it was bland. Food really did not have a lot of flavor. I had to add a lot of spice and soy to my bowl before it was to my liking. The service was terrible. Had to flag down our waiter for water. The waiter got mad at us when we wanted to order more food. Would probably not go back to this place. There were two other ramen shops in the plaza.
author: Duong H.

description:
If you enjoy non-existent customer service and poor air ventilation then this is your place! Our party of 8 was seated immediately but it was all downhill from there. It was a warm Sunday late afternoon and it showed inside the restaurant. The ventilation was awful; it was hot and muggy when you saw down. Our orders were promptly taken thereafter. First, only 1 bowl came out initially. That took upwards of 30-45 minutes. Then our appetizers came after the second wave of bowls. The last bowl never showed so we had to inform our waiter who casually acknowledged that it was "forgotten". At that point, one would think that missing bowl would be expedited but we sat and watch as other bowls of ramen were served while the last bowl took another 20+ minutes. By the time the last bowl arrived, the rest of the table had finish. The waiter lacked any sense of urgency. Only a simple "sorry about that" at the end of a nearly one hour wait. 

One more customer service anecdote: apparently there was a waitlist after we arrived. There was a family of about 8 sitting outside waiting. One of the ladies had to peek her head in and ask the waiter about open tables because across the room, there were three tables wide open, without any patrons. The waiter/hostess didn't even bother to go out and follow up on the waitlist once guests were leaving. We also saw another angry party leave during our stay here. Of course, this can be all considered heresay.

Finally. The ramen itself? It was alright. The broth is flavorful as advertised, not as salty as Orenchi. I ordered the Yamadaya bowl which was packed with 2 types of meats and eggs. The portions are definitely abundant. The ramen itself isn't as thick as Orenchi, however. Overall though, Orenchi is better Yamadaya.

I am not returning here. One and done.
author: Jimmy D.

description: I just had lunch there and ordered the Miso Ramen, I am beginning to think that I do not like the Ramen they are serving in the Bay area.  The flavor in the broth had a very strange flavor that I did not like, they boil large portions of animal fat with some meat to make the broth, I can see a lot of "grease" floating in the Ramen, this turned me off.  Most of the broth flavorings are generated with fat.  This is not healthy.  There was a large piece of fat in the bowl, about 4" by 4".  These authentic Ramen places will not be my favorite places to dine.  There also was a semi raw egg in the bowl, I do not eat raw eggs due to the risk of Samanella.  Other Japanese dishes appeared to be acceptable.
author: Marvin M. U.

description:
I love this restaurant! Everything is very fresh and seasoned properly.  They make the broth from scratch and you can definitely tell  by the True Flavor! YUMMY! 
The staff is so nice and the manager Abraham - is the nicest guy. Sometimes there is a wait for dinner so hubby and I go down the street for a drink. It is well worth the wait.
author: Tambo T.

description:
Wow. 3rd time I've been here, and this is the last time. Had the Tonkatsu Ramen with yamada toppings again, and what a MAJOR disappointment. I can't believe I gave this place 5 stars at one point! Ugh. Was such a ramen noob at the time. 

As always, broth is good (though needs some spice additive). Noodles (.50 for thick) were decent. That's where it ends. 

Highlights of my disappointment:

- Egg is ICE cold, hard boiled with hard yolk, and zero flavoring. It's basically a hard boiled egg you make at home that has been cooked too long. 
- Pork belly had ZERO meat on it. All just blubbery rubbery fat. I asked the waitress if that was normal, and she said No, and gave me a free piece with a some meat on it. 
- Chashu was ice cold and hard. 
- Wait staff (let's be honest... waitresses at this place) don't check back to see if everything is ok (probably because they know it isn't)

Ramen doesn't come out hot enough as-is, and when I added the ice cold toppings, it cooled it down even more. You slurp ramen to cool it off, but no need to slurp this ramen because of the tepid temperature. 

So much for this place.
author: Matt S.

description:
This is one of the best places I've been to for ramen, and of course it would be in SF Japantown! It's in the food area right across from the small Japantown shopping mall. 

I ordered the tonkotsu ramen with the Yamadaya toppings (with seaweed, bamboo, boiled egg, and slices of pork). Compared to other ramen places I've been to, this place was quite generous with the pork, which I definitely appreciated. The soup isn't very oily, and the noodles are one of the thinnest I've had (I prefer thin ramen noodles). The broth was flavorful and the toppings were a great addition to the meal. They serve half the toppings separately on a little plate, so you can choose when you want to put them in later. The other half comes already in the soup. My friend ordered the vegan ramen, which comes with a soy milk based broth and she chose the spinach noodles. She said she especially liked the noodles.

The service was good, the workers waited patiently until my friend and I had finished eating since we were one of the last customers, and they are all friendly and attentive.
author: Kailin H.

description: This ramen place was pretty decent. I got the sesame oil broth and the broth was definitely fatty. The slices pork was kinda chewy but the fatty pork was better. I liked the runny egg yolks for the boiled eggs. It was a little scary to see that the restaurant had poor sanitation but hopefully they have fixed the issue...
author: Uerica W.

description:
A welcome addition to Japantown. It's not the best ramen I've had (that distinction belongs to Izakaya Sozai), but I would come back and eat it again.

We went for late lunch on a Sunday so no wait at all. Although it did get crowded even as the closing hour of 3pm (for lunch) was fast approaching. Yes the empty space in the middle is weird but they've only been open for 12 days! I think they are waiting for more tables LOL

Their menu is easy simple and easy to understand. It's 4 different tonkotsu broth (I chose the 3rd one, tonkotsu kotteri.. something about "fatty" that I liked haha). Then made it easy and selected Yamadaya ramen, which comes with 2 types of pork, egg, seaweed, and scallion. Easier than having to pick my own toppings. The tonkotsu broth by itself is about $8-10, then you add toppings like egg ($1), pork belly ($3.50), etc. Or get the Yamadaya for about $12. It is a smaller bowl of ramen so we also ordered Takoyaki (octopus balls.. very good!) and Gyoza (dumplings.. also good). That was enough to get both of us full. 

Service was good and quite quick. I don't really have any complaints.
author: Vol T.

description:
I'm a visitor from Tokyo. My hobby is to visit Japanese restaurants, compare with restaurant in Japan, and review them.
This place is very crowded but not worth going.
I ordered Karaage Chicken bento box and Ramen.
Karaage Chicken is some what eatable but that just it. Nothing special. Miso soup which comes with bento box taste normal but... just normal.
Ramen. Oh ramen. Ramen is one of the soul food for Japanese. You do not want to think that this is the Japanese standard. No wow factor, just soup with noodle.
You do not want to visit here unless you have no where to go to.
author: Kuma A.

description:
Just like what everyone's already said, there's a line when you go on the weekends, but the line moves quickly. 

As a tip: if you're really hungry and live nearby, order it to-go, you'll get your food in about 10-15 minutes. Also, you can order drinks while you wait. 

Moving on to the actual service and food. 

Service/Ambiance: The service was really great! They were so friendly, attentive, knowledgable about their menu/product, and also very accommodating. I loved the vibe here because it's not too crowded and it almost makes me feel like I'm actually in Japan (I am in Japantown). 

Food: This is where it gets a bit disappointing. The ramen is good. Was it the best ramen I've ever had? No. They soup is flavorful, they give a healthy dose of toppings, and they cook the egg just right. However, THE NOODLES were thin. I've never had thin noodles in ramen before so this REALLY threw me off big time, and I couldn't really appreciate the dish as much as I'd like to because I felt like it was missing such a key component. 

Overall, I wouldn't mind coming back here again just because the service was so great and the food wasn't bad, but this is definitely not going to be my top choice when I'm craving ramen.
author: Sam B.

description: Came here for ramen after language school around noon, there's a short wait and I was seated at the big communal table.  The table was slightly sticky like it wasn't completely wiped clean.  I ordered the Tonkotsu Kotterie ramen and a side of buta kakuni.  The ramen was pleasantly rich but I could barely taste the black garlic.  The chashu in the noodle as well as the side of buta kakuni are both flavorful and fork tender.  I probably won't order both again as they're both very rich.  Will probably come back again to try a different soup base.
author: Becca S.

description: The wait before seating procedure was confusing and the service was haphazard. Though the staff was running around it was odd that some people got served really fast while some older people had to wait a LONG time. I felt apologetic because I was lucky. The menu is too limited and needs more chicken/sf options instead of beef, pork or vegan with nothing in between. The quality of the food was good though, or I would rate lower. Also do you have to be a super hipster to get a window booth? just wondering.
author: Miguel L.

description:
Overall Impression: Probably the most wallet friendly ramen in Japantown that keeps ramen simple, delicious, and adequately spiced.

Cost: Under 10 for almost any ramen bowl. Quite a bargain! You can add 4 pieces of chashu for only 2.50 more.

Taste: We ordered the spicy ramen with medium heat, and that is exactly what we got. The broth was really delicious and hit the spot on a cold evening. The meat melted in your mouth, and the noodles were thick and absorbed a lot of the flavors from the soup.

Customer Service: Nothing special. They didn't refill our waters at all.

Ambience/Atmosphere: The place looked nice and there was a long rectangular table in the middle for large gatherings.
author: Kevin T.

description:
For a place that is well-regarded enough that people endure quite a wait to enjoy, this place let us down with pretty appalling service.

After a 40 minute wait, we ordered as quickly as possible. However, despite ordering ahead of quite a few tables that were still getting seated, we were the last table in the entire restaurant that had not been served. After asking our server to check on our order for us, he lashed out by saying "don't be a jerk, be emotionally intelligent" and "go back to your seat and wait."

Shortly after, we were served with our dessert item order - first (before the ramen)! When the ramen finally came, the left out my extra order of kakuni. When we asked for garlic, one of the servers dropped of a plate of raw, whole garlic and a grinder, explaining that she didn't want to "touch our food" so we would have to do it ourselves.

For inquiring out these issues, we were rewarded with the servers huddling to whisper and point at us. Finally, the manager came over to discuss with us. Although he offered to take care of the bill, I really didn't detect much remorse, instead insisting that "every story has two sides."

Food was also pretty whatever. Not memorable. Service was very memorable - probably the most rudely I've been addressed at a restaurant when told to be "emotionally intelligent." Not a good experience.
author: Alvin Y.

description:
The food is good, but the reason I'm giving it 2 stars is cause of TERRIBLE service. 
First, we asked the girl server if we could transfer seats, she gave us attitude saying "why can't you guys just sit here"
Second, their chopsticks are disgustingly old
Third, my bf asked if they have tayakis, then the server started yelling at everyone "who wants tayakis???"
Last, we asked them if they can split the bill but said they couldn't because of the system, but they split the bill table next to us.
Never coming back. TANPOPO next door is a lot better
author: Jenna R.

description:
OMGeeee!

Never had Ramen before. Their broth was off the chart - it tastes liquid pork. Two in our party tried ramen bowls, two had bento boxes. We also ordered gyoza, fried fish and chicken appetizers. Everything was amazing.

Highly recommend.
author: B J.

description: usually I'm a 3 strike rule person so I'll make this quick. this is strike 2...I'm not sure about the chicken karaage, there's some pink but not chewy so I'm not sure that was uncooked or not, BUT the ramen...disaster. how? I'll just attach a photo to explain it, i hope the owner will see this ball of ramen that I purposely left in the bowl and improve. it's a shame that the quality is not up to par when you're located in japantown
author: SK Y.

description:
I went to this place a few days ago with friends and I was thoroughly disappointed because of the bad service and mediocre food. This restaurant is a mess. When we first arrived, they split my party of friends because they couldn't accommodate 8 people. No worries about that, but the waiter was much more attentive to my friends at the other table as opposed to the people at mine. Though we arrived at the same time, my friends at the other table got their food and drinks and we didn't even get served water yet. I didn't mind this at first since it was busy at the time, but the service kept getting worse from there.

One of my friends ordered the tofu salad but felt nauseous when she ate the tofu so she opted to order something else instead.  However, they still charged her for the salad on the bill. The manager argued with my friend saying that she wasn't allergic to anything and wouldn't take the order off. When he finally gave in he said "fine but you're killing me." Excuse me? I understand we ordered the food but if it made someone feel sick, why would you still charge that person for it? I also work at restaurant and I know that when an order changes, you may get charged still since the kitchen wasted ingredients for your meal but my friend had a legitimate reason as to why she didn't want her food anymore and they wouldn't listen to her. I'm not sure if they didn't believe in her reasoning but they handled the situation so unprofessionally compared to what I've seen before and that's what really shocked me about this restaurant's service.

While we thought it wouldn't get any worse, I made a stupid mistake when I left this place. My friends were in a rush to leave so I left my credit card at the restaurant on accident. It was my fault for not being responsible for my belongings, but I called 5 times the next day and left messages asking if they could contact me back but they never returned my calls and I'm pretty sure they still have my card. I canceled my card, and luckily there were no extra charges on it, but not calling me back regarding the issue is just so improper on their end. 

Aside from this, the food I ordered was alright. I tried the chicken karaage from my other friend's bento meal and it tasted delicious. However, I had the shoyu ramen and the noodles were overcooked and the broth was a little too salty for my taste. My boyfriend ordered the cold ramen and his also turned out this way. But he was amused with the idea of eating ramen that was served cold so I don't think he seemed to mind. The ramen menu was also confusing to look at because it shows you a selection of choices but does not explain what is in it. I'm assuming they changed the menu's look because the pictures on here look nothing like the ones I saw when I visited. I guess that doesn't really matter though because I'm never coming back to this place.
author: Jireh O.

description:
So a little background.  Tanpopo used to by my favorite ramen-ya in Japantown but I've noticed their quality has been in decline.  My last trip there I saw a sign for a new place called Ramen Yamadaya and made a mental note to give it a try.  Fast forward a few months and I finally made it there.

I gotta say I'm a huge, huge fan.  I've been diggin Ken Ken and Ramen Izakaya Goku recently but I might have a new fave.  My wife and I ordered the kotteri tonkotsu, shoyu kakuni, and some agadashi tofu.  Here are the food details:

Kotteri - Nice richness.  Fairly thick without being overly dense.  A nice sweetness to the broth, which was unexpected.  There was supposed to be black garlic oil but we hardly tasted it.

Kikuni - Really nice big portion of the belly.  I did order shoyu, but by the end of the meal the less salty broth from the kotteri was preferable.

Agadashi tofu - You get 2 really big cubes.  I prefer having several smaller cubes so you get more crispy fried surface area.  The dashi has a really nice sweetness to it.

Noodles - They definitely buck the trend here by using long, thin noodles instead of the standard curly noodles.  We tried both the default regular doneness as well as 'hard.'  The regular doneness was fine.  If I could choose I would pick curly noodles but these were pretty damn good too.  No real complaints here.

Egg - The yolk was slightly cooked through and it was not marinated.  Ken Ken still has the best egg by far... marinated and perfectly gooey.

So to summarize in one word, awesome.  The wait for a table of 2 on a Saturday night was only about 20 minutes.  Very reasonable.  We'll definitely add Ramen Yamadaya to the regular rotation.
author: Alan C.

description: Totally unparalleled between the tastes and price. So I do not suggest this at all. Probably my worst experience with ramen because this tastes bad
author: YiKun Z.

description:
Sad to say, but this place has gone downhill. The service is terrible and thankfully I had something to occupy my time while I waited to order, much less see any server near where I was. Even over tables were slow to be served. It was that obvious. 

The menu has changed since I was last here and seems somewhat simplified. The portions got smaller and the overall quality has decreased. My ramen wasn't nearly as hot as it should have been either. I was very disappointed  since I really enjoyed it last summer. I really hope they can get their act together because I'd really hate to lose a good ramen place in Japantown.
author: Therese G.

description: Such a bad service got there to eat some Ramen with my Friends the waiter take our order wait for like an hour to have our ramen but those people just give as bullshit that our order is place and the waiter said were on the 3rd line to be serve while those people who just got in have theyre order already bunch or bullshit!!! Im never gonna come back to these ramen house no more!!!.ITS NOT EVEN GOOD ITS SO SALTY AND GREASY!!!!!
author: Lailani C.

description: Best ramen in SF at the moment. The broth is excellent - very thick with collagen unlike most of the ramen in Japantown. The noodles that come standard at the thin type of noodles usually served with Tonkotsu broth, to get more traditional noodles order the 'thick type' for 50c more - this adds to the chewiness and is much more satisfying. Broth can be ordered with soy, garlic oil or lots of chilli. Toppings are good quality including kakuni, chashu and tonkatsu pork as well as soft boiled egg and usual vegetables. I recommend spicy level 3 with the special yamadaya toppings. Small rice, dumpling or salad dishes can be added to your ramen for a few dollars more. Good quality import Japanese beer is also available including unusual options like Yebisu. Service is fast and efficient but gets busy on Friday / Saturday nights. Come early or late to avoid the line.
author: Amaya B.

description: Just got some ramen from here before checking Yelp. And guess what!? I got food poisoning. My friend who was trying to do a kind gesture by surprising me at work with some soup also got food poisoning. Throwing up, sweats, cold sweats, death. I had to leave work early from this. Stay away. 0 stars if I could.
author: Vanessa G.

description: The ramen (shoyu) was delicious and tends to get served fairly quick. My main issue is the service and staff. I have been here several times and usually get the same order but I also see the same people with the same crappy attitudes. I dont live in SF and do not have a good ramen place near by. It really sucks to have good tasting food with bad service. What I mean with bad service is: they dont pay attention to what you are requesting. They try to juggle too much at one time and forget their initial tasks. They dont come to check on you and then you have to wave at them like a dog (which is not something I feel happy in doing). Their comments or remarks at times are not funny or appropriate. They could easily improve their services if they wanted to. Im sure they are great people but in that environment they shouldn't forget their mission statement (if they have one). Overall, the ramen is really good and the employees there could learn to service others with excellence.
author: Gabriel C.

description: The food was good. Love the pork belly in my ramen. The broth was excellent. The portion size was good. Love the crunch of the garlic. The rules at the front were fair and hilarious. The service not so much. We got our waters when our ramen arrived. Not cool. Also we got our check a little bit later, despite the joint not being too busy on a Saturday.
author: Philip-John T.

description: First time here after a friend recommended to my husband and I. the flavors were ok! The noodles were too mushy and way too floury! It had the right amount of spiciness but I just had to keep adjusting the flavors. We will be sticking to our original spot.
author: Wanh D.

description:
Holy cow, that health score! Never eat here unless evacuating your bowels and getting yelled at by your boss for being away from your desk for too long is considered a good start to the weekend. 

On the flip side, the server was helpful with suggestions and explaining the menu.
author: Rachel H.

description:
