One of the best places I had ramen at. I had my first vegan ramen, MUST TRY!! Great flavor with spinach noodles and the broth tastes like vegetables straight up. I highly encourage you to try this place out!

On the other hand service was a little slow and very minimal talking but they know their stuff and welcome you with a warm heart! 

ENGOY!!!
author: Dharmil P.

description:
Just alright..
First of all.. there are too many ramen shops in SF Japan Town.  Might as well change the name to Ramen Town.
If there are so many similar shops how would you make it stand out as your choice of ramen shop.
Yamadaya, in my opinion does not offer anything special.
Cost to make a bowl of ramen must be like two dollars, three at most.
I think it will be easy to upgrade the ingredients or voluminous the toppings and still remain profitable.

My favorite ramen joint remains Tampopo, two doors down.
author: Mark M.

description: Yeah,,,we loved Yamadaya in San Diego so we were so excited to hear it opened a new one in SF...first time when we visited, it was great, but second time....the soup was cold..the total including sales and tips was $15 for just one ramen.....too expensive....
author: Machiruda Y.

description: Ramen bowls are wonderful.  Very flavorful and roast pork is tasty and moist.  Came Friday night and they were busy but wait was not long.  Kids loved them and will definitely rerun as again.  Only issue is too hot.  AC is now Rowling as well so consuming extra spicy ramen results in sweatiness.  But worth it!
author: Terry P.

description:
Expensive food and no ac or fan in a 90 degree day.

Charges extra for spicy and there is only one piece of pork in the ramen.
author: Edwin L.

description:
Disappointing ... 

The food was honestly fine. We waited in line for over 45 minutes for 2 people to be seated. The waiter was nice but had no idea what he was doing. I had to remind him 2 times to brig us our drinks, our appetizer never arrived and when we got our food the egg and seaweed were missing. We asked him what was going on and he said they were out of eggs but the seaweed should have been there and that he will check on it. I personally love the egg in Ramen so it was a huge disappointment that he didn't mention they were out when he was explaining the menu to us. Needless to say we finished our meal and the seaweed never came and nor did our appetizer. I'm sad we had to eat here because Waraku closed their list early. I'll know not to compromise next time.
author: Sam P.

description:
I'd put the tsukemen at 5 stars and the tonkotsu ramen at 3.5. 

Service first off - everyone was super friendly despite the mad rush of the cherry blossom festival, so big kudos to them for handling the crowd with a smile. The wait wasn't too long, and I think they do a really good job of ushering people in the second space opens up. 

Now the food - the tsukemen was killer! Be forewarned that the dish is meant to be lukewarm/cold, so if you like your food piping hot, you may be disappointed. But the noodles were nice and thick and chewy - my favorite! And the broth was delicious and is lighter than their ramen broth. But I mostly like tsukemen just because of the whole dipping experience. Somehow it just seems more fun and yummy. Hahaha. Rivals Rokurinsha in my opinion (David Chang's beloved bowl of crack). 

The tonkotsu ramen was good as well, but not perfect. I enjoyed the broth and thought it had some depth and a good amount of fat. The noodles I actually thought were better than most places that also serve the thin version. Held strong but still had some flavor to them. The misses for me were the chashu - which was pretty dry, and I thought the flavor of the egg was just okay, too. The piece of pork belly was awesome, but I only got an itty bitty piece, so I'm not even sure if it was supposed to be in there, but it was delicious. 

I will definitely return for the tsukemen!!! So excited to have found a good tsukemen place.
author: Melissa H.

description: We were really hungry and picked this Japantown hangout for a nice bowl of ramen. I got the Paigu black oil ramen which was tasty but probably a little pricy at $13.25. Wife got vegan which she said was very good but a little tofu would have been nice. Daughter got the traditional and thought it tasted fatty and it actually contained big chunks of fat with only a little meat. The bast thing we had was actually the octopus balls which were just like the ones we got in Osaka. Fresh and hot with barbeque sauce and bonito flakes melting on top. It was a Monday so we did the best we could but next time we will try one of the places in the Japantown shopping mall.
author: Jeremy R.

description: My favorite ramen place after trying another 4-5 in Japan town. The broth is just so flavorful - I can tell they tooked it forever. The restaurant has vegan option, pasta / noodle thikness options and lots of other things on the menu ( cheese ramen, anyone ?). Had the seaweed salad too ( nice large portion). Their fried chicken is amazeballs. Went 2 days in a row after I found this place. #ramenheaven
author: Zita M.

description:
I truly pity those who have never had authentic Japanese ramen. This place is OK for an average Californian ramen ship, but don't expect anything to excite your taste buds.

The broth is OK, but the noodles are the real slap in the face. They are straight up packaged noodles. Probably homemade in a factory a couple months before you order it.

Custom service is also subpar. Be prepared to be treated like another walking dollar bill.
author: Michael S.

description:
ramen is good but need Japanese manager for soup and service.
broth is too thick like others where got not real Japanese manager.
chashu is amazing !
super yummy and a lot!!!.  
send manager who knows ramen broth.
i think you guys need more hot water when you serve.  Its not sauce. its soup!
author: Lika K.

description:
They occupy a pretty sweet spot in Japantown, but they are on the second floor. So when you spot the shabu place where you think Yamadaya is supposed to be just walk up the stairs to find the entrance. I really wanted to try the spicy tonkotsu, but unfortunately they'd ran out by the time I got there, which was ~7PM :(. Instead I got the Tonkotsu ramen with a side of pork belly + egg. They do add a fair bit of pork belly, and fwiw there's already half an egg inside of the ramen which is nice. 

But overall I didn't really like their noodles, I felt they were too skinny, and the broth felt a bit lacking to me as well. I wish it'd more depth instead of just the kinda salty taste.
author: David C.

description: This is good ramen, just had the Tonkotsu  Koteri Ramen and about to start on the Tsukemen. I heard a lot of bad things by word of mouth about this place but it proves to be a lot of people that do not know ramen. With the Ramen boom going on in SF, this place is standing out. A place to check out  IF YOU HAVE LIVED IN JAPAN AND KNOW RAMEN.Place is located at the old Iroha and above Tanpopo at Jtown.
author: Thecreos S.

description: Came here before concert at the Regency ballroom on a Tuesday night. The food was delicious, the wait was short and the service was friendly. The broth tasted amazing and the bowls were very generous with noodles. You can really tell the broth takes time to make. Plus the surrounding area of the mall is super cute, so leave some time to explore the other shops. Make sure to write your name down when you first get there, and read the rules haha, no forks!!! Which I love.
author: Jacob P.

description: I had the vegan ramen which was good but not spicy at all and lacked a bit of flavor. The noodle portions are also very small. I waited for 30 minutes as well and the service was very slow. I would check out another ramen place in Japantown if you have the opportunity.
author: Campbell R.

description:
The staff was friendly and relatively quick to seat our party of 9.

The Yamadaya ramen was really tasty - thick flavorful broth with egg, nori, pork belly, and 4 slices of chashu. I thought there was too much chashu though as it felt really heavy eating it and just overall too much fat in the bowl and ruining the balance of the ramen.
Tried the Tonkatsu Kotteri and I rather preferred the kotteri's black garlic broth over the tonkotsu broth in the Yamadaya ramen.

I would question the health score of this place though as the staff was scooping up jugs of water from a giant tank of water. This was also right in front of the kitchen window. I guess you could call this transparency but this is a little ridiculous.
author: Jeffrey Q.

description:
Came here because I've had their ramen at their SD location and this place took over my favorite Japanese restaurant in all of Japantown :(

I'm only giving this location three stars because the pieces of chashu pork that were found in each of my family members' bowls were either too fatty or too overcooked. I also have to make a complaint that my bowl had...one piece of chashu. It wasn't even a big piece. That, and they charge $1 for tea, which was served in a plastic cup. It wasn't even good tea, in fact, it was powdered tea. Ugh.

Still pretty decent ramen, but I don't think I'll be coming to this Yamadaya location for a while. If you're like me and have had their ramen at their other locations, don't come to this one. This one is a sure disappointment. I'm willing to give them another chance the next time I swing by Japantown as they just recently opened.
author: Zoe H.

description: Takoyaki is a dish everyone has to get, whats not to love about octopus in balls? Also don't use a fork when you're eating ramen, thats just disgraceful :P must read all signs before entering! its pretty entertaining. the lunch wait isn't bad. Also the demon killer was just a tad too killer for me :( but the ramen was delicious!
author: Nancy W.

description:
Their donkatsu is OK but Ramen is below average. I dont usually write bad reviews. But this place is definitely not as good as other reviews. Their wqiting queue is long but not worth waiting. Servers r not friendly too
 Would not recommend this place. There r much better Ramen place in nearby jtown.  I tried their signature ramen which costs around 12 dollars. Its worse than  instant noodle.
author: Sam L.

description: So many people lining... We ordered the basic ramen, the soup was delicious. But the egg was cold! Should improve that. Another group of guests asked to change seats with us, so the waiter gave us hot matcha tea which was nice!
author: Yuqun F.

description:
My friends and I had a great time! Our server Justin was really nice and checked in on us for water refills and whatnot, even though the place was starting to get busy.
We all got tonkatsu ramen, but one of my friends got the kotteri and I got the spicy (level 2). The spicy one was really delicious, and I highly recommend if you aren't picky about spice or ramen noodle perfection. The pork is soft but holds together well, and students like us get extra servings of noodles or rice if we show our IDs! I certainly ate my fill, haha.

I guess I would only recommend that they get draw down curtains for the windows at afternoon/sundown. The food was great, the service was excellent, and their taiyaki was pretty decent too! The prices are pretty cheap too, esp for J-town. Def go if you're on a budget and want to eat well!

EDIT 4/2016: Yelpers beware! Their spicy ramen has since gotten considerably spicier! I always forget to check in but the last time I went, I got a Level 3 and my friend got a 4 (out of 6) for a relatively easy time, and those were definitely comparable to the 5 and 6 of ye olden days. Our friend pointed out that the waitress looked concerned LOL
author: Angie W.

description: The food looked good in the pictures and the inside setup was nice. I say that because I didn't even eat in there. When my boyfriend and I first walked in there was a guy standing there and I had to ask him if we needed to wait to be seated because he didn't even acknowledge us. So then we asked if we could sit by the window and he said "NO! That's for parties of 4 people or more" ... When only two of the six tables were occupied. Then we were waiting to order for about 10 minutes and no one helped us. Not even for water but got too annoyed by a loud beeping sound that their registers were making so we decided to leave and went across to Shalala Ramen.
author: Abby S.

description:
My friend would like to try this restaurant because he read some good reviews.  We went there around 4:30pm today and there was a long line already.   We waited about 30 min and got in.

I ordered the Yamadaya Ramen. I had to say I was disappointed about the food I ordered.   I am not a fan of greasy food.  The soup was really greasy though.   The pork belly was 90% fat. The egg and Chashu pork were cold in the soup.  It seemed they pre-cooked those items and froze them, then just threw them into the hot soup when they served the ramen. 

The tea costed $1 and tasted bad as well.  I think it was from some kind green tea powder.

I am not impressed about this place at all.  I think a lot people came here due to the good review on the web.  It could just fool me once though.
author: Jon W.

description:
Oh man Tonkotsu broth here is RICH, I'm talking Bill Gates, Warren Buffet, that one guy in Mexico new money $$ rich!!! 

The best broth I've had in the Bay next to Santouka in San Jose. It's so thick and opaque that I could barely see the corn sunked to the bottom of the bowl, and I didn't know my meal included bamboo shoots til the end.

I'm not a fan of thin noodles, so next time I will definitely order the thick for an .50 extra charge. In addition, the chashu included in the bowl wasn't that fatty. If you prefer leaner cuts, then you'd like this place, but if you're obese like me then order a side of deep fried pork belly for $3.50 more!

It comes out to about $10-$15 per bowl which is pretty standard for ramen in the Bay Area.
author: Lille L.

description: Don't come here! I ordered a ramen to go and it took them more than 20 minutes where they had said it would be 10 min. I think the waitress had forgotten. Also it is a tiny portion, the noodles all stick together and look like the package ones, it wasn't miso like I ordered. No seaweed no egg just corn, salad and bamboo.
author: Belgian D.

description: The ramen was terrible. I'm perry sure the noodles aren't fresh.  For almost 10$for a bowl of ramen contained a single piece of dry and old pork.  Really disappointing.
author: Susannah M.

description:
Not as good as the LA branches.  But still pretty good. 

As advertised they cook their Tonkotsu broth for 20 hours+ and it is creamy and delicious. 

There is often a line and a wait with this place.  Tip is to come here at off times, like 5pm.  They do run out of broth, so don't come too late. 

Their menu is super confusing.  I never actually know what I'm getting.  Does the basic ramen come with toppings?  Or do you need to order that separately? I've been here twice and I still don't know.   I certainly don't remember the LA branches being this confusing. 

They have improved the ramen noodles themselves the last time I was here.  Still not as awesome as Sapporo-ya's.  Though the broth is one of the best, however still not as good as the LA ones. 

I would say that, Ramen Parlor/Ramen Dojo down in San Mateo, still has the title of best ramen in the bay area. This would come a very close second.
author: Maggie F.

description: Not much long of a wait, everything tasted really good, service was good and prices were worth it ! Definitely would go again, also it's on the second floor so it was a nice atmosphere !
author: Vanessa R.

description: Went on a Saturday for lunch with a group of friends and was seated on the area with the view that you can see from top.  Four of us ordered the Kotteri ramen and one of us ordered the spicy ramen and if you are a student you get extra noodles!! And garlic! It was very flavorful and delicious! Only complaints are that it took a while for the people to take our order, bring us drinks, or to get us something. Also even though it was nice seating, the sun was blazing hot and made eating the bowl of ramen more uncomfortable that it should be, they should put blinds or something on the windows. A friend of mine who got the spicy ramen was sweating from the hot sun and spice from the ramen and would have to wipe swear every 3 minutes. Other than this, it was pretty good!
author: Jeanette Q.

description: I actually like their noodles okay (other items meh~~~~). BUT a BIG BUT... their service is horrible. Ok... I know Japantown is no Japan, and I shouldn't be expecting the same hospitality as I was in Japan. But the people there were far from welcoming. I was reading how the ownership changed and even the food wasn't as great as before. Maybe I totally miss out. :( Now there were just full house of Filipino servers and cooks. Hey... I STILL wouldn't have a problem if they are nicer (my husband is half Filipino too). No welcome, yelling out names, hurrying people to order, no thank you, not even enough glasses of water. I almost felt like I was begging them for food. The look on their faces... just bunch of unhappy ppl. Oh and their bathrooms are gross and stink!! I had a compact stroller which could convert into a carseat... when the waiter saw me, he just gave me a stern look and said: no stroller! WAO. so I said: then carseat is ok? because my baby needs to sit there. He then said: but this is not a carseat. And I then just made it a carseat!! He then tucked us at the booth seats which was pretty impossible to seat comfortably (we had 4 ppl + the carseat), despite there were other tables which the tiny stroller could easily tuck under. We then decided to press on him to get one of those tables. There are so many choices around SF for a good bowl of ramen. I guess we will pass this place.
author: Jo U.

description:
This place has good spicy miso ramen.  There's always a line, but we never wait more than 20 minutes because the turnover is pretty fast.  The menu is really confusing when it comes to the ramen toppings, but after a few trips I know exactly what to order!  Beware, level 2 spicy ramen is very spicy.  

Tip: order the spicy paste on the side so you can adjust it to your taste.
author: Sara B.

description: Wow is the only one word that i can use to describe this place....the Ramen was unbelievably tasteful. The pork was cooked to perfection and the egg inside was absolutely devine. My one request for you if you are in fact reading this post....is to eat the egg slow, let it sit in your mouth for a few seconds and just enjoy all the amazing different flavors it has to offer. I will definitely be coming back here for more!
author: Virginia V.

description: We ordered two spicy(level 2) ramen with extra pork and bamboo shoot. The soup is thick and kinda salty.
author: Christine C.

description:
Hm, so I'm torn between what to give yamadaya. Food? That was great. Overall experience? 3.5 probably. Solid place though, definitely would go there for ramen again, just, I dunno, I don't feel like I can give it a four yet? Don't let the fact that it's less than 4 stars on yelp dissuade you from going though, I thought it was still pretty tasty and worth going to.

My friend and I came here for lunch and ordered the takoyaki as appetizers. They were so delicious! Super hot though, watch out when you eat them. They might feel fine on the outside, but inside is ridiculously hot (but totally worth it - I burned myself the first time then went back and promptly ate another one haha). 

I love that they give you fresh garlic and a garlic press if you ask for garlic. Do it! It makes your ramen so delicious X) I mean, their broth is tasty without it, and their noodles are actually pretty tasty (Hakata style, though a little less firm than others I've had, which I personally kind of like). But garlic! 

There were two main things that dropped this rating down to a 3, in my opinion.

One, ordering was super confusing. Honestly I'm still puzzled at what I was supposed to do. My friend ordered the yamadaya ramen, but then the lady said something about having to order the broth and that those were just toppings. I was like wait does that mean that the regular ones don't come with any toppings? (They do, though I seriously thought mine didn't have any until I managed to unearth some menma and an egg, to my delight). I'm not a huge fan of the toppings coming on the side though; I got an order of chashu and it came on the side, but it was cold and made it not taste as good. I had to wait for it to warm up in my broth before I wanted to actually attempt to eat it, especially because there were fatty parts that honestly taste a little gross if you eat them when they're all cold and solid. 

Two, and this is a major one for me, their chashu... sorry, it was just so disappointing. I'm a huge fan of chashu - it's usually how I judge ramen restaurants and whether or not I'll go back (what's important for me is chashu, then broth, then noodles, though they're all important). Yamadaya has great broth, but their chashu lacks richness and flavor, and falls a little flat IMO. The regular bowl of tonkotsu ramen came with a (very thin) slice of chashu, but I had ordered a side dish of (much thicker) chashu and I kind of regret doing so. Their chashu is a 2. Do yourself a favor and splurge and order the kakuni (pork belly) instead. It's way way tastier.
author: Jess S.

description: One of my friends took me here. I tried the vegan ramen and we keep coming back for it every time we're around Japan town. One of the best ramen places in SF!
author: Gauri A.

description:
About the only good ramen place in Japantown, ironically. 

The ramen is good here, nuff said. Bring your student ID and you get extra noodles. Good broth, could be more meat, but tasty.

Yep.
author: Kevin W.

description:
I come here for the broth -- mmmmm!  As SF is often foggy and cold, and Yamadaya is luckily no more than a 10 minute walk from our current abode, a big bowl of noodles in good broth is nothing to turn your nose up at.  

I've gone for the spicy tonkostu the last few times, which is good, but if you're looking for the full fatty mouth-feel experience, go for the tonkotsu kotteri.  Bowls come with some toppings (not a lot), but for about $2.50 more, you can get a sampler plate of extra toppings (chashu, pork belly, green onions, bamboo shoots, etc.) for the table, which is good for sharing between two bowls.  

Fairly priced, and usually pretty quick.  And fresh garlic is always free!
author: Cherry L.

description: How this place has less than 4 stars is mind-boggling... Great food (karaage was perfectly done and served with Japanese mayo), ramen on point and "eastern al dente" and they serve Orion beer, an Okinawan brew that is a must whenever you can find it.  We eat lots of ramen and this one is recommended.
author: B J M.

description: CHICKEN KARAAGE is one of the best that i've had tasted in the USA (mine making at home is better of course).  Ramen is decent, perhaps because i'm ok with Ramen, not a big fan.  There could be  a long wait time at certain hours.  3.5 stars.
author: Dung L.

description:
I had a great experience here! The service was on point and friendly, the ambiance was good, and the food was tasty. I've had a decent array of experiences with ramen, having tried various spots across the city, and Yamadaya is one of the better choices for SF.

We got the Yamadaya Ramen with the spicy tuna bowl & salad combo. The spicy tuna bowl and salad came out first - the salad was refreshing and the spicy tuna was tasty and served as a good appetizer.

The ramen itself was also great - broth was just the right amount of spicy (I got the #2 on the spicy scale), 2 egg halves (you usually only get 1), 3 pieces of seaweed, and a lot of meat. 

Left feeling very satisfied and will definitely come again!
author: Eli B.

description: I love when a restaurant knows what it's good at and is unapologetic about it.  Ramen Yamadaya serves ramen.  That's it.  Don't come here asking for or expecting anything else.  The other items on their menu (e.g. chicken karaage, tempura, etc) are simply bonus.  You come here to eat ramen.  And if you accept that, you will not be disappointed.  Long lines, bustling, somewhat noisy interior, nice little 'group' table in the center of the seating area, definitely reminded me (a little) of some ramen shops I've been to in Japan... overall, (again) what I would expect.  Now for the ramen.  Delicious.  Rather large portions, lots of meat, noodles were just right, and the soup was delicious.  You may have to wait a bit to get a seat and the restaurant is a little difficult to find (second floor above another restaurant in Japantown), but overall, it's worth it.  Definitely recommend this place.  And oh by the way, make sure to read the "How to Eat Ramen" sign in the front of the restaurant.  Classic!
author: John K.

description:
Good Food and Quality Service!

Went on a Monday night. Relaxed crowd but upbeat atmosphere. I would go again!
author: Garrett K.

description:
I've waited until after my 4th trip to Yamadaya to write a review because I wanted to be sure I got it right. Every time I've visited I've felt that they were just on the verge of something, approaching greatness perhaps, or at least very goodness. But after this trip, I think that it's clear this place will just never be that good.

One thing to note: maybe it's the extended drought and lack of rainfall to wash away the pee collecting in the stairwell leading up to this restaurant, but the breeze blowing in from the window behind me was distinctly wee-wee scented -- and not in a pleasant way. 

I ordered the shoyu Yamadaya ramen every time I visited and the broth at Yamadaya has consistently been very good.  In fact, this is the thing that made me think that one day everything would fall into place and it would be a great place for ramen. But everything else has been inconsistent, varying from okay to barely acceptable to flat out gross. 

While I may be wrong about this, and apologies if I am, I've gotten the impression on more than one occasion that some of the ingredients may be slightly more aged than is desirable. There are some odd flavors and unpleasant smells (I'm talking about the food now, not the pee-pee breeze).

If they're still in business in a year, maybe I'll give them another try, but I certainly won't be back any time soon.
author: Horace A.

description: Really good Japanese food at great prices. Pretty busy on a Saturday night but the staff handle it really well. Nice first time experience. We will be back:)
author: Nicole S.

description: One of the most delicious ramen restaurants in San Francisco. My favorite place to head to when I crave for ramen. I usually order Spicy Tonkotsu Ramen level 1. Oh man, It is so delicious. First, take a sip of the broth, then go for the ramen. I definitely come back for more.
author: Theresa N.

description:
Currently this is my go-to ramen spot in San Francisco.  Compared to the other places, I feel like Ramen Yamadaya has the right thickness of broth, diversity of meat, texture of noodles, and assortment of toppings. 

Typically I order the black garlic ramen "Yamadaya" style, along with an extra serving of pork belly to share with my friends.  I find that that is more than enough food for our party.  Service is generally good, I haven't had bad service at Ramen Yamadaya yet, though be prepared to wait as the line is out the door during dinner time.
author: Cristian L.

description: We were seated and made our order after being asked three different times, by three different waiters within seconds if we were ready. Terrible communication between the mediocre staff I might add. After making our order we waited for over 30 mins and watched as others, that had been seated after us, receive their orders before us. So we just got up and left without saying anything. Hope the food didn't go to waste. Would not recommend the place at all.
author: Marcos E.

description: been here several times, still think the yamadaya spicy is my favorite, before this place was delivering a japanese style ramen place in tokyo, when you entered the staffs will greet you in japanese. however, for some reasons, the whole serving team changed to PHILIPPINOS, and they are just not as nice as japanese or others.
author: Lei B.

description: Had the Tsukemen (thick broth ramen for dipping) and Yamadeya Shoyu. The broth is pretty tasty but the pork was not to my liking. The pork slices were way too thick and does not look appetizing. I would prefer thinner slices though. Waiting time for food was quite long as well (~20-25 min), even for the appetizer to arrive.
author: Nina J.

description:
Came to this Ramen shop for lunch the other day.  I made the cardinal mistake of not ordering the specialty of the house.  I could have hardly imagined that what I ordered would turn out to be the Chicken Katsu of doom.  The breading was tough, and the chicken was dry;  eating it was much like self-inflicted punishment.  My mouth would be sore for days after eating this culinary fail.  In retrospect I should have had the sense to have sent it back and order Vegan Ramen instead.

-  While reading this review watch the Spock Pain Remix on youtube for added effect.

Note to management, go to Daiso and get those handy wobbly table fixers, because a wobbly table is an easy thing to fix.  Also the hipster light bulbs in your establishment are very hard on the eyes.  You would save money installing L.E.D. lighting instead.
author: Jim M.

description:
First let me say I have never been here of all the times I have eaten at japan town. 

Second let me say this review has nothin to do with RAMEN.

I was really craving a nice thick curry with juicy flakey katsu and saw the pictures outside looked legit so I thought to myself 'oh why not'.

Their chicken katsu curry is legit!

The curry is thick and has nice balance of spicy and sweet. The Katsu is flakey yet moist inside. 

Adding to my list of favs.
author: Cheung L.

description: The noodle is really good. It's homemade. Really chewy . Non spicy broth taste a lil salty at the end, the +1.5 spicy is perfect. Not that spicy and salty. U will feel u want dessert after u finish. And the nijia super market is right in the corner. Go after 6 can find street parking easy. Really worth to try. To me it taste better than Genki and 21 Century.
author: Johnny J.

description: I came here for dinner last night and was pretty unhappy with the ramen. I got the regular tonkotsu ramen and the broth was not flavorful at all. I had to add in a lot of togarashi and almost a head of garlic to make it edible. It's not enjoyable to slurp noodles that don't have any flavor -- especially with tonkotsu-based broths because it's so rich and fatty. This used to be one of my favorite places to go for ramen but it seems like their quality has declined over time. Not sure if I'd recommend this place again to friends.
author: Hana K.

description: we had to wait for about 15min and got seated fast. it was not that busy. ramens are bit salty. those soy sauce are even worse. think about it; salty ramen noodle + soy sauce with sodium. below average table services. we decided not come here again because of the salty ramens.
author: Duke B.

description:
Looking at the old reviews about the service in 2013, I'm pretty sure they fired all the bad eggs. Service now is very good. Friendly, responsive, and quick. 

As for the food, It is definitely one of the better ramens in san francisco. The meats are extremely rich in taste. Ramen broth might be slightly on the tasty/salty side. But I can see how some people might love that. Personally it can be more balanced. But it's satisfying overall. Eggs are boiled well as you can see from pictures. And i believe it was boiled/marinated in soy sauce. Really makes the eggs explode with flavor. 

It got 4 stars because of the salty broth. But try it out. you might like it!
author: Ken T.

description: Taste was first experience for me but it was not bad. However, it was nothing for any special so I am going to try other ramen store if I have such an opportunity.
author: Goo F.

description: Best ramen I had in SF so far.  I am wondering if there is better and I would love to try, but so far this is the best for me.  Tasty and thick broth!
author: Sherry S.

description:
A group of us decided to try Yamadaya after the cherry blossom festival. It was around 4:30 when we walked in. As we walked in, one of the waitresses asks us, "how many". We tell them 4. It looks like they are getting ready to seat us, when another waitress yells at us in broken english, "go...go outside. Wait outside". Another group of customers is already standing behind us as we try to make our way out, but the server gets impatient...and yells "go" again. Everyone walks on out. There were plenty of tables open. In fact, they had more people working then customers. How hard is it to sit a group of 4? I already annoyed at this point since they were treating us like kids, I wanted to leave, but it wasn't 15 seconds later after we walked out that they came to get us. WTF seriously? Why couldn't they just sit us the first time.

Anyways, we got to our seat. The waitress left hastily as if she were too busy. We started looking at the menu. The prices are more than the other ones around Japantown (such as Warnaku or Tanpopo). We sat there for 10 minutes and no one came to take our order. It would be totally different if they had a packed room, but they didn't. The service is rude and inefficient. I was annoyed at this point, and I opened up  my Yelp app to write this review, and then I see the reviews about FOOD POISONING. I was already ready to leave before, but those reviews convinced everyone else it was time to leave too. We walked on out and no one even noticed.

For a new place, the service sucks and they are inefficient. Don't waste your time going to this place.
author: Christopher K.

description:
I loved the ramen! It was my first time having it too. It gets pretty crowded it seems, but the staff is really friendly and quick. We got our water and food so fast! 

Ramen is definitely not an everyday food( I don't think I could consume bowls of creamy pork broth and noodles), but once in a while, come here to slurp up that rich goodness.
author: Bahar A.

description:
My friends and I went here during the ramen festival and we waited an hour and a half before we got seated. I'm sure it's not that busy during any other day though. Related to that, I really didn't like how we had 4 waiters constantly asking us if we were ready to order. It felt like they were hassling us to hurry up because they were busy. It almost ruined the place for me. 

This is the first time I had ramen and I must say, I quite enjoyed it. 
It was a bit too salty for me, but I don't know if all ramen is like that. 
The price was reasonable. It was not super expensive, like a lot of restaurants in the city.
author: Ilah Kristel M.

description:
I wanted like the place but I did not like it because lack of something.

I AM TIRED OF TONKOTSU CRAP!!!
TONKOTSU is every where! But none of them are real thing.
The thin noodle has no "Koshi", Koshi means as strength of al dente noodle, means some what reasonably firm but not too hard, and the noodle should be bouncy.

The noodle breaks like an old thin candle. Ugh!
I hate those half cooked thin noodle.
I think they don't really know how to cook the thin noodle.

And the broth, something about the yo-yo-broth, ugh, I don't know, wasn't strong enough. I usually drink all ramen broth when I liked it, but I couldn't do it. That's my sign telling I am not really happy for the ramen.

I had the Yamadaya Ramen, 11 bucks.
I liked the Kakuni, seasoned egg, chashu-pork and dried seaweed, but the noodle and broth sucks.

No more TONKOTSU!
No more Miso shit.
Tired of Kimchi Ramen Crap!
Even though I still love Kimchi Fried Rice so much, I am tried of Kimchi-Miso-Fxxx-Ramen.

I like an old time Ramen.

Just take those old top-ramen off the shelf 
I'll sit and eat to 'em by m'self 
Today's ramen ain't got the same soul 
I like that old time ramen and roll 

Don't try to take me to the Yamadaya 
You'll never even get me out on the floor 
In 10 minutes I'll be late for the door 
I like that old time ramen and roll 

(Chorus) 
Still like that old time ramen and roll 
The kinda ramen just soothes the soul 
I reminisce about the days of old 
With that old time ramen and roll 

Won't go to hear 'em eat a TONKOTSU
I'd rather eat some Shuyu or funky old Wantan-men 
There's only one sure way to get me to go 
Start cookin' old time ramen and roll 

Call me a relic call me what'cha will 
Say I'm old fashioned say I'm over the hill 
Today's ramen ain't got the same soul 
I like that old time ramen and roll 

(Chorus) 

(Chorus) 

(Chorus) 

(Chorus) 

Still like that old time ramen and roll
author: Nobu K.

description: Food tastes fine and there's usually a wait.... But the place smells like piss and the service is something left to be desired. Also, $2 for one cup of hot tea and they don't even come by to refill?!
author: Cynthia W.

description: Their ramens are good, but their service is terrible... They let people wait although there are some tables available. Hope they don't lose their customers by operating their business so slow.
author: H M.

description: Love this place, brought my spouse with me and his ramen had corn added and was way to spicy for level one. Restaurant refused refund meal only gave half off.  Come on guys step it up, if you make someone's Order wrong you own up to it !!!
author: Wanda M.

description: Was walking through Japantown when we saw the menu of this place on the outside window and wondered if the amazing prices meant they skimped on portion and flavor. They did NOT. The prices were incredible and the food you got was plentiful. And not only that it was incredible! I ordered the tonkotsu ramen and it was fantastic. Full of noodles and pork goodness. A very healthy portion. This place was great, especially on a chilly San Francisco afternoon, and I highly recommend it if you are in Japantown... Or even nearby! The service was also exceptional, but mind you, they don't have forks, so don't be a heathen and ask for one! Great service, great food, great prices. Go. Now.
author: Roger M.

description:
Ok so we went for the ramen festival but ended up here. I wanted to be at Tan Po Po next door but...oh well. Oops did I just name dropped ? 

Anywho, my bf wasn't hungry so we were just gonna share one bowl. And by share, I mean, I eat most of it and then offer him whatever I can't finish. LOL.

This is what I got: tonkotsu spicy ramen (lvl 1 spicy), with yamadaya toppings, kakuni pork belly, and we got an iced green tea.

First off, the price for a bowl of that spicy ramen was 9.45, and that's without the toppings. I think that's a little pricy for what it was, no toppings?? But the price to add the yamadaya topping was 2.50, so that was reasonable. The broth at first taste seemed good, but the more I ate it, i realized it was actually salty...like really really salty, i was dying for water! I really like spicy food so i got the level 1 spicy but i think i should've gotten the level 2. I Need to have my spice! The noodles were too thin for my taste and overcooked. The egg was also overcooked. The pork belly, although they give you a good portion, was so plain I had to dip it into the salty broth lol I guess that's what you're supposed to do with it. 

Iced green tea, it came in a can! Wasn't expecting that. This is unsweetened green tea. Definitely refreshing after a bowl of hot and salty noodles. I needed that. 

The service was pretty fast considering how busy it was that day, and customer service was ok too, nothing bad nothing great. I think they could have utilized their space better, especially that big table in the middle, it's cool but a whole nother table could fit there!

overall, wasn't horrible but nothing great to make me want to come back.
author: Molly M.

description:
I craved for ramen bad! Being in JapanTown, how can you not have some Japanese cuisine? The "ramen" sign stood out from across the mall. My friend and I went ahead and waited for 20 minutes till we got in. There are always people in line during lunch hours. 

We were called to sit in the booth near the windows. It would have been a great spot to have some nice views going along with some good ramen. But the moment we sat down, I couldn't help but notice this weird foul smell. I could not figure out what was the deal with that at first. (Ps I have a really sensitive nose.) I consistently informed my friend of this stink and asked her if she sense it as well? She insisted no. 

The whole time I was staring at the menu uncomfortably. I seriously was going to lose my appetite if I stayed where we were. I asked if we can move somewhere else and we got to sit in the big table in the middle of the room. Yay, it was not as bad and my appetite was back!!

I ordered the Tonkotsy Spicy because I love spicy food! My friend ordered the Yamadaya Ramen and Takoyaki. The ramen noodles are exceptionally good, chewy wheaty noodles man! The broth is really thick and authentic. All the other stuff in the bowl I don't have much to say. Just so-so. The spicy chili pepper paste is pretty good as well. 

Will I come back? No, not if they don't better the ventilation. Ps I think it's the smell of the pork broth. If you don't have a nose like mine, but a nose like my friend's then it's a good place for ramen. Noodles are the yummers!
author: Howie J.

description:
Went here during the Cherry Blossom Festival. For this special occasion only, they decided to change their menu. we were only able to get the ramen with regular noodles. I ordered the Spicy level 2 ramen. It wasn't as spicy as I thought it would be. Service here was pretty slow due to the festival. The ramen was really good. Probably better than most San Jose places I've been to. They give you a whole egg here which was surprising to me. 

Must try? Yes on a regular schedule
Try again? Yes I would.
author: Thomas N.

description: Oh so yummy. I normally do not eat pork but we had the ramen and it was well worth it. However the menu was slightly confusing and the waitress didn't explain anything to us. Also the table we sat at was sticky. Like needing to be scrubbed with cleaner multiple times sticky. I'm not sure if we would go back.
author: Alix F.

description:
Yes..! This ramen place might be second to Orenchi in San Jose in my book.

We ordered the Tonkatsu Kotteri and the Spicy #2.

PROS: Extremely flavorful broth. A full layer of chashu pork and some pork belly (they didn't skimp at all). Freshly minced garlic to taste. Lots of seaweed. The spicy #2 was actually somewhat spicy too!

CONS: Noodles were slightly thinner than I would have liked, but I like soggy noodles, so this is only half a con.

We also ordered cold sake. Our glasses were pre-chilled and the sake had a cooling chamber that kept our beverage chill while it was sitting. Huge plus in attention to detail.

Will be back for a ramen fix in the near future!
author: Tiffany W.

description:
I must say, the tonkotsu broth was amazing!!  They use thin ramen noodles which holds up more soup inbetween the noodles compare to thicker noodles. Tonkotsu flavor in every single bite. 

Cons: The center table is new so it's fine but the booth tables had a funny smell and the tables were a little sticky. It kindda bothered me when I was eating.
author: R C.

description: I've been here a number of times but not been super impressed. Recently though they must have been some changes to their recipe because the broth is so much more delicious! Gone from "ok" to "highly recommend".
author: Nader E.

description:
This is my first Elite review so I am really glad to be writing a review for a very good ramen place.  This place serves all tonkotsu broth (my favorite) either with shio (for the regular and black sesame flavor) or shoyu (also in the spicy flavor). I had the regular tonkotsu broth here because I feel that is the best way to taste if the broth is good or not. The tonkotsu broth at Yamadaya is the best around.... creamy, slightly oily and gelatinous, and pleasant savory taste.  The thick curly noodles (50cent extra) is a must to go with the broth. The thicker noodles with more surface area than regular noodles get coated with more broth creating a better experience. The Yamadaya ramen comes with 2 types of pork, kakuni and charsiu, and a nice flavored egg.  I thought the charsiu was a little too lean making it a little dry. The kakuni tasted good and I think they smoked it.  There is enough fat in the pork belly to balance out the smokiness. 
Very attentive servers and reasonable price for a great bowl of ramen. The layout is good for many 4 person groups and there is a large communal table in the middle. Good for kids and families
author: James W.

description:
i've been to Japan but i only had ramen there once, so i don't consider myself a ramen expert. and i've just started to scope out Japantown.

so, with that very helpful introduction, let me say that this place makes a solid ramen. the base one is about $10 and it's a perfect size for the price, though if you're really hungry i might suggest adding a little appetizer or side dish to make sure you fill up.

also recommended: the 1 L (i.e. almost three beers) Asahi. hell yeah.
author: Ronny K.

description:
THE CHECKLIST

I have been on a ramen rampage lately. And even came up with a checklist. Kwangto has a checklist?

Just like every grown adult has a checklist for a partner. You know, the one that goes like this ....

Employed
Passionate
Cute
Healthy
Clean
Funny
Unique 
And so on.

Here's the lowdown at yamada.
Noodles - love it, al dente and different
Broth - spicy and was like drinking butter
Meat - soft and flavorful
Egg - hmmmm wth happened. Hard as rocks.

So what do you when its only 50 percent up to par? Like that potential partner, I'd keep
that phone number for those drunken nights.
author: Q L.

description: Sat for 40 minutes with no service. Server forgot to enter order, and was ignoring us. Had to walk over to get attention directly. Not recommended.
author: J L.

description:
Got here on a Sunday and managed to beat the dinner rush around 5:30 pm.

My bf and I got seated by the window which was great because the place does get a little stuffy so it was nice to be the window with the breeze coming in.

We started off with gyoza which were only ok. They were stuck to each other and so a lot of filling came out when we were trying to pick at a piece.

For ramen, my bf ordered the ramen yamadaya with the spicy broth and I got the kotteri with a side of the pork belly. The side of pork belly is a pretty good size so i would recommend ordering one piece that would be enough among 2 to 3 ppl. The ramen was good but it was a little too rich since it was tonkatsu broth. I didn't realize that I didnt get any fixings with the kotteri reman so I was missing out on the seaweed pieces and mushrooms that were in my bf's ramen yamadaya bowl. My bf liked his ramen, the broth wasn't too spicy. The chashu did seem a bit overcooked? Also the pork belly was a little dry. All in all its a decent place to get ramen on a cold day. I would come back to try more!
author: Christine W.

description: Bad bad service, the waitress was so unfriendly, and she seated us 7 people In a small table, when I said I wanna move to another table she said I'm so picky.... Wtf and the food was not good.
author: Quincy C.

description:
The noodles they served us were Hella mushy, wtf is that?  I wish they would've put top ramen noodles in that broth, then it would've been on hit.  I was told later that it's because the noodles aren't fresh anymore.  Who'd feed their custys rancid food?

I'm sad because the only time out of the year my girlfriends and I can get together, we ended up here.  Good thing there was super fun conversation with great dialogue to get through it.  We also consoled with shi-shi la-la imported mochi and daiso after...and thought about buying rare flavored spam. lol
author: Isa H.

description: The spicy tonkotsu ramen was delicious! I got a level 2 spicy, but definitely could have it a bit spicier next time. :) The noodles were firm and the broth was on point. The soft boiled egg was perfect. I only wish there was more pork chashu with the ramen. Overall, it met my ramen expectations. The place was a bit crowded so prepare to put your name down and wait if you arrive around dinner time on a weekend.
author: Maria V.

description: They are very slow with service and took too long with wait times to get seated. Food was average.
author: Ji C.

description:
The best ramen we've had in the bay area so far. Unfortunately.

In Tokyo no one would give Yamadaya a second glance. The prices would be too high and the quality is just mediocre. 

But in San Francisco, this place shines, if only by comparison. The broth is not as tasty as Ken Ken, but the lower salt level makes this broth actually edible, where Ken Ken's is not. 

The noodles are good, if not quite as al-dente as we'd like. The egg soft in the middle as it should be, and the pork tasted ok. 

The one major problem was their extremely foul tasting menma (bamboo shoots). If you go, ask for them on the side, or perhaps just leave them out. 

Gyoza tasted right, and were crisp on the bottom from frying although perhaps not quite as crisp as they could have been. 

Service was friendly if a bit scattered...

It's too bad Yamada is the best we've tried so far, because it's really just OK. But apparently being OK is not easy, and they have managed it.
author: Jacob L.

description:
ラーメン屋で 乾燥麺⁇‼

We're seated right away for Sunday Lunch. But waited 30 min. for Ramen, another 5 for gyoza. There were 5 servers , just 2 in the kitchen. They need to do something about wait situation. Food is not coming out so table will not turn. By the time we were done, there was long line down the stairs.

Soup was good, but noodle .... which is the very important ingredient in Ramen as well.
I am almost sure they use dry noodle!
Unbelievable!!! 
If they do use fresh noodle, my apology.
But it's their fault to make it taste like dry one.

Ramen is getting so popular and it seems like everyone is serving one. Sorry to say that this place is not real for my expectation.
author: Emiko H.

description:
Im not at all impressed with the noodles or flavor.  7 people in my party & only one loved it. 
I also ordered the potstickers which had a very chemical/ plastic taste "yuck " my hot green tea came in a large plastic glass, which made it hot to touch/ drink.
author: S. Rene' P.

description: I came here with my relatives from Florida.  They were busy that day and the food was great!  Today, my husband wanted to go there since he missed out that day with the family and wanted to taste really good ramen.  This time they just opened at 5pm and they weren't busy.  But this time it was really bad service.  We ordered our food but then the booth smelled like urine.  So we requested if we can move to another table.  But one of the workers wouldn't allow it because they can't delete the table number because we already ordered and they can't remember the previous table we were at.  For example, we were seated in table 35 and we wanted to sit in table 12.  The restaurant is not big and it's not busy at all.  all they had to do is remember that we were previously seated in table 35 just to bill us. And if another family sat in table 35, all they have to do is bill that family in table 12.  Pretty simple.  But no!!! They still wouldn't let us move.  I even suggested we won't order anymore food and that if we did order food, we would remind the waitress that we were the family seated in the other table.  But still they didn't allow us!  So, to make it easier for them we told them to cancel our order and we left and went to the restaurant across from them and that place smells better and did not smell like urine.  Another sad thing about that worker, is that he just made his staff look dumb because they couldn't remember a simple adjustment.  I hope if we do come back here, they should clean and dry the floors and table properly.  Because I don't know how people can eat and smell urine the same time
author: MariAbe E.

description: Eaten there three time all great. Love taking my friends here. Great price the service is so so tho. The ramen makes up for it tho.
author: nancy w.

description:
FOOD POISONING!

I ordered the Yamada ramen, which the waitress recommended as their specialty. I have been vomiting for a full day now. It is clearly food poisoning. DO NOT EAT HERE! They need to be shut down immediately. I am not the only person this had happened to. Be warned!
author: Chris S.

description:
I've been scoping all the ramen places in SF with my boyfriend, who loves ramen, and this is one of our go-to's. I personally think their broth is one of the best I've had, I always get the Kotteri Tonkotsu broth which comes with black garlic oil. I'm always a little disappointed by the thin, plentiful noodles. We always get it with half noodles which works out much better. It's hard to overlook the limp noodles even though I love the broth.

The wait isn't usually too bad and the food comes out fairly quickly. Their menu is fairly limited, and I've tried their takoyaki and cod roe rice, which are both fairly decent.
author: Kate M.

description:
Excuse the brevity but I'm going to keep it simple.

Phenomenal rich tonkostu broth with garlic oil, far superior to Waraku on Post street.

Noodles are a little too thin for my liking. 

Kakuni is tasty and not too fatty 

I like that the onsen tamago is not smoked like at Waraku, so it doesn't compete with the flavor of the broth.

It was my favorite spot in LA, glad there's one in SF  now :)
author: Mia H.

description:
I ordered a bowl of tonkatsu with fresh garlic on the side, and extra noodle for my 2.5 years old daughter. I made her a bowl before I grated the garlic for myself. But because I didn't add too much broth into her bowl to begin with, I accidentally gave her some of my broth with the garlic in it. She then complaint it's too spicy for her. I did regret adding the broth with garlic to her bowl, but because she's still hungry, I asked if I could have some extra broth, like 1-2 tablespoonful. The waitress 'politely' told me she would need to charge me $5. Really?! The whole bowl of noodle is $9 and you want to charge me $5 for 30 ml of broth?! I re-emphasized that I just wanted a little bit so the extra noodle that I ordered would not be as dry, but she insisted that she would need to charge me $5. I don't mind paying but $5 seemed ridiculous. 

The customer service was just bad in general. Not sure of it's because I was with my toddler or not, but the entire wait staff (3 people) was busy serving other people when I was trying to get my check. My meter was expiring and my daughter was cranky, so after not be able to get anyone's eye contacts in 5 minutes, I decided to stand up and see if anyone would help me. I kept trying to get eye contacts from anyone but no one seemed to have noticed me, even though they kept walking back and forth in front of me and I was just standing 2 ft away. 

If you have kid(s) with you and are craving for ramen, please do yourself a favor and not come here, unless you want subpar customer service with mediocre ramen.
author: Jessie C.

description: I've been to many ramen places in SF and in the Bay Area and this place stands out to me the most. Clean and great service too. Spicy is definitely the way to go here! It's always crowded here so get here extra early!
author: Chris S.

description: I've only recently discovered the unearthly magnificent wonders of ramen, and this place was delicious! Located in the heart of japantown and easily accessible from the parking garage is a plus. The menu wasn't as large as other ramen spots but nonetheless they have enough straightforward options for you to choose. I had the spicy ramen at level 2 which wasn't spicy enough for my taste but still yummy.
author: Natally A.

description: Really fast service.  Ordered the Yamada Spicy ramen.  Soup was rich and fatty, great flavors!  Noodle texture was a bit hard. There were two types of pork in the soup,  one was good,  one was dry. Overall, a place I would recommend trying.
author: Ricky H.

description:
One of the newest ramen digs to hit Japantown/SF.  It's quietly tucked on the second level in the building next to Tanpopo, so it's easy to miss if you're hanging out just in the mall area.

We waited about 10 minutes for a table around 6:40 on a Friday night (our first choice was Waraku, but after seeing the line we were like hellz naw).  The restaurant is oddly spaced, with a huge empty section in the middle.  I get that it's easier for the servers to walk around and across, but they could've easily accommodated for at least 6 more guests just by adding 3 small tables.  Otherwise the restaurant does not feel warm and cozy, but instead sort of cold and sterile.

Positives:
+ We received our food fairly quickly - we were probably in the restaurant for a total of 30 minutes.
+ Fairly limited but good choice of broths: tonkotsu, shoyu, tonkotsu with black garlic oil, and spicy tonkotsu (1 for mild, 2 for hot, 3 for extra spicy)
+ Gyoza was decent - if it hadn't been for the dipping sauce, it would've been bland though.
+ Great broth, and HUGE, thick pieces of chashu if you order the Yamadaya toppings (which basically just means extra chashu, seaweed and egg).
+ BF loved his spicy tonkotsu (#2 - hot).

Mehs:
- Thin noodles means not the delicious chewy ramen noodles I love so much.
- I didn't receive much broth.  Actually it was to the point where I was afraid to scoop up a whole spoonful with each twirl of noodles for fear that I would run out at the end.
- Chashu, though we each received 3 HUGE slices, was so tough I couldn't eat it.  Pretty sure I almost pulled my teeth out when I tried to rip one slice apart.
- Once you get your food, service is pretty sparse.  We had to flag someone down for our check.

Not a bad place, but I wouldn't wait longer than 5-10 minutes for a spot here.
author: Tori S.

description:
To tell the truth, I don't want to leave a review and my 5 stars for Yamadaya. That would make this place even more crowded and I would have to get in longer lines when I want Yamadaya. However, there are so many fake tonkotsu in the city which I am upset with and I have to speak out because those overpriced, low-quality ramens have to disappear from the city!

My recommendation is tonkotsu shoyu. I love their tonkotsu also, but I just love the kick of soy sauce which is SOOO GOOD!!! Good flavorful broth, really thin tonkotsu noodles (which you don't see in fake tonkotsu ramen), and super tender chashu!

Pricing is reasonable. Yesterday we ate: 
Tonkotsu Kotteri ramen + extra Kakuni 
Tonkotsu Shoyu ramen + Mentaiko bowl set 
and, the bill was less than $30.

I am so glad I would no longer have to fly to LA or NY for good tonkotsu ramen.
author: Chu R.

description: This place used to be so great, even on their busiest days they manage to keep the flow of customers. Mainly coz of the Japanese lady waitress/ manager. During my visit today, the entire service staff has been replaced. Not a problem, but the new male manager, carried a horrible aura about him. There was more vacant, uncleared tables than there was people waiting outside. There was approx. 8 ppl waiting, with lots of vacant tables, just uncleared. A simple example  of how a single person can destroy a once successful business.
author: Lily H.

description:
I'm from LA which is home to some awesome ramen joints, and have been looking for one in SF; not the south bay, as I don't have a car anymore. A friend recommended we go here on a Sunday as it wouldn't be too crowded.

What I had: spicy Yamadaya ramen, potstickers, and rice with spicy fish roe. The ramen broth was luxurious, and backs up their claim that it takes 24hrs or so to prepare. The pot stickers were meh, I would pass on them. The rice bowl was decent too, but you really do come here for the ramen. 

Back to the ramen; it was full of chasu pork, mushrooms and green onions. The noodles were a bit thin and not quite al dente (not like santouka or daikokuya), but still serve their purpose well. The spicy was not painfully spicy, though I got one level below the max. 

So far my only true ramen experience in SF; I would go back for sure. It also helps that its so close to the Nijiya market where I can buy pocky.
author: Josh P.

description: Good ramen spot. There was a line which is probably common so make sure to walk to the front to add your name to the waiting list. Service was not the best but the food is yummy.
author: D G.

description: I was a bit surprised to find that when I got there on a Sunday night, we had to actually put our names on the wait list.  The good news was that it only took 15 minutes or so.  The menu was a bit confusing, but we ended up ordering the ramen yamadaya which seemed to be the house special.  It has two types of pork which are apparently the regular chashu pork as well a couple of pieces of pork belly.  I preferred the shoyu (soy sauce) base over the regular pork broth option, which tasted a bit too fatty.  We ordered extra corn, which ended up showing up in two side dishes.  Overall the ramen was great.  The seaweed salad was too icy, and the kara-age chicken was too heavily battered.  Maybe we'll stick with the ramen next time.
author: Vivian W.

description:
We came here after seeing this place listed in 7x7s ramen places.  We were not disappointed. It is in japantown, right above shabusen.  We were seated promptly upon arriving.  I guess its an LA chain.

I had the tsukemen and also a mentai rice.  Both were delicious!!!

The service is also pretty awesome.  We had a fourth person joining us and she didnt arrive until close to closing time.  They had told us to let them know when she arrived so they could fire up a fresh bowl.  The waiter was really insistent that she get a fresh bowl of ramen!  It was pretty awesome. 

Will need to come back!
author: claudia y.

description: The wait is usually pretty sucky, but you can get a beer while you wait for your table! I highly recommend the spicy tonkotsu with pork belly on the side (it's a HUGE slab, yum) - make sure you ask for fresh garlic! It comes with whole cloves and a press and is complimentary.
author: Brock H.

description: Ramen here is awesome. I really enjoyed Tonkotsu Kotteri Ramen. It had lots of toppings already so I was told that I did not need to buy extra topping. The soup tasted like real pork soup, not made from artificial flavored powder. I know the difference- you get a sticky feeling on youe lips after you have real pork soup, and you will only bacome thirsty after you have the fake one. The only thing I don't like is that the noodles were a little hard (tasted like not fully cooked). But I really love the soup, so I don't care how hard the noodles are...
author: Sheri K.

description:
Nothing BAD about the tsukemen. Just nothing particularly impressive. 

The broth was saltier (as it should be) than normal ramen broth but not any thicker. Found that interesting. Noodles were cooked correctly. Egg was more hard-boiled than soft. Chasu slice was minuscule yet flavorful. Karaage was average. Where was the fish powder they advertised with the tsukemen in the plastic displays out front?! Gimmie the POWDER.
author: Anthony R.

description:
Tasty! I had the tonkatsu kotteri ramen. Nice thick broth. I liked the finer gauge noodles. The basic set up (without the Yamadaya  extras) was perfect for me. It included 1/2 an egg and a piece of pork along with scallion and mushrooms. The pork was a good sized slice, and tender.  My dining companion had the salt base with Yamadaya set up. The broth tasted a little...fishy, but perhaps that's just because of the more savory version I had. He enjoyed it, so that's what's important. 

As others have mentioned, it was agonizing watching people linger over their meals through the windows, but it's not like this is a stand-up noodle joint where you're expected to slurp and go. We went on a Friday at 6pm--it was packed with a 20 minute wait. But, by 8pm, there were a couple of empty tables. 

It's not super quick from order time to food on the table but we enjoyed the people watching, and our server Nori was super sweet and helpful. 

We will definitely be back. The bento plates looked yummy, so I'm going to explore that next!
author: Jen L.

description: I am giving this place 1 star for being fast.  EVERYTHING about the food is awful.  First the edemame was not cooked enough.  Second the pork in my ramen was the driest I have ever eaten.  Third my wife had katsu curry which she swore the pork was pre made plastic and over cook.   There are so many good ramen places in SF and Japan Town.  Do not waist your money here.   The place down stair and next door to the left is 1000x better for just one example.
author: Dale H.

description: Waited 30 minutes bumped our table three times finally got in. Watched everybody get waited on besides us. Finally walked out. Went to Sanppo seated right away ordered right away
author: Vicki W.

description: Awesome service, great ramen and they even have a vegan option! Great place to get a bowl of ramen!!
author: Amy H.

description:
Great ramen place!  All the bowls have a pork flavored broth, but they do have a vegan option. My wife generally doesn't like the pork flavor but she still loved the one with black garlic oil. 

This is one of the places I always eat at when I visit Japantown.  There is often a line but it moves quick. The menu is simple and there are a few other options besides ramen. 

If you like ramen check it out!
author: George A.

description:
finally a good ramen place in the Bay Area! when I heard there was a yamadaya opening up in japantown, I got very excited because in my opinion, there are average ramen shops up here compared to SoCal.  

having had the yamadaya at home, of course I have to compare the two locations. the portions here about the same size, but the quality isn't exactly the same. 

the broth is very flavorful and rich, but it isn't overpowering and you don't feel disgusting and weighed down after eating it. the noodles are cooked perfectly as well. the one difference I did notice is that the meat is more over cooked at this location. usually with ramen the pork melts and falls to pieces, but the pork belly we ordered on the side was definitely a bit overcooked, but luckily the flavors were still there & delicious. 

what I love about this branch of ramen shops is that they provide free fresh garlic to squeeze yourself into your bowl of noodles. I love garlic so it just adds more flavor to something else I love! also, they have free kaedama (refill on noodles) if you're a student with a valid student id. 

eating here made me feel less homesick for the Japanese foods at home because it was just so tasty and delicious.
author: Janey H.

description:
This used to be my favorite ramen place. Always had a good experience with service and the food (despite sometimes having to wait a while due to large crowd). Never really had any issue with the ramen but my husband would say that it was to oily for him and would upset his stomach, so I always came by myself.

However my last time being there I got severely sick afterwards and dealt with all the bad things that happen with food poisoning. Even had a doc do tests to make sure it wasn't anything serious an all came back good. Just extremely messed up stomach for a few days. 

Now looking and seeing how poor their health score is, starts to make sense. Very sad about that, I really did like this place a lot.
author: Alexandria K.

description: Originally in Los Angeles, Ramen Yamadaya comes to San Francisco! Situated in the heart of Japantown. This place is located on the 2nd floor. I ordered the Yamadaya Ramen with Tonkatsu Kotteri broth (black garlic oil). Yamadaya Ramen toppings include two kinds of meat, bamboo shoots, seasoned egg, and dried seaweed. I added corn to mine for an extra dollar. Don't forget to ask for fresh garlic... it's free and definitely adds flavor to your ramen. Overall, the broth was full of flavor and I finished it fast, a lil too fast. They close at 3pm and re-opens later for dinner. I still see them serve people coming in around 2:45pm. Very nice of them to still seat people but I guess we can all be a lil courteous and let them take a mini break before dinner time :)
author: Nancy N.

description:
Opening night today and there was already a long line. I waited 17 minutes for my table and 28 minutes for my ramen. Not too bad for the first night.

They only serve ramen right now; no appetizers yet. Their menu is not very descriptive as it doesn't tell me what is in each bowl. The server couldn't tell me either, so I ended up ordering an extra egg.

Onto the Ramen:
- Presentation: what presentation?
- Soup: it was pretty good. Not too salty. And it was hot and I like it hot!!
- Noodle: it was thin and some people may not like it. I am fine with it. Problem was it was slightly over cooked. Since they are still figuring out the logistic, I think they should cook the noodle 15 seconds less. By the time they put the bowl together and bring it to the table, then the noodle will be perfect. The soup was hot enough to continue to cook the noodle.
- Egg: There was half an egg in the bowl and it was between soft boiled and hard boiled. I think they should cook the egg 7.5  second less and it will be perfect. I think there was also half a quail egg there but I am not sure. 
- Cha Shui: One pretty thick piece of pork. Thicker than most other ramen shop.

I ordered an extra egg and pork belly. The pork belly was big. Tasted pretty good but I wish it was softer.

This place has potential but I think they should perfect their logistic before adding more tables. Better to let people wait outside the door than wait at the table. 

Here are some specific:
- Logistic: go learn from Santouka, Ramen Dojo or Orenchi. These places know how to handle a big crowd.
- Noodle: go learn from Ramen Taka on how make thin noodle sing.
- Presentation: go learn from Ramen Dojo on how make the bowl look good.

I will be back.
author: YueStudio Y.

description: Server took our order and then either left or went on break, and no one returned for another half hour only to drop our food and leave. No water refill, and we had to flag them down to come back to get the bill. Staff was incredibly RUDE and the food was mediocre. Will definitely not return. P.S. Heard of windex? Those windows were disgusting.
author: Sarah P.

description: Sorry only 1 star.  Noodle was not bad actually but terrible customer services.  Right after my friend and i got seated, this girl came to our table and said "Are you ready to order?"  I said to her that "we need a few minutes.". then she gave me a dirty look.  what do you expect??? Am i supposed to order on getting seated?!?!  We also asked for two teas but she never brought us teas.  She was busy chatting with her other waitpersons. Mind you, there were only a few customers except us.  Too bad their noodles were not bad!  I make it a rule to NOT go back to a restaurant that has terrible waitpersons.
author: Mike M.

description: This is the best ramen I've had in a long time. The noodles are nice and thin, and the broth is super salty (which I love). The service was great and fast. I definitely recommend this place.
author: Emily J.

description:
Its not easy to find good ramen in the Bay Area, especially San Francisco.  You feel this particularly when you've been to Japan a lot and realise how good it can be.

I had their Tokyo-style ramen and thought it was delicious; my dining partner had Tsukemen-style ramen and it was also great.  Two key points: the noodles were just the right texture, food was served hot and the egg was almost perfectly cooked with that nice, slightly runny yolk.

Service was friendly and attentive (but not too attentive).

Definitely will being going back here regularly and we should support good shops in Japan town since it seems to have been having a hard time in recent years.
author: James M.

description: Grand opening today, 12-21-13! They opened at 5:30pm and we arrived at 5:40pm, waited 40mins for a table, an advantage for us since we were the first of the 2nd wave and we got our ramen in less than 10mins! Waitress's were attentive, even apologized for the wait to the people in line. It looks like they are still waiting for new tables and chairs as the entire center of the room is emptied. They currently have the tables along the wall. For their first night they were only serving ramen. Their other items included donburi and salad combos. Let's talk about the ramen. We ordered the tonkotsu ramen and the tonkotsu kotteri ramen which is supposed to be more fattier and include black garlic oil. We really couldn't taste the difference with the black garlic oil. We both added the yamadaya topping for $2.50. A great choice if you are really hungry! Extra half an egg, seaweed, and pork, we almost couldn't finish our bowl! The broth was rich and lip smackin good! The noodles were thinner then most ramen shops and soft but next time I'll ask for noodles to be less cooked. Will return soon!
author: Vinkin Ken T.

description:
What else are you going to eat when you go to Japantown!?!?  So the wife and I decided to grab some ramen and came across this place.  This place had a line but looking across the way at another ramen place that had no line we thought "this place has gotta be good!"  

So service was terrible.  The couple who was three people behind us on the waiting list was actually served there food first and we pretty much ordered the same thing.  From the time we ordered to the time we actually got our food was 45 minutes.  The waitress kept coming by to tell us our food was coming out but it never did.  It was almost to the point where we were just going to walk out.  Service: F-!!!

When the food FINALLY came out it was so so.  Nothing to crave at this place since there's better ramen joints around.  Add the terrible service with so so food and this place is one I'll never come back to.
author: Scott T.

description:
I've seen this chain in SoCal but have never been. It's been recommended so I decided to check it out. Yamadaya specializes in tonkotsu ramen. Its birthplace is the island where I am from, Kyushu. Tonkotsu broth should be thick and somewhat creamy. Yamadaya does this well and it's not over salty like most places. The noodles are oddly thin like angel hair pasta.

Service is attentive, friendly and efficient. The manager was a bit loud in his "Irrashaimase" even for this Japanese. I felt like responding like Sheldon Cooper in the episode where he enters a sushi restaurant. "Stop shouting!"

I want to give this place 4 stars but the noodles need to be thicker.
author: John T.

description:
This place needs a lot of work.

Got here on a Sunday night and there was a line out the door. Not sure how they prioritize seating but they passed a booth that could have easily fit my group of 6 to a party of 2..... Waited about 40 minutes to get in and the restaurant has an interesting lay out. All tables and booths hug the walls so the middle of the place is completely empty and unused. You could easily fit more tables in the middle.

Service- Only one person really knew what they were doing. The others were running around like headless chickens. They need a better system.

Ramen- How long does it take to make a bowl of ramen? Waited at least 20 minutes. Broth was actually decent however it was drowned in hot chili sauce. Pork was pretty good however the noodles were on the chewy side.

The ramen itself could not save the mediocre service. If you want better service and better ramen, I suggest eating downstairs at Tanpopo.
author: David W.

description: health score!  come on Yamadaya.  This is one of the best ramen spots in SF, BUT not with that health score.
author: Mitch M.

description: Oh I loved our salad and I had yamadaya ramen in tonkatsu sauce. I wanted tsukemen but they ran out, but I was very very pleased with the flavors of my soup broth. The ramen was very different from my usual ramen but it was good. We tried soy sauce tonkatsu, spicy tonkatsu and vegetarian spinach ramen! It's very authentic!!!
author: Nancy F.

description:
Stopped by for lunch again, and the cool thing is, they offer thick noodles for an extra .50! Not that I cared, since I was fond of the thin noodles last time. This time around I got the kakuni bowl and ended up eating all of it. Whoops. I guess I was hungry.

As usual, the service was great. There's this one waiter who's always super nice, and he's awesome! When he asks how your meal went, he sounds so sincere, and I'm always so happy to eat there. I should've gotten a non-ramen meal like I said I would, but how am I going to go to a ramen place and NOT get ramen? It just doesn't make any sense.

This remains at four stars mainly for the excellent service. The food is awesome, but I'm still trying to find the perfect amount of kakuni-to-noodle ratio, plus the right amount of toppings to make it extra-awesome. Next time, I'll be sure to order non-ramen (or order a side dish with my ramen). Still doesn't change the fact that I'll definitely be back!
author: Robbin A.

description: I think I found the ramen place that tastes pretty similar to my favorite ramen place in Austin! The broth was just right! The broth was so rich in flavor! I recommend getting the fatty broth.
author: Monica N.

description:
Stumbled upon this place by accident while seeking another restaurant that has since closed. 

Food was delicious (chicken katsu curry) and service was good. 

A 'warning' message popped up on Yelp before writing this review, as it did when I looked up another nearby restaurant in Japantown. Not sure if it's a glitch or a legitimate complaint/warning. Lots of patrons were waiting to get in when I finished lunch and table turnover was quick.

*Update, as of 3/11/16, there is still a 'poor food safety score' that pops up for this restaurant -- is this accurate? My meal was good but I won't be back if this rating is accurate.
author: D L.

description:
I really enjoyed the spicy tonkotsu ramen, although the chashu (meat) was much too tough. In Japan, the chashu will practically melt in your mouth, and there are never any fatty portions.

The environment is very charming: second floor, nice view of Japantown, and relaxing atmosphere.
author: Kenneth H.

description:
Do yourself a favor, sit down and wait for a table to be seated here. The wait time, and there is a wait at almost all hours they're open, is worth it. 

I ordered the Yamadaya Ramen combo which is a lot of food. I had a pork based broth that is very rich along with karaage that was decent. What I like about this place is that the portions were just right. The ramen had a dark oil floating that made the broth very delicious to slurp on.
author: Johnas D.
