description: The tonkotsu soup is deeply flavored and paired well with thin ramen noodles. The gyoza is flavorful and delicious. Two points because they did not bring the gyoza until we were nearly done and when we inquired about it we got attitude. Spoiled our good impressions and probably won't be back.
author: Priscilla O.

description:
Went here with the family over the weekend. A ton of stairs to walk up, so you'll feel better about eating so much food....lol. Get your cardio on! We were seated right away. Everything looked so good!!! I ordered the ramen with everything in it- level
1 spicy. Sorry. I can't remember what it was called!! Came quick. IT WAS THE BEST RAMEN I HAVE EVER HAD! My boyfriend is not a fan of ramen, but he loved it as well! I would change two things: order thick noodles & move on up to level 2 spicy!!! It's far from home (kind of....), but I can't wait to come back!!!!!! YUMMM!!


Customer service was also great. Very accommodating. VERY NICE!!!
author: Tia Marie M.

description:
Both my wife and I had Tonkotsu spicy. I had level 3 and my wife had level 1, and I'd prefer level 1 in the future.
The broth was very good. 
My son had Yamadaya Ramen, and it was even better.
author: Josh C.

description: Vegan Ramen in Japantown? Hooray! Totally chill and unassuming place to get lunch across the street from the main Japantown mall. Vegan ramen broth has soy milk, bamboo and a few other veggies. Service was good, ramen noodles were cooked well and it's nice to have this place as an option.
author: M M.

description:
A few weeks ago, I met my other food photo colleague at Ramen Yamadaya. He gets to try lots of new restaurants and photographs food spreads often for the San Francisco Chronicle. He shared this find with me, because I am partially, a Japanese citizen, well.. not quite (!), but having lived there before, I am always in search of great and authentic Japanese food in San Francisco. 
I have to say, this place, is about as authentic as it gets; the Japanese wait staff, greets you at the door, with  いらっしゃいませ or irasshaimase, in a friendly way.  We were sat down in these wooden booths, that felt like something I had experienced in Tokyo; where Ramen is king. We ordered the basics, pork ramen with shoyu, or soy base.  It was delivered hot and steamy, and with the customary egg on top.  And the prices were quite reasonable.
I think my friend and I could honestly, say that this was a good grubbing place in San Francisco, and one that is much like one we might have if were in Tokyo together.
  Ja mata!

Paul Mansfield
Food aficionado & photographer
author: Paul M.

description: Decided to go back because my little guy loves the ramen!! I think it is a tad bit heavy but I enjoyed watching my kid slurp it down like it was the next best thing.
author: Charlene L.

description:
My favorite ramen place in San Francisco in terms of flavor, consistency, and atmosphere. The base price is reasonable too. I've been here a couple times now and the tonkatsu ramen has never disappointed. No problems with service, though it can be a bit slow when it's crowded. The gyoza is really good too.

I've been lucky to come here and always get a seat within 10-15 minutes; however, I would not wait longer than that for a table.
author: Zell C.

description:
Love this place! The ramen was super yummy!! Reminds me of when I was in Japan when I sat in the restaurant. It is very authentic!

mmm I miss that place and I don't usually eat ramen - carbs. 

LOVE LOVE LOVE! Definitely coming back here again!
author: Peach K.

description:
Ramen Yamadaya is a good addition to Japantown occupying the spot where Iroha once was.  It is on the second level above Shabusen and it is a little hard to find because they stilll have Iroha's signage up.

This restaurant uses thinner noodles than most ramen places but had good aldente texture and good balance to the taste.  I had the garlic tonkotsu ramen and the broth was almost creamy and not overwhelmingly garlic.  The portion size was a bit on the small size, so small that I had to go to Nijiya afterwards to get more food because I was still hungry.  I probably should have ordered the "extra noodles" option.  Also, my boiled egg was hidden deep into the soup and might have been overcooked a bit.  

A couple of things:  there is a bare area in the middle of the room.  It seems as if it could accomodate more tables.  Also, this restaurant is overwhelmingly vegetarian unfriendly.  All of the broths are pork based, no fish or vegetarian broths available.  They even removed agedashi tofu from their menu.  

If they can bump up their portion sizes a bit and provide some options for vegetarians, it could get five star.  I'm hopeful that this new place can work out these kinks soon.
author: Re-pley Z.

description:
Sadly, I tried the tsukemen last night and it looks like I'm going have to stick with Iza Ramen for my fix and current tsukemen champion in the bay area.  

The dipping sauce was definitely more brothy and salty than it needs to be, and it wasn't quite special enough to discern itself from the regular tonkotsu/kotteri ramen broth.  Now, if Yamadaya is able to mix the awesome thick noodles with the kotteri broth, I think it'll have a winner there, but until then, I'd recommend sticking to regular bowls of ramen here.
author: Jeff N.

description:
The service here was great. I speak Japanese and they speak Japanese so that might have helped... a lot maybe.

I was disappointed with their Tonkotsu ramen though, both Tonkotsu and Kotteri. 
I grew up eating Tonkotsu Ramen since I am from Fukuoka, and I may have high expectations when it comes to Tonkotsu Ramen but both their soup & noodle needed a lot of work I thought...
author: Wakaknee J.

description:
While most people are sticking to their New Year's resolution of a healthier lifestyle, you'll find me stuffing my face with their DELICIOUS tonkatsu broth and pork belly. 

I am happy to say Ramen Yamadaya has not disappointed, and in fact, I can confidently say it is my new favorite spot in the city. It was my second attempt coming here because the first time we left after realizing how little tables there were and how long the wait would be. For our second attempt, we arrived at 11:15am and as crazy as my boyfriend wanted to think I was, I was right. At 11:15am, no line. At 11:29am, there were 6 other parties behind us. Smart girl I am! 

We ordered the following based on a friend's recommendations:

$9.95 Kotteri Tonkatsu- angel hair thin noodles with black garlic oil, a slice of chashu, half an egg, bamboo shoots, and green onions. 
           As another yelper complained, I too felt like my toppings were stingy. I really only had one slice of bamboo shoot and I was left wondering, did it fall into my bowl by mistake? I also split my bowl with my bf and too bad for him I saved the bamboo shoot for myself!

$8.95 Dipping Ramen- served with traditional ramen, chashu green onions with a smokier tonkatsu broth. 

$3.50 Pork Belly- enough for two people, super tender and almost cuts like butter. 

Takoyaki is not served during lunch and we were bummed but a great reason to return.

There's also more tables now. They added 4 two person seatings in the "empty" space in the middle. The service was not the best but the servers were certainly sweet! They didn't quite seem to have their routine worked out yet. It may work to their benefit if they split up responsibility for a section of the restaurant rather than scrambling around and just helping customers as they walk around. I had no problem walking up to the sweet ladies and just asking for extra bowls and waving them down for the bill.
author: Connie C.

description: Ramen was pretty alright but it took forever to get it once we actually ordered. Had to wait quite a bit to be seated and unfortunately got seated at a table right by the door and it was cold and drafty. Broth was very rich and the noodles were thinner than other ramen places
author: Sally S.

description:
I came here because a friend of mine said that the ramen here was really good and tasted authentic.

We came on a Sunday night an hour before it closed and we were able to get seated quickly. There's a large open area in the middle with a large table that people could sit around it to eat.  We got a corner seat and got a good view outside and was also able to open the window to let some air in.

I got the Yamadaya ramen with level 2 spiciness. The amount of spiciness was just right for me. My friend got level 3 spiciness (which he had to pay a little extra for) and he couldn't finish it because it got too spicy near the end. He likes spicy food but it was just a little too spicy for him to finish it. The ramen was delicious! One of the best tasting ones I've had.

We also got a side of Pork Belly each. You can see the pictures from their Yelp and it is really big. We were putting it in our ramen and realized that we should have just split one. It's really tender and tasty. I recommend getting at least one between two people unless you're really hungry. 

Overall, this is a great tasting Ramen place at Japantown with great tasting pork Belly. I would come here again.

Pros:
-Spacious seating
-Large pork belly and tasty
-Tasty ramen
author: Paul U.

description: Best ramen bowl i've had since i have moved to SF two months ago. The vibe in here is pretty modern too, as in good music & cool rustic decor. IT's usually pretty packed but dont let the wait fool you, it goes by pretty quick & honestly the ramen makes up for any wait time. Also, really decent prices for such huge bowls.
author: Ashley B.

description: Great food and very reasonably priced. It was perfect weather sitting upstairs with open window seating. The Katsu sauce was the best I ever had.
author: Marya H.

description: Very good Ramen place compared to all Ramen places in San Francisco. I stop by everytime I came to SF. Have not disappoint so far. Prices have gone up abit, but everything is expensive nowadays​.
author: Johnny N.

description:
The broth was pretty good but the service was atrocious.

The Japanese lady in her 40s was super unprofessional and yelled at customers who were waiting in line.  Something about waiting behind the sign up sheets or whether everybody has signed up yet.  I've never seen this type of attitude in Japanese establishments.  Then during the entire service, wait staffs avoid eye contacts and ignore customers' additional requests.

Making the restaurant run at 50% efficiency and creating a faux line outside is one way to market.  But not doing your job when customers are in the restaurant isn't cool.

Portions are also pretty small (compared to other Ramen places in the bay area).  Broth is kinda nice.  But the chashu we got was mostly belly fat - where's the meat?
author: Koalie W.

description: For ramen I usually prefer thicker noodles and the ramen noodles they have here are thin, not to my liking. The soup is also okay, nothing special and kind of oily.. I got a stomach ache afterwards. This place has nothing on ramen places in San Mateo.
author: Michele M.

description:
Went to dinner w/ my favorite guy, his been talking about this place he just found. He ordered tonkatsu kotteri w/ black garlic oil. Was I in surprised,  it was so flavorful n portion was perfect. Someone like me who eats so little. He order tge be to chicken karrage. That was so fresh n good.
We both like ramen but this is the place to go. Cant compare what san mateo dojo,  Santa ramen places. So so good. There tea is perfect,  strong flavor.
We got there 7:15pm no wait n our server was very prompt, polite n knowledgeable.  
Make this place ours!!! We'll definitely go back!!!
author: ML A.

description:
=Pretty good service when I came with a group. Got the spoons, the bowls, the garlic all in a timely fashion. My only complaint is that something smelled like dirty mop. Wasn't sure if it was the server's hands... or if it was something on the floor.

=The food here was comparable to the Irvine and San Diego locations and perhaps slightly better. 

=Don't forget the extra portion for students. My ramen literally was packed with noodles. If you like the broth more then don't get the extra noodles because it'll just soak it all up. 

=The karage was decent here, not dry and hard like other places.
author: Scott K.

description: The seating was comfortable. My buddy and I were both tired and we were lucky to get quick service. I tried the yamadaya ramen (tonkotsu), and it was pretty good. Wasn't mind-blowing good, but yah. We ordered a glass of shochu to go with our food. I told my friend to try the agedashi tofu, and he said it was good (you only get two pieces though). The most important experience for me was when I asked for free garlic, and they gave me a few cloves, and this tool thing. It was some garlic crusher or something, so you dont have to mince it with a knife (MIND=BLOWN). That was the best part of my day. Also the workers were all friendly.
author: Benny L.

description: Ramen was cooked perfectly. Broth was flavorful. The pork slices were very tender and the egg was cooked just right. Would definitely come back
author: Garry H.

description:
Wanna preface that I liked the Tonkotsu Kotteri.  I'm pretty spoiled with all the great Ramen places we have here in San Diego, so I was pleased to find the style and preference in a Japantown restaurant still so tasty.  That being said, we had THE WORST SERVICE I've ever experienced in a long time.  And then just as I came here to review, yelp let me know this place has a terrible food safety score!  WTF!?

Sunday 2/21/2016 I went with six of my cousins to Ramen Yamadaya.  The wait was about 25 minutes with maybe 2 parties of two or three people ahead of us.  When called, we were walked down to a raised booth that barely fit six people.  We waited for 5 minutes for somebody to check on us, at which point I walked back to the front and asked for a host.  A server assured me he'd come check on us.  Five minutes later a guy in a blue shirt and blue pants, came down and dragged a stool over to our table and said, "There, seven."  This was a raised booth so the table would end up at the seated person's chin, while also being about a foot away (because of the step).  I suggested he move us to one of the unoccupied floor level booths, but he laughed and said he couldn't even fit 5 people in one of those tables.  Then he said we could move to the center table seating but it would be 30 minutes, even though there were enough spots for us all.  There were also two tops along on the wall that were unoccupied, but instead we made it convenient for this rude gentleman by splitting up our party.  The party that separated were served promptly by a young server.  They had their food before the rude guy in blue even got to our table to ask us our orders.  He didn't check up on us, didn't refill my empty pitcher/glass, and I found out later he bumped into one of my cousins on the way out of the bathroom while dragging trash out the front door.  He didn't apologize or acknowledge my cousin.  This was single-handedly THE WORST I've ever experienced in the service industry as a customer and a server.  Do yourself a favor and avoid this place!
author: Del A.

description:
The open space in the middle of the restaurant reminds me of a dance floor, and some part of me secretly wanted to dance when I had dined here. Fortunately that thought was washed away when the ramen arrived. The decor and visuals are yet to be worked on, but the food is the real selling point here.

Good ol' ramen. It will almost never disappoint. What makes one bowl of ramen better than the next is the quality, variety, and, to an extent, quantity of the broth and ingredients. There are several options for the broth, including a fattier, richer broth that's sure to please everyone. The ingredients and additional toppings were also great, and with the Yamadaya Topping, which contains the various toppings already found in the ramen + more, you'll surely be happy with your meal.

However, despite the great service and delicious ramen, I was not fully satisfied after the meal. Though $10 for a meal REALLY isn't that much for SF standards, I couldn't help comparing Yamadaya's quantity and portions to other ramen establishments. It was a good amount of noodles, but I was definitely hoping for more toppings in the main dish. 

What I LOVED though, was the FREE GARLIC as a topping. Yay for garlic lovers!
author: Jason T.

description: The service today was one of the most disappointing experience I have had at a restaurant.  I am a pretty patient person so a couple mess up like forgetting water doesn't bother me much.   First of all they did forget our water which took 3 times of asking them within a good time spand in between each time we asked.  Secondly, they completely forgot one of my cousins order.  The main reason why I am writing a bad review is because another cousin of mine ordered the yamadaya tonkotsu kotteri with no mushroom.  Upon receiving his ramen they accidentally made his with no bamboo (or menma) instead.  After receiving the bowl, we kindly asked the server that he had gotten the wrong order and was suppose to have his without mushroom instead.  However to my surprise, the older lady who was our server argued back that our order was correct and she said after checking the order "he ordered the ramen with no mushroom which is no menma".  After trying to talk to the server, it seem she was too insistent that the order was correct and that there were no mushrooms in the bowl when we could clearly see the wood ear mushrooms in his bowl.  After awhile my cousin just did not want to deal with it anymore and decided to eat his bowl after taking out all the mushrooms.  I have never had a server who would argue back that their order was correct when we could clearly see that it was not.
author: Tyler N.

description: Had the Yamadaya Ramen.  It was way too salty.  Ramen Underground across the street is still the best.
author: TopCat W.

description:
For all the hype, this place was disappointing for a pretty stupid reason if you ask me.

I was lucky enough to avoid the 2 hour wait line I saw the night before since I came around 1:30pm right before they closed. I was excited to see they had the Black Garlic Oil flavored broth for the ramen and huge slabs of pork belly according to yelp so I ordered both.


At least that is what ideally would have happened if they didn't run out of pork belly, but that didn't stop my thirst for the broth. Service was pretty quick and the food came out pretty quickly, but what i saw before me was pretty pathetic. Of all noodles you use, you use those thin flimsy angel hair noodles? THAT IS LIKE A CARDINAL SIN FOR RAMEN! I was really hoping for the thicker noodles used at most ramen places...bu i guess what can you do. That pretty much ruined the ramen for me right there but the show must go on. Also, they are really cheap on their toppings. Although they gave me a lot of corn since i added it, the cha shu and green onions were pretty lacking in number and the cha shu was that tender piece that didn't add much to the ramen.

The only saving grace for this place was that the 20 hour cooked broth was amazing, one of the best broths i've had. It was super salty and delicious, just as anyone looking for good broth would want. 

Also, I've heard their pork belly is quite generous but I am not sure if it is worth it to go back just for the pork belly...

If they change the noodles, give a few more toppings, and rethink about the cha shu preparation, this place would probably become a 4.5 - 5 star place. Until then, they are disappointing in my book.
author: Dylan T.

description:
Opens at 5:30p for dinner but we came early to ensure we got seated in the first wave. Currently has 8 tables that seat 4-6 people per table. 

I ordered the Tonkatsu Ramen #1 with the Yamadaya side (1/2 egg, bamboo shoots, pork, pork belly, black mushrooms, green onions and nori). It was a LOT of food. Everything was delicious. Be sure to add crushed garlic to complete the meal. 

The chicken karage appetizer was just okay. A little too breaded for my preference. 

Will definitely come back again.
author: CL S.

description: I like the second floor location and the slick decor. I ordered the black garlic tonkatsu ramen, and it was overall pretty good. The broth isn't the best (could be thicker and tastier), and the black garlic really doesn't add much to the base, so I would just order the original. The portion is big, and the pork and egg are good. The bamboo has a little bit of a strong and strange canned kind of taste. And as always, I wish the noodles were the thick kind. They did not have the thick ones on offer when I was there for lunch.
author: Jennifer H.

description: This place rocks. Right in the middle of Japantown. Perfect food every time and great service. Hanging with Coconut Milk (Peachy).
author: Harrison K.

description:
My first comment is that I love the people who work here!
I have eaten at Ramen Yamadaya twice now; my first time was about 3 days after their opening, and the second was a week or two after that. Both times, I was struck by the incredibly gracious and friendly staff. Everyone from the host to the kitchen crew was extremely friendly and expressive of gratitude to their patrons. 

Onto the food: I'm totally sold on the Yamadaya 20-hour broth. It's amazing! Between the two groups I visited with, we covered pretty much everything on the menu, and none of us were disappointed. The potstickers were decent, though nothing special, but I really didn't need them anyway, since the ramen portions are generous. My favorite item on the menu was the Tonkatsu Ramen- it is simple, delicious and simply delicious. The broth is rich and the noodles are tender and flavorful. 

The only reason I couldn't give them five stars (or can't yet) is because they don't have their liquor license yet, so you can't opt for the perfect sake or beer to wash it all down with. Add that to the menu, and I'd be good to go! All in all, I'm very excited to have this tasty and affordable new addition in the neighborhood!
author: Ilse C.

description:
Came here around 8pm so there was no wait to be seated.  Service was a bit slow for the food orders though so -1 star. 

We ordered tonkotsu kotteri and tsukumen.  Also ordered the pork belly and takoyaki.  

The takoyaki was average.  The pork belly was delicious and generous serving.

I really liked the tonkotsu kotteri.  The broth was flavorful but not overly salty.  The tuskumen has different noodles than the kontotsu ramen.  They were thicker and chewy.  Really enjoyed the noodles.  But the dipping sauce was way too salty and not thick enough.  It felt more like a bowl of soysauce.  It was also cold by the time i was one third of the way through the noodles since the noodles were served cold.  After that point, I find it hard to continue using the sauce.
author: Jeannie C.

description:
The place is newly opened - and you could tell. Service is a bit hit / miss, but they were friendly.  Here's are the misses..

Saw a queue when I arrived, so put my name down on the list. 10mins or so past and a serving person comes out and asked another girl (closest to the door but only just put her name down) how many people she had. She replied 1 and went in immediately. 

Ermmm... I was a table of 1 too ?!? And last I checked there was 2 other tables of 1 on the list after me too.

When I asked how their 'system' worked. Ie. you either use the list (paper provided by them) or you don't .. Can't have it both ways. The server didn't really know how to answer - read: lack of English skills.

In the end I got seated only to find out there was no pork belly (1:30pm) and that they also don't serve hot green tea.  Must be the first Japanese restaurant I've been to that doesn't serve hot tea. 

I ordered the tonkotsu ramen (black garlic) with the yamada toppings. It also took 30mins for my table of 1 to get food :((

So the food..

Tonkotsu soup base: thick, milky white and porky as it should be without being overly salty. 

Ramen noodles: thin. Reminds me of the dried noodles you can get from Asian grocery stores. I prefer the thicker curly ones.

Toppings: In the bowl there was 1 piece of chasu pork, bamboo shoots and 1/2 egg. Toppings are of decent size. Egg tasted a bit like any hard boiled egg. :(

Additional toppings: yamada was $2.50 which came with 2 slices of pork, seaweed, shallots, bamboo shoots and black fungus mushrooms (sliced) with a tiny piece of pork belly. (Yay!!)

The stewed pork belly is pretty amazing :))

There was an offer of free garlic on the menu.. But I think you do have to specifically order it.

Will be back for the pork belly :)
author: Alice C.

description:
Went with my dad to try out another restaurant in Japantown after a bit of shopping as usual, and was surprised to find out that it took over another restaurant I used to like. Oh well. Just beat the crowd so the wait wasn't too bad. I assume they only seat all present parties cause there WERE some people waiting outside, but we were seated first. Thought it was really weird that I saw the waitress move another party of 2 to a table that could comfortably seat 4, so my dad and I could sit at that table for two that the other people were just sitting at.. even though both parties were the same size.. which really irritated me.

Anyway, the food was really good despite the fact that they mixed up our orders. I ended up with the Yamadaya ramen with kotteri broth which I thought was pretty good. I liked that there were two different types of meat, and the eggs were flavored. Also, I don't know if it was a mistake or intentional, but I got two halves! :)

The only thing that REALLY bothered me was their tables. Whenever my cold, wet glass was put down on the table, or the waitress dripped water, or any type of liquid hit the table it would leave rings or spots that would remain for a couple minutes and were disgusting to look at. Also, watching them spread wet puddles of water all over the tables with their rags was disgusting to watch as well.

Service is kind of slow but the food is pretty good so all in all I'd go back again.
author: Jennifer J.

description: Chicken katsu was basic, loved the side salad and potato salad that came with it. The server was very nice and accommodating. There computer systems where down so he came to the table to let us know he had to write the receipt out.
author: jennifer p.

description:
A friend from out of town came and wanted to go to Japan town. I've lived in Bay Area for a couple of decades and have NEVER even been to Japan town. 
Anyway~!!! We were hungry and I've been searching for a Ramen place for a few years now. (Had REAL Ramen in Japan about 6 years ago and have been searching since I came back to the US.) 
The other place at East Pacific Mall was pretty decent. The new place in Alameda, on Park street was alright. But this.... This Ramen house brought me back to Japan. It was just as the way it tasted when I had it in japan. The waitress was pretty nice. She was all smiles and good service. 
The only thing is that, there isn't a lot of air moment in the room so it does get slightly stuffy. BUT we were there on a pretty warm day in SF so... perhaps in the winter, it's just THE place to be?
author: SmOoOoteensie L.

description:
The ramen broth is good. Flavorful without being overwhelming.
The noodles here are thiner than usual but quite delicious. They have that hand tossed starchy taste to them that I enjoy with noodles.

The meat is meh, it looks good on the pictures (pork belly) but it was kinda dry.

Still a good ramen place though.
author: Rohan D.

description:
Nothing really special about this place. Another full of MSG, chunks of meat and too oily. Very thin noodles. 
Service was bad. Brought the salad and gyo za after i finished eating the ramen. 
Table next to us got their appetizers right away, but they didnt have any copsticks or napkins.
author: Maya B.

description:
Delicious tonkotsu ramen in Japantown, but still working through the new restaurant kinks.

We were lucky to beat the dinner crowd to get the last table for two on a Sunday evening. We each ordered a ramen (~$9), and I got the gyoza (4) and salad add on for $3.75, which bordered on just too much food for me. 

Their specialty is the 20-hr cooked tonkotsu soup -- the "kotteri" is the uber rich, flavorful garlicky version. It comes with one cha-shu (pork), egg and menma, so I didn't add on, though all three were just fantastic. Thin noodles were perfect, and I finished the broth to the last drop (yes my BP must be through the roof...)

Gyoza was quite good. Crispy and flavorful, garlicky. The salad is a thin cabbage and tomato, yum, very Japanese :)

The service is still working through kinks I think. The servers, when you get their attention, are very friendly and attentive. Easy to flag down but not the expected cadence of usual service for meal and check. There is a funny waiting area outside, and I agree that they could probably add tables in the space once they get their engine running. They seem to have run out of their tonkotsu soup by 7PM this evening and were turning away customers.

Food was amazing though, and I look forward to coming back so I can give a proper 5-star review!
author: Aki N.

description: Ramen is so good. It tastes so traditional.  I think this store would be busy even in Tokyo.
author: 洛祥

description: Really nice ramen place came here because we were hungry and it had good reviews  I thought the ramen was good and it was a good amount of spicy and my boyfriend likes his too
author: Jessica N.

description: On the plus side, they offer an alternative to those of us who can't eat pork. I had the Vegan ramen option, and of course, this is not my first choice, but I understand that if you don't eat pork, you don't go to a ramen place. Just about all ramen broths are derivative of tonkotsu (pork bone), so I am glad that there is an alternative at all. I got the tomato noodles and I got menma and shiitake mushrooms in my soy based broth. I ate all the noodles and drank all the broth. My complaint would be that I couldn't get a size-up on my vegan noodles even though I showed my student ID. That deal only applies to everything else. Also, we simply had to wait too long for our ramen to come out. We came in as a party of 12, and we split up into two tables of 6 each. That should be easy enough to serve, right? Wrong. The other table got their orders before us, and had finished eating when we finally got our orders. And we got our orders in a weird order, as in person A got his chicken dish, and then person B got his curry dish 10 minutes later, and then the other four us got our ramen 10 minutes after that. Since we all came in at the same time, it's wrong that some of us should get served sooner than others. OK, 12 might be impossible, but getting 6 shouldn't be that hard.
author: John J.

description: One of the better tonkotsu ramen spots in SF.  Cheap, easy and good.  Noodles are solid, broth is dope.  Fresh garlic doesn't seem like an obvious add, but I highly recommend it.  Service can be hit or miss depending on the crowd - it's to your advantage not to be shy.
author: Arthur Y.

description: A relatively okay place for ramen, nothing fancy. Reasonably priced, the service was quick. The ramen was thin noodles, though I prefer thick noodles when it comes to ramen. The noodles were cooked perfectly, and the broth was very tasty. They give free soda with order for lunch, a pretty good deal!
author: Marbles L.

description: I finally have some time to sit down and write my review on this place. Came in hoping for some delicious ramen on 4/12 around 4PM after much convincing by my cousin who goes to school in the area. Here's the kicker - they ran out of broth. Yup. Ramen place smack in the middle of Japantown, and they ran out of broth. I understand that it was probably unusually busy because of the Cherry Blossom Festival - but I really would think they would of planned ahead. Not only that - but they refused to seat us for the longest time (almost half an hour?) because they, didn't have broth ready. When we finally got seated - the server approached us asking if we would like to order some appetizers - we kindly declined and asked if we could just order our ramen - and they informed us that no, they do not take orders until the broth was done. Um... okay? Do restaurants normally not take orders until the food was cooked? A little frustrated, we said we would just wait until the broth was done. About 15 minutes later - the same server came by again, and asked if we would like some appetizers to start out. Again - we asked if the broth was ready so we could order, but once again - we were rejected. I'm not exaggerating right now - the SAME server came by 10 minutes after that, and you guessed it! SHE ASKED IF WE WANTED TO ORDER APPETIZERS. Lady - if we said  no TWICE already, WHY would you come and ask AGAIN? Of course we declined - and this time - she kindly informed us we could finally order our food. HALLELUJAH. *Note that I did give them two stars because the tonkatsu ramen really was good - although the portion was pretty small.*  Friendly reminder to the owner - please do try and work on your customer service skills and how you handle situations.
author: Lynn A.

description: The soup base is good, but they could improve on the noodles.  The noodles aren't the typical chewy ramen and very thin like spaghetti noodles.  The add-on portions are decent, but not extraordinary.  I would come back if I was in the neighborhood, but not if there is a line.
author: Food C.

description: Any of the ramen options are good ! They have 3 levels of spice (level 1 is good for me) and a variety of toppings that you can add. Yamadaya probably has the best seasoned eggs. The pork belly is a little too fatty for my taste but still really tasty! It's definitely worth the wait!
author: Katherine H.

description:
My cousin and I ventured into japan town to look for some ramen, We stumbled upon this place, Ramen Yamadaya on a Sunday afternoon. Its a small little place upstairs with 10-12 table with an open center (which i really think they can put another 3 more tables easily). Anyway the two of us waited about 20-25 mins. Once seated service was pretty fast. I ordered the spicy ramen with an extra side of pork belly. 

Pork Belly- Decent amount, but it was a bit cold and did not have the melt in your mouth experience. I was sad.

Spicy Ramen- it was flavorful, ramen seemed a bit soft, and broth a bit watery. 

Anyway, it was satisfying for us hungover folk, but if i were to visit japantown again, i'd try somewhere else.
author: Vincent W.

description: Ramen is good but with everyone focused on noodles and soup in Japantown, we decided to venture with Tonkatsu, Curry and Appetizers as well. Sadly, those items are at par with most other establishments here... We are eating what would returned in Japan, or even Korea and China. Cabbage is cut too thick, it's still wet from wash. Oil wasn't changed and temperature unmonitored so Tonkatsu was brown, dried out and the juicy flavor and texture that defines a chef and restaurant was lost. If you decide to go Japantown to get a taste of Japan.. You may even do better or equal in a deli. Ramen is good enough for the price and if you need to fill a time slot. Don't venture too far.
author: Paul K.

description:
we're sitting here waiting for our food. Without warning hardcore trance starts blaring out of the speaker.... Please make it stop :(

I was really excited when I heard they were opening a Ramen Yamadaya in SF but I was very disappointed.

came here within a month after opening...
The staff were all nice and friendly but you can tell they were still very green.
The food...not a fan. We all got the pork belly and I abandoned it after a bite. It was extremely dry...like sand paper...
author: Jess L.

description:
I FREAKING LOVE THIS PLACE! 

Came here on a weekday for dinner with my boyfriend and there was no wait. We both got the Tonkotsu Kotteri. The noodles were thin and very angel hair pasta like (like everyone says on here), but still good. The broth was delicious as well. The have an option to get a side of garlic with the garlic crusher (which i was really excited about) but it doesn't really work, or maybe I just don't know how to use it. 

After that dinner, I couldn't stop thinking about it and literally went again 3 days later for lunch with my boyfriend (thank you for keeping up with my ramen craze haha). It was on a Sunday and there was no wait again! Yay! This time I ordered the Tsukemen. I was a little hesitant because the description says its fish flavor. But man was it delicious!! I couldn't really even taste the fish flavor in it. It was however, very salty. But still sooooo good! Also, the noodles for the Tsukemen aren't thin and angel hair like their other ramens. 

I think this may be my favorite ramen place in San Francisco. 

p.s. get the fatty pork belly!!!
author: Lina C.

description:
Long wait, bad service, cold chashu

1st review. Annoyed enough to go though the trouble

There are 2 other ramen places 100ft away and a dozen within 2 blocks. Why bother going upstairs to wait in a long line for subpar food? 

Their broth and noodles were good. I sent back the meat. Every other ramen place I've been too, including the tiny one in the San Diego mitsuwa grocery store, was better. 

I'm not a snob. Their meat just plain sucked. Chashu is supposed to be freshly cooked with the ramen and be juicy and hot. What they gave me was cold dry meat on a plate that was probably in the fridge for hours. Same with the egg. They said that's the way they serve their ramen toppings, which blew my mind. If you're vegetarian, then you probably don't care. 

Service. 
- Long wait. Fine it's Friday night and Zagat rated. 
- Watered down tea and no offer of refill
- no one asked how food was, which is the bare bones check box for service.  
- The must have written me off after I sent back meat. Even then I left 15%

Could have gone next door to get great ramen 10 minutes faster. Next time.
author: Kevin K.

description: Freaking fantastic. I don't know ramen but I know what I like. I will be returning for sure!!!
author: Jeremy S.

description: So this is a sorta chain n I'm about to try it and behold my honest review.  I love ramen and ate plenty in Japan .  The bowl for a large is still small compare to the popular ones in San Jose .  They just give you extra noodles for a large.  $.50 extra for thick noodles, which I prefer.  The broth although look creamy but not as thick as one might think... In regards to a rich pork flavor.  It was more of a slight pork flavor mix with chicken broth.  I'm not fond of the mix.  When I order tonkotsu I want pork flavor !!  The broth so bland, I had to ask for soy sauce n added like 4 tbsp of it n still bland.  What freak happen to seasoning. Pork was hard n dry.  I also decided in the combo which for an x tra 5.00 came with ur choice of small Donburi n salad . I'm opt for the chasu bowl which gosh darn it, the meat was dry n hard.  Dang it this just so bad.  Small portion, bland broth, hard meat...can it get any worse!!!!  Overhype for its name but sad taste ....so dang sad, I wanna cry cuz I can put up with anything buy bland food and dry meat. No no recommend.
author: Tee K.

description:
Definitely one of the better ramen places in San Francisco. Their menu is pretty much just ramen with no suhi, no terriyaki, no bento....etc. 

I read it on some other reviews too that this place has a dirty rag/mob smell and the tables are kinda sticky. I hope they look into their cleaning routine soon.
author: Maggie C.

description: I had their tonkotsu kotteri, spicy ramen, and deep fried octopus balls. They were all very delicious in a very comforting way. The broth was very rich and thick. The boiled eggs were cooked perfectly. The waitresses were very helpful and friendly.
author: H K.

description: Delicious ramen! Friendly staff - helped explain the different options. They also have kid-friendly stuff like gyoza(potstickers) and edamame.
author: Pickles P.

description: Good ramen noodles. Cheese ramen was amazing. My friend ordered the chicken karaage which was also amazing. I unfortunately have to say the service was nonexistent. They forgot my order, my two friends got their meals a good fifteen minutes before I did. Because they're so busy and popular, they tend to hurry people out too which was also kinda rude :/. Good food tho.
author: Yalda B.

description:
First off, I came here because it was pretty cold and rainy.  I wanted to try a different Ramen place since the one I usually go to is great, but having a variety of different places doesn't hurt.  When walking up the steps to the second floor, there are signs saying "cooked for 24 hours".  Those are the main words that I see and I think to myself "this sounds really really good.  If they take this long to make their brother, then it must be legit". 

After being seated, my family orders ramen, tar-tar chicken, gyoza and a spicy tuna over rice.  The first thing that came out was the tar tar chicken.  It looked delicious because it looked exactly like the popcorn chicken you would get at a milk tea place.  However, it didn't taste anything like it.  The chicken was bland and the only sauce for the chicken was a little bit of mayo on the side to "dip" you chicken into. 

My girlfriend had the gyoza and she didn't like it.  

Next was the Spicy Tuna over rice.  I didn't see any pictures and I wasn't sure what to expect, but boy was I surprised.  When the dish came out, it was rice, and on top was ground spicy tuna.  If I'm having raw fish, I tend to like it whole or at least in chunks.  This was more like baby food and grossed me out. I tried not to think of it, but the texture was very mushy.  

Last but not least, the ramen.  I ordered the kakuni ramen that came with a large piece of cha siu.  The broth was excellent living up to my expectations and the cha siu was delicious as well.  However, the noodles were pretty skinny, similar to angel hair pasta.  I was not expecting to get that thin of a noodle.  There was half an egg in the soup too, but you can't go wrong with a hard boiled egg.

Overall, I would suggest coming here if you like thin noodles or if you want something to warm you up.  Also if you are a poor college student, this is a great ramen place to go too because they said "if you are a student, we will give you extra noodles free of charge"
author: Jeremy H.

description: Ok San Francisco, you impressed me with your ramen. As someone who is spoiled with great ramen joints in Vancouver, my standards were high going in. The noodle was thin as others have mentioned, but I didn't see anything wrong with that. They were cooked al dente, and the pork broth was flavourful. Check, check. If you have a hankering for ramen and are in the area, this place will hit the spot.
author: Colene C.

description:
we order the classic tonkotsu and gyoza. Hot green tea wasn't ready at 1130am.

The service was good.  The food was on the very salty side, we had to chug down a few cups of water afterwards to wash out the sodium.
author: Stacey F.

description: Great place too good portion they give! This place before was Iroha but change ownership! Ramen Yamadaya have several locations in California! Looking to try it in LA sometime!
author: RICHARD W.

description: not many veggie side/app options, but very nice to have a clear Vegan Ramen option so you don't have to ask about the soup base being veggie or not.  they also have a veggie chili paste, too.  while it's veg-friendly, i thought it could've been more flavorful compared to the veg ramen options at Ramen Underground.  might be the only veg ramen option in japantown, though!
author: Karen O.

description: Had lunch here on Sunday during the cherry blossom festival. The wait went quickly for our party of two. We liked how open the dining area was and were almost disappointed we didn't get a seat at the communal table (which we normally dread) since it had a cute little garden thing going on in the center. I ordered the tonkotsu spicy (level 2) and my husband ordered the kakuni ramen. We both loved what we ordered and argued which was better (Mine, obviously). They both had tons of meat. And the thin noodles were perfect. I loved how spicy my broth was and was surprised by the kick of the level 2 (wtf do hell and death taste like?!?) My husband commented that he liked the flavor of his broth and it had an almost creamy taste to it.  I just wished there was a bit more broth in general. I think this ramen will be one that I will crave in a couple weeks and I can't wait to come back.  But a warning for the ladies: The restrooms are gross. I knocked a star for that.
author: Nicole C.

description:
I love this ramen joint.  It is in the main square of Japantown and the menu is simple and delicious.  We order the Yamadaya topping which includes a slice of chashu, half an egg, bamboo shoots and other fixins.  I love ramen and wish we had a place like this Boulder.  Heads up, seating is limited (they have added additional seating since opening) so if you go during peak hours expect to wait in line anywhere from 10-30 mins.  

House made noodles were delicious and the meat was always done just right.  We have never had a tough piece of meat and we've eaten here 5 times.  They recently added new menu items and we tried the fried chicken bites and they were GOOD!  You can even add them to your ramen order and make a 'combo'.  Looking forward to eating here the next time we are in SF!
author: Carmel U.

description: This place single-handedly improved the lackluster ramen scene In SF by quite a bit. The broth is deep and rich, pork is tender and noodles are decent (I always ask for thicker noodles). Currently my go to place for ramen, but that could change with up and coming joints soon to open.
author: Edward L.

description:
It's maybe 3 1/2 stars. Came 2 other times and it was closed, so anticipation and expectation was high and hopeful. It was pretty good but we've been hunting for the perfect ramen restaurant, so have tried many and it just didn't hit the 4 star mark. The broth was good, liked the thin noodles for a change but prefer the thicker noodles which can be more al dente, chashu was a slice of pork belly, so it was fat, so it was tender, good. Chicken kaarage was not quite there, not marinaded long enough or not enough ginger and garlic, not crunchy, kind of flat. The pleasant surprise for my big sons were the free portion upgrade with student ID. May try again if the other ramen place up the block is too crowded. 
Service was ok but had to signal several times for drink, water, bill...
author: jane f.

description:
It's my 4th or 5th time coming to Yamadaya Ramen, and it's probably my last visit. REALLY BAD SERVICE and MISLEADING PRICING!!!!!! *******Highly NOT RECOMMEND*******

My friends and I (a group of 10people) came here on Sunday for lunch, and since its a crowded place, we were okay to split into two tables (table of 6 and table of 4), but by the time our second group got their table, which was about 5mins after the 1st group, the tables next to them were all opened that was ok to fit all of us together, so we asked if we can join back in 1 group, and we were given a "no" for it... Well no biggie

Then we were given 2 menus - 1 look like a regular menu, and one had a title of "NEW MENU (starting at 7/2x/2014)", both of them have the same item - their FAMOUS Cheese Ramen, but with different prices, and sadly we didn't notice it till we got the bill. When my friends order the Kotteri ramen, the waitress was serving us in a pretty "unprofessional" temper, I mean, pretty bad one.  She stopped one of us who was going to order for the group as she was "asking" the "1st person" of the table.  Then, my friends were suggested to get the "Yamadaya Ramen" with Kotteri flavor without being advised the add-on price. 

So when we got the bill, we were "surprised" to see the price was more than we thought, so we tried waving our hands to ask one of the waitresses on the pricing issue. The 1st one told us that she wasn't the one taking the order and advised us to look for that particular person (again, in a "not so polite" way). And when we were able to stop the waitress who took the order, she just said "it's 12 something" then left us, and after several round of passing by our table, she never stopped by again.

We were somewhat pissed off by that service, but we also understood that it was a pretty busy restaurant, we decided to go out to the cashier to talk about it, and that's where the craziest thing began.

So the waitress finally noticed she can't ignore us and came into us trying to explain the bill. 1st she said the price included tax... WHAT? The tax was charged under the tax column and we still being charged tax again on the ramen column? Then she walked into someone who "might" be the store manager at the time, and that "manager" told us that it's "common sense" that if there is a "~" next to the price, it means "price starting at". Hmm never heard about that, and even if it's true, usually there'd be a note or whatever inside the menu stating that, then she blamed us not asking about the "~" meaning... WOW! My very 1st experience of being told by that! Are we really expected to know the "~" sign meaning without any note? Don't even think that's lawful.

Then we were told that the "regular look-like" menu was the new menu and we should follow the price on it.... Lol then why did you even give us the menu with a title "NEW Menu (starting ...) while the other one doesn't even have a date on it! She then said its "common sense" again and asked us if we ever heard of a restaurant having their pricing decrease instead of increase... Yeah I do, should I introduce those restaurants to you? And is that a solid point that it's your customer's responsibility to understand this "confusing" price increase?

At last, after having some tough conversation with the waitress and the "manager", they agreed to take out the price increase of the cheese ramen ($12.95 to $11.95) but not the other Yamadaya ramen which was all $0.50 up of its original price stated on the menu. After all, the price wasn't really the issue as it's just like 3 bucks different on the bill, but the service, the experience.... Nah, I'm not coming again, and we won't go there again, and even though your ramen tasted good, we will surely help Yamadaya to spread the word of this "common sense" experience to our friends and neighbors too! No need to thank us! :)
author: Henry M.

description:
This is only the second ramen place I've tried in Japantown (the other being Waraku), and the third place in SF (the first being Ken Ken), but so far its my favorite of the two I tried.  I ordered the spicy tonkotsu and my boyfriend had the spicy yamadaya   The ramen broth is very flavorful and rich.  I am not a big fan of the pork in any ramen but here it was less fatty than I normally have which was pleasing. In comparison, I wish there 
were a whole egg like Ken Ken, and a bit more broth.  But the richness of the broth made up for any minor lack in toppings.

We also had the gyoza and kara-age chicken (basically fried chicken).  The gyoza was very good, nothing extra special but very tasty.  the chicken on the other hand was fantastic!  It was juicy and so flavorful!  I'll definitely be ordering that again.

The interior is simple but nice.  I like that they have a community type table which is great for those dining alone.  And the service was quick, helpful and friendly.

I'd still like to try more ramen places in the area but this will become a regular spot I'm sure.
author: Angela R.

description:
The food was good - not great, but good. 

We had to ask for things more than once which can be annoying. They were out of the first two things that I ordered. The server suggested the chicken tonkatsu, and I told him that I didn't want something fried. So, he suggested a pork curry plate, which I ordered. When it came, it was pork tonkatsu, so of course, it was fried. 

Food - 3/5
Service 2/5
author: Karen C.

description: Went to eat here last Friday on 06/03/16 with my co worker. I been here a few times but this time I noticed the menu was different from before and there were new waiters. Our waiter told us he was new and of course he didn't come to our table to check on us except to take our order and when we asked for the check which took longer then 10mins to get. The busboy was some older Asian guy who was to pushy trying to clean while we were still eating. When we looked around there were still open tables so they weren't that busy yet so I didn't get why he was trying to hurry up and get us out. The worst part of it all later that night I started to feel sick and I knew it was because of this place because I didn't eat anything else at the time. It's now been 3 days and I'm still suffering from what's most likely some sort of food poisoning. I did like this place but won't be going here again worst experience eating here.
author: Radwell C.

description: The food is fantastic!!! The portion is pretty big. And you can also get even a bigger portion if you are a student and show them your student ID. The restaurant is fairly new and the decoration is on point! The service is great, there is this one guy who work there and he is super nice and would smile all the time. However, I wasn't able to get his name but you can figure it out when you get there.
author: Tuyen T.

description:
I've been here twice now and it's decent. The service improved after our first visit but I think they need a restaurant manager if they haven't found one yet. 
Broth is rich, noodles are different and thin for my liking. I like their combo add-ons. All in all I'd keep going back but not my fave in the 'hood.
author: Meredith K.

description: The service could be a little better on certain days, but overall the taste is good, the price is good, and I'm a big fan. I go here pretty often when I'm low on money!
author: Kathleen Elisabeth S.

description: I wrote a review already and forgot to give this joint 5 stars for the tonkatsu shoyu ramen
author: Michael C.

description: I've given this place two chances now: bad food, even worse service. One of the waitresses in particular was extremely rude to my boyfriend. Won't be back.
author: Emily A.

description:
it was my first time eating japanese food in j-town, ever ever, and yea i live here. typically eat japanese and (the best) ramen down in the peninsula but you know, when you don't feel like driving 25 minutes away from the city, you've got to suck it up, and drive around j-town for 20 minutes looking for parking. went for lunch on a beautiful sunday with friends. everyone was out - all the locals AND the tourists. gawd just terrifying.

anyway, we had no plans. no idea what we wanted to eat and especially didn't know what would be good. saw the first sign for ramen and decided to eat here. i had read the yelp reviews beforehand and thought we'd give a try. 

there were about 7 people ahead of us but we somehow managed to get a table within 15 minutes. our orders were taken immediately then we sat there and waited...FOR 45 MINUTES. this killed it for me, killed it for all of us. it was terrible. as for the food and flavor. i must say that it was quite good. a bit on the salty side, but i like salt. if you don't like sodium, please stay away. i ordered spicy tonkatsu - spicy level 1 - and it was a bit too spicy for me! add a little of their japanese white pepper and my bowl was on fire. the ramen noodles itself wasn't all that great. i like the noodles used at other restaurants much better. this one was very thin, almost like a hong kong style egg noodle. 

a regular bowl was $9.75 with two pieces of pork, 1 HARD boiled egg, and nothing else. not even seaweed! i guess in the end, i thought it was a decent meal because the broth was good. perhaps one day they'll start using better noodles.
author: Thao T.

description:
Ramen Yamadaya advertises them cook their broth for 20 hours, which is what they're proud of. They're located on the 2nd floor of the building which is above the shabu shabu restaurant. 

== Food ==

Tonkotsu ramen broth tasted pretty good.  The ramen noodles had a nice texture. The boiled egg was more cooked that I'm used to. Not a lot of meat given. I would advise you order extra meat or noodles to make it filling.

Fresh garlic that you crush yourself is really nice.

== Service ==

Service and food were really quick.

== Overall ==

So so ramen. The broth was above average and the noodles were good. Nothing else was amazing to me.
author: Steven B.

description: The food is fairly good. Outside there are pictures of the menu, inside the pics were smaller and more confusing. (Very small print) If I knew ramen, it would've probably easier to order. The restaurant was very warm. Almost uncomfortable. Our waitress was very nice.
author: Sam K.

description:
I guess they just opened up because they don't look "finished." As previous yelp reviews stated, there is a large dance floor type space in the middle. Very few tables - and the chairs are super uncomfortable. 

The ramen is pretty good. The nooddles in the standard ramen is a bit thinner then I am used to, but the soup base is very tasty. The soup in the tsukemon was actually COLD - and if I am not mistaken, I believe it is supposed to be piping hot. 

I will try again in a while to see how much they improve and will edit my review accordingly.
author: Daniel K.

description: The ramen soup is very good and better than most ramen spots in SF.  I gave it a four instead of a five as I ordered the Kukini on the side and it was on the tough side...
author: John L.

description:
The ramen with the rich broth and the black garlic oil is pretty good, and I got the Yamadaya toppings: a generous portion of extra toppings, as others have mentioned. The gyoza is great too: crispy on the bottom, decent on the inside. What left me cold? The lack of condiments on the table (shichimi, specifically), no beer (beer goes great with ramen, trust me), and the interior decor. They forgot my garlic, but no big deal since the broth was garlic-flavored.

Not contributing to the rating was this girl who cut in front of me on the waiting list, apparently thinking I wouldn't notice. Seriously woman, how do you (and your dining companion) live with yourself? I didn't make a fuss since I thought there were a lot of tables available...which I ended up being wrong about. Whatever.
author: Maximillian M.

description: Fantastic. Best ramen we have had in the city. Terrific pork bun too.  Would totally come back. Excellent.
author: michael d.

description:
It gets hard to differentiate yourself from the quickly growing horde of Ramen shops in the area. 

Although not the greatest in terms of service or taste, Yamada will serve up a mean bowl of noodles that will satisfy you when your favorite places start to get old.

Look to the chashu, braised pork shoulder and noodle quality when you are here. They are quite impressive.
author: Charles P.

description:
Really Really BAD service- long waiting time to order, also my friends being badly treated while ordering for each other, the waitress said, "im not asking u but the 1st person"...what?!

Misleading menu- inconsistent pricing on TWo menus, list pricing without clearly stated for extra charges...

BAD service attitude- Blaming customers w/ kind of insulting without admitting to their responsibility, YELLING to customers, impolite waitress and "manager"...

***HIGHLY NOT RECOMMENDED***
author: Otaru H.

description:
Completely average.

Tried their Tonkatsu Kotteri and Karage with salad. Both were good, though on the small side. I have had better and have had worse. If you happen to be in Japantown and there is no line then go ahead and try it. Otherwise it is not worth a special trip or waiting in line for.
author: Easwud C.

description:
Great Raman. Flavors are great, I love the garlic. 
The place is kinda small so at peak times you might need to wait, but it's well worth the wait!!!!
author: Dan R.

description:
I've been craving ramen for the whole week and sadly, Yamadaya just didn't satisfy that craving.

At $12.50 per bowl, their Yamadaya Kotteri Tonkotsu ramen comes in a small, deep bowl. The broth is very opaque and drizzled with Black Garlic Mayu. The broth itself is very salty, yet flat in flavor. The Mayu added nothing to the soup as there was neither much garlic nor sesame aromas from the oil. Minus one star. I was expecting to be able to upgrade the thin noodles to the thicker ones as other Yelpers mentioned but unfortunately, that upgrade is no longer on their menu (they had it crossed out). I'm not a fan of the thinner ramen noodles. Minus another star. The worst part was definitely the meat. The kakuni pork belly was not tender at all and flavors were mediocre. Chashu was even more disappointing. It was tough, hard, and dry. Minus another star. The only redeeming factor was the egg which was a good soft boil and seasoned well. Menma was also decent but they literally only gave me three measly shoots.
author: Maggi K.

description:
When I lived in San Diego, Yamadaya was my go-to ramen place for both tonkotsu and tsukemen. It was soooooo good. Although I've moved to San Francisco, I still have the same yearnings for that Yamadaya taste. So today, for Monday's lunch, I dropped by this SF branch for some tsukemen. The menu looked pretty much exactly the same as the one in San Diego. They even had the same free extra noodle/rice with student id note at the bottom. That was a good sign :) but I came here for tsukemen, and the extra noodles were for ramen (I guess I could've asked for the rice, but I wasn't really thinking at the time.. my mind was too transfixed on eating tsukemen). 

When my two bowls finally arrived, I could tell this was not quite the same as SD's tsukemen... First of all there was only one piece of chashu, secondly there was a bit of chalkiness on the bottom part of the egg yolk where the egg white is at it's thinnest, and thirdly there was no lime/lemon slice... I guess I probably could have asked for  a lime/lemon slice, but whatever.. that minor detail doesn't really have much impact on my rating system. So!!!! I dunked my first plop of noodles into the tsukemen broth.... *mMmMm* the flavor is quite reminiscent of that thick, salty, almost slimy broth I so dearly missed, but something was off! There were no pork bits in the broth! In SD, there was always these little hidden pork gems throughout the soup, but today, sadly they were nowhere to be found. All I had was my single slice of chashu.. Very well, so be it. I dunked the chashu into the hot broth for a couple seconds, and took a bite. Oh... the center of it is still cold... Okay... I'll just leave it in the broth for a while longer... *bite* hmm it's still kind of cold at the center. Into the broth again while I eat another plopping of noodles. *mmm* Back to that chashu *bite* Still not quite the warmth I wanted, but whatever! After teasing myself for so long, I had to eat this chashu right now.... but alas! this chashu wasn't quite right for other reasons. It was hard and bland! SO DISAPPOINTED!!! :( A couple more mouthfuls of chewy, thick noodles :) and nicely flavored bamboo shoots, and I'm onto the egg. I dunk the egg into the broth really quickly just enough to get a bit of saltiness on it, and pop that thing in my mouth. It's not bad, but my suspicions were correct... The chalkiness on one side of the egg indicates that it has been marinated for a little bit took long, causing it to have too strong of a sake flavor. Ehh okay. I finish the rest of my 7 oz of noodles and I'm glad to have tasted the flavors of SD's Yamadaya again, but I'm also slightly disappointed. My search for really good tsukemen and ramen in San Francisco continues...
author: Andrew S.

description: Get the tsukamen! Best takoyaki I have had on any coast. It was perfectly crispy on the outside and the inside was steaming hot. They put the mayo on the side so that the balls don't get drenched.
author: Wes L.

description: I wish I could give zero star to this terrible restaurant. Worst service ever. We were waiting out outside for more than 40 minutes with another 15ish customers while the restaurant was half empty. No one bothered going out and calling anyone in. All they did were just standing there chatting. Please save your precious life not going to this restaurant unless you really have nothing to do and you are not hungry.
author: Zhen X.

description: We came strictly for the tsukemen ramen and were disappointed. Broth was really lacking the tsukemen love and care and left a lot to be desired. Still searching for the perfect bowl of tsukemen in SF. Waraku Ramen down the block comes a bit closer. Super nice staff though and fast service.
author: Gina R.

description: The broth is somewhat fatty but pretty good overall. Got the yamadaya ramen which already includes egg and roasted seaweed with 2 different types of pork. The fattier pork was very good but the thinner slices were a bit rougher than I expected. Thin noodles were just chewy enough. Be sure to get the fresh garlic on the side - comes with a garlic press, a fun touch. I think this has 4 star potential but will need to have again. Wait staff seems a bit overwhelmed and still working out things.
author: Gonzalo S.

description:
Food wise, this isn't a bad place to eat. I really like the broth and while the noodles are thin, they're pretty tasty. They have a good range of toppings and they seem to always be busiest during lunch time.

I'd really like to go there more often but the reason I'm giving them one star is that they totally forgot my order. Maybe it was because they had a lunch rush, but I should have known better than to wait when every party that came before me got their orders first. 

When the  waitress eventually came to check on me she was very apologetic and asked if I had five more minutes but I didn't, my hour lunch time (I haven't had any problems with time at any other sit down ramen places) was up and I had to go back to the office.

Sorry Yamadaya, I really wanted to like you, guess I'll have to find another place for my lunchtime ramen cravings.
author: Allison L.

description:
Ramen was ok. the egg was not as good as expected.
Do not order Takoyaki. The one the I ordered was meh.
Kara Age was meh too.
author: Echo Z.

description:
Ah so the quest for the perfect ramen bowl continues on and leads me to the "motherland"... Japan Town! We popped by this place after my cousin suggested it following a heavy night of drinking and bouncing around the city. This restaurant is not located in the main parts of the mall area but it is in the plaza with the cobble stones across from the main mall.  Its location seems to benefit it, as it's not ridiculously packed with a line of people leading out into the street like so many other restaurants in the area. We seemed to come right in the middle of a rush so there was a few parties ahead of us. Waiting patiently for our party to be called, it was probably about a 25-30 minute wait for our party of 4. Suddenly, the hostess calls another party of 4 before us, even though this group of chattery girls had CLEARLY arrived after us! I nearly snapped the hostess' head off because I was HAAAAAANGRY at this point. Not funny, hostess!!! She amended her mistake, and seated us :D 

So right off the bat, the service did not impress me. But I was willing to side step that little factor and just try and focus on the food. I ordered the tonkotsu kotteri ramen with the black garlic oil in the slow cooked creamy pork broth. My cousin went on to describe how they give you complimentary fresh garlic which you can crush at the table to add more garlicy goodness to your bowl, as you please. I. Could. Hardly. WAIT! Mouth watering, the food arrived within a reasonable time. We kept asking little things of the server and she honestly did not seem to like us and the fact that we kept requesting little things from her. A bowl of rice, more tea, more water, more garlic, etc. As a previous server myself, I can understand why this could be irritating but hey.. it's the job at the end of the day and she repeatedly kept asking us "is there anything ELSE...?" in a not-so-pleased-to-be-serving-you fashion. Like I said, I realize it is irritating but you are in a customer service role so please try and act like you enjoy your job..? 

ANYWAYS. The ramen was fantastic! The broth was incredibly rich and creamy, and the black garlic oil blended in so nicely. I added some fresh crushed garlic cloves to my broth and it literally brought the flavors out EVEN MORE so I highly recommend doing so! The pork itself was not out of this world, and I've had more tender, juicier slices in other ramen places. The boiled egg was sufficient but again not anything crazy good. I would say what stood out to me the most were the fundamentals of ramen: the broth and the NOODLES. Not everyone likes the thinner style ramen noodles but I love them. They remind me of soba, but a guilty more sodium loaded version of soba. Great bite to them and added texture! I slurped up every last inch of noodle I could get! 

If it weren't for the shaky service experience I would have given this place 5 stars. But it was just the little things that got to me that made the meal a little off. I would certainly come back to try more variations of their tonkotsu broth ramen and to try some of the other items as well.
author: Mariko M.

description: I just had the worst ramen I've ever had. I got my dinner delivered at home, and the order came completely fine and looked delicious. The only good part about the ramen was the pork belly that came with it. The broth tasted horrible, and was excessively salty. The chashu bowl, which had pork, was extremely dry. So not worth the price. AND I found a long hair in my rice.
author: Charlotte D.

description:
Their veggie ramen is amazing -- when they have it.  They don't have the best track record.

It sounds weird to have a soymilk-based ramen, but it works surprisingly well!  If you bring your student ID, they give you a free bowl of rice (and you can ask for furikake.  Yum.)
author: Vincent Y.

description:
last weekend was my second time i tired.
i ordered yamadaya special with tonkotsu. i thought they changed some broth.
First time was better taste as my friends agreed.
however they started to carry Aji fried. that was soooo good. meat was thick and tasty.
i hope they start to carry fried rice too.
author: Urara L.

description: Their Vegan ramen is truly a treat with rich broth and spinach noodles. They offer fresh cloves of garlic on the side for free that they will bring to your table with your own garlic press. There is often a line but totally worth every minute standing in it!
author: Stephanie M.

description: This is a pretty mediocre ramen place in Japantown. The noodles and the toppings were fine. I mean those are the basics for ramen and you can't really go wrong with them. Although the pork was a little too fat and I didn't like it, but that's just my personal preference. The problem was the broth. This is what makes ramen so special. I wouldn't call myself a ramen expert, but i know that the broth was saltier than it needed to be. With that said, there are other good Japanese restaurants around the place with the same prices, or even cheaper. After all, you are in a Japantown. So don't be lazy and explore the place for more delicious Japanese food. Before I go, my last advice to those who still wants to try this restaurant out is eat inside the place. Don't try to order delivery or take out!!!!! They package the ramen in weird way and trust me, you will not enjoy it. Even though the line looks intimidating, but the wait is really not that bad.
author: Weixin T.

description:
The ramen broth was rich, pork belly was tender and full of flavor, and the dark curry rice, sprinkled with minced meat, was delicious. 

A couple grand opening related wrinkles, I'm sure will be ironed out soon:

1. Arrived at 7pm on a Thursday. I could see 2-3 tables open, but they insisted that we put our name down on the list. Not expecting a wait, I play along and put my name down as requested. Almost immediately, a server came over to check the list and ask if we (the only 2 people standing in the hallway, and the only 2 on the list) were the party I just wrote my name down for....

2. The menu in the hallway we read while waiting was colorful and full of detailed descriptions. When we were seated, we were presented with black and white menus that had no descriptions at all....
author: Calvin W.

description:
Huge let down considering the SoCal locations are really good.  :'(

Needs work but i'm rooting for you - Yamadaya!
author: Monica C.

description: I tried this in LA and there was nothing different in particular. I love the tsukemen! My friend told me it's just to separate the soup with ramen but i just like it!
author: Chang L.

description:
I was extremely happy to see a vegan choice of ramen appear on the menu for my vegetarian friend. But when we tried to order it, they said they weren't sure when that option would be ready yet. 

Please don't put something that is not on the menu on the damn menu!
author: Jennifer H.

description:
Came here with a group of four on new year's day. Short wait, not many people were here. They just recently opened and you can tell, they're still working out a few kinks. They were out of their number one and three ramen. I ordered the spicy level two ramen. 

Ramen was decent, it had one slice of pork and half an egg. It lacked veggies, it had two pieces of bamboo shoots and a kernel of corn, which almost made me think it was in there by accident. Broth is thick. 

Service is slow, short of staff. Which attributes more to a newly opened place. They did not seem prepared for the crowd.

I wouldn't go out of my way to come back here.
author: Thuy P.

description: Who doesn't love a nice bowl of Ramyun soup?. If you love a pork base soup this is the place to go. I took my kids here the other day again and they absolutely loved it.  Their side dishes are okay nothing special. Although i did noticed they do turn around their table fast which causes the table and utensils are not as clean as I expected.
author: Ichi Y.

description: I'm sorry but 1 stars is all this place is getting, the food is great but the service is possibly the worse I have had. Fire your servers and get new ones.(Especially one of the girl servers)
author: Rajee S.

description:
4 Star Ramen! Finally, the City is on the brink of Ramen boiling into the streets of Japantown. Lord only knows why it took so long for the epicenter of Japanese culture in SF to have decent Ramen. The Tonkotsu broth is rich and thick, add some fatty garlic oil in there and you have yourself a legit bowl of Ramen! I typically ask for thicker noodles in my Ramen, as you'll have two options. Also, don't hesitate to try the Tsukemen for dipping noodles, although the dipping broth could be hotter, and definitely give a crack at the cheese ramen (yes, I frequent this spot way too much). 
The only thing I wish this place had, was better service. They just can't seem to deliver a bowl of noodles to the entire table at once. This is particularly a problem of execution when a bowl of Ramen needs to be enjoyed piping hot and not room temp while waiting for your friends to get their bowls on. I will stop there, before I lower a star.
author: Brian C.

description: Used to go here and then stopped when they had such bad health food scores. They raised those up to acceptable levels so we thought we'd give it a try and found the noodles had changed and now were incredibly doughy, as in they tasted basically uncooked. Like straight out of the bag play-doh. Never had noodles like that. My wife, who is Japanese, couldn't eat hers, and when we mentioned this to the waitress they took 20% off the bill, which was nice I guess. But we won't be going back. Especially when a bowl of ramen is 14 bucks.
author: shimon t.

description:
First time eating here! My previous two attempts were folly, climbing the stairs only to find a 10 person line? No thank you. Sunday is the best because...no lines!~ Welp I shouldn't say that because I took my damn sweet time and when I left there were 3 parties waiting for a table. Price was appropriate, $11.39 for a Tonkotsu Kotteri with extra egg. I like that they give it to you on a dish..gave me a place to put my hashi so it didn't have to sit on my bowl or the table. I don't like that it came several minutes before my ramen...I was staring at it like...what the hell am I supposed to do with this?

I agree with the other yelpers on the main points of this place, lots of unused room, service feels pretty unorganized but everyone is trying. Takes a pretty long time for ramen. (waited about 15 mins). There are a few hanging lights that hang reallly low so that anyone err 5'5(?) and up will whack their head on them. I passed the time staring at these lights and thinking whoever came up with that is an idiot.

3/4 of the servers also spoke Japanese which was really good. Kitchen spoke Japanese too. Not sure if they had beer, I failed to ask but I won't the next time.

So the Kotteri right? Flavor was spot on. Izakaya Sozai is still better. Going by the taste of the broth the spicy is probably their crown jewel. However, this placed has usurped Waraku on my list for Tonkotsu. I'll still go to Tanpopo for their shio but Yamadaya captured my vote for tonkotsu. 

Oh and those hosomein....sooooo goood I love/hate that they didn't cut the noodles too! Noodles go perfectly with the heavy broth and show everyone whats up! Their Charsiu sucks though....I think they'd be better off getting some from the store..stuff has the texture of frozen meat.

I hope they put in a ramen bar in the middle.
author: Garrett N.

description:
It was just a meh for me... I really miss Iroha..But anyways. 

1. I really didn't like the table decor. It was so empty in the middle of the resturant when they could have put so much more tables there.

2. Not much variety on the menu. But like everyone said, I guess they're still fixing it up and stuff. They also didn't have any side dishes available at the time...

3. If I remember, I got the second one. The ramen itself tasted like lai mien or something. They were really thin and didn't taste like normal ramen noodles :( I guess it's just my opinion but it was alright. Not my type of ramen. 

Overall, I probably wouldn't make a special trip down here again unless I'm with friends who want to try it out. But then again I would recommend other ramen places in Japantown or in SF.
author: Samantha Y.

description: Omg, the worst ramen ever and bad service. If you want a cold soup with lots of fat and saltiness, go for it.! The waitresses expected a tip when their rice had hair in it.
author: Gen V.
