description: I had their Tonkatsu Shoyu Ramen. It was good. I wouldn't say their servers were as attentive to their customers. They had us move to another table in the corner when they had a large party arrive and forgot about us until it was time to pay.
author: Erika Y.

description: UPDATE! I've discovered they do thick noodles (unfortunately no large portion for them though. Boo!). Still a big fan!
author: Richard K.

description: I admit that I'm relatively new to the world of real (not college style dry packaged) ramen, but of all the ramen places I've tried, this was hands down the best I've ever tasted. I got the shoyu and it changed my life. The broth is full of flavor. The noodles are so fresh and perfect. The pork was cut so thick and was oh so tender. My mouth is watering just thinking about it. Would definitely come back again!
author: Amy S.

description: what's wrong with their services and english? why are they hiring those non fluent english speakers as a server and mess up my food..and let me pay extra tip???
author: Momo G.

description:
Service. okay.

Taste. Had the Yamadaya ramen and Tonkotsu spicy. Not the greatest I've had, but better than many other places in the city.

Selection. Meh. Went there at 7pm. No wait in line but they were already out of hot tea, kakuni and paigu.
author: Jerry S.

description: The food was decent and the staff were nice, but service is so slow! We had to ask for our water refills after the cups were already empty, and the check never came even once the table was cleared and we finished our drinks, so we had to ask for that too. But even then, they forgot so we had to ask again about 15 minutes later once the waitress made another pass by us. Overall, I probably wouldn't come back again.
author: Samantha S.

description: Ok, out of all the ramen places that are actually in the city, I have to say that this is definitely up there. They're not exactly on the same level as Santa or Dojo, but they're pretty darn good! The noodles are slightly al dente, just how I like them, and the broth is delicious. I had the yamadaya ramen when I went and I'm looking forward to trying the other ones. Do yourself a favor and give this place a shot!
author: Ty L.

description: Just went there yesterday (7/23/15) with 4 of my friends and while it wasn't our first time eating ramen it was our first time eating at Yamadaya. Both servers were very nice,  and one even was kind enough to explain the whole menu to us after hearing it was our first time there (which was really nice considering we got there right before they closed). We got 4 bowls of tonkotsu ramen bowls, one spicy ramen bowl with pork belly, agedashi tofu, and croquettes. Everything was really good! I'm used to really spicy food so the spicy ramen bowl wasn't too spicy for me (I actually got extra chili paste Lol). The eggs were perfectly soft boiled too! the age dashi tofu was really good! And the croquettes we're good too but maybe needed some seasoning, but they were warm and crispy. Really great experience overall.
author: Samantha R.

description: Best Ramen we had at Japan town! Great costumer service too! The noodles are great and tasty , like freshly made. And you can appreciate how well they prepared the pork belly. Soup base is not artificial , its the real deal. The side curry is also great!
author: Ivan V.

description: Honestly it was mediocre. The pork (supposedly braised for 12 hours or so) was tough, broth was thick and creamy, it wasn't the best ramen. I ordered yamadaya ramen with level 1 spicy broth. It wasn't spicy at all which I was fine with, but the pork was just so meh. I've had better ramen in Chicago. This wasn't a good ramen, I expected better since it was in Japan town, it was a disappointment.
author: Claire C.

description: Can be a little hit or miss, but this place reminds me of the ramen I had in Japan.  I get the kotteri ramen with thick noodles and the yamadaya topping.  Pretty delicious.  When you catch them on a good day, it's hard to beat.
author: Brian Y.

description:
5/5

*PARKING - Space is adequate for its fanbase.

*PRICE - Right price, double the value! :)

*STAFF - Majority of the staff are Japanese, and are doing the "irashaimase" greeting. Feels like you teleported to Japan! Authentic Japanese hospitality and customer service! 

*FOOD - TOP RAMEN is in the house!
author: DirKandCy G.

description: Tasty ramen, nice staff, great organic sake and cool environment. The ramen broth is a bit sodium rich but other than that, pretty comforting on a cold foggy night.
author: Jennifer B.

description: Delicious ramen for me. Actually I do not like eat noodle before.
author: Xinyue Z.

description: I came to this place with my one of my close friends and GF looking to try Tsukemen for the first time and although the food wasn't such a let down the experience was. Our server talked up the ramen shop even calling it "the #1 ramen shop in San Francisco" which is a pretty bold statement in itself. He gave us a run down of the menu since it was our first time there and even let us know which dishes were the popular ones and trying to sell us on them. It worked on my friend and GF, but I was there on a mission to try Tsukemen. So our food comes but we're missing one of our appetizers (chicken karage) which the server fails to tell us that they're out of until we've already finished our meals. The food itself was not of the "#1" caliber the server spoke of or anywhere near it. The broth for my Tsukemen was very salty. The chashu was very dry and rubbery, and overall the my Tsukemen experience failed to live up to its hype. I'll probably give Tsukemen and other shot but definitely not at this place. To end off our experience here, the service was slow and it took a good 20-30 mins for us to pay for our food and leave. Although the server was a good ramen salesman, I don't recommend this place.
author: Gerald P.

description: The tonkotsu ramen here is so delicious and this is the only place closest to the fukuoka style tonkatsu ramen in Japan.  I've been here multiple times and the go-to's are:  tonkotsu kotteri (with black garlic oil), their fatty tuna over rice (so delicious), and their takoyakis (squid balls with bonita flakes and takoyaki sauce).  Every time I went, the line was pretty long with people sitting upstairs. The wait helps build up the appetite and their ramen and takoyaki are worth the wait.  The service is ok, but isn't an excuse to knock off a star.
author: Sammantha T.

description: Been here twice - ordered Tonkotsu Shoyu both times.  The best Ramen broth I have ever had.  Service was efficient.  Only downside is the long line.
author: MT Y.

description: DO NOT COME HERE. Customer service was freaking rude. She mispronounced my family last name and even said freaking "whatever" right after she said it wrong. The fuck??!!!
author: Duy M.

description: The first time I came here I would have given it 4.5 stars; the bowl of ramen is solid, no doubt, and I love that they have the japanese potato salad, and also tayaki (super overpriced but whatever). In my subsequent visit unfortunately the TV fame has gotten to them the quality has gone down... not to mention everytime I've been here after that first time I get this server who is clearly not Japanese but speaks such poor English she screws up the order.... every single time. If you work at a Japanese restaurant you should be able to speak Japanese, or English (we're in America), and knowledge of the food is kind of required. But not here. And not to mention - the wait is always insanely long. Why go here when you can go downstairs to Shalala, pay the same $ and eat better quality food, and have more interesting selectons, and maybe even more of an intimate experience. I will say they have great pork belly. But everything else can be done better elsewhere.
author: Y K.

description: Awful service and mediocre food. Considering this place is pretty expensive, there are many hole in the wall ramen places that are much more delicious. I came with a party of 8 but our party was split into two tables because they could not accommodate our entire party. For some reason the table with majority of men, received more attention and quicker service. Once I ordered the food, it made me feel nauseous and so I asked our waiter for another dish. I had barely touched the first dish and explained to the manager that I simply could not eat it and should not have to pay. He then continued to argue and said it was my fault for ordering it and so I should pay. He finally agreed to void the first dish but exclaimed that this argument was "killing him." It was unprofessional and rude behavior. Would not recommend this place whatsoever.
author: Sim S.

description:
Went for lunch and it was extremely disappointing.

First if all, the waitress( non Japanese Asian) was really rude.
And quite frankly she looked dirty. She just couldn't communicate in a regular way. For example, she just brought me the menu without saying anything. Never smiled either. If its other places, at least they say "hi"

And another waiter (male non Japanese Asian) wasn't nicer than her either. They just can't seem to say hi or anything.
He just brought me a food without saying anything.
And they were too busy gossiping about their low low life which no one wants to hear,  to care about other customers.

And again, she came back to take my credit card without saying anything at all, no eye contact , nothing.

And more upsetting is that either of them is cute or attractive at all. They can't just afford to act like that if they look that ugly.

Seriously I'm so disappointed that since I know their original LA location , is much better but now its influenced by typical SF rude ppl. 

Btw food was very bad as well. Suggy soft noodles made by Mexicans who don't even know what real ramen is.

And also I found a hair in my ramen. Possibly ugly Asian guy's dyed hair. Disgusting. Never again.
author: Kimo Y.

description:
Weird decor and weird use of space.   Table pushed to the walls and corners.  Empty middle space for nothing.  Waiting space is not comfortable.  Patrons got to wait in the hallways and staircases. 
Very mediocre menu and food is just OK. Service was good and friendly.
Also, no booze.  I think they just opened and no liquor license. 
We will not return.
author: Alex R.

description:
When i'm craving Ramen this is the place to go to!

I have had the Tonkotsu Ramen, regular and the "Kotteri" (rich broth) and the Karaage chicken.  I'm a person that loves rich broth.  The thicker the better! Being my first time that i went i got the Kotteri.  It was fantastic! Extremely rich in flavor! they add a black garlic oil to this one as well.  The only thing though is that it was actually "too rich" for me...I ended up getting a little sick from all the flavor and richness of the broth because i eat and drink the entire thing.  With that being said if you are going for the extra rich don't drink all the soup.  I have an iron stomach and even i couldn't take it hahaha!

The regular Tonkotsu ramen on the other hand was perfect.  just enough richness and oilyness that makes Tonkotsu Ramen in the first place delicious! The Charsiu is great overall! but if you get the thick cut pork belly......HAVE MERCY it's amazing and don't let anyone tell you otherwise! the noodles are cooked perfectly! Because it is a Tonkotsu style ramen they use thinner noodles.  So don't be butt hurt and complain about thin noodles.  It's supposed to be like that.  and just for the record obviously the slower you eat the colder everything gets, and the soggier the noodles get.  don't blame the restaurant for that.  Ramen is supposed to be eaten fast and as soon as you get it.  It's disrespectful to the cook otherwise.  So don't wait until everyone gets their ramen JUST DIG IN!!

The Karaage chicken is by far THE BEST that i ever had in the bay area thus far.  seriously, no one does it right and i will argue with you over and over about this.  the Karaage is the closest to Japan and Hawai'i as far as flavor and texture goes.  The salad they give you has a bomb sesame dressing as well.  

Now, as some people have mentioned about the cold egg, meat and blah blah blah.  I had a great first experience but, the more i went the more i realized that they are not as consistent as i want them to be.  the last time i went which was 5 days ago the egg was a bit cold.  but if you understand how onsen egg is made you will know it takes some time.  if they made it super fresh for you all the time you would complain about waiting too long for the food!  I'm sure when they just opened up they were not expecting such a huge amount of people consistently coming in and putting pressure on the cooks and staff.  I am sure they will step their game up to make all our fellow yelpers complaints into positive ones! =)
author: Lance Y.

description: i come here all the time with my best friends and enjoy having their nice and quick meals of ramen. i love their broths and can't help but finish an entire bowl with desert afterwards al by myself. love this place!
author: Marinela V.

description: I love this ramen place. Good food, buzzling atmosphere, reasonably priced. This is my go to place when i'm craving ramen! Keep up the good work.
author: Jeff A.

description:
No wait time, staff was perfect, atmosphere was decent (slightly too warm but tolerable). The food arrived quickly and was excellent. Not the best but still a solid 4/5 or 4.5/5. Prices were also reasonable and I'd recommend the combination option when it comes to the ramen.

The staff was definitely the high point. Very friendly and efficient, they were some of the best I've seen at restaurant work.

If I'm in the area I'd be willing to visit again. Definitely a good place.
author: Gordon L.

description: Food is good, but service is slllloooww. We are there for 45 minutes before or appetizer was served. To add insult, the large table next to us arrived after us but received their food 10 minutes earlier.
author: Adam A.

description: More like 1.5 stars. Ugh, this is the worst ramen place in J-town. I just don't understand the popularity, as every ramen place within a stones throw from here is superior. Both times I've been, the ramen was low quality. Meat is very grisly and tough. In fact my piece today was so tough it was like a rock and I would've broken my tooth if I tried to bite into it. Broth is greasy and oddly reeks of dirty water or old meat, and "black garlic" in the kotteri is basically just eating burnt black little specs of grit. Service is equally lacking, and management was apologetic but didn't do anything to regain my confidence in the place or earn my business back. DON'T waste your time and take a hop, skip, and jump to the dozens of ramen and noodle spots nearby!
author: Jenn M.

description: Amazing place, amazing ramen! Rich but not too rich, spicy but not to spicy, on Fri night got sited within 20 min!
author: Natalia M.

description: We were excited to try this place on our way out of town but we're very disappointed. Terrible service. The waiter never checked back in us. He totally forgot one of the bowls of ramen. He gave the vegan bowl to one in our party and never brought the other bowl. The place was not that busy so the terrible service is not ok.
author: Becky B.

description: Great ramen.  Everyone in my party loved it.  Lots of great choices on the menu.  Students can get extra noodles by showing their student IDs.  The manager here working at that time (a gal whose name I will keep anonymous) provided outstanding service.  Many speak fluent Japanese so felt right at home.  Because this place is popular, there is a little bit of a wait but it was well worth it for me.  Would definitely come back again!
author: Brandon L.

description: The most HORRIBLE STUCK UP manager ever!!! We waited for 45 minutes in front of the store. He 'allegedly' called our name and waited for 3 seconds. When we came up and check, he was not apologetic that we couldn't hear his voice at all. A racist who makes fun of people with unusual names. Other waitresses were too afraid to call him out on anything. The TANPOPO ramen store downstairs was much better in service!
author: Lientra L.

description: Great food but the service is absolutely terrible! Every time I've gone it takes forever for the waitress to even greet us after being seated, they have forgotten multiple items on the order and take forever to bring anything out after being asked. Most recently, I tried calling 5-6 times to put my order in and got no answer. When I showed up in person they told me the to-go order would take a half hour (which is fine) but when I mentioned I called the pointed to all the tables and laughed and said "well we are busy". As a business, don't have a business line if you aren't going to answer it. Poor poor service. I left and went to Tanpopo downstairs.
author: Tracy C.

description: The ramen here is good i had the Kotteri with curry bowl and side salad and gyoza.  The Kotteri soup base was pretty good very goood taste, the curry and gyoza was good too. The noodles were excellent, but char su was too tough i felt that it should've been more tender.  It's a very good eat but just average compared to ones that i eat at in Oahu
author: Kory K.

description:
My friends and I had come here during the ramen festival, so we were expecting it to be busy. The wait was only an hour (compared to more than that at other places). 

We were told we could not have our checks separated as I was paying for one of my friends, which I was ok with. The food itself was rather subpar. The broth was ok and the chicken karaage was probably the best part of the meal. The ramen, for a ramen shop, was pretty terrible; the noodles were not cooked all the way through, so there was a doughy/starchy texture to them.

The service was extremely terrible, and I had expected it to not be amazing due to the crowd. When we had asked for the check, our server returned and said it seems we had paid for ours. I had told her we had not paid yet and that it wasn't given to us by anyone else. A second server came to us and asked us the same thing. We thought "the next time they tell us we paid, we would just say ok and leave", we were joking of course. It took us twenty minutes to get the bill and we couldn't put it on two cards, so I said I would just use mine. I was in a rush to leave so we handed the card to the server, but when we did the math, we realized they had provided the wrong check and nearly charged us fifteen dollars more than we owed. I had brought this up to the server, and she attempted to argue with us about how we were given food that we weren't given. It took nearly ten minutes to receive the correct check and a refund for the original tab.

I probably won't be going here again as there are many other better ramen places in SF for a better value.

Atmosphere: 5/10
Food: 4/10
Service: 4/10
Wtf: $1.00 charge for hot tea, which isn't all that great.
author: Evan K.

description: Used to be a good spot, no longer! they changed the broth and the slices of pork and their service is the worst!
author: Eric L.

description: Possibly the best bowl of ramen I've enjoyed in SF so far. The pork bone broth is extremely rich and fatty (if you're super health conscious, try the vegan ramen bowl).  The toppings are generous too! I loved the soft-boiled egg and the texture of the noodles was perfect. Service was impressively quick as well. Once they took my order, they brought out my bowl in less than 10 minutes! Great casual spot for lunch/dinner in Japantown, although depending on when you come, you may have to wait to be seated. I came just before the lunch rush so was seated quickly, but by the time I left half an hour later, there was a line out the door!
author: Jenny N.

description: I've tried all the ramen spots in SF, trust... this is the one. Get the Tonkotsu Ramen spicy, add corn with a side of their kara-age chicken. Your wasting your time at the other spots. Might as well eat, packaged Sapporo Ichiban ramen with chili oil and chili seasoning, then go somewhere else.
author: Sara K.

description: It does not even worth one star, ugly attitude towards customer. Poor customer service , especially the man who is calling name. Improve your service okay???otherwise hehe won't go there again
author: Yanzhen C.

description: I wish I could give no star.  This is my second time at this place. It is was passed one at the afternoon and no lines at all. Then when I walked in with my friend, no one welcomes us or say have a seat. They point their finger to a table and ordered us to sit down. The. When I was to order, the white lady came to us and didn't say anything like " hello, what can I get for you ? " either . She just said " yes" . It was very rude to us. This is not the service she supposed to treat the customers. I believed that she thinks she doesn't own the restaurant so she doesn't have to be nice at all. I will definitely not recommend anyone you guys come to this place. Stay away from this place and there are many other choice. And the food were very salty. Bad seasoning !!!!!! The white lady were rude!!!!! No water or tea !!!!!!! Damn!!! Who is the owner would allow its employees to treat customers like shit???!!!!!
author: Ken Z.

description: Good ramen joint.  Thanks for the vegan ramen option! Tonkatsu  and spicy ramen bowls were flavorful, though light on toppings.  Great Gyoza and agedashi tofu.  Highlight: unexpectedly good fish shaped waffles stuffed with red bean paste.  Service a bit slow for a Sunday lunch, though friendly enough.
author: Julia S.

description: Large Orion and some on point noodles. Place rules.
author: Gates S.

description: 10 minute wait on Saturday night. The Shoyu Ramen was delicious and the broth was so flavorful. The place reminds me of a Ramen place in Tokyo. My go to ramen spot from now on. Also ++ points for the appetizers and quick service.
author: Kelly C.

description: Had the Yamadaya ramen. It was amazing. The service was great, and the bowl was huge. Also had sake, which was great even though they unfortunately didn't have any hot sakes available.
author: Zach H.

description:
This is currently my favorite place in San Francisco for ramen. I'm not a fan of their thin noodles, but I really like that they now offer thick noodles (although the boyfriend feels that they are a bit too al dente), and the broth is a good level of saltiness. You may also request fresh garlic, which is pretty neat.'

I haven't had any issues with service. The staff is both friendly and responsive.

Is it anywhere as good as the ramen in Japan? Not really, but as many people know, it's ridiculously difficult to find good ramen in the city.
author: Connie J.

description: During a cold rainy day- one craves a warm savory bowl of ramen. I made my way here as it was booked marked. I ordered what the waitress recommended. Tonkatsu  ramen. She called it their special. After I had it I kept burping... As the food was indigestible??? Later that evening I threw up... My AHA moment- DAMN FOOD POISONING!!! So will I come back? OH HECK NO
author: Monika T.

description: There is a reason for the low health score. I got food poisoning after eating here last night. Go at your own risk!
author: Dominique B.

description: Unreal pork belly, so delicious! It's perfectly cooked and melts in your mouth. I get take out here and that can be problematic with Ramen, however they do it right. Great place.
author: Lydia W.

description: We came here for lunch and then read how there were 7 different people who got food poisoning the week before HAHA. Seriously, not a good feeling going into the meal. BUT, I didn't end up getting food poisoning and the ramen was good, just not amazing. I really don't know what this placed is hyped but I guess if you're into ramen, you should try it out. Service here is QUICK because I think they're trying to turn over as many tables as possible. I think from the time we sat down to the time we left, it was only 25 min (we went at 12PM).
author: Diana Y.

description: the tonkotsu shoyu broth was excellent, our server Ken was awesome, the canned green tea is good BUT everything else not so much.  I know that tonkotsu ramen comes with thin non way noodles but I did not like this one. even though I ordered it hard, the noodles have no chewiness. the chasu pork was also gross.
author: Wakako U.

description:
The service here needs some help; I understand that we are in japan town and I can understand why everyone working there would have have broken English, that isn't my qualm... When food comes out 20 minutes apart from each person's dish I have an issue. Such slow service and because it seems like there is not a single fluent english speaker on the wait staff there was no way to clearly communicate either way what was going on. So as we were getting dishes and each person was eating things as they came it became apparent...

The food here needs some help as well; Three of us got ramen, the forth a bento box. The curry in the bento was a gelatinous paste and the pork was way over breaded on my friend's bento box. The taste was okay but not anything to write home about. The other three of us got ramen but mine was so repulsive tasting that i didn't eat any of it. My husband and I got the tonkotsu ramen and the broth tasted like canned clam juice that was left in the sun. My husband ate about half of his, but I just couldn't manage more than a few sips before I seriously was fighting to not vomit. 
I believe this place may have once been good. There are articles written about it being lovely, but I refuse to believe those gushing literary praises were based off of anything even close to our experience. 
In short, poor service, and horrendous food that will haunt your bathroom for a few days.
author: Ayla B.

description: Coming from LA, with great ramen everywhere, I had high expectations for this place. In many aspects my expectations were met. I ordered the kotteri kakuni ramen. Kotteri means extra fatty broth while kakuni is the meat that would go on top. When the bowl of ramen came I was instantly excited. Three thick slabs of kakuni pork belly, as well as a soft boiled egg and bamboo shoots were resting on a bed of noodles submerged in a fatty, milky white kotteri broth. The pork belly, while slightly chewy, was decadent, soft, and fatty and almost 1 inch thick! The broth was easily the best part of the ramen. It was silky and rich without being overly oily (it is still kind of oily, but thats to be expected with the type of broth I got). The toppings were splendid too; the egg was perfectly soft boiled and the bamboo shoots were nice and crunchy. The downfall of this ramen is definitely the noodles. The noodles were very frail and thin and unable to stand up to the impact of the rich broth and fatty kakuni. Other than that, this ramen was very satisfactory.
author: Ryan F.

description:
dinner

food: yamadaya ramen. the noodles were tasty and the broth was flavorful. the meat was tender and melts in your mouth. ***4/5

service: we had to wait a bit. at least the waiting area has good seating. you have to sign yourself in. service was fairly quick. since we all ordered the same thing, we got everything all at once. ***4/5

atmosphere: i like how they have a communion like table in the middle now instead of a big empty space. it feels japanese-y with the decor around. a lot of wood and natural art. ***4/5

value: i couldve picked the cheaper one but i feel that its not really that much different from the others. ***3/5
author: Andy Z.

description: One of the most amazing experience for Japanese ramen I've had in the SF area. Wandering about with some friends, we found this place, Yamada-ya, and the tonkotsu they have there is simply amazing. I had the Tonkotsu Shoyu (tonkotsu, with black garlic oil), and it was simply delicious. The flavour was rich, fulfilling, and I felt as if I ascended to heaven to taste the godly wonders of a very nice ramen soup! Then of course, the service. The staff were simply outstanding, and I swear I thought was in Kyoto, with the amount of hospitality they had. Greeting with a holler at the moment we step in, we were greeted with warm service from all the staff crew, and it was a wonderfully phenomenal experience for ramen. I highly, highly, HIGHLY, recommend this place to ANYONE looking for some good Japanese!
author: Howard C.

description: Came for lunch and had the Tonkotsu Shoyu Ramen.  The noodles were delicious, thin yet firm, though the portion was quite small.  Had I known this, I would have ordered some extra toppings.  The broth is just okay.
author: Rory K.

description: This was amazing! The broth was rich and the Pork Chashu we got was delicious! Can't wait to go back the next time we are in Japantown.
author: Maka M.

description: I came here on a Friday for lunch with 3 friends. We waited for about 10 minutes and was looking in through the window and noticed a lot of people didn't have their food yet. After we were seated my friends all got the #1 TONKOTSU RAMEN and one of my friends got the spicy ramen +extra spicy for 50 cents. When the ramen came I saw right away that it was super milky, creamy, and looked flavorful. I also had the extra chashu which was tasty but was disappointing that I couldn't get the pork belly. I'm hoping the next time I come it will be available. I think it's only available during dinner right now. The garlic with garlic press definitely made the ramen taste even better but i'm a lover of garlic. I would give this place 5 stars if it weren't for weird layout of the place with low lights in the middle of the room. Additionally, the wait time for the ramen to come out is extremely long. The place is still new, so I assume many things will change. However, the ramen is good and that's why I will come back.
author: Jason L.

description:
New ramen place that still needs some work... but I'm hoping in time, they'll be one of the better ramen places in the city cause I'm basically driving to San Mateo for ramen all the time since... lets be honest... there's no decent place for ramen in the city!

Came here at 720 1/1 with a party of 3. Put my name down and was waiting in line... luckily a few parties ahead of me left. Around 7:30, the hostess comes outside to count how many people are on the list... goes back in and then comes back outside saying they are low on broth. They can basically guarantee the party of 4 (which was ahead of me) their bowls. I looked at the clock and looked at what time they opened... 2 hours into opening and you're out of broth!?!? All the people behind me left, while my friends and I busted out our phones to frantically find a new place to eat.. eventually the other party got seated but nobody came out to say that's all folks! They seated us literally 30 seconds after them. My friends and I were worried about not getting anything to eat, we raced to order before the other table... suckers! lol. Luckily, they had enough broth for both tables... that or they diluted the broth or they're just straight up crazy. I'm not sure. I got the kakuni ramen with the yamadaya topping. My friends both got the spicy tonkotsu, levels 1 and 2. The yamadaya topping is basically everything you get in the kakuni ramen... so I basically had double the toppings, which was fine with me. Chashu was fine, pork belly was nice and thick. I'm not sure if it was because they were scraping for broth, but the broth was extremely flavorful... almost to the point where it was getting too salty. I kind of wished they did dilute my broth! So not sure if it's normally that salty and thick or if it's because they were running low on broth... guess we'll find out next time. Overall, the broth was tasty and flavorful. Noodles was fine, didn't have any weird taste that other ramen places sometimes have. Tried my friends tonkotsu spicy broth, not sure if it was salty since all I tasted was spice.

Overall, the food was good, could use a little bit more refining. Service was fine, waiter checked on us a few times. Could use some more seating, since there's a big open space in the middle. Hopefully they figure out how much broth to make and not run out 2 hours into opening anymore!
author: Johnson S.

description: The waitress was so rush us in order food and buying check. I understand there was a busy lunch time, but my friends and I really don't feel comfort about the attitude. Also, the food doesn't worth to pay that price.
author: Jo W.

description: We've eaten here twice and really enjoyed everything.  The service is friendly, quick and attentive.  I prefer the ramen here to anything else in San Francisco.  I had the dipping ramen (which I liked better than Orenchi's) and the basic pork broth ramen; my discerning date had the spicy ramen Yamadaya.  The pork is lovely, the noodles had a nice bite and the broth was truly delicious.  Adding a bit of garlic kicked it up a notch. I look forward to coming back!
author: Jennifer F.

description: The ramen was average in my opinion. The salad dressing was very good. We waited about 15 minutes to sit even though half of the tables were empty and there were only 3 people ahead of us. It's not bad if you have a ramen craving, but I wouldn't necessarily go out of my way to recommend it.
author: Danielle D.

description: Very good ramen and excellent service. The pork belly was interesting and the tonkatsu broth was very savory and rich. Lots of different topping to add to your ramen.
author: Mario W.

description:
another ramen place opens up in japantown... and still they can't get it right.  don't get me wrong.  it's not crappy ramen like tanpopo right next door.  just not worth the trouble of waiting in line for.

i had made plans to meet up with 3 other people at 6pm knowing a few things from reading the reviews.  none of the booths are big enough to fit more than 6 (7 if you put a chair at the end of the table - which i doubt they even had).  there are a total of 8 booths at this place.  4 that can fit 4 (skinny) people and 4 that can seat 6.  they say that there are plans to put a table that can seat 12 in the middle of the dinning area - like a community table i guess.  but for now, it's just a sad piece of unused space.  there was a line of maybe 5 other groups ahead of us when we walked up the stairs to their entrance.  at first, there wasn't a sign-in sheet to be found at the door, so i assumed there wasn't one and got back in line.  but then the host person came out with it later and i almost lost my spot to someone that came after us cuz i didn't notice that happening.  so it pissed me off that people in line knew about the sign-in sheet and said nothing when i went to the door to look.  WTH?  the wait was about 20 minutes or so before we got seated (only cuz a group of 6 left before their name was called).  after being seated, the H2O technician gave each of us a glass of water.  i say H2O technician only because she didn't do much else but fill everyone's glasses all night.  we never got any menus until one of my friends noticed the H2O technician putting menus on an empty table after getting us our water.  the menu lacks useful information for first timers.  all soup base for their ramen is tonkotsu (pork bone) broth.  when you see tonkotsu shoyu, it's not just soy sauce based broth, it's a combination of tonkotsu and shoyu.  weird.  under toppings: yamadaya toppings is basically a small dish of onions, bamboo shoots, mushrooms (or fungus as the waiter kept calling it - like it was going out of style), half egg, small piece of pork belly, two slices of chashu, and two pieces of nori.  the best deal under toppings has got to be the kakuni pork belly for $3.50.  make sure you ask for the free garlic if you like garlic in your ramen.  they won't offer to bring you any if you don't ask.  i'm not usually a noodlephile, but this time i did think that the noodles tasted of alkaline (which is very common in chinese wonton noodles and such).  maybe it was just me.  i don't know.

i know that they just opened, but this is a chained ramen place.  they have 6 other restaurants in socal with a 7th one on the way.  i feel like there should be no excuse for new restaurant pains.  it would be nice if they hired people with actual restaurant experience.  it's like they just walked off the street and got hired cuz they had a pulse.   also, how do you not have hot tea but everything else on the drinks menu?  opened for a week and still missing items from your menu is just poor planning.  no offense to the staff, i'm sure they're nice people and all.  i blame the owners/management. if you really want good ramen and want to stay within city limits, go to sawaii or izakaya sozai on irving.  heck, i'd even say genki if you don't want to drive too far from jtown.  otherwise, drive down to san mateo for ramen dojo or orenchi in santa clara.
author: Charleston C.

description: Great soup... (had the tonkatsu soup base)... yamadaya noodle soup is what i ordered... ingredients are superior than most ramen shops. The noodle is softer than i'm used to or kind of average. Service is good given this is almost a fast food place. Long lines during the weekend prime hours, but the wait is short. For a fast eater like me, it only takes me 1/2 hr to finish.
author: Art L.

description:
I have to agree with the reviews I've read thus far about this place. The service needs a lot of work. Our group of four waited only 5 minutes on a weeknight for a table. We placed our order and then the problems began. 

A waiter came by and noticed we didn't get our waters yet so he said he'd be back with them. He never came.

Our karaage arrived first and it was ordinary. Then two of us got the sides that we ordered to accompany our ramen. So our ramen orders were coming next, right? Of course not! That's too obvious! My other two diners got their orders of ramen while me and my other friend still waited for our ramen order as our sides got colder and colder. As our two friends were nearly 3/4 of their way through their ramen, we stopped someone to ask when we were getting ours. The waiter checked and it turns out they gave our orders to another table. Thank you very much. He assured us that ours would be the first priority. I had a perfect view of all the orders leaving the kitchen and ours were definitely not the first priority. When we finally did get our orders, the waiter was very apologetic. I assumed he would at least say that our ramen would be on the house or that he wouldn't charge for our appetizer, but he just kept apologizing, while all I wanted to do was finally eat my ramen with my extra cold toppings.

The service issues left a sour taste in my mouth which made for a very unenjoyable bowl of ramen. The noodles were different, but the broth was flavorful...not the best, but decent. Having read about how this place was successful in Southern California made it all the more disappointing that it could have all these basic service issues. My favorite ramen is still around the corner at Waraku.
author: Rick T.

description: Excellent ramen, the pork and noodles were delicious.  I also really liked their katsu curry. The service was wonderful!! We will definitely be returning here often.
author: Julie P.

description: I was excited to try this place out since it had a line forming before this place even opened.  My girlfriend ordered the regular Tonkotsu Ramen with extra Chashu pork and corn.  I ordered the Tonkotsu Spicy Ramen which was good, but nothing spectacular.  We had another couple dining with us, and when the bill came around they refused to split the check in 2.  I completely forgot to take a picture of the food because I was so flabbergasted that 2/4 dishes came 10 minutes apart when we all ordered similar dishes.
author: Joe D.

description: I love Ramen noodles.  If often use Yelp to find a new Ramen place wherever I go.  I accidentally found this place while I was walking around Japan town.  Since there is a line to go in, I told myself...."This place must be good.."  I did not have to wait that long.  My friend and I sat on middle big table sharing with many other people.  It did not bother me.  It actually reminded me about Japan.  We were not sure about portion of the food so we ordered 2 appetizer before Ramen....  It was way too much food, but everything taste good.  I think this place will stay Japan town forever!!
author: David O.

description:
Although the food at this particular ramen joint is decent, the service leaves much to be desired.

The food is pretty standard of any ramen joint. They offer a few variations on the traditional tonkotsu broth (pork broth), with kotteri (fatty broth) and the shoyu (soy sauce) option being offered. There are other things added to the ramen such as bamboo shoots, pork slices (which by far are the best part of the ramen), some strange mushroom and scallion onions. The overall taste of the ramen was good, however the food was not my particular issue with the restaurant; the service was.

At first everything seemed fine with the service; we (my friends and I, 6 people in total) were seated by the hostess at one of the tables surrounded the center bars. We were asked what we wanted from the menu, as per usual. The restaurant also offered extra bonuses for free (such as a larger portion of noodles or a bowl of steamed rice) with the presentation of a valid student ID, so about 4/6 people opted to do this. After having the order taken, the waitress proceeded to ignore us for the next 30 minutes or so, not even offering us refills on water or fetching pepper. The restaurant wasn't all too crowded either, with the lunch wave almost being over, so there weren't that many people to attend to. 30+ minutes was a ridiculous time to wait for a bowl of ramen, seeing as most of the ingredients should have been prepped ahead of time. When the food finally arrived at the table, the waitress had somehow managed to put in an order for 7 bowls of ramen, for the 6 people at the table. Not only that, but the wrong bowl of ramen arrived first ( with the waitress not realizing that the wrong bowl was delivered. Apparently they can't differentiate their own food.) Which meant when the second bowl was delivered, the right bowl delivered, most of the first bowl had already been eaten. Eventually this was sorted out, with the first bowl being comp'ed (made for free). Mind you, this process took at least another 15 or so minutes to figure out, with the staff either not understanding our issue, or being too confused to deal with it properly. When the check finally came, we realized that some of the free student ID additions had been charged onto the bill, which caused another delay. Finally, after dealing with the staff, we were allowed to leave. Overall, if you want only okay food and want to deal with confused staff members, this is the place to go to.
author: Kristina L.

description: I had really high expectations coming here because I really love their SoCal location. Sadly I was let down because the noodles didn't taste anything like what I remembered (aka heaven). Overall, this place was... Meh. I much rather eat at ramen dojo in San Mateo.
author: Lana L.

description: Great meal, I went level 3 on the spicy level and did not regret it.
author: Bernardo M.

description: I can understand waiting 30 minutes to get seated, but after we were seated, we watched as group after group were seated and waited on as we waited for someone to take our order.  After about 10 minutes of this, our large group had enough and just left.  The ramen place around the corner was more than happy to give us good service, so we left them a big tip.  Perhaps this was a blessing in disguise because Yelp is currently telling us that Ramen Yamadaya is in the bottom 5% in terms of health grades for San Francisco.
author: Carl B.

description: I won't waste a lot of time boring you with the details, but the service is "OK," the environment is "decent," but the food is sub-par at best. I realize that a lot of people have not experienced truly good ramen, but this place does not serve it. Place was full of Millennials, thus I'm not sure if they really care about the quality of the noodles and the broth, but they should. It was busy time there, and our waitress did the best she could to pay attention to us, but it certainly could have been better. The prices were decent as well, thus if price is the primary issue for you, be willing to accept the food here and you should be OK.
author: Average Guy R.

description: First tried this place with my bf as part of our spontaneous trip to sf. Without reading any yelp reviews about this place, it definitely was a gem to find. I ordered the shoyu ramen with the karage combo and it was absolutely delicious. The chicken was crisp and juicy paired along with the savory ramen. Spent about 13 in all and it was definitely a well spent dinner. Oh, also, i took a japanese friend here and got her approval on the ramen. So needless to say, this place is legit.
author: Isabel B.

description: Awesome food, reasonable prices, and good customer service! I'd never been to any ramen restaurants until my friend brought me here recently and needless to say I'm glad she did! Can't wait to go back!
author: Shaniah M.

description: I think this place has the best ramen in japantown in SF. Although, that's not saying much since the japanese food in japantown is actually not the best japanese food in the city strangely enough. I got the tonkotsu shoyu ramen today and their takoyaki and chicken karaage. The noodles are really thin so if you like fat chewy ramen, you might not like this place as much. Although, I did notice that you can pay a little extra for the thick noodles. The chicken karaage was just okay, but my friend really loved their takoyaki. Their egg was definitely overcooked though =( it didn't have the soft center. I originally gave this place 4 stars, but compared to all the other ramen places I've had, I think this place falls in the a-ok category. If you're in the area and you're craving ramen, I'd point you in this direction but if you have to drive more than 10 minutes, I still recommend san mateo. Might as well drive a bit more for yummier food!
author: Annie Z.

description:
I've been here probably a dozen times, and feel like I have to review after my last experience.

Food: 4 stars. I'm not a ramen expert but I love what I get there: Tonkotsu Spicy ramen with a side of Kakuni pork belly, since the chashu pork that comes with the ramen leaves something to be desired. I think getting spicy is necessary to cut the super fatty heavy flavor, but I hear that's what ramen is supposed to taste like.

Service. 1-2 stars. Again, I've been here a dozen times and the service ranges from fine to bad. Everyone is super nice but it is SO DISORGANIZED. I think they don't have assigned tasks or sections. All of the servers are trying to serve everyone, and the result is that everyone gets forgotten.

A sample of my experiences:

-I walked up at 9pm on a Thursday and there were 20 people waiting to be seated. I almost walked away, but then I realized that half the restaurant was empty, they just hadn't got around to seating people.

-It usually takes 15 minutes to get water. You get your ramen, ask everyone that passes by for utensils, and 10 minutes later you get them.

-They often run out of things. Some days they're out of pork belly. Fine, I think, they get it fresh every day and had higher demand than usual today. They run out of corn. I think, ummm, okayyyy I guess the corn is ordered fresh every day? 

-Finally, the most recent time I went there they had run out of to-go containers. NOPE. Unlikely that's anything but poor planning. I'm mostly bitter because I intended to eat take-out in the comfort of my own home but ended up eating alone in sweatpants in a brightly lit restaurant.

I'll be back because I live 3 blocks away, but PLEASE HIRE MORE PEOPLE OR WORK ON YOUR ORGANIZATION!
author: Jillesa G.

description: I usually prefer udon over ramen and I haven't written a review in over a year, but I was so impressed with Yamadya's ramen that I had to write one. Their noodles are thinner than most ramen I've tried which makes them tastier. All the chefs in the somewhat open kitchen were Japanese so you know it's legit. Get the spicy tonkatsu at level 2 spiciness. Best ramen I've ever had! So good that I went there two days in a row (oops). Nice modern interior as well.
author: Andrea H.

description: Update: they seem to be more consistently cooking good chashu. I'm still not a fan of thin noodles in my ramen but it's worthy of 4 stars.
author: Baron C.

description: I've tried four ramen places in Japan town, and this one is absolutely the best! The soup and meat are flavorful as the ramen I had in Japan, only difference is that the noodle is the thin type.
author: Pamela Y.

description: Tonkotsu Shoyu ramen was delicious. The soup was just right, very smooth and not too salty. The marinated boiled egg cooked to perfection and it's very tasty.  The ramen noodles are very skinny ones and it taste good, a bit soft to my liking as I personally prefer thicker ones.  Also had an order of the Chicken Karaage which was super good! Crispy on the outside and very tender inside; very light but tasty.  Overall experience was wonderful, service is good and everyone smiles all the time! Would come back!
author: Tiffany T.

description: A ramen joint from socal. My favorite ramen spot in SF by far. Thin noodles are the way to go in my opinion over the traditional ramen you find elsewhere. This reminds me of the best ramen spot ever, shinsengumi hakata ramen in socal.
author: Will L.

description: I had the ramen yamadaya for about $12. It was very good, very tasty, very filling. Love the big slab of pork belly that comes with it. The thing is basted so long, it literally melts in your mouth in a savory pool of deliciousness
author: Ross I.

description: Delicious authentic tonkotsu ramen just the way I used to enjoy it when I lived in Japan. The gyoza were perfectly crafted and cooked with just the right amount of burn on the bottom. I also love the taiyaki dessert - these are just as good as the ones at Tokyo street fairs. The communal table makes this a perfect place for dining alone or for making new friends. The service is friendly without being overbearing. What more could I ask for? Parking is pretty easy on neighboring blocks to the north and east and there's always the Japantown parking structure.
author: Keith R.

description: Healing, fatty pork ramen just as it should be. Delicious and fast, customer service is equivalent to that of Japan - top notch.
author: Julia F.

description: I know this isn't the best ramen joint in San Francisco but since I had very little time and wanted to get together with friends and family, this was the central place in J-Town.  First, we started with the takoyaki, and karaage.  Both were not bad for an appetizer.  Most of our party ordered the Yamadaya Ramen, which equates to the Works and I asked for extra noodles.  I'm from Tokyo and I am used to a more robust thicker noodle but the buta and the charshu were very good in this soup.  The tonkotsu could have used a little more distinction in the broth I thought and wasn't overwhelmed by the whole dish.  I think it is slightly better than Tanpopo, right below it though.
author: Koichi E.

description: Get the kotteri!  I ordered extra pork, and man I was full!  The huge slice of pork melts in your juicy mouth.  I came with a group of 5 so it took longer to get seating.  It gets hot inside and especially when you start eating, but this doesn't matter as long as its for a n good bowl of ramen!
author: Kevin Z.

description: Ordered the Tonkatsu Yamadaya with the black garlic oil last night. It seemed like a good idea, but I got FOOD POISONING 6 hours later. Just had to call off work today to deal with it. I've gotten food poisoning only 1 other time before so I don't have a weak stomach or anything.  DO NOT GO. I scrolled through all reviews and while this place just opened 4 months ago, there have been roughly 7 instances of food poisoning. That's just foul.
author: Carita O.

description: This place is different from other ramen shops I've been to but at the same time, the food has that familiar feeling that shows that they haven't been innovative to the point that they made ramen unrecognizable.  I had the kotteri ramen and the karaage.  The broth was good, not the richest kotteri I've had,  but still good.   There are some toppings that already come with the ramen,  and after deciding to stick with those instead of getting more, I was pretty happy with the amount.  Now onto the noodles.  They make their noodles thinner than other ramen shops.  While it doesn't affect their taste exactly, I think I prefer the thicker noodles.  They just seem much easier to slurp up than these thin ones.   These ones don't taste bad,  but I'm just not used to it.  The chicken karaage was delicious.   Simple,  non-pretentious,  and homey.  The outside was perfectly crisp and the inside was not dry.   Now onto the service.  We had a great server who was very courteous and just great.   All our food came out reasonably fast, so we didn't have to wait too long.   However,  this is all one you get in.   Waiting to get in is the long part.  There's no real waiting area except the stairs so the line starts going down the stairwell.  There seems to be plenty of unused room in the establishment for more tables.  However,  since I went just about a week or so after they opened (when they seemed to still be fixing things up), hopefully this is no longer the case and that space is being put to good use.   Coupled with the somewhat rushed and dreary atmosphere, (again because it looked like it was still being "finished" at the time) it didn't make for the best impression.  All and all,  once you get past the appearance and the long wait,  this place proves that it has the potential to win you over.   The food is pretty good;  it's a new spin on ramen,  but still comforting and the service is impeccable.  I hope to come back once this place has its legs, as I'm sure it's bound to get better.
author: Christine W.

description: Well to be honest, there's no good ramen places in San Francisco if you're used to authentic Japanese ramen. This is probably the best ramen catered toward the American palette. Americans love pork belly so they love to use pork belly for the char sui. I never quite understood this concept. Overall, I'm a fan of the noodles. The thin noodles really go well with the soup, but in the end I felt it was shitsukoi, but I'll definitely come back for the tsukemen.
author: Cody M.

description: The free fresh garlic that you can crush into the broth was genius. And they offer extra portions for us hungry and poor students!
author: Yunah R.

description: Really good ramen and chicken kara-age. So far I've tried the tonkotsu ramen, tonkotsu kotteri and the tonkotsu spicy ramens. The tonkotsu ramen is the basic pork broth ramen. Kotteri adds black garlic oil which gives the pork broth zingy umami. And the spicy has a great gochujang-like kick (there's three degrees of heat--one is the lowest and is probably best if you want to taste the pork broth). My favorite by far is the kotteri, which I was told is the most popular. Like at most ramen places, the menu includes curry and rice bowl dishes. Sadly, the SF Yamadaya menu has fewer choices than the L.A. branches (at least according to the main website). Hopefully, this will change as the staff gets a bit more experience at this new location. It'd also be great if they had beer...
author: Kit P.

description: Bad service! Waiter is so rude. Waiting too long. I would not come back this place again!
author: Angus Q.

description:
i love ramen dojo more but this place was surprisingly good.  will i go back, definitely if i am in the area.  the broth is very rich and full, but i was disappointed in the noodles.  personally i prefer the thicker noodles over the thinner ones but lucky for them the pork belly won me over.  

ordered:
tonkotsu kotteri - rich and fatty ramen with black garlic
ramen toppings: kakuni pork belly

tonkotsu ramen - basic pork borth
ramen toppings: yamadaya toppings

the tonkotsu kotteri is super flavorful, i'm all about the broth and it hit the spot but the charshu pork was thick and tough.  boo! so sad!! but luckily the pork belly was super soft! so yay! :)

i highly recommend getting the yamadaya toppings, you get a little bit of very thing in the toppings section except for a few things. toppings you get: scallion, seasoned egg, menma, charshu pork and kakuni pork belly. 

do show up before noon or early noon to avoid large crowds and a starving tummy, as due to limited tables.  which i find very odd considering there's a huge dance floor in the middle.  lol  the staffs are very friendly.
author: mea f.

description: I've been here multiple times and have never been disappointed with the ramen. The soup bas is delicious, as is the ramen. Their pork belly and pork loin are just fantastic. So tasty and well done. I can't recommend it enough.
author: M C.

description: How is this place a three stars!??? The broth is rich and the noodle is of the right firmness. The waitress is friendly too highly recommended
author: Tekl P.

description:
Chasu pork was overcooked.  Only ONE piece in the basic order.  Waitress didn't seat us at the booth, wanted us to share a big table .... until we asked and insisted, and the booths were not reserved.  Unfriendly waitress, lousy service.  First time and last time!

Suzu inside the mall is WAY better!
author: Portia C.

description: OMG: They have a solid Vegan ramen! Soy based broth, with spinach ramen- and it doesn't suck at all!! Ramen has been one of my biggest laments after going veg- most places just serve up a weak bowl of boiled veggies and bland broth, but now I have somewhere to go for a nice, steaming hot bowl of cruelty-free ramen. :) Thanks Ramen Yamadaya!
author: Cindy S.

description: Eh, nothing special.  Small serving size in a chaotic environment.  Kinda slow and waited a while to get our food.  Broth too salty.  Curry too sweet.  Go to Suzu instead.
author: Joel M.

description:
so if anyone knows a better tsukemen place than this in SF I'm all ears. 

regular ramen here is average to above average. I wish the pork in here was bit more melt in your mouth good. noodles aren't that chewy for the standard ramen when I got it. 

tsukemen was really flavorful. I go here just to eat that now. noodles are fairly chewy not authentic Japan chewy but better than their standard ramen bowls since it's not sitting in the broth over cooking. 

tsukemen broth is very porky and savory. I love what seems to be a smoky bonito flavor to it. 

All in all a pretty exceptional place to go grab ramen if you are in Japantown and wanna grab ramen. 

oh if you aren't into really porky tasting ramen you may not like this place. I on the other hand I like porky ramen.
author: Myk S.

description: I went to Yamadaya knowing that it had a positive reputation in So cal! but didn't have the opportunity to try it until my visit to SF. This was some of the best ramen I've had. Noodles were perfect texture. Broth was the right flavor - not too salty. Service was fast and courteous. If I'm ever back in SF Japantown, I will stop by for another bowl of ramen.
author: D G.

description: Best Ramen I've had in the Bay Area so far. Even the chicken curry is excellent. Service is surprisingly good.
author: Mark M.

description: As a neighbor, instead of charging 25 cents for the take out containers and adding an additional 10 cents for the bag...just bundle the price as a takeout charge instead of making your customers feel like they are being nickel & dimed. Ramen is good but Waraku is a much better experience from a service standpoint.
author: Wendy W.

description:
Tasty broth and I like the Hakata style thin noodles. You don't see those very often. All in all, I thought it was a complete bowl of noodles. Definitely will go back again. 

Ramen was better than the Tsujemen for sure.
author: yutaro t.

description: So disappointed. Service was extremely slow even thought there were three waitresses in this tiny place. I ordered the tonkotsu ramen and it was EXTREMELY salty. I barely finished my $11 ramen and my daughter had to take sips of water in between bites.
author: Al T.

description:
good:
-chashu
-kakuni
-paigu
-curry
-katsu
-tonkotsu broth
okay:
-mentaiko
-noodles could be more al dente
-karaage

servers nice but they act kinda frazzled
author: Jeffry C.

description: Excellent Tonkotsu broth and the noodles have good body. We waited twenty minutes on a Saturday night and it was really worth it. The chef came out to the line to announce they were out of their famous pork belly.
author: Ina D.

description:
Mediocre ramen - small portions, almost no meat or toppings (a tiny sliver only). Too salty. 
It was super hot inside since its on top floor. Also, toilet was broken. 
Wont be returning here, specially since tanpopo is next door.
author: Priya K.

description: It's good ramen. Better with more garlic which they offer. :) tokoyaki was good as well. :)
author: Nica I.

description: Thin noodles, nice experience. Came here on a hot day, so the place was warm too. I actually prefer thicker noodles, but it was nice to try this type.
author: Doris U.

description: Best Ramen place in San Francisco's Japan town!
author: Titanium M.

description: Maybe it was just the waitress we had, but it took about 20 minutes to get our drinks for 4. Two other groups got in after us and got their drinks and orders taken before we did. We got the house special ramen (yamadaya) and overall it was good, but not the best around this area. Gotta try the tuna over rice because that was probably the best dish I had that night.
author: Toua H.

description: Had the #4 spicy level 2. The spicy does certainly cover up the creaminess/ milkiness of the broth. I do like that you can add in your own crushed garlic once they bring your bowl to you.  I wasn't completely satisfied though because I didn't think there was enough meat etc in my soup but that is pretty common for me since I tend to eat alot haha.  Overall pretty good I'd come back if I was in the area.
author: Julie F.

description: Pretty good ramen, even the vegan one tasted very good! It gets pretty busy so you might have to wait some 15 minutes before getting sited, but it is worth the wait. My husband has ordered the spicy one number 3 and it was too spicy so is better if you order the number 2 and check first if you can handle it.
author: Camis S.

description:
I went here with no expectations and ordered the Tonkatsu  Yamadaya ramen (recommended by the waitress) and my girlfriend ordered the Tonkatsu Kotteri, which is flavored with black garlic oil.

Neither ramen were spectacular. The main issue is that the broth lacked richness... I tried both the thick and thin noodle as well. They thick were good, with the right smell and taste, but they were over-cooked! The thin were mediocre.

My biggest issue was that the service was terrible. I even considered dropping the rating to two stars because it was so bad. I ended up waiting 15 minutes for a serving of extra noodles, by which time was my ramen was cold. If you want to run a ramen shop, there was just some things you have to get right...
author: Jesse K.

description: Omg, I wish this restaurant is in Sacto so i can be a regular. I have never been a ramen person. To me, its just something good when its in the winter but their ramen is so good that I want to eat it everyday. The broth was so tasty as well as the pork belly. Just talking about it makes my mouth water...
author: Ai M.

description: Not the best place for ramen. But, we were in japan town and all of the other ramen joints were full. We were a party of five, which included 2 kids one baby and one toddler. It clearly stated party of five gratuity will be included. Once I got my check, they put 18% tip and it was written on the check! The service was okay. I'm not a big fan of that. Two kids that didn't even order anything!
author: SF S.

description: Not quite San Mateo (Ramen Dojo, Parlour) good. Tonkutsu broth pretty darn good and the stewed pork is good, but my bowl was short on other fixings -- one slice of chasu and the menma was too salty. I dig the al dente thin noodles. But overall, not on the same level as the ones down in San Mateo.
author: Lawrence M.

description: The ramen here is very good, the service however was really bad. Someone in my group ordered a ramen where the toppings came separately. Well,they brought out ramen and broth and no toppings.  When the toppings finally arrived the broth and ramen were both cold. Lastly,if you come here on a Friday night come early. Anything past 7, you might as well forgedaboudit.....
author: Monina T.

description: I love the ramen here. The tonokotsu ramen with thick noodles is delicious! It tastes exactly like what I want from my ramen, full flavored and satisfying. I've also had the spicy sauce added when I feel like I'm getting sick, and it hits the spot. The service was great each time I've been here, even the last time when they were completely packed.
author: Tina C.

description: I thought the Tsukemen was great, actually went there twice. But once I peered back into the kitchen area I was disgusted. Being that this place is a month old, you would think their kitchen would be clean. Sad to say, it wasn't. Not too sure I will be returning unless they clean up their act.
author: Richard O.

description: I'm writing this after just leaving this place. It was all bad. I ordered the takoyaki, gyoza, and pork belly ramen. My partner ordered the spicy tuna bowl. Everything food wise was fine, save for the ramen. It had a not so great texture and taste to me. Which I tried to tell the waitress. That's when things went downhill. She was rude. Condescending. And just wouldn't listen to me when I tried to tell her about my ramen. I was pretty upset and cut my dinner early, paid, and left asap. I had to go somewhere else for me dinner. It was just all bad.
author: Jessica J.

description: We used to come often but today we have decided to leave. We've been waiting here for 20 minutes while at least 10- 12 seats were open. Many people have left in the mean time. Do they think that making people wait will make the restaurant more prestigious or something? Bad practice!!
author: S T.

description: My friends and I went here on a Sunday night, and they were pretty busy. The ramen noodles are cooked perfectly, and the soup bases are tasty. I liked the Shoyu best. The service there is fantastic--all of the servers and hosts were friendly and attentive. This is my  new favorite ramen spot in the city.
author: Gavin M.

description: Super greasy  oily ramen that doesn't leave you feeling satisfied or well in general. The Gyoza aren't worth your time as they taste as if they are filled with blended meat and veggie scraps. The atmosphere is cold and the dance music is loud and offensive. The food also comes up very slow. All in all Id say if you want ramen in japantown your better off with Suzu or underground ramen. This place is a waste of time, money, and stomach space.
author: Eliza W.

description: All the yelp reviews were spot on: I could care less for their setup, but the appetizer came out as we were half way done thru our soup. Soup was salty,  ended  drinking all my water. Portion of soup is lot smaller than tanpopo, saiwaii, ramen underground. Service still unorganized and run around like chickens with their heads cut off. Meh, momijji in Daly City was much better
author: Miss J.

description:
the ramen is great. we were deciding between the kakuni or the yamadaya on tonkotsu ramen broth. and went with the yamaday b/c it included the kakuni and other meat. the kakuni (pork belly) was delish. the broth was great. the food was great. 

but what errked me was the service. we came on a sunday for lunch so of course they're busy. we had already picked our items while waiting for the table so we wanted to order. i asked the lady twice to order but she didn't hear me, but also if you were observant, you could see that we weren't looking at the menu, so we were ready. anyways, we finally were able to flag someone down. 

then what's worse is that we waited over 30minutes for our food. seriously?! we had a party of 6. and there was a party of 7 before us and they were done with their food before we even got ours! (we only got seated about 5-10min after them). they need to work on the assembly line in the kitchen. com'on there's only so many things on the menu. and putting ramen together can't be that hard.
author: Jen S.

description:
The ramen here is pretty bad, even by SF standards.  Not as bad as ramen underground, which is the reason it has two stars instead of one (ramen underground still holds the crown of shitty ramen.) 

The broth is far too meaty, it has the smell and consistency of rendered pork fat.   They need to add ginger or rice wine to mask the "porkiness". 

Noodle were of poor consistency. No chewiness at all, but at the same time felt under done.   This is even worse than ramen bar in fidi.
author: Jonathan D.

description:
Good place!
The appetizers were really good i.e. chicken karaage and takoyaki, staff was really nice as well. 
The spicy tonkotsu ramen is the bomb! The broth is on point, it isnt too salty or rich. And the noodles they use are the best in the city...
author: R S.

description: So far the best ramen place in SF! The noodle was firm and really good, but the broth is what completes this dish! I've had ramen in many different places and this reminded me of home!
author: Andy C.

description: Loved the soup but the pork belly was a bit dry. Wait staff was very friendly.
author: Donna B.

description: Got the tonkastu spicy #3.  They warned me it was very spicy.  Actually it was pretty bland.  The noodles were pasty.  I got 1 slice of chasu.  End the meal with a big group (5 or more) tip handwritten in when person #5 was a sleeping infant is ridiculous.
author: Paul G.

description:
i liked it. i'll be back.

noodles are thin, but had enough "tooth" to it, enjoyable to chew. shoyu was rich but not too salty like other places here in SF. pork was thick-cut, and flavorful, but maybe not traditionally fatty. egg was okay, flavored not plain boiled. 

gyoza was good, thin skin, and seemed fresh (or freshly frozen).
author: Loocha L.

description: Found this place on Yelp, where they post all the new grand open. Now parking is not that hard to find around this area. I came here for lunch, there was no line but all the tables were fill. This place looks clean and pretty roomy. The food is not that bad, but they were very salty, a little less salty would be perfect. I would say that their Ramen noodle is very unique, somehow different than every other place.
author: Justin L.

description: Came here with friends on a Sunday night around 6. This place is spacious but is also pretty busy so be prepared to wait a bit. A big surprise was finding out that they serve tsukemen here! I never had it before and ever since I saw it on The Mind of a Chef, I've been dying to try a version. The portions here are good! I got the 12oz and there was a ton of noodles but not a whole lot of anything else. One slice of pork, 1/2 of an egg and some bamboo shoots. I ordered extra pork belly on the side for a bit more variety. Overall, the broth was good and coated the noodles very well. However, because the noodles were so cold, over time, the broth became cold as well so by the end it was just cold noodles in cold broth. I'm not sure if I could have gotten more hot broth or if the noodles are supposed to be hotter but the cold part wasn't cool. I think that I will return if asked, I don't think I'd rave about it.
author: edward k.

description: Outstanding broth (got regular tonkotsu). Kakuni pork also highly recommended. Takoyaki were very good and fresh (hard to get any non-frozen in SF). Gyoza were good, too. The chashu pork in the soup was the only thing I wasn't crazy about. Also they were out of tsukemen (must've sold out at lunch?) We got in right away at 5:45p but they were already closing for the night at 7, so get there early!
author: Ian C.

description: The pork ramen is probably the best ramen I have ever had, and easily it's worth double the price. I *never* post Yelp reviews (this is the first one), but the food was so good I just had to. Would give 6 stars if I could.
author: Jake P.

description: Best ramen I've had in the city. Got the garlic broth, with pork belly, and chili sauce on the side. Also excellent gyoza and seaweed salad.
author: Rohan S.

description: It was everything I could hope for in a ramen place. broth was amazing and the meat was cooked perfectly that it easily melted into your mouth. wasn't a big fan of the small table that we say by- mainly because I was right by where the kitchen was (like maybe 10 feet) and the aisle where the guests would walk in and out by so one could easily be bumped or something.
author: Melanie S.

description: WOAH! Can I just say WOAH, again? Ok, so I am a vegetarian. Vegetarian and ramen rarely ever mix because ramen is all meat broth - that's what makes it ramen, right? Wrong. Well, right, but vegan ramen is heaven sent & Ramen Yamadaya really knows how to do it. Coming from someone who's never had actual ramen before, just the vegetarian options in NYC - Momofuku, Totto and the likes, I have to say SF's Japantown has done it right. I ordered the Vegan ramen with vegetable broth, noodles, corn, mushrooms and scallions with a side of "fresh" garlic and hot sauce. The garlic was pretty darn fresh, literally from the clove, raw, whole, "fresh," and we were able to mince it ourselves. Once the sides came out, our orders of edamame and dumplings followed. Plus, I ordered a side salad, which was refreshing sliced cabbage with a side of peanut dressing. It was light and not over-pouring, a light start to what was about to commence. Once the ramen came, the slurping and noodle-gorging began. I just couldn't stop! After adding the hot chili sauce, the ramen was perfect. The broth wasn't too salty and the scallions added a crunch. The mushrooms, corns and noodles were all cooked perfectly. For a vegetarian, I was fully satisfied and let's just say the empty bowl speaks for itself. Plus, the tab came out to under $15. All in all, not a bad way to end the day filled with trapezing and aerial silks with friends.
author: Krutika D.

description: I really didn't like the ramen here.  Toppings came on side and were cold. Egg wasn't properly softboiled. The level 3 spicy only tasted like chili oil. Tanpopo and Waraku are much better. I won't be back.
author: Andrew H.

description: This place had great ramen definately would come back again but music was loud. On two ocasions the ceiling in the bathroom was leaking in the mens restroom. Great to get there early otherwise wait is longer. They used to give away free soda on the weekdays during lunch. Bummer that they no longer have that. Tasty.
author: Min G.

description: Ordered the Kakuni Ramen with an extra egg. Let's just say I was super excited to try this place out when I saw the excellent slice of pork belly you can add on. First of all, I would like to say that I often judge a ramen place by how well they cook their soft boiled egg because I usually order a second egg with my ramen. After my two friends and I ordered, we waited about 10 minutes to get our appetizer. No big deal, didn't mind waiting because we were not in a rush. Then the first side order of pork belly came out with a side order of egg, which I find weird since these were suppose to be ramen toppings. My friend ordered the dry ramen with the soup on the side, and he received his order 10 minutes before the remaining orders came out. I think as a restaurant, they should be able to synchronize the tables orders together so no one is stuck sitting there staring at the other person eat or having the other person wait on the rest of the people. I found the portion of the ramen to be somewhat small. The broth was okay. Let's get back to the egg. I had that side dish of an egg, which was semi-hard boiled, and the two egg halves in my ramen (one was soft boiled and the other was completely hard boiled). That's kind of unacceptable. Normally, I would give places a second try because maybe what I ordered was just bunk. But, the service was not great and the egg was highly inconsistent..I would rather give other ramen places a try in that plaza before I ever come back to Yamadaya. At least some of the staff members were friendly.
author: Qui C.

description: I took my parents to this place because we have one in San Diego and it was great. However, after being seated, the waiter kept on coming back at a minute interval to take our order even when I told them we weren't ready multiple times. After being tired of getting harassed by them, we finally ordered, and she seemed annoyed at the questions we asked even though it was they're first time there. 5 minutes after we ordered our food, the side paigu came out with the extra ramen that my dad ordered. We thought that our ramen well come out soon, but it didn't. We waited for another half an hour for the ramen to come out. When the ramen came out, everything was cold, the extra noodle and the paigu. It was ridiculous. I didn't understand why they didn't just wait for everything to come out at the same time and why the ramen took so long. When I went to the one in SD it was quick because their broth is ready ahead of time and they just bed to boil the ramen. It was really disappointing after having to eat at the one in SD. The waiter was also better in SD because the one here just ignore you even though more than half the room was empty and there was a long line of people waiting to be seated.
author: Jessica H.

description: Tonkotsu broth wasn't too oily or salty, good amount of bamboo shoots, fast service. Chashu was a little dry. I've only had one place with better ramen in NY.
author: Sandra K.

description: The noodles are good, chose the pork-based soup which is very rich.  I realize pork bone soup (tonkotsu) is popular now and that's their speciality, but it's a bit too heavy for me.
author: Dan C.

description: Super good! The ramen noodles were not the typically kind, but it was so chewy and I really enjoyed it! I got the shoyu ramen. The only thing I would say is that they only give one piece of meat and I expected at least another one, but it was overalls really good! Service was awesome and the waiter was funny :)
author: Cathie D.

description: 3.5 not quite the same as the LA chain.  didn't like the softer thin noodles, guess it's better to upgrade to the thick.  the egg was dry halves (embarrassing if compared to Japan quality), seaweed already limp (plating issue), pork kakuni and cha siu was tasty enough in the yamadaya combo.  had the regular tonkotsu broth, quality has dropped with expansion--difficult to maintain quality control on timing and strength.  karaage just ok.  tsujita I wish you'd make it up here.
author: Rob C.
