description: Qulity of food and service dropped big time.  Tons of MSG in the food and expensive, not recommended!
author: Cookie M.

description: They really try to promote how long they cook their broth for and i'll admit, its a pretty good broth, very rich and creamy.  Whats different is the fact that they use a thinner type of noodle, which can be good since it feels like you're eating less and has a nice delicate feel to it, but I felt I lost a lot of the texture from the thicker noodles that I'm more accustomed to seeing.  I do think they offer the thicker noodles but it cost extra.  If you're a student you can also get extra noodles for free which is pretty awesome but I'm more a quality over quantity type of guy.  The toppings were solid, nothing extraordinary but nothing bad.  The menu was a bit confusing, i can't even tell you what exactly was confusing but I do know my friend had a difficult time ordering and eventually didn't know what he ordered.  The chicken karage was dissapointing after seeing an article posted on the wall about how great their chicken karage was.  It was very bland and didn't have much texture to it for pieces of fried chicken.  It definitely could have used more batter and a longer cooking time to get that great light and crunchy texture.   For awhile, Japantown didn't have many options to get a good bowl of ramen, but now there are some decent options.  Ramen Yamadaya certainly isn't the best bowl of ramen in town, but it does serve a very decent bowl of ramen.
author: Darren W.

description: quite popular spot with a slightly modern spin on things. first version of this review was for a different place so i have to write more since i couldn't just delete the review.
author: Max M.

description: Overpriced and the food is very vanilla. Not much variety or selection.
author: P K.

description: First time to Ramen Yamadaya, the Ramen was delicious, the pork tonkatsu broth was excellent ... so tasty.  There were four of us and we all ordered the pork belly and cha sui, yummy yummy good.  Service was great, our waiter Mike was friendly, patient and helpful.  On the afternoon we were there (4/7) everything was perfect.  For sure we will be back!!
author: Marie H.

description: spicy broth (level 2) was delicious but the noodles were sub par... restaurant is nice, service was fine, but seems a bit pricey for the amount and quality of the ramen.
author: Sherman L.

description: Customer service was good. The ramen was salty.. and this place gives you an actual whole egg as oppose to other places they just give you half of one. The chicken Kara - age was pretty good. Didn't care for the salad.. it was just bland and medicore. The pork in the ramen wasn't as tender as I liked it to be. Overall, this place is pretty good, I'd come back.
author: Joe C.

description: While the pork broth does not measure up to Jinya in Studio City or Tsujita LA. in Little Osaka it does reflect some good effort by the cook. A welcome addition to Nihon Machi (replacing the old Iroha). Broth maybe a tad too fatty, but I would go back and try again.
author: Stein H.

description: The positives: the service is better than the old Iroha which was really going down hill. We were seated and served promptly. Waitstaff were courteous and helpful. Lots of hype around the ramen, but I do not understand it. Admittedly, I am not a big ramen fan, but I grew up on it and certainly ate it in Japan and other places on the West Coast and Hawaii. That said, the broth is fine, ingredients fine, but what is up with the noodles? They are thin, a bit too chewy and lack the typical waviness that comes from cooking in baking soda or something similar. Further, my ramen loving kid had a hard time eating the noodles. He couldn't seem to swallow them and kept coughing and choking on them. Weird. That has never happened to him elsewhere in the US or Japan. It also seems that they only serve tonkotsu ramen, and I could very well be the only person in California that is not a tonkotsu fan. I am partial to lighter fare, such as shio ramen or the seafood ramen of Sapporo. But ok, they are catering to the latest non-Asian trend of tonkotsu  ramen that seems to be hitting SF lately. I understand. We also ordered a side of gyoza (pot stickers). They came out just as I would have expected to see in Japan, and my gyoza loving kid inhaled most of them. I did get a taste of one, though---waaaa! Too much ginger. They do offer a better assortment of beverages than I would have expected. They have Calpis on the menu, which is my kid's fav, so he was happy while we waited for our meal--so yes, pretty kid friendly. I mean, who else drinks Calpis but kids and maybe teenager? On  a rare warm SF day, I was also able to get some iced green tea (granted, in a can, but it was just what I was wanting). Based on other reviews, it seems that the SoCal locations are better. I will stick with Miki for now--or just wait to eat ramen when I go back to Japan.
author: 和子

description: I'm giving them one star because the waitress that served us charged us a mandatory twenty percent when it was not called for. I do not mind giving tips especially when we get excellent service but it should be left to the discretion of the customer and not because the waitress wants extra money in their pocket. The food was alright and nothing spectacular.
author: Benjamin L.

description: Best ramen I've ever had! Strongly recommend yamadaya ramen with spicy soup base! And don't forget the fish cake with red bean filling. The waitresses are very sweet!
author: Amenglala S.

description: food was ok, but it was a bit pricey. 12 bucks for ramen was expensive. long waits on sunday
author: Ethyl M.

description: I went back the other day to try the spicy sauce - the menu says there are three levels: 1 (spicy), 2 (hot) 3 (very hot), and 3 costs an extra 0.50 buck. I got number 2. The sauce was more salty than hot - not my kind of hot chili sauce, and not my kind of spicy ramen soup. I think I'll stick to the black garlic oil or the original tonkotsu flavor.
author: s c.

description: Ramen was just OK, but portions were small compared to other places in the bay area.  Service was a bit cold.  After spending $50+ for a family of 4, they have the nerve to charge $.25 for a take out container.  Can they not account for that in the price of the food?  We went there with 2 other families, and I don't think any of us would go back.
author: Craig U.

description: this place seems like it's doing pretty well! came here for lunch this past saturday, and as time went on more and more people kept coming in. the updated decor is a lot more modern than the old iroha's. we both got the yamadaya ramen and an appetizer of karaage. all the food was pretty good, but i was a little overwhelmed with how much stuff the ramen came with -- i felt like my bowl was filled with a little too much stuff, but it was a nice change from the other ramen places that give skimpier portions. it came with three pices of seaweed, bamboo shoots, a whole egg, green onions, those squiggly black things, and three HUGE pieces of pork -- so much pork that i couldn't even finish half of it (i chose to finish the noodles instead). my boyfriend ordered a side of corn with his also, and i liked how they brought it on the side so that both of us could add some to our bowls (there was a lot of corn!). they also give you complimentary fresh garlic if you ask for it! will definitely be back!
author: Sabrina L.

description: The service here REALLY NEEDS IMPROVEMENT. As a customer, I felt very disrespected and uncomfortable while dining here. After the Cherry Blossom Festival, my friends and I decided to go try this place. Right when we got seated, the server asked us "Are you ready to order?" We replied, "No, we just got here." Then she proceeded to tell us that our food will take 15 minutes to make after we order and we reply with "Okay, that's fine." Immediately after that, she asks us again if we are ready to order and we say no. We barely had time to look at our menu and we felt very rushed as customers. The food was okay and the lady messed up our order twice. When I told her that I wanted to share with my friend, she said there is no sharing allowed and I would have to order in order to stay in the restaurant. I'm fine with that but the way she said it sounded so demanding and rude. When we were leaving, the server brought the check over to my friend who was paying and she kept looking over her shoulder to see how much she would tip. THAT IS UNACCEPTABLE AND MADE US ALL FEEL VERY UNCOMFORTABLE. The server should NOT be standing there over our shoulders watching how much tip we would leave. She stood there for a good 3 minutes just watching the whole time as my friend signed her name on the device. When my friend clicked NO TIP (because we were going to leave a cash tip), the server made a sound and reached her hand over to the device to try to click the back button. WHAT?!? I just couldn't believe that happened! Even though we were going to leave tip after the horrible service we received, we didn't even want to tip anymore after that. Nonetheless, we left a cash tip anyway and just left. I have never in my life experienced service like this. I am DEFINITELY NOT going to recommend this place anyone and will NOT be going back.
author: Bijin H.
